description:
I grew up under the influence of Japanese-American parenting.....the good and the bad. One of the really good things it nurtured is my love for quality Japanese confections. Manju and Mochi.....Ohhhh Yeeeaaaahhhh! What's strange is that the offspring don't share that same enthusiasm and love of this sweet treat as I. O well, more for me. 

Benkyo-Do is one of the few remaining manju shops in Northern California. San Jose is the other. I am deathly afraid that the sands of time will not be kind to the future of this shop. I can only hope and dream that this institution can withstand the march of time. I try to patronize it whenever I am in the City. My patronizing is however very selfish.

My favorites are the traditional plain manju with the brown sweet bean filling. The unmistakable trademark of their pillowy soft mochi gives way to the soft slightly sweet filling inside. The powdery fine rice flour dust coats my lips, fingers, the front of my shirt, the tops of my shoes, and the floor which I stand. I can often order 6 of these sweet delights and not even make it to the corner stoplight before downing half of them. The pink manju/mochi with white bean filling are good, and so are the specialty flavors, Mango and Blueberry. I like the Blueberry, berry, berry much.

The service here is delightful. It's a small family run enterprise, and has been for since...forever. Smiling faces behind the counter as they quickly and very cutely place my ordered pieces into the light pink boxes and then tied up with thin pink ribbon tape-string. Such a nice gift wrap that won't stay wrapped for more than a few seconds after I hit the door out.

My ATF is and always will be the plain. It will until I can no longer stuff them into my pie hole. I dream of it when I haven't had a few in a while. 
Please, please, PLEASE: Continue to support this ethnic and embattled iconic cultural food destination in the City's Japan Town! It is more than worthy of your patronage. 

Extinction is not kind to places like this.
author: william s.

description:
If you love mochi, this place is the one!

Benkyodo Co is located in japantown and we had no trouble finding this store. We came here on Thursday around 2:30 and there were many Japanese ladies having some tea and desserts! We got kinako (mochi with redbean and soybean powder $1.35) , Age (donut with redbean paste $1.35) and blueberry mochi!
Kinako 5/5 - it was so soft and chewy. Redbean paste was not too sweet and just perfect!
Age 5/5 - it's bit oily but still very tasty!
Blueberry mochi 2/5 - taste artificial for some reason. My least favorite

Mango mochi is only available on friday and saturday and also they only accept cash so make sure to bring some cash :) 

If I'm in the area, I would definitely visit again!
author: Clare L.

description:
Wow!! I ordered the mochi with smooth red bean and flour on top and the donut with red bean. I loved the mochi. It was amazingly soft and smooth. I would come back!

The donut was really sweet and probably less than impressive.
author: Rose F.

description:
Note: this place is cash only !

Benkyodo offers a large selection of different mochis and some will be sweeter than others. I usually tend to come on weekends because that's when they'll have their seasonal flavors like strawberry or mango. The strawberry, mango, and blueberry mochi will have a huge chunk of the fruit in the middle surrounded by bean paste. 

My personal favorite is the mango and strawberry comes into a close second. I like these because the sweetness comes directly from the fruit 
and the fresh fruit adds a nice crunch! These fruit mochis do not last and must be eaten the same day... by the second day, the mochi will start absorbing the liquids and it becomes soft and will start disintegrating.

I'm not a huge fan of the peanut butter mochi because I think it's just chunky peanut butter in the filling and it's a bit too thick.

If you're in the area, definitely try this place out for tasty, inexpensive, and authentic mochi!
author: Andrea K.

description:
so so so so SOOOO good. And I got there late so much was gone. It's now 5 days later and I discovered in my little lunch bag one of the mochi snacks I picked up and it's STILL delicious and soft - but I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS! Why? Because it's better fresh, smartass, that's why!
What wonders do they create here? The folks at Benkyodo are doing it right, and super nice to boot. I grabbed a few of these white bean mochi and some of the pancake wrapped mochi, all super yummy. The lady that helped me behind the counter said if I come back to call ahead and they'll set aside some of the famous strawberry mochi. Oh, it's happening. FOR SURE. And you know what, what the hell. Next time, I think I'll get there in time to have some lunch too. Go whole hog. Because that's how adorable this place is. Makes me feel good. Go feel good and get yourself to Benkyodo, because mochi is LIFE!
author: Holly C.

description:
I just had to try it as an experience. So I head over before having any breakfast, very hungry.
I ordered the blueberry and the mango mochi.

The place is so authentic and cute. However, this is personal taste: I did not like it at all and threw both away after getting out the blueberries and the piece of mango from the centers.

I can see it is a traditional culinary experience... that is just not my personal taste. But the staff is friendly and the prices are good to try this out! 
And there's a cute diner type of seating to have coffee inside! And tons of public benches outside to sit down too.
author: Apple S.

description:
Apparently they have different fruit flavored ones on weekdays vs the weekend

I think I came close to 3pm and they had run out of the fruit filled mochis :(

But the lady who helped me was very nice and informative
If you are planning on picking up some mochi, you can just give them a call and they will hold on to it for you! 

The mochi is soft and chewy and the fillings were creamy
I preferred the ones with the red bean filling to the white lima bean ones
They were sweet but not too sweet

I think i grabbed 4 for a little bit over $5
author: Mai L.

description:
Fresh mochi is such a cut above the normal mochi found in grocery stores! It's SO much softer/chewier. Prices are cheap (1.35 for normal, 1.60 for fruit filled) but it's cash only which is a little annoying. 

I tried the blueberry filled mochi and the kinako (green mochi with red bean inside) and thought they were both amazing. The blueberry flavor really shined through! The kinako was more dense b/c of the red bean but I'm a huge fan of red bean so I still enjoyed it a lot. 

Excited to come back and try more flavors!
author: Melissa H.

description:
*** CASH ONLY ***

Unfortunately I will have to go against popular opinion and personally these mochi were just "A-OK".

Benkyodo Co is one of the original businesses in Japantown (started in 1906). This small mom & pop shop specializes in manju & mochi. Prices vary from $1.35 (Traditional, Peanut Butter, Sakura Gawa), $1.60 (Blueberry, Apple, Mange), $1.95 (Strawberry, Domyoji, Ohagi), $2.25 (Kashiwa), and $3 (An Pan).

***

Peanut Butter ($1.35): I felt pretty special because the staff had to take one peanut butter mochi out of pre-packaged boxes with a set of four peanut butter mochis in each box. Peanut butter filling tasted really dry and really sweet.

Strawberry Mochi ($1.95): There was a big chunk of fresh strawberry inside of mochi. It was not as sweet as peanut butter and red bean, so I like this one the best.

Yomogi (Green Mochi with Whole Red Beans, $1.35) & Habuta (White Mochi with Smooth Red Beans, $1.35): Red bean filling still tasted pretty sweet, but not as sweet as peanut butter.

***

All mochis here got incredibly soft texture and they were all really huge (not to mention inexpensive), but fillings were too sweet for my taste and I couldn't finish my mochis. Sakuraya and Chikara Mochi (both located in Gardena, CA) have better mochi fillings than Benkyodo Co.
author: Luke L.

description:
This place probably has the best mochi that has ever touched my mouth. I've only been here once, but it left an impression on me. If it weren't so far away, I would stop by always. I came by looking for the strawberry mochi, but I came later in the day so I wasn't so fortunate. I ended up getting a few other kinds, and they were all amazing.

I don't remember exactly what they were, but I remember enjoying them. The texture is just perfect! You can tell they were made fresh and they were chewy, but not too chewy where you would be chewing on them for days. Service here is nice too, BUT CASH ONLY...

I'll be back especially for the strawberry one!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Benkyodo and their coveted mochi have been on my radar for a while now. We finally made it over to J-Town on a recent visit back home from LA. Benkyodo was our immediate priority after flying out on the first flight headed to SFO. We arrived in Japantown a little before 1030am. We drove around the block a few times before finally finding metered parking up the hill. There was a decent line of about 6-8 people in front of us and not much mochi left. Nervous time... 

When we finally got to the front, we were able to get 2 mango (fresh mango and smooth white lima bean), 1 domyoji (steamed sweet rice with smooth red bean). 1 yomogi (green mochi with whole red beans) and 1 age (donut with smooth red beans). 

I had the fresh mango and it was really good. Loved the mochi and the juicy mango filling. That is as fresh as a mango mochi can get. Yumm. I also had the age and liked it a lot. The baked donut outer, drizzled with sugar and the smooth red bean paste inside was a great combination of textures and flavors. I really liked them both.

I was hoping to try the strawberry mochi but they arent in season yet. The gentleman at the counter said they would probably have them in about 1-1.5 months. So next trip, I am for sure making it back for that.

Cash only. Great, simple and delicious mochi... If you've had 2 Ladies Kitchen from Hawaii then you will certainly appreciate what Benkyodo offers... Half the space is a coffee shop counter. They also sell a variety of Japanese snacks, candies and crackers... I love the old time, simplistic feel of the place. I hope they keep on keeping on for decades to come.
author: Chuck D.

description: Their mochi is so good! I ordered the green mochi with red bean, blueberry mochi, and age donut. My favorite is the blueberry one! I like the fruit ness of it and to the mochi dough itself, it is soft. I would come here to try their other flavors in the future.
author: Kochamon S.

description:
This place is so cute. It looks like a diner lost in time from the late 60's that was converted to a Japanese confection store. There was a local man sitting at the counter having a conversation with the waitress on the coffee shop side. They were just chatting about the happenings. They sell donuts and advertise that they sell hamburgers and sandwiches, which I think is funny if not out of place. Maybe they just don't want to update the signs. Either way, I like the cozy feel of this store.

But we all know this review is for their mochi treats. There was not one mochi that my girlfriend and I didn't enjoy. They have peanut butter, red bean, strawberry, Lima bean, just all terrific stuff. I think we went when they first opened, so they brought out more flavors the longer we stayed there. Don't get too excited and jump in and blow your load on flavors you think you HAVE to get if other ones are coming out.

We bought a ton to share with our family and friends and there were no complaints. Only gripe is that it's cash only and if you're not fast enough then they might sell out of a flavor. Or you'll have to wait for them to make more. This is where you have to go if anyone is craving mochi.
author: Corey P.

description:
I finally tried the strawberry mochi and omg it's amazing. I've never seen the strawberry one whenever I pop in to the store, but I was able to order it for pickup a few times. If you're planning to visit definitely call ahead to see if they can make/reserve some strawberry ones for you. 

Mango and strawberries are a must try. The blueberries one is my least favorite fruit filled mochi. 

The peanut ones are good too! This is still an item I always get whenever I come.
author: Michelle T.

description:
The 3 oldest continuously run Japanese American businesses for over 100 years with the 4 year hiatus due to the unconstitutional incarceration of Japanese Americans during WWII in my recollection are Fu-getsudo- in Little Tokyo, Los Angeles; Kogetsudo-in what was Japantown in Fresno, and Benkyo-do-. 

Of the three, Benkyo-do- is the only one that serves also as a luncheonette so it has for years served as an invaluable, unofficial meeting place for  Japanese Americans living in the Bay Area. Bobby, one of the owners, plays host & knows many of his customers by name. 

It's a "Cheers" type of place where strangers as well as the regulars strike up friendly conversation drinkIng Japanese green tea or coffee, eating their counter ordered food, or eating Japanese pastries bought from the confection counter. 

This reminds me of long gone Usui restaurant on First Street, Little Tokyo, DTLA where Mr. Usui presided over his large group of regulars of which I was privileged to be part of. 

Besides the luncheonette, the primary & original raison d'être is for its Wagashi/Japanese confections. Mochigashi is made w/ a rice covering.  Manju is shaped like wheat flour based bun. Dora Yaki is closer to a wheat flour pancake. Most have some kind of fillng. 

Traditionally most of the sweet filling was either Kuroan (koo roh ahn)made from cooked Azuki beans which can be puréed smooth or have the rough skin, or smooth Shiroan (shee roh ahn)from Lima or other white colored beans. However, w/ cultural diffusion at the flick of the internet, chocolate, toffee, peanut butter, tropical fruit flavours, etc. are possible. 

The holy grail at Benkyo-do- is their signature Strawberry Mochi which has an almost translucent puréed smooth, soft, velvety rice pastry. Inside is a sweet sour, lIghtly acidic fresh strawberry, coated w/
a sweetened, strawberry velouté of Shiroan. Only available starting in April until the season runs out in fall. I couldn't get it in January. Such a Japanese concept where the cuisine is determined by the season. 

Kuri Manju- is a cakey, flour based baked bun egg yolk washed for a dark golden brown hue. The filling is Shiroan w/ a texture & taste reminiscent of puréed  chestnut. It's another tasty winner. 

Daifuku Mochi is soft, velvety rice pastry filled w/ either Shiroan or Kuroan. The textures are ultra suave w/ subtle earthy sweetness. 

That was all the Wagashi that was left by 3pm on a Saturday besides Anpan which is sweet bread bun filled w/ Kuroan. It's kInd of a Japanese European fusion food from over 100 years ago. 

Benkyo-do- also stocks Arare (ah rah reh) also known as Senbei (sehn beh ee) which are Japanese rice crackers either salt, Sho-yu/soy sauce, sugar flavoured. 

5 Yelp stars especially for serving as the community center for Japantown and continuing the tradition of making Japanese pastries for over a century.

http://www.benkyodocompany.com/
author: Gary I.

description:
One of the oldest shops located in Japantown. They make fresh mochi daily and they usually sell out quick!

They usually have a fruit mochi available and on this day. They had a mango mochi.  The mango inside was a nice tartness contrasting the mildly sweet mochi. The texture of the mochi was nice and chewy and very reminiscent to that of mochi I have had in Japan.
author: Jacky C.

description: Amazing mochis! I got the green mochi with red bean paste and the blueberry mochi. Both are very very soft and delicious.
author: Liyan H.

description:
I have been waiting so long to try this place out. And it is definitely deserving of all the praise I've heard. 

Their mochi is delicious! The layer of mochi is just thin enough to make you feel like you're not cheated of filling, but also thick enough to have the perfect amount of chew. 

Their fruit mochi is a definite must try. Blueberry mochi was available when I went, and it was deeeeelish. Having whole blueberries inside the mochi is a genius idea. Feeling the blueberries pop in your mouth combined with the chewiness if the mochi is just so delightful!
author: Christine L.

description:
I first heard about this place from my 先生 who raved about this place that sold manju (Japanese dessert) and I knew I had to go.  Every time I went they were always closed or I didn't have cash (Cash Only place) but this time was a success!  The manju is really good and so is their blueberry mochi!! Must try!!
Ordered: manju, blueberry mochi, age (kind of like a malasada) [all for $5]
author: Mikayla M.

description: So first off, I'm Vegan. Mochi is almost always Vegan, this isn't the case when they do mochi ice cream or something. So moving on... This place is incredible! This was most certainly on par with what I had in Japan. If there is any fresh fruit mochis left, jump on those first! The little steamed buns are Vegan. I confirmed the red bean buns have no egg or milk (not the ones in the full on plastic wrap, but the label will tell you what's up.) Typically these are safe, but I like to check. Those are also on par with what I had in Japan. I think if they were super fresh it would of just been even more incredible.
author: Hong T.

description:
My favorite place to get mochi! The only sad thing about this trip is that they did not have any strawberry ones as it is not in season.  They do, however, had blueberry ones.  They taste great and fresh! This place never disappoints.. only when they run out. 

Also... cash only place.
author: Charlie T.

description:
Definitely the best mochi I have ever had. They taste extremely fresh and true to their flavors. The mochi taste even better if you go home and pop them in the fridge a bit before eating. My favorite out of the ones I have tried is the blueberry. The mochi is sweet, but not overwhelming. This applies to both the fruit flavored and red bean fillings. 

I wish they had more selection to choose from. There were only four mochi flavors available when I visited. However, that may be due to the fact that I came at 2 pm, which is roughly a couple hours before the shop closes at 5 pm.

I definitely would come back to try more fruit flavored ones. They are also cheap at $1.35-1.60 each. 

!!!CASH ONLY!!!
author: Linh N.

description:
I got the assorted mochi and I gotta say my fav is the strawberry mochi.
Best mochi I've ever had!!! 
Nuff said.
author: Candice L.

description: This is the best mochi that I have had.  The line was kind of long, but I think it was mostly because the Japanese Cherry Blossom Festival was going on.  The plain mochi and baked mochi was good, but my favorite was the strawberry mochi.  It was made fresh, had filling inside, and a fresh strawberry inside.  Every bite was delicious
author: Arianna C.

description:
The mochi served here are mostly the authentic bean filled ones. They are alright, but they are very sweet. They didn't have any strawberry ones that others recommend on the day we visited. They are interesting and are worth a try, but the regular mochi are just not my thing. I like the cream, fruit, or ice cream filled ones. 

Cash only.

They are located across the street from the main Japantown Center.
author: Thien H.

description: This is a cute place selling authentic Japanese-style mochi. I never noticed about this place until my Japanese friend brought me over. Benkyodo Co makes mochi daily and there are many different kinds to choose. I picked three kinds: one with fresh mango chunck, green mochi with red bean paste and baked mochi. I have never had baked mochi before. I have to say Benkyodo Co's baked mochi is really yummy. It is not as stretchy as the unbaked mochi. It's a bit more cakey but I really enjoyed it!
author: Clare L.

description:
Mochi: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: best mochi in town.  I come all the time when I need a sweet treat!

The extended review...

Mochi:

Doesn't matter which ones you get...they are all good!  Amongst my favorites in this order are...

Habutai - red bean wrapped in plain mochi.

Chofu - mochi wrapped up in a pancake. So simple but sooooo good

Strawberry - a strawberry wrapped in mochi.  This one is seasonal I believe.

Blueberry - this one I had a couple days ago and was tasty!  Might be a seasonal item.

Kinako - red bean wrapped in green tea mochi.  

Service: friendly service as is the Japanese way!

Ambiance: it's sort of a diner and mochi shop in on.  For the mochi I typically take it to go as there is limited seating.  But it seems like a place for the local community and the customers are repeats!
author: Spencer Q.

description:
My husband and I have been wanting to try Benkyodo for a while now and it took us three tries to finally get it. 

We were visiting San Francisco this past week and decided to go to Benkyodo first thing Saturday morning. We got there at around 10 am and we were already a little late. They had two special fruit ones: mango and blueberry. The mango mochi was already sold out. They were making some more but it won't be ready until noon. However! We were able to have them hold some for us! We can come back and pick them up. 

They also give you the option to call it and have them hold some mochi for you :) That's pretty awesome of them. 

We got a total of five different mochis to try. The blueberry and the mango were interesting. They have chunks of the fruit in them with some sweet paste. We also tried one filled with lima bean paste. My favorite was probably the chofu, which was a piece of mochi wrapped with a layer of pancake. Skip the pancake and just eat the mochi. The pancake was dry. 

During strawberry season, they'll have a strawberry mochi available. I wish it was strawberry season! Strawberry mochi is my favorite! 

The prices are decent. They're $1.25 each or $1.50 if you get the fruit filled ones.

Overall, nothing was really that mind blowing. Nothing stood out. Their mochi's consistency and texture seemed like it was really soft with no chew/budget to it and that's just not my preference. Everything we tried was really good but I'm not so sure if it's something I'd go out of my way for.
author: Doriee D.

description:
Mmm, mochi and manju! Benkyodo has been around for more than 100 years. I would recommend to look at their website before going, so you can have an idea of what you like or may want to try. The best option is to call early in the morning to reserve what you would like because otherwise they sell out pretty fast. Usually around 1pm, most flavors are already sold out (as I've found from experience). 

My favorites include dorayaki (pancake with red bean), age (donut with red bean), kuri (manju with white lima bean), and habutai (white mochi with red bean). They also have a good selection of fruit mochi, though I've found that the fruit mochi 's go bad pretty quickly so you should consume them asap and they're also very sweet so I'm not too keen on those. 

Out of my list, the dorayaki is supreme. It's my absolute favorite, my #1. Their dorayaki is amazing. The pancake is so soft and the red bean is not overly sweet. It's perfectly done and a great size. It is so good, you should definitely try it if you can!

Bring cash because it's so worth it!
author: Jessica H.

description: Still the best Mochi in SF.  They have Blueberry right now and mentioned they should have Strawberry in the next few weeks.  They also mentioned that they have Mango on the weekends.
author: Scott L.

description:
Such soft, chewy, delicious, freshly made mochi! They're sold in sets so I don't believe you can buy just one - not that you'd want just one anyway!

I thought I was smart by coming here right when they open at 8am on a weekday. Unfortunately, a lot of their specialty flavors weren't even ready by then. The nice Japanese lady suggested that I come back at 10am when they'll have a lot more flavors.

Definitely worth a stop by!
author: Sally L.

description:
"Never trust spiritual leader who cannot dance." 
- Mr. Miyagi

Benkyo-Do Co is a place so Japanese. 

It's simple, compact, and filled w/ bite sized delectables. If you are into mochi... Benkyo-Do is the place to be!

I admit the first time I approached this place a little voice said: "is this the legendary Benkyo-Do I heard so much about... hmm not much to look at." A nondescript building on the corner of Buchanan & Sutter Streets in the heart of Japantown. If you blink you might miss it. And just like Mr. Miyagi from the Karate Kid movies, it's what's in the inside that counts most. Ohh the beauty of mochi... 

If you haven't had mochi you don't know what you're missing. Wait. Let me rephrase... if you had mochi, but not Benkyo-Do mochi you don't know what you're missing! It's that good, that soft, that fresh, and oh so Japanese. I advise to walk-out with at least half a dozen. 

My favorites are: Habutai (white mochi filled w/ smooth red beans), Peanut Butter Mochi (pink mochi filled w/ peanut butter) & I die for the seasonal Strawberry Manjū! (white mochi manjū filled w/ with fresh strawberry)!

If you're a Mochi or Manjū afficionado Benkyo-Do has it all: Age, Chofu, Dorayaki,  Habutai, Imo, Inaka/Yabure, Kinako, Kuri, Kuri (Goma), Mushi/Fukashi, Peanut Butter, Manjū, Pink Habutai, Strawberry Manjū (Seasonal), Suama, Yomogi, etc. All are delicious! 

Open Monday through Saturday, 8:00am - 4:00pm
Closed Sundays and 1st & 3rd Mondays of each month. Note: Benkyo-do was one chosen as a recipient of the California Small Business of the Year Award.

So the next time if in Japantown look for the nondescript building at the corner. You'll see the Benkyo-Do sign and walk into the heavenly Japanese confections that go back many centuries. In 1906, Suyeichi Okamura first opened Benkyo-Do and who would have known his family business would still be around to celebrate the 100th anniversary in Japantown. Today, now 111-years old, it is still family operated by his grandsons, Ricky & Bobby, who have continued the family legacy. And after a bite you'll see the love put into something that is so loved... 

"The true measure of a hero is not the size of his sword, it is the strength of his heart..."
author: Eric R.

description:
Boyfriend and I came by right before it was closing around 3:30 PM on a Saturday. There wasn't much of a selection left - only mango, pink and white habutai, and kuri. So naturally, I had to buy a bit of each. 

The mango mochi was absolutely delectable; the softest and most tender mochi skin I've ever feasted upon envelopes a fresh and moist slice of mango in the center. It would be doing it injustice to only buy one piece and even more so to devour only one. But seeing that this was the most delicious mochi we ever had, we decided (sort of unwillingly) to share the rest with a nearby friend (I cried a little inside). 

I'll definitely be coming by this place again to experience the rest of these heavenly chewy squish balls.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Walked in here to try their mochi . I'm a big mochi fan and I picked up two:

Age: Donut with smooth red beans
Habutai: White mochi with smooth red beans

I liked the Age considerably more than  the Habutai which is suprising b/c based on initial impression I thought it would have been the other way around. 

All in all a good experience. The items were super cheap as well I believe less than $2 per pop. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. 

Here is a look at how I rank the SF Bakeries I've visited and I indicated what they're known for or a dish I recommend:

Rod's SF Bakery rankings (and what they're known for or what I like). ?) Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.

34 Panaderia La Mexicana=mexican sweet bread
35 Hot cookie=Cookies
36 Les Gourmands Bakery=Croissant
37 Mee Mee Bakery=Cow ears
author: Rod M.

description:
A long standing historical mochi store in San Francisco that existed pre-world war in a different location, currently stands in the same spot its been in since the 50s. Small little shop north of Japantown across the street that opens up daily at 0800AM, selling out even before noon. They are normally closed on Sundays. We had arrived around 930AM and they were already sold out of the mango mochi, but stated they were going to make another batch later. Apparently you can call in and ask for some to be held for you for a short amount of time. 

First things first.... CASH ONLY ! 

Mugwort (mugwort mochi with whole red bean) - didn't really taste the mugwort too much but the red bean was pretty sweet. 

Kinako (green mochi with sweet red bean paste topped with toasted soybean powder) - im a fan of roasted/toasted soybean powder as i love getting the traditional korean shaved ice topped with this very same powder. The flavor is pretty similar to peanut. The powder was fairly light. Offset the sweet red bean paste a little bit. 

Chofu - its like a thin pancake wrapped around a piece of mochi. The pancake itself is dry. Would be nice if it was just the mochi itself. 

Blueberry - one of the two fresh berry ones. Originally we wanted the mochi where it has a whole strawberry inside but apparently they dont make it when strawberries arent in season. This was a pretty interesting one. Never had anything other than strawberry before. Blueberries were sweet which added an additional berry sweetness to the mochi 

Mango - the other fresh fruit. Just like the blueberry, it adds a nice fruit sweetness and the mango is very soft. 

Didn't try - Pink Habutai (pink mochi filled w/ peanut butter) and Habutai (white mochi filled w/ smooth red beans)

MAN so i had 2 left over, pretty sure one was pink habutai and possibly the habutai that hand-carried to the airport and brought it on the plane. I put it in the front pocket AND I FORGOT TO TAKE IT WITH ME WHEN I GOT OFF ! SAD FACE ! IM TOTALLY CURIOUS ABOUT THE PINK HABUTAI NOW ! DANG IT ! 

The Kinako and the two fruit ones were probably my two favorite. Im a huge fan on the soybean powder and the fresh fruit was nice! If i ever have the chance to come back again, maybe ill put the fruit ones in the fridge for like 15 minutes. Sounds like a great little cool treat ! Shouldn't mess with the mochi's texture too much. 

The prices are very good. $1.25 to 1.50 each. Each one weights a fairly good amount. I had originally got 6 and they were placed in a nice black plastic container with a lid and tied with a bow tied. Friends who got 4 got a clear plastic clamshell type container. XD 

The only thing i wished they had was fresh hot mochi. XD always wanted to try fresh ones
author: Andrew C.

description:
Recently after dining at San Wang restaurant in Japan Town my parents wanted to walk over to purchase mochi for my nephews birthday celebration. First time I have walked into Benkyodo and now I will surely return! The mochi is fresh, soft and truly one of the most scrumptious delicious mochi's I have ever enjoyed! 
We arrived at a good time since there was no one in front of us when we arrived. Shortly afterwards while we were choosing our selections I turned around and saw a long line going out of the door! We ended up with one dozen to go-a sweet sensation of colorful and delicious treats!
author: Yoh M.

description: This place is just what I needed, and is a wonderful asset to the community. I originally came to try their sweets, but was hooked by the little diner they run alongside their mochi bakery. They make fresh sandwiches and coffee at very affordable prices, which is super refreshing when you don't want to be limited to what's in Nijiya Market's food take-away section. Their blueberry mochi I had was stellar and definitely fresh, and I bought another one as soon as I finished the first one. All in all, it was lovely to sit down and overhear banter amongst regulars while I filled up on mochi and a cheeseburger sandwich (which was $4.80, by the way).
author: Lucy T.

description: The one and only place I know in the country that specializes in purely mochi. Benkyodo is a small shop that offers homemade mochi and imported Japanese snacks. The shop is run by an elderly couple and they're closed after 5pm. They sell it pretty quickly so I recommend going as early as you can. Everything is made fresh and they have a huge selection to choose from. Each piece is about $1 - $2 each. I usually get half a dozen to bring home or to eat at the plaza outside. I love the diner set up and it feels like you walked into the 90s.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
This is the first time I'm having legit Japanese mochi. Honestly, it did not disappoint. We ordered the 4 most popular mochi balls. All of them tasted great. They were light, soft, chewy, and delicious. 

Worth trying and getting. Cash only spot.
author: Alan L.

description: I got 6 different things to try and for me they were okay at best. I like the mochi part for its texture, but the fillings were either bland or too sweet. I obviously can't speak for everyone, but I prefer something with a little more flavor and less sugar.
author: D L.

description:
Benkyodo is the place in SF to purchase fresh mochi. Mochi, or a chewy Japanese rice cake, is plain but has a smooth silky texture. Inside the mochi are red bean paste, whole red beans, lima bean paste, or fresh fruit. Personally I favor the red bean paste over the whole red beans for a more smooth and uniform consistency and texture. The fresh fruit mochi (mango, strawberry, or blueberry) are Benkyodo's best sellers and run out quickly.

Other variations such as deep-fried dough with red bean filling, pancake-wrapped mochi, steamed buns filled with red beans, and plain mochi are also offered.

The mochi run slightly over $1 a piece, but the portions are quite generous and certainly shareable. And just to note, a box of 12 mochi is heavier than you'd think, especially if you're carrying it around for a few hours.
author: Priscilla W.

description: All flavors of their mochi are superb! Come early for a wider selection as they can sell out fast. Very friendly and efficient folks.
author: Clara T.

description:
This is the freshest, softest mochi I have ever tasted.  What a gem.
A little messy to eat. This is a must visit when in J town.

Connie
author: Connie W.

description:
3.5 is my rating

Stopped by here when we were in Japantown to try the mochis after seeing all the high reviews but I gotta say, I was a little disappointed. They do have a wide selection of mochi flavor though I'll give it that. But in regards to flavor and taste, I've definitely had better. All mochis were $1.25 USD except for the strawberry one which is $1.75 USD. 
I tried the pancake wrapped mochi, matcha mochi with full red bean paste inside with outside rolled on soybean powder and the strawberry mochi. The strawberry one was the best, actually had a large strawberry stuffed inside along with the strawberry paste. The textures of the mochi were too sticky for my liking.
Overhyped in my opinion.
author: Debbie P.

description:
CASH ONLY
If you want some fresh and delicious mochi this is your place!
$1.25/piece

Flavors they have are red bean, lima bean, blueberry, mango, and peanut butter. Also certain flavors are only available on the weekend. 

They also offer other snacks as well.

Mochi: Very fresh and soft. Chewy texture. Not too sweet, just right.

Across the street from the east mall japantown
author: Michele G.

description:
Best homemade mochi place in the Bay Area. It's a small shop that mostly is unnoticed. I've walked by this place many times and never noticed it. 

Come early or call to put your favorites on hold. They often sell out of the blueberry and strawberry mochis before 2 pm. The mochis are soft and filled with various traditional and some non-traditional fillings. It's been making mochis since 1906 and it's still made by the same family. Such an amazing tradition. 

Final note is that this is a cash only place. Make sure you go get some cash before coming.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Tip: don't come as they're closing or your options will be extremely limited. My friend and I split a white mung bean pink mochi though - super yummy and squishy! Quite sweet, but not overly so. 

There are Japanese cracker snacks available for purchase, as well as a few other food items. I'll be back...if I come early enough for more mochi selection!
author: Melanie W.

description:
Unassuming Japanese sweet shop that has the feel of half grocery store and half diner. The mochis are very traditional with a few varieties to choose from (i.e. white bean, red bean filling, fruit fillings). The store also sells Japanese sweet breads and some imported snacks.

I don't claim that these are the best mochis I've ever had; they do taste homemade with natural ingredients and the price is not outrageous. They're better eaten fresh. I made the mistake of saving a few for later and the skin hardened and the taste went downhill. So consume asap.
author: Shijie F.

description: This small shop is great.  I remember going to Benkyodo as kid about 45 years ago and buying manju, pizza bread and frozen pops.  The shop itself has changed very little since then except for the prices :).  Even the gentleman who used to work behind the counter is still there.  The manju is always fresh and tasty.  The only downside is that Benkyodo often runs out of the most popular manju flavors by early afternoon.  Hopefully, the shop will be around for another 100 years.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Super small little market looking place that sold mochi and other little japanese treats! Their mochis were really good!! Like, I just went to Japan a month ago and it was quite comparable (not quite as good, but good enough!)

The mochi were really soft and squishy and so so good. Especially the strawberry ones! I was so happy bc I had just missed the strawberry season in Japan when I had gone, so it was nice to be able to try it out.
author: Rina P.

description:
this place is original and a true San Francisco experience.

I went here with my girlfriend for mochi.
and that's what we get.
mochi! kimochi! ;)
this place also has a deli that serves breakfast and lunch daily.
but mochi is what making this place stand the test of time since 1906.
author: Rudy H.

description:
I wasn't a huge fan of mochi until I found Benkyodo! I found this place while exploring Japantown and this place is such a hit! They offer a variety of different mochis with red bean and they offer fruit mochi! 

Based on the season, they specialize in fruit mochi. They have blueberry, mango, and strawberry my personal favorite! The usually have the fruit mochis on the weekend only and they sell out FAST so I recommend going in early or calling in and reserve the mochis you want if you know you're going in late :)
author: Katty X.

description:
All the previous times I've visited Japantown, I haven't once been able to try Benkyodo since they close pretty early and are closed Sun/Mon. Finally, I came at a time when they were open, so I decided to swing inside for a peek.

Benkyodo is famous for their various mochis. They were sold out of all but one flavor, which was a white bean mochi, so I ordered a package of mochis to go. They were so good -- the skin was light and chewy, and inner bean paste was soft and mushy. It gave me pleasant flashbacks of  the good mochi that I have tried in Japan!

For the decently large size and the great quality, the mochis are very reasonably priced, at $1.25 per. Definitely will come back (early) to try the other flavors. Highly recommended!
author: Alvin W.

description: Very nice selection of good mochi,.. sweet and delectable fruity goodness,.. i like the doughnut stuffed with red bean,.. doughnut compliments the red bean nicely... i also like the peanut butter ones,.. its a must try for peanut butter kind of folks...
author: Chester V.

description: Wow! This place has the softest mochi ever. I thought mochi was chewy and stretchy, but this mochi was like biting into a cloud. Never thought mochi can just melt like that. This is one of the oldest establishments in Japantown. Know what to expect before you give it a shitty review please. It's a great place to go if you want to try really well-made authentic mochi to-go. A very sweet treat for a very affordable price that allows you to try multiple flavors.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Delicious and fresh mochi, inexpensive and the woman behind the counter is very friendly. I come here whenever I wanted to get some mochi for my mom or coworkers to try. 

Price is around $1.35 per piece while the seasonal fruit ones are $1.60. Cash only.
author: Jen M.

description:
I am such a sucker for manjuu, as is my family. If you can ever get fresh manjuu please do so; there is no comparing fresh soft mochi outside to any other mochi. 

This is a cute little shop with a cafe inside also. The selection is a bit sparse for mochi and they appear to run out fast; my friend specifically asked for the strawberry mochi (he read good things about it on Yelp) but unfortunately they didn't have anymore by the time we got there around noon. Or actually, referencing the website, it probably isn't the season they have strawberry daifuku.

This is what I ordered:
- Pink Habutai: Pink mochi with white lima bean filling

- Kuri: Manjuu baked with white lima bean filling

- Suama: Pink, Green, White (rainbow) plain sweet rice

First thing, since all are freshly made, the outside mochi is super soft, and the inside filling very smooth. Kuri is a personal favorite of mine as it is different from typical daifukus; the outside is baked. Suama is good if you just like the mochi and not the filling inside. Or it's just good if you want some extra color in your mochi!

I got 4 pieces for only $5. Great price for fresh traditional Japanese snacks! Definitely a place to stop by if you're in the area.
author: Kathy O.

description: Mochi was delicious and fresh, very inexpensive. Great environment and had an engaging conversation with some elderly Japanese ladies.
author: Geoffrey T.

description:
I went to try the mochi with a strawberry in the middle (love getting these in Japan). They only have them on weekends.

Pros: 
- Mochi is soft and chewy.
- Beans are smooth and creamy.

Cons:
- I wish they had the strawberry one :(
author: Rachel U.

description:
Really good fresh mochi.. 
I'll come back for more!
Service was nice and fast as well
author: Dimples P.

description: Found this place based on some internet tips. Tip was to come early because they sell out. And they're also closed 2 mondays of each month - 1st and 3rd. It's conveniently located in Japantown. Great place to walk around if visiting the city like I am. I walked out with a box of 15 Mochis hehe. Oops! I tried the peanut butter one (comes prewrapped to prevent contamination) and the mochi is soooo soft. I cannot wait to dig into others.
author: Patricia F.

description:
Ok, I'm kind of giving a biased review because this store has been here for so long and I appreciate that. Also, pricing is pretty decent at around $1.25-1.75 per mochi!

I'm surprised they even had a decent selection when we came in around 1 pm! SAD I missed the peanut butter mochi but I snagged the last mango mochi and was a little disappointed that there wasn't as much filling as I would've liked. I wish there were more mango and less of the mochi (which was huge!). Not sure if I like that it's super soft because it's definitely a nice plush touch but not the best for enjoying. 

Tasted good though.
author: Lilian K.

description: A good place to enjoy traditional Japanese Dessert.  I recommend every red bean dessert because it's soft, not so sweet, you can see the red bean inside!
author: Mengrou L.

description:
Since being introduced to Benkyodo Co and their delicious array of mochi flavors, I have not gone anywhere else to get my mochi fix...honestly, why would I?

Benkyodo is located in a shopping center in Japantown. If you visit around 11am, it is easy to find street parking. The small shop is half diner and half shop. I have yet to eat here, but the food looks good. Place is CASH ONLY. Mochi is $1.25. Flavors that I have tried: Yomogi Green (whole red bean), Kinako (mochi with red bean paste sprinkled with soybean powder), Pink Habutai (mochi with lima bean paste), and mango mochi (seasonal October - February?). While all of these were delicious, my favorite is the mango mochi. It is seasonal so call beforehand to see if it's available. Other seasonal flavors include strawberry and blueberry. Go early in the day to get the seasonal ones before they are sold out. 

I also bought a box to give as a gift and it was a hit so if you're looking to get a gift, go with mochi.
author: Katie C.

description:
The closest thing you'll ever get to sweet, soft balls of heaven is here. The mochi is unbelievably delicious. Each bite of soft mochi is HEAVEN. I kid you not. 11/10 would go here every single time I'm in J-town. 

Line goes by pretty fast. 

Get here early or your options will be limited!
author: Cindy M.

description:
Warning, I do enjoy mochi ice cream more than regular mochi, but both are still very much enjoyable when done right.  We had some time to kill in the meter and parked about a block up.  I remembered how I've been wanting to check out Benkyodo.  I got there yesterday after we finished lunch at Marufuku Ramen, maybe after 1:00 - 1:10.  There was a small line but we didn't have to wait more than several minutes.  I was a little disappointed in the limited selection of mochis.  I thought for all the hype they'd have more than like 5-6 types.  I ended up just buying us two strawberry mochis for $1.75 each.  Service was friendly enough and I appreciate the freshness of the mochis made onsite.  At first I thought I may have taken the last of the strawberry mochis, but they instantly brought another tray out.  

I didn't eat them til several hours later, but for both of the mochis, one side was serverly sticking to the wrapper making it difficult to eat all of it.  They also had a lot of rice powder on them making a little bit of a mess on my black maxi dress.  A bit doughy but I'm alright with them as they were pillowy soft.  We also enjoyed the big strawberry chunk in the middle.  I've had my in laws bring me back home mochis from Hawaii which were probably several days old that still had a better consistency.  It makes sense that the strawberry mochi is made when in season, and I've seen the rotating fruit flavors here mentioned on Yelp (mango, blueberry, etc).  Glad I gave them a try, but I'm not itching to go back soon.  I think I'd rather save the calories for a slice of coffee crunch cake at nearby Yasukochi's.
author: Cat C.

description: One of the softest and freshest hand-made mochi I've ever had. I think the strawberry one that's filled with white bean is only sold during certain days, but be sure you get it if you can. This shop can be found right in Japantown and it's been open since 1906!
author: Sherry V.

description:
Quant little sweets shop in Japantown that provides cheap and delectable  homemade mochi!
Benkyo-do is the real deal. For only $1.25 you can get delicious homemade mochi with a variety of fillings  and styles. Mochi is a bite sized sweet that commonly accompanies tea and matcha. A common variety is made from pounded glutinous rice and filled with red bean paste. I opted for the Kinako (mochi filled with sweet red bean paste and dusted with toasted soybean powder). It was quite large and only $1.25. The perfect afternoon treat. 

Several establishments in the area sell imported mochi for a higher price, this is a nice local option.
author: Wes H.

description:
An early breakfast of freshly made mochi on Christmas Eve was pretty much the most perfect thing that I've done all year. But, I get ahead of myself...

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Street parking is a pain, so go early
+ Cash only
+ Clearly a relaxing cafe/diner/bakery for locals
+ The mochi is some of the best I've had in California (fresh blueberry mochi was INCREDIBLE)

A girl can only eat so many mochi, and we were a little early (9 am on a Saturday) for the entirety of the display case to be filled out, but the options we did get were incredible.
author: Claire S.

description:
The mochi here is amazing! Highly recommend if you are a fan of sweets or japanese desserts :)

I came here one afternoon with my girlfriend around 3PM and to our surprise, they were sold out of most of their flavors! When we asked them about the empty displays, the manager said that they make their mochi in-house. That's a win for me -- I love supporting the community! More than that however, you can taste and feel how different this mochi is compared to the packaged mochi in convenience stores. The mochi here is incredibly soft and not very chewy with a subtle sweetness. 

My girlfriend and I bought a box of 9 to get their cute cardboard container. We ended up eating 1 and sharing the rest with family. Looking back on this though, I wish I kept some to take home because I'm craving some mochi now!
author: Brandon T.

description:
Went for breakfast at 1030am on a Saturday and sat in perfect peace with the fleshy, soft, pillowy, fresh and legendary blueberry and mango mochi. You have to get these. I've had all the mochi at this place, including the pancake/baked/fried ones, and these two are by far the best, packed with fresh fruits around the soft mochi.
Come early, leave happy.

5 stars!!!!!
author: Bonnie G.

description:
Super fresh & authentic homemade mochi. 

Mochi is a Japanese rice cake.  It's chewy but silky smooth (kind of gelatinous).  If you've never had them before, they might not be to your taste.  They're not very sweet and have a bit of a chalky flavor. If you like mochi (and not just ice cream mochi), you will love this place. Typical fillings will be lima bean paste or bed bean paste.    The seasonal manju are excellent.  These are plain mochi with fresh fruit (mango, strawberry or blueberry inside).  

The shop itself is family run. It's cute and small and not at all pretentious.  Half of the store is a diner, and you'll usually see a fair number of regulars at the counter.
  It's nice that places like this still exist in SF.
author: Holly P.

description:
Came when it was close to closing. Tried the kinako flavor and it was excellent! Mochi was so soft, had the right amount of red bean inside, and was just the right sweetness. They run out of flavors later in the day, so it's definitely better to arrive earlier. The blueberry and mango were sold out, so it was a bummer to not be able to try it. You can call ahead for the flavors of the day and to ask if they still have any left. 

This place has the freshest, softest mochi that I've had in the states.
author: Edward W.

description:
Maybe i just didn't get the right one. I'm not even sure which flavor it was but it was green (I'm guessing green tea?) and had some brown (I'm guessing red bean?) filling inside. I did go half an hour before closing though, so maybe all of the good ones were gone. The consistency of the mochi was a little too soft for my taste. I like my mochi with a tiny bit of give.

Even so, I wouldn't mind going back next time I'm in SF (if I'm in the neighborhood). But next time, I'll go a lot earlier. The mochi with the strawberry inside looks pretty amazing!
author: Mel T.

description: Here to visit for just a couple of days and was excited to find out about benkyudo's strawberry Mochi. The last time I had it was in Kyoto many years ago. But I was disappointed to find out they only had the red bean! Supposedly the shop owner expected her customers to call in to reserve fruit mochis.. so I got the red bean one instead, the mochi layer is not thin but it's very soft ... it sticks the the paper cup that was holding it ... was it great? Eh... I've had better but it definitely has a home made taste. Personally I think the reviews on yelp is overrated ..
author: Jojo L.

description:
Big. Fresh. Delicious. Mochi. 

Came here around 2pm on a random Wednesday and they definitely had lots of flavors to choose from. The kinako and the seasonal blueberry are my favs! I do think the fillings can be a bit too sweet but nothing a little green tea won't balance out. 

Remember! Cash money only!
author: Alice Z.

description: Love this place. Mochi is easily the star of this show, and clearly homemade and fresh, unlike mochi you'd get in stores. To me, the lima bean and red bean paste all taste the same. It's fresh and homemade, so it is lighter in color, but it's also more... grainy and past-y. I definitely like the sticky rice wrapping of it more than the inside. They all aren't too sweet, and the easy favorite was the one with a whole strawberry inside. That one tastes AMAZING, fresh and how strawberry flavored treats are supposed to taste. Definitely grab a whole dozen of those!
author: Ke C.

description: Seasonal blueberry mochi are a definite recommend. I tried it once and fell in love, but I haven't been in town when they were in season, which is still a major bummer. Although, my second go to would be the mango mochi. A majority of the seasonal mochi has burst of freshness that comes along with the freshness of the mochi, since I heard that the mochi are made fresh daily. I haven't found a place that served yummy fresh mochi like this place and I'll come back when I'm in town
author: Teresa L.

description: Wow, how is it I haven't written a review for Benkyodo yet?! Must be I was trying to keep it all to myself! BEST peanut butter mochi in all the world! Also the fruit mochi! hullo! But don't skip the traditional favorites! get it while it's fresh and try not to die of euphoria!
author: Emma F.

description: One of my fav mochi shops i ever had. My only regret is that they do not carry black sesame mochi but red bean mochi is just as good. I did not have the strawberry mochi but my friend claimed it was delicious. If you are lucky and come when there is no one in line you wont have to wait for 30mins+....
author: Ji T.

description:
5-stars. Every single time. No doubt about it. 

If you're in SF, there is no comparison to who makes the best mochi. Years and years of practice has made this spot my #1 pick for whenever I'm in the area. Sure, store bought ones imported from Japan at Nijiya/Nippon-ya/Super Mira is alright, but I can promise you that once you've eaten a Mochi from Benkyodo... you'd never look back at packaged ones. They make them fresh daily with a nice variety of flavors ranging from fresh fruits (blueberries) to red bean filling. for about 1.30 a piece, they are worth every penny.
author: Tyler D.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  Getting a mochi from here makes getting a mochi from Ranch 99 taste like crap.  I have to warn you, this place is cash only, so bring cash! This store is outside of the mall and is located at the end of the block.  It looks like a diner from the outside, but when you go in the diner is on the right side and the mochi on the the left.  They have many types of mochi, they have whole red bean mochi, red bean paste mochi,  yellow bean mochi and my favorite fruit filling mochi.  

Depending on the season, they have different flavors.  They have blueberry, strawberry and mango. However, i haven't seen the strawberry one in a long time. My favorite was the mango one! I love mango so this was perfect! There was mango puree inside and small chucks of mango all mixed in.  Their other mochis are all super fresh, you can tell the made it that day.  I like the mochi with red bean paste more than whole bean.

If you order a lot they will actually if you want it wrapped.  It makes a great gift because they box it up all nice and use very nice wrapping paper.  However, you need to order a 4 mochis for them to place it in a box for you. If you want the fruit mochis, i recommend coming here early.  There were times i got here at 10 am and they were almost sold out!   Rise and shine!!
author: Belinda C.

description: A simple coffee place selling mochi balls, sweets, and Japanese coffee. That's it. They keep it simple, and therefore keep it amazing. Soft mochi with awesome filling. About $1-1.75 per mochi ball.
author: Minh S.

description: Love this Little place . I try  the red bean mochi . The skin is very soft and chewy. The downside is too sweet the inside red bean . Anyway good place for dessert after lunch near by Jtown
author: Fay B.

description: Best mochis ever!! There's nothing like soft, chewy, delicious mochi from Benkyodo. All their flavors are really good but the blueberry is my favorite. Best consumed right away, not that you can wait that long to eat them anyway. Perfect for a snack or as dessert after Japanese food nearby. Cash only!
author: Wendan L.

description: Tried the peanut butter, fresh mango, and fresh bluberry mochis in January and they were very tasty. PB mochi has crunchy pb inside and was my favorite of the three. Fresh mango mochi has a chunk of mango, enhanced with mango flavor and white lima bean paste. The fresh blueberry mochi has several blueberries enhanced with blueberry flavor and white lima bean paste. Mochi skin is slightly sweet and perfectly chewy. I'll be back to try fresh strawberry mochi when it's in season :)
author: P C.

description: YUM. Fresh mochi, excellent quality. I tried the strawberry one and it was so good. They run out of mochi early and then close, so get there early. Perfect texture and even a non-mochi lover would enjoy
author: Antonio R.

description:
So good!

Got to experience here while on the Japantown food tour by Edible excursions. I got an Age and it was so so good. My hubby tried the green mochi with red bean paste and he enjoyed it, it wasn't my fave. 

This is a must stop for mochi.
author: Crystal B.

description:
I pass through Japantown all the time and somehow always miss this inconspicuous and somewhat dated-looking diner. When I finally stepped through the doors of this 100+ year-old establishment, I took in the sight of rows upon rows of handmade manju and mochi. I don't know the difference between mochi and manju. Both are made from a rice flour base. Perhaps someone can explain it in more detail to me one day.
I picked out a few to try, but I might as well have closed my eyes and taken a stab in the dark. While I was clueless, other patrons who were obviously regulars, were loading up dozens of manju into gift boxes. The owners seemed somewhat impatient, which I guess goes along with running a no-nonsense, no-frills family business, so I quickly made my selections and went on my way.

I got 2 blueberry mochi, a pink habutai - pink mochi with lima bean filling, and a chofu - mochi wrapped in thin pancake. They all tasted very fresh, soft, and not too chewy. I liked the blueberry filling the most, because the liquidy berry filling balanced out the glutinous rice. I wasn't a fan of the chofu. The thin pancake and glutinous rice combination dried out my mouth.

If I were in the area with a sweet tooth, I'd stop by Benkyodo to try out the other manju. Like a lot of the other shops in this neighborhood, they close pretty early and they are closed on Sundays, so that doesn't allow many opportunities to stop by. Unfortunately they do not accept cards, so that is an inconvenience. Good thing the little confectioneries are affordable. So if you happen to have a few dollar bills burning a hole in your pocket, give Benkyodo a try.
author: Joy W.

description:
This place has been here for decades. Established in 1906. Japanese family business.

As you walk in, there is a diner to your right. To your left is the mochi. Down to earth place with an out of this world product. 

Fresh homemade mochi. Nice selection. There are seasonal flavors as well. The seasonal strawberry is a highlight for me. Come early to ensure your favorite flavor is not sold out. 

They distribute to selected Bay Area stores. I've seen their mochi at Berkeley Bowl if you want to sample a few flavors. To get the true measure of their products, visit the store.

This is the number one spot for the mochi aficionado in the SF area. 

Cash is king here.
author: Jaqen H.

description:
I thought the Mochi here was too soft and kinda flavorless. They are super fresh and made daily. However, there wasn't much give or spring to the "chew" like the Korean ones I've tasted or some other Japanese ones I've had in LA. It was interesting how they put an actual piece of fruit in the middle of the strawberry Mochi though -- a fresh surprise. Except that the strawberry was pretty meh. Higher quality ingredients would help, but probably can't happen at this price point.

My friends that frequent Japan rave about this place though, so maybe it is just my taste buds. And you can't beat how cheap it is. All in all, it was okay.

Place is a tiny old old shop with one Japanese lady working who probably does everything from making the Mochi to janitorial duties. Feels like a donut shop from the 80s that has never been renovated and the recipes are still exactly the same.
author: Latef X.

description: Soft sticky mochi with a delicate sweetness! Blueberry and white lima bean filling was the seasonal today and it was delightful!  I also got a peanut butter one which was ok for me. I'm not a huge peanut butter fan but if you are, it's got crunchy peanut butter filling that went well with the mochi. I misread and thought it was traditional peanut filling which should've been crushed roasted peanuts and sugar. Def stop by this place for mochi very rare and traditional!
author: Lillian H.

description: The mochi was the best I ever tasted! Will definitely go back on next visit to SF. Would have like to try the mango mochi but they didn't have any that day. However the strawberry mochi was very tasty . If you're ever closed by there, try it!!!
author: Puvadol S.

description: Forget the packaged store bought mochi. The stuff this place sells tastes so much better. Just enough mochiness wrapping what tastes like fresh made red beans. What a treat.
author: Lams L.

description:
Delicious MOCHI handmade here. We went to Japantown just to check it out. Not much to see here and our friend had told us that there was a shop that specializes in mochi. We didn't catch the name of it but we saw this shop and went in. It didn't fit the description of specializing in mochi to me. I imagined a crazy elaborate shop that may have people making mochi in front for people to see.

Except it was a small quaint shop with a small diner and a counter that sold mochi. It didn't look too tempting to me but le beau got a mochi and loved it. We sat outside and he ate his mochi and I messaged my friend the name of the shop it was the one we went in! So going with my friend's recommendation we went back and I got my own.

AND IT WAS AMAZING! I got the blueberry mochi and it was soft and fresh. We also came later in the day about an hour before they closed and the selection was minimal. So I would think they would have a better selection when they first open. Would recommend 10/10
author: Sandy T.

description:
All you need to get is the blueberry mochi. Okay fine, get all of them. I can't say anything bad about it because they're so good! I would get mochi here anyday! You really feel the love here. 

6 for about $7? I can't remember but it was worth every penny. Mochi coma.
author: Jacqui L.

description: The blueberry mochi was really good but everything else was okay. In fact, most of their other flavors tasted the same except for the blueberry one. Like the strawberry mochi, which sold out before I could try, the blueberry mochi contains real blueberries!
author: Judy M.

description: Best mochi I've had outside of Japan. We parked around the corner and "discovered" this historical treasure. I wish the food they serve was Japanese but it seems to be very traditional American diner food...but...the mochi is well worth the visit.
author: Leslie K.

description: the red bean paste tastes not too sweet which is exactly what I want ! very homey style. The age mocha tastes like donut lol. 4 pieces for only 5 bucks !!! cash only tho.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Benkyodo makes the best mochi in the Bay Area, maybe even the entire state. Sure you can try other places, like the one in San Jose's Japantown, but why bother when you can get the best from Benkyodo. There's such an amazing feeling when you walk in and see the counter where locals and regulars go for coffee, breakfast, and great conversations. Their selection of snacks is amazing. And of course, the mochi. Oh boy. 

The mochi pieces are HUGE! Everyone I've tried has been nothing but delicious and you can tell they were made with care. I definitely recommend the fruit ones - blueberry, mango, and definitely the strawberry. The strawberry piece is of course seasonal, so be sure to go during season. I highly recommend calling ahead (a day or two) and placing an order for the pieces. You don't want to miss out of any of their goodness. (Of course going late in the afternoon without preordering is a gamble because the mochi may be gone by then - since they're just that good!)

You really want to be sure to stop at Benkyodo whenever you're in SF's Japantown or anywhere close (even if you're in SJ).
author: Joe Y.

description:
I came back on Friday and it didn't disappoint!  We loved the peanut butter mochis.  It's my favorite now.  I also enjoyed the baked lima bean manju and the donut looking one though the donut was too sweet.

Definitely will come back and get more of the peanut butter mochi.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Oh Benyodo!

I had the mango mochi this past weekend and it was absolutely delicious! You have to get here early if you want all the selections! They typically run out by 12/1PM but I suspect they lose half of their flavors much earlier.

It's cash only. 8 pieces for about $10. really good prices for the quality imo.
author: Mimi T.

description:
This classic establishment is a must-go destination in the San Francisco Japantown! Playing a dual role of a American breakfast bar and a Japanese grocery counter, Benkyodo's signature item is its handmade mochi - if you have not had their mochi and never went to Asia, you never had real mochi before!

Benkyodo's mochi flavor selection is small but sufficient. Here, you will find the classic choices like the red bean paste or the more luxurious options like real fruit pieces. No matter which one you pick, expect the real delight of tasting the chewy, stretchy texture of handmade mochi made from grounded sweet rice. Until you experienced it, you won't know what you are missing out if you had only packaged mochi! It's really beyond words.

Although each piece is rather massive (two makes a good breakfast!), each one is $1.40, which is probably a good deterrent from eating too many. I highly recommend coming by and picking up at least one mochi to try out the real deal; I said at least one because you'll probably return to buy a whole box!
author: Jay Y.

description: Best place to get fresh strawberry (seasonal) and mango mochi. Best to call ahead.  I ordered 6 of each.   Yum.
author: R L.

description: Good luck trying to buy something at this place. Not only the opening hours overlap with a normal person's working out, I just tried to visit at 4.48 (12 minutes before closing) and it was shut, with the guy cleaning up inside who completely ignored me. Appalling customer service, I'm very disappointed.
author: Kasia R.

description:
One of the original businesses in San Francisco's Japantown, family owned and operated since 1906, Benkyodo is a City staple. 

Pardon my long overdue review, 20 years in the making. 

Highly recommend the fruit-filled Manju. $1.40 per piece of seasonal mochi: blueberry on weekdays, mango / strawberry on weekends only. The silky mouth-feel of the smooth lima bean filling that surrounds the fresh fruit is unlike any other mochi. 

Age: fried Japanese donut filled with smooth red bean paste. 

Pink Habutai: pink mochi with smooth white lima bean filling, basically like the Mango / Blueberry / Strawberry filled Manju minus the fresh seasonal fruit. 

I really miss the chocolate and marshmallow-filled manju they offered years ago. Once in a while peanut butter-filled manju is available. 

Whether you're in the area or making a special trip, stop by Benkyodo for classic Japanese confections, handmade fresh daily. 

They carry quite an assortment of packaged snacks and candy too (although you can purchase the store-bought treats for far less at Ichi Ban Kan down the street).

Note: 
Cash only;
Street parking is limited & metered;
Closed Sunday's and major holidays.
author: Geminyna J.

description: I'm a SF Native and this is my favorite mochi store. This has been my go to spot since I was a kid!
author: N A.

description:
I only got to try the Pink Habutai mochi (lima bean paste) because they were all out of the other flavors. The mochi itself was so incredibly soft! If I could make a bed out of it, I'm sure it would have felt like sleeping on clouds. The lima bean paste filling was decent but was overshadowed by the mochi outer layer. I would have been more satisfied with no filling at all.

I definitely recommend coming early so you'll have a choice in flavors. We got there maybe 45 minutes to an hour before closing and I had to stand there and watch as they sold the last mango to someone ahead of me. Sad times.
author: Cammie W.

description: Okay but not as good as expected. The owner/ server is nice but the wait time is a bit long when I ask them if they still got the mango one
author: Jade Y.

description:
If you like mochi or more properly named Daifuku, this place is your slice of heaven. Ordered two or three of everything and literally everything tasted amazing. Incredibly fresh and tender, you will not get better mochi than here.

As mentioned, good luck with parking. We came here during the cherry blossom festival and got lucky with street parking. I also got lucky with a limited edition DBZ poster from a street vendor, so maybe I was on the right side of Karma that day.
author: Amir S.

description:
I love this place!! So authentic and as one reviewer mentioned, it reminds me of the strawberry mochi place in Hawaii- 2 sister. It is out of this world and worth whatever wait you may have.

This place does sell out quickly so the earlier you get there, the better. 

Street parking in the area can be tough which is probably true of all of SF.

I happily drive up from Palo Alto just to buy a few mochi- worth the drive and the traffic!
author: L S.

description: Super delicious! Very traditional Japanese confections does not disappoint! Definitely go during the early hours of them opening and get all the flavors or ones you like. Too bad I didn't come when it was strawberry season. If you're here during mid April to the summer definitely try it!
author: Sarah L.

description: Fresh and sweet Japanese treats- Blueberry mochi. Found this place on Pinterest and was not disappointed. Small store, pleasant service. But i wish they had more flavors.
author: Anya E.

description:
CASH ONLY

I can't believe this store has been around since 1906! This was definitely the best mochi I have ever had! Normally the mochi I get in stores is hard and lacks good texture. The ones served here are soo soft. You can order it to go and sit outside on the nice benches and people watch.

Each mochi is very reasonably priced at a little over $1. The lady at the counter recommended the strawberry mochi as it's their bestseller and is seasonal. I am so glad she told me to get it. It was the perfect sweetness and I loved the little piece of fresh strawberry inside! I also got the green mochi with red bean and it was equally delicious although not a sweet as the strawberry. Highly recommend stopping by!
author: Linda X.

description: Benkyodo makes the most authentic Mochi's! They are not too doughy, too sweet nor chewy. They are just right! Though you have to go there early in the morning to get the fruit mochi's. Like mango, blueberry or strawberry.  On weekends, you should probably go there before 11AM.. by noon there is no more of the fruit only the traditional ones.
author: Cyndi L.

description:
tldr; delicious handmade mochi!

LOVE this place. This is my new go to when I want mochi. Benkyodo hand makes their mochi and it is delicious. Softer than anything I've ever had, and the red bean filling is wonderful. It really does feel like it melts in your mouth. 

It's a really cute small mom and pop place :) They are also right across from a tiny one counter diner that I've been meaning to try as well. Mochi here is super cheap -- not sure of the $/piece price, but it's fairly affordable.

My favorites are the white mochi with red bean and the mango mochi. Had the pancake mochi which tasted weird to be because the pancake kind of interfered with the mochi goodness, but the more classic white mochi with red bean is delicious. Highly recommend.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Be aware that this is a cash only place!

If you find yourself in Japantown, please give Benkyodo a try. You will no be disappointed.
I recommend getting here early and stock up on their blueberry mochi (the absolute best). I've tried a variety of their mochi and there wasn't a single one that I did not like.
author: Elisza T.

description:
Mochi heaven!!!!
We've been trying to go here for quite a while, the last two times we came the place was close, however we finally caught it open and boy was it worth it.

We got three of their mochis, a blueberry and two of the red bean.  Let me start by saying that there are very few places if any besides this one that make fresh mochi in sf, boy was their mochi amazing, pure heaven, it literally melts in your mouth.  The blueberry one is probably my favorite, however they were all delicious.

I can't wait to come back here, make sure to bring cash so you won't make my mistake and had to walk to an atm to get cash argggg!! If you love mochi this place should be at the top of your list.  I wish they made mochi ice cream, that is the only thing I wish they would make.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Japantown has now become a dangerous place with my discovery of Benkyodo Co. At first I was confused when I walked through the doors because there's a diner on the right side, but I soon saw the impressive collection of fresh mochi in the glass display cases on the left side. There was no line, but I took my time deciding which mochi I wanted to get now, and which ones I wanted to get next time.

The lady at the counter told me that the red bean mochi was most popular (of course) and the blueberry mochi has been a seasonal favorite. I was going to get lunch and tea with my cousin and friend, so I got 8 pieces for $10.50 and selected an assortment including red bean, blueberry, and plain. The mochi was placed in a plastic container with a clear lid, so you will forever be tempted until consumption. Good thing they tie it up with a ribbon to prevent you from digging right in without some effort.

Classic red bean was probably my favorite, though blueberry was surprisingly delicious! It tasted like there were whole blueberries in there. Wow!! I was impressed by the amount of filing that was inside and by the perfectly soft mochi part. I will definitely be back to try more flavors and buy a few more for friends and get-togethers. Great find!!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Small little mochi place with a small cafe with this Japanese lady making sandwiches.  

The mochi itself is pretty good but only have a life of around 3 days cause then it gets moist.  The mochi is nice and soft and it's not too sweet.  Yum.
author: Alice T.

description:
I'm no mochi expert, but this may be one of the best tasting mochi I've had so far. 

Each one costs about $1.50! "Say whaaa" 
 They are a good chunky size! "I like them plump Mmhmm!" 
Consists of fresh fillings since they handmade all of them! "uh, sold!" 
Skins that taste softer than silk! "Best believe!"
 Literally can't go wrong with any flavors here. 

We got the Green (consists of red bean inside) and Strawberry (with pink filling and a fresh slice of strawberry inside). AMAZING. Both had the softest smoothest skin that even baby skin can't compete with. Both fillings were SUPER fresh and flavorful. 

This place is super small but there's always people coming in endlessly! And now I know why.

This place has a hefty legacy since its very first shop opened in 1906 and was passed down to their future generations. They've been at this for HELLA decades so, yes, experts you are. 

Do stop by for a taste of delight! :) you won't regret.
author: Chena N.

description:
Mochi's and service on point
Lady was super nice to me 

Mochi not too sweet.  And the consistency is on point delicious. 

1.25 a moch.  Seems worth it.
author: Pin C.

description: Never expect to have this precious mochi out of Japan but here it is!! I had two mochi, one strawberry inside and the matcha red bean for the other one. Love both of them. Super soft dough and super juicy stuffed. I'll go back there again I promise to myself!
author: Ferrari D.

description:
Benkyodo is my favorite mochi place and because of Benkyodo, I can never buy prepackaged mochi or manju at the supermarket anymore. The mochis and manjus here are always super soft and fresh. My favorite is the strawberry mochi because there is a piece of strawberry in it. I like their chofu too because it's really cute and simple but so yummy. 

The place is small and there is usually a line, but the line moves quickly and the staff is friendly. However, it's cash only.
author: Helen L.

description: Mochi is super soft here! I loved the Lima bean filled mochi a lot. I think the ones filled with fruit and Lima are a bit on the too sweet side, but the Lima bean filled one is perfect.
author: Kaori B.

description: There mochi is the best mochi I have ever tasted. The mochi had such a wonderful texture, you can tell that it is homemade. The people are so kind and nice here! I love the vibe. I will DEFINITELY be back again.
author: Celaena P.

description:
Was quite excited to find out about this local mom and pop shop located in the heart of Japantown. Came here originally only to buy a box of mochi as a gift but decided to snag a few mochi bites for myself!! I couldn't resist...mochi for $1.25 each, whip up a box for me please!! 

Grabbed 5 different flavors : the famous blueberry, kinako (red bean paste with crushed soybean sprinkled on top), pink habutai (Lima bean paste), yomogi green mochi and another mochi that may just be a traditional white colored mochi with red bean paste. 

The lady at the register was very sweet, friendly and welcoming. Wished they had more flavors. No strawberry mochi, slightly bummed. But will definitely trek back to this little gem.
author: Diana L.

description:
Benkyodo is definitely one of Japantown SF's notable attractions. Benkyodo is Japantown's longest running establishment, bringing handcrafted Japanese confections to San Francisco since 1905. Century-old recipes still continue to excite and bring generations together.
