Inside Benkyodo you will find a small cafe counter that is a popular meeting spot for older Japanese generations to linger over Japanese sweet treats and good conversation. 

This was my first time to Benkyodo Co. as I usually get my bean buns from Shuei-Do Manju Shop in Japantown SJ. I really love the selections from both family-run shops and the warm cultural connections. 

Benkyodo has all your traditional manju flavors but has added a few enticing nouveau flavors to their line-up including peanut butter, strawberry, blueberry and age (deep fried donut), really pushing the red bean envelope. 

I loved the Age and the Strawberry manju. The Age is a donut-manju hybrid bringing together a soft jelly center with a crispy sugary exterior. The Strawberry manju features smooth white lima beans with fresh strawberries and strawberry flavorings. I was glad I brought more than a few of the strawberries home with me as they were one of the favorites. 

Discover one of Japantown's most storied businesses and enjoy some delicious delicacies at Benkyodo. They are closed on Sundays so do plan your trip or visit accordingly.
author: Nicole D.

description:
Benkyodo has the best mochi in town! Not only are these little guys affordable at under $2 a pop, but they're squishy and cute and absolutely delicious! The mochi is fresh and has the most delightful pillowy soft and chewy texture. My favorites are the strawberry and blueberry mochi, which are both stuffed with smooth lima bean paste and a fresh piece of fruit inside. The blueberry mochi are seasonal, but the strawberry mochi are full time. Other flavors include peanut butter and red bean, but they have a bunch of other manju (Japanese confections) that are more traditional. Some are baked and they even have one called Age, which is a small fried donut ball with red bean inside that's rolled in sugar. Yum! 

Keep in mind that they're cash only and close at 5pm, so some of the flavors sell out towards closing. Benkyodo is a mandatory stop over for me whenever I'm in Japatown, but they're easily a destination spot as well. The mochi keeps for a few days in your fridge so grab a box of 'em while you're here!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Found the place. A little bit shocked to see it was a hole in a wall place, half was a small diner with the opposite side as a pastry somewhat kinda. There they have 3-4 variety of mochi, i was expecting like at least a dozen..  oh well bought two kinds. What can i say it was OK nothing fancy or special about it....way to sweet. I would rather go to Costco and buy tve Mochi Ice cream instead.
author: Jamil T.

description: Benkyodo, I love you so much I will go out of my way for you even tho you make my Mochi needing existence more difficult than it should be. I will do anything for your fruit mochi and it breaks my heart that you are closed on sundays and that you generally close at four. Also, last time I went the final two mango mochi sold out for the day to the customer in front of me. Burn. Pls make more and consider being open longer/full weekends! You are making magic
author: Sally R.

description: A highly recommended stop for anyone visiting Japantown! The mochi are made fresh daily and are only 1.25-1.50 a piece. I tried the kinako mochi which is mochi filled with red bean paste and topped with roasted soybean flour. It was large and soft; totally delicious! They are closed on Sunday and every 1st and 3rd Monday and their daily hours aren't too long, but try and stop by if you can!
author: Charlotte I.

description:
Small shop, not the most convenient hours but some of the BEST mochi (on par with this place on the Big Island) I have ever had. Everything is good and top-notch! Get there early before they sell out early. The man and woman behind the counter were so nice!

$1.20 a piece.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Best mochi I've had in the states.  I love how they they use real strawberry chunks as filling!

You step into the store/diner and you'd think it's 1985.

A little over a dollar for one.  Cash Only.
author: Angelica C.

description: After returning from Japan...I was still craving more mochi. Benkyodo exceeded my expectations - the mango mochi was especially delicious! I got there early on a Saturday morning, so easy parking & full selection. Will be back soon! :)
author: Kristen S.

description: Fresh handmade mochi!!! What a delightful experience. I am so lucky my hotel is 10 steps away from this place. It's located on Buchanan and Sutter next to the Paper Tree origami store in Japantown. I ordered a dozen mochis from the counter and listened to people behind me speaking Japanese and enjoying their breakfast. These mochi are so fresh and half the price of mochi I can find in San Antonio, TX. The traditional red and white bean fillings are homemade and the strawberry/blueberry filled mochis are wonderful too. They use real berries inside the mochis. The berry ones are only available on the weekend apparently, but I just got some on a Monday morning! Get you some mochi!!!
author: Mina B.

description:
Everytime I step into this tiny shop I'm 4yrs old again, and I look around trying to find my tiny Japanese grandma. Nana loved coming here, I think because it reminded her of her childhood in Yokohama. She would always let me choose the last two mochi to complete the dozen she was buying. Unfortunately I'm now 35, and my Nana passed away a decade ago.

I treasure those past visits, following my grandparents and parents in the door and looking to my right to examine the old regulars at the lunch counter before turning my attention to the display case on the left filled with so many varieties of fresh manju and mochi. I could also count on my dad to buy me a box of JFC Botan Rice Candy which was always neat because you can eat the wrapper.

I continue to come here, with my wife and my two little girls, for the mochi, and for Nana.
author: Chris J.

description:
The mochi has great elasticity which means it was freshly prepared that morning. The range between $1 and $2. Not bad for the quality. 

Wish they made enough of the strawberry mochi's to last longer in the day.
author: Liz N.

description:
Came here several times, sometimes it was closed (family owned), but I always got the fruity mochis whenever they had them. Also tried the fried mochi (dough-mochi) and red bean ones, but the fruity mochis really stood out. They are soft and chewy like all other flavors here, but with chunks of berries and mashed beans in the filling - haven't got better mochi than these.

Cash only! About $1.4 each these days.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
I saw a write up about this place on Eater SF and I was expecting some fancy sweet shop.  For the life of me I couldn't picture it despite having lived in the neighborhood for the last 5 years.  When I arrived I thought, holy mackerel! I've walked past this place a hundred times and would never have thunk about its history!

So in I go, there were some Japanese ladies enjoying tea and a sandwich and I look over to my left and there they were...mochi porn.  Maybe I have an oral fixation but there have been times I've been on a mochi bender, I just need that soft, chewy, baby's bottom texture and sweet filling.  Please don't get me wrong, I don't get off on baby's bottoms but...

I got three pieces - more than I should be having - the blueberry one, the Age (fried doughnut filled with red bean paste, and the classic yomogi  - which is mugwort filled with red bean paste).  I sat outside and thought, OK I'll just take a bite out of each and discard them, so I can say that I've tasted them.

Oh yeah! Mochi monster nom-nom-nom! They were inhaled within minutes.  The blueberry, oh the blueberry! OMG! So fantastic good.  And none of them were too sweet either.  I've had mochi from Minamoto Kitchoan and although it's a higher end experience, I've found their mochis very sweet.

I wanted to run back and tell the sweet lady behind the counter how wonderful the treats were but a line had begun to form and I thought, she knows...she knows.

P/S no baby's bottoms were harmed in the course of this review...
author: Favoloso M.

description: Yum I love the blueberry mochi! It was super soft and sweet! I got four pieces of mochi for $5. I think that's a fair price because they were big and tasted fresh. The flavors of the other mochi were great as well, but I'll definitely come back for the blueberry one!
author: Grace Z.

description: Love this place so much, just tricky sometimes to time a trip over to Japan Town early enough in the day to get it when it's fresh! Love the ones filled with red bean paste or the ones wrapped in a thin pancake. Always a delicious treat, make sure to buy a box or you'll be kicking yourself later but remember they don't keep for very long.
author: Ally B.

description:
Stopped in to get some freshly made mochi to bring to the fam for Christmas. Obviously it was a hit with blueberry being one of the faves. 

NOTE: cash only.
author: Selena L.

description:
This had been sitting in my list to try, but it was definitely impossible for me to come M-F while I worked the exact hours this place opened. So as soon as I had time off, I knew I had to visit.

The shop is a lot smaller than I expected, sharing a space with an American-style grill on the opposite side. There was only 1 glass display of mochi and the rest were Asian snacks. I am not a fan of red bean, but love fruity stuff so my only option was the Blueberry Mochi. WOW. It definitely met my expectations. The melt-in-your-mouth, fresh blueberry treat is something I will always remember.
author: Sandy T.

description:
I will only get Japanese sweets from Benkyodo. I will not go anywhere else in the bay area and am super loyal because their mochi is the BEST in the city. They are the OG Japanese sweets confectioner and their mochi is always spot on fresh and delicious.
  
     Also Benkyodo is the only place I tried outside of Japan that makes the consistency of their mochi right. Its always nice and chewy, never too chewy, never too hard, and never too soft. There is texture in each and every bite. Also, the quality is always consistent because I've been coming here since high school and I have never been disappointed. Not only that but I used to work across the street and would come here at least 2-3x a week LOLLL so that's saying a lot. 

   So, I came here again yesterday with a friend because I wanted to show her all my favorite food spots in the city. I took her to Japantown and took her to Benkyodo to let her try the mochi. I got 2 blueberry mochis and 1 kinako (soybean powder). Of course, their blueberry was spot on with real blueberries in the mochi. Also they have a thin layer of sweet white bean paste in the middle. It worked well together and even though both blueberries and the paste was sweet, it didn't make the mochi overly sweet overall. My friend loved it. 

   Then we shared the kinako and it was super good as usual, they had red bean paste in the middle and the soybean powder on top was really fragrant and tasted roasted. I love their kinako and its honestly my favorite selection in benkyodo. 

Next time you're here, stop by and try their HANDMADE kinako mochi. It's hands down the best in the bay! ;)
author: Janet K.

description: Love this spot in Japantown! Great mom and pops spot with a diner too. The mochi here is made fresh daily and runs out in afternoon sometimes so best to go early. The mochi here is so soft and not super sweet but just right.
author: Rissa K.

description:
An old school diner but with a twist, they make on the premise homemade Mochi.
Many unique flavors and types that vary by the day. Be prepared for something new.
Worth a visit to try something sweet.
author: David H.

description:
I came here in search of the blueberry mochi, but they were sold out by the time I got there. If you're coming later in the day, I would recommend calling ahead of time and double checking to see if they still have them available. I had the Habutai instead. The mochi was good, but the red bean paste was a little too sweet for my taste. 

Next time I come I'll definitely have to try the blueberry mochi! Also keep in mind that this place is cash only.
author: Janice J.

description:
If you are looking for Traditional homemade Mochi, you've come to the right place. Mochi texture is very important and they do it perfectly. 
They have their staple flavors, Kinako, Yomogi, etc. but their seasonal flavors are the best. This week they had blueberry which was delicious. Each Mochi has a great filling to Mochi ratio! 

We tried the three mentioned flavors above. First was the Kinako, green tea Mochi with red bean paste and peanut powder on top. The filling was a creamy, smooth texture and there was a good amount of peanut topping. Next was the Yomogi, green tea Mochi with whole red bean. With having whole beans inside the bean paste filling, there was a nice play of textures. Last was the blueberry. Sooo amazing. The blueberry flavors really came through! 

Their next seasonal flavor is strawberry and on Fridays and Saturdays they do mango. It's too bad I live in Los Angeles.... I so wish to be there!

They also sell other Japanese snacks imported from Japan. And there is also a long counter where they sell hot foods, the menu includes hot dogs and sandwiches. I haven't tried their hot food but my mom tells me it's pretty tasty. That will have to be proven on my next trip here. Which will have to happen sooner than later!
author: Preston M.

description: Loved the strawberry, blueberry & peanut butter mochi so delicious and fresh!!! Call ahead of time to put your order in as most times its sold Out.
author: Keko A.

description: Absolutely legendary mochi. Melt-in-your-mouth soft and the fillings are always en pointe.  Definitely come earlier in the day if you want to try all of their offerings as it doesn't seem like they make more during the day.
author: Dennis C.

description: Drove here from the airport for over an hour and found out this plaCe was out of mochis! I'm very upset. Not professional at all with no explanation
author: Ludi V.

description: One of the only traditional mochi shop in San Francisco. Get there early to buy them or they are out.
author: Jong Han P.

description:
The fresh strawberry manju is so yummy!

Having made one of or even created the first fortune cookie, this establishment has a great history.  They are known for their fresh fruit manju and being a manju/mochi/dango lover, I had to try one of these.

I was lucky enough to have one offered to me! It was larger than a typical manju which made me happy because that meant that the strawberries were big.  I took my first bite and I had to take a picture of it to share with the Yelp world.  

It was a great combination with the strawberry surrounded by pink lima bean and encased in soft rice.  These strawberry manju definitely live up to all the hype and you should definitely try them!
author: Michelle D.

description:
Amazing fresh mochi! Benkyodo is a small bakery with lots of goodies, but the thing to get here is the fresh mochi. Come early in the day to get the best flavors! Cash only. 

My boyfriend and I tried several different mochis here, but my favorites are the ones with real fruit. The blueberry and mango ones were SO good - nice chewy texture and fresh fruit in the middle, and not too sweet.

The infamous fried mochi is also good, but tasted more like a donut with powdered sugar to me. 

This place has ruined all packaged mochis for me now. Can't wait to come back and try more flavors!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Been here once many many years ago and I'm finally writing a review for this place.
This place is pretty much the only place you should go for fresh Japanese mochi in SF. If the only mochi you've ever had are the ones in the freezer section of Safeway and Trader Joes... Boy, you're in for a treat! The only thing is they have very limited business hours and I've been disappointed once too many times.
author: Sally Z.

description: I have been an ice cream mochi fan for a while now and had to try an authentic mochi while in Japantown. Benkyodo had all the positive cult like reputation on Yelp and the simple/nondescript location makes it seem even  more authentic (it looks like the Japanese mochi version of a milkshake/bakery diner if that makes sense). First of all, the service was perfect, they described the popular mochis, the mochis liked by "old" people, and the more acquired taste mochis. I thought there'd be a wider selection, but we went with the three most popular choices (Blueberry, Pink Habutai, and Green Tea). Out of the three, I liked the more traditional Pink Habutai with the white lima bean filling but overall I wasn't that overwhelmingly impressed as most other Yelpers are about these mochis. I'm happy I stopped by because it does seem truly authentic and prices aren't bad at all ($1.75 each and cash only!), but maybe I'm just used to ice cream mochis or maybe it's just not for me, I prefer the load my dessert calories with other dessert/treat selections in the bay area.
author: Jesus Z.

description:
I've passed by this place so many times (for years, like decades!) and had zero idea that delicate house-made mochi's were sold here.  I always thought it was just an old fashion coffee house for locals to hang out at, which it is!  But on the other side of this diner is a display of tender mochi's waiting to be eaten!  And the only reason why I knew was because of a foodie I follow on Instagram (Thanks for the photo posts, Oshimoments!).

I arrived late in the day and there were only 2 flavors left.  So, I bought 2 of each.  One was a red bean paste and the other was an white almond paste.  Oh my, oh my!  The mochi's were like eating a piece of heavenly cloud!  It was light, airy, and delicate to my palate and had a touch of sweetness that made these mochi's perfect.  So soft, so tender and completely addictive.  I can't believe I've been missing out for so many years!  But now that I know of them, you bet your panties I'll be back for more!  EVEN if it's the last 2 flavors they carry, as those were completely delicious. 

Mochi mochi mochi!

Get into my belly!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Imagine my surprise when a Yelp friend told me fresh mochi could be found in Japantown. 

I make my own mochi with fresh fruits or home made red bean paste especially for Mother's Day gifts and Children's Day. 

Now I learn I could buy the same thing and skip the work?

I say yes! I'm a mom. I'd love a box of fresh mochi for Mother's Day! Yes!!!

The modest shop is across the street from the Japantown "mall" so don't do what I did and spend a day and a lot of money walking around there looking for it. 

Back on track. They brilliantly use sweet rice flour to offer 3 varieties: traditional mochi, steamed, and fried. They are the size of golfballs. I was in heaven! It took me four bites just to finish one. 

My daughters devoured the fresh blueberry ones. I liked the steamed one with the wonderful texture of whole beans nestled inside the paste. The green one was ...green. 

The fried one, covered in sugar, filled with red bean?

Mommy likes! 

I should have gotten a dozen ::cries:: 

This business is cash only. Why should mom and pop shops pay money to accept a credit card? They shouldn't - and I support that. 

To my surprise when it was time to pay I realized I gave the cash I had in my wallet  to my daughter earlier that morning and didn't have any.

The nice lady ringing me up took a check. So kind. 

It's love!
author: Jennifer C P.

description: Came here on a Saturday after browsing Japantown. Short line, selection of 6-8 mochis. Got a few, fresh & soft, decided to order 15 more for the flight home.
author: Jen J.

description:
These were so delicious and kept surprising well in the plane; I picked some up on the last day of my visit back home to California and ate them on my redeye flight back/the morning after. I probably wouldn't recommend not keeping these refrigerated, but hey I'm still alive to write the review right? 
The blueberry mochi was my favorite, but I was also surprised that I also found the white bean filling enjoyable too (I thought I wouldn't like it but I wanted to try variety). Cash only but so worth it. 
I can't wait to return and try the strawberry one!
author: Jiyea C.

description:
Amazing is an understatement to describe this place. Benkyodo made me a believer of mochi. A lot has been said of the freshness and texture (rightly so), less of the ratio of flour to filling and balance of flavor. Whichever way you look at it, Benkyodo does it well. My guests, who I served these to as an alternate to a birthday cake or cupcakes, strongly agree! Icing on the cake, the owners made it so easy to preorder and were extremely friendly and kind when I picked it up the next day. 4 of the 5 flavors below (unfortunately, I forgot the 5th):

* Kinako: mochi w/ red been paste sprinkled w/ soybean powder
* Mango: mochi w/ mango filling
* Pink habutai: pink mochi w/ lima bean paste
* Yomogi: mugwort mochi w/ whole red bean

Repeatability: Absolutely. I'm returning during strawberry season to line up for their strawberry mochi.
author: Jay C.

description:
Biting into a plush piece of mochi from Benkyodo is akin to: the thrill of first love, the sunshine after a frigid winter, and the kisses of an eager puppy dog. In short, the stuff of dreams. 

Benkyodo is sure to delight any fan of mochi. Also, please don't be caught without cash, or you'll be without your mochi :(
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Benkyodo Company has been opened since the establishment of J-town in 1906, which means this place is 109 years old!! Please note that the shop accept cash only, and go early for the best selection as most of the goodies are usually gone by 2PM. 

Initially I thought I entered the wrong bakery lol, because there was a small diner that sell fries & hot dog on the other half of the shop. The candies selection were quite overwhelming for me, especially when I don't really eat candy.... And I'm pretty sure you can find most of these in T&T back in Toronto. 

So the mochi seems to be the best seller here as they are freshly made in house daily. If I remember correctly the mochi were around $1-2/each and they were being sold in boxes as well. I really wanted the strawberry mochi as it had actual strawberries inside, but it was already sold out by the time I arrived, so I settled for the mung bean mochi. The mochi tasted fresh and both the skin and filling of mochi were soft, smooth and not overly chewy. It was not too sweet either and the mung bean flavor really came through, just lovely! 

I also got a blueberry pastry but  I didn't enjoy it as there was more dough than fillings, and I hated how mushy the fillings were. In general I prefer to have some real "bites" for the filling, rather than just a spread of a sweet paste.
author: Anh T.

description: We were in the area and stopped to pick up some mochi. They had blueberry mochi today, one of my favorites. They seem to alternate the Blueberry with strawberry mochi.
author: Doris M.

description: We stopped in just after opening. All of the mochi flavors were not ready yet. What we did get was good quality and delicious. It also held up for the plane ride home and stayed fresh for the rest of my family to try. The strawberry is amazing.
author: Emily P.

description: The mochi was amazing, traditional, and savory. This is definitely not a tourist place. There were many locals that walked in and chatted with the employees. I was the only tourist there and the employees paid me little attention. However, the strawberry mochi is something you definitely need to try. And the mochi flavors change depending on the day.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I don't think I need to add to the 4.5 stars and 600+ reviews, cause that should say it all.

This place is just the best hidden treasure in the heart of Japantown.

What they're known for: FRESHLY MADE MOCHI, yes it's made fresh daily.

My favorite: the strawberry mochi, they use fresh strawberries!!!! However, it's seasonal.

What's so special about them: not only do they make it fresh, but the texture of the mochi is just perfect. It's soft and chewy. You can actually stretch the mochi out like cheese. It's honestly the BEST mochi I've ever had.

I've also tried their red bean (Habutai), white lima bean (pink habutai), blueberry (also seasonal), and baked apple manju. All were delicious.

You can buy them individually for about $1.15 each a little bit more for the fresh fruit ones, I think they were around $1.35. Or you can buy them by the box (yes you can buy dozens!) They are cash only (or check).

This place is family owned and been in the business for multiple generations. Their quality of mochi is just incomparable to any other. I highly recommend everyone to try this place at least once. I recommend going earlier in the day, they do run out of mochi :O
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Really soft mochi. Very sweet
Super nice owner

Tried the blueberry and was happy there were actual blueberries in it

Also got the nut dusted green tea red bean one. Preferred the overall flavor of that one between the two

Would want to try the strawberries one if I return
author: wolfie g.

description: Love the Strawberry Mochi!! Too bad they only have this on the weekend! All mochis that I have tried so far was delicious. Impeccable chewiness and not over-bearly sweet. Best part moist and perfect mid-day snack!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Their strawberry manju is the best manju I've had.
author: Matt L.

description:
Definitely a hole-in-the-wall type of place. There is an array of standard food options (hotdogs, sandwiches, etc) which I did not try. These items did not look special, or worth purchasing. 
However, there is a decent amount of very authentic Japanese snacks. I purchased a whole red bean mochi, and a standard red bean mochi ball. These were absolutely fantastic. The mochi itself was soft and gooey, and the bean paste inside melted in your mouth. Each mochi was $1.25.
Not a great place to sit and hang out, but there is a cute courtyard outside that provides the perfect eating place.
author: Mikowai A.

description:
Coming from Hawaii, I have fairly high expectations for mochi. Benkyodo delivers better than any other I have had in SF so far.

Located in Japantown, this small shop has around 10 types of mochi. This includes a number of red bean types as well as peanut butter, baked lima bean, an interesting cinnamon flavor and their most popular item, strawberry mochi.

If you're only going to get one, get the strawberry. It is an actual strawberry inside, coated with strawberry cream filling and a layer of mochi on the outside to hold it all together with just a touch of powdered sugar. The flavor is delicate and sweet and the texture comes together nicely with the solid fruit, creamy filling and chewy mochi. 

I will definitely be coming back here for more in the future.
author: Mark O.

description:
They have the best wagashi (Japanese confectionary) that I have come across in San Francisco. I got 4 daifukus, one pancake wrap with mochi, and one mushi manju. 

The 4 daifukus I got were:
- Regular daifuku with koshi-an (smooth azuki bean paste)
- Pink daifuku with shiro-an (smooth lima bean paste)
- Green daifuku with koshi-an doused in kinako (roasted soybean flour that tastes similar to peanut butter)
- Yomogi (Japanese mugwort) daifuku with tsubu-an (chunky azuki bean paste)

Out of the 4 daifukus, I would say my favorites were the pink daifuku and the green daifuku. The lima bean paste in the pink daifuku was sweet and delicate. The green daifuku was doused just the right amount in kinako, which is always a win in my book. The regular daifuku was also delicious. What fell short for me was the yomogi daifuku. I wish the yomogi flavor shined through a little bit more! I'm wondering if the plant is hard to get here. However, all of them had a great soft and chewy texture that you can't get enough of.

Personally, I would not get the pancake wrap and mushi manju. The pancake wrap was delicious but I wish there was tsubu-an in it to add texture, and amp up the flavor a little bit more. The koshi-an inside the mushi manju was delicious but the manju itself was a little crumbly in texture. The perfect manju would have been steamed longer and therefore softer. So i'm taking off a star for both of those.

Service was amazing. The lady in the front told me that I should come back again and try the strawberry one and to call ahead and ask if they have any left before I come. I also loved they tie a little bow in your to-go container. Very Japanese of them :)

Come here for the daifukus (that's what they are called, not mochi. Mochi is just the rice cake). I personally think that's what they do here best out of all the wagashi they sell. Also, CASH ONLY!
author: Hana K.

description: I came here with a friend after she told me about the strawberry mochi and I have no regrets! It was the perfect amount of sweetness in a soft chewy bite. I also got to try the kinako with red bean paste and that also did not disappoint. I wish I found out about this place sooner!
author: Amy L.

description:
Absolutely delicious mochi -- you MUST visit and get some of Benkyodo's homemade fresh, delicate, and so perfectly chewy mochi's when you visit the San Francisco area (:

My family and I always try to visit this store when we're visiting California. The flavors they had during our visit this time were white mochi with red bean paste, pink habutai (white mochi with white bean paste), blueberry, and strawberry mochi. My favorite was strawberry because I'm a sucker for anything strawberry flavored; it had the perfect balance of sweetness and chewy/soft consistency, and I love the real strawberries you find on the inside of the mochi. My parents were bigger fans of the red bean and white bean paste mochi though. (Taste preferences differ among ages LOL).

If you're ever visiting Japan Town in San Francisco, definitely try to visit this store early for their mochi because they may run out! I recommend that you try all the flavors~ (:
author: Jodie R.

description:
This mochi place was delicious!!
My and my friend had spent the whole day adventuring around San Francisco and made it a priority to come to this shop. The lady who I believe owns the shop was so kind and the service was wonderful. I tried the Kiru with Lima bean filling, blueberry with Lima mean filling, Korean misu powder (I believe) with mung bean skin and red bean filling, and regular Mung bean with red bean filling. All of them were very chewy and deliciously traditional tasting. You can really taste the difference between pre-made store bought mochis and homemade. My favorite was the Kiru with Lima bean, very sweet and delicious!!
author: Hannah L.

description: Benkyodo is a small, local eatery that serves fresh, homemade Japanese mochi. Most times I visit SF, I make a special trip just to buy a box of them. They are superb and perfect! They offer traditional selections such as red bean, pink mochi with smooth lima beans, green tea coated in soy bean powder with red bean filling, as well as special fruit selections with mango, strawberry, or blueberry fillings. If this is your first time, I suggest ordering the traditional flavors first (red bean or lima bean) before trying the more adventurous, fruity flavors. At $1.40 a piece for a homemade delight, you really are getting a taste of the best authentic mochi in town.
author: Joanne K.

description: The texture of freshly made mochi is awesome and must be experienced, if you haven't already. Great place to reminisce about Japan!
author: Puay K.

description:
Second time here on a Saturday morning. I bought a Strawberry Mochi and an Imo - its a pancake wrapped with a mochi cube. I cannot wait to try the Strawberry mochi - so I bit it and it was oozing with a fresh strawberry and the mochi was freshly made, and still warm. Mmmm... great confections to start off the day. The Imo was also great too and who could resist warm, freshly cooked pancake wrapped with a warm mochi in it. It was sublime and a perfect breakfast item. I thought this shop was better compared to the one in San Jose. All of their manju, daifuku, wagashi and other treats are fresh and made to order. 
Don't be fooled when you enter the shop, on the left side is where all of the wagashi and japanese confections treats are located within lacquerware boxes filled with different selections of these tiny treats. On the right side of the shop is a small diner where they sell coffees, teas, sodas, sandwiches. Great way to chat the locals too. Only on Fridays and Saturdays, they serve the Strawberry Mochi- Mochi wrapped with a strawberry cream and fresh strawberry. Imo - a pancake wrapped with mochi and some lima paste. This was great breakfast starter.
If you are in Japantown in San Francisco, you have to try out 1 of each of their wagashi and daifuku - they are freshly made every day, and come out warm when they open at 8:00 am. You can call them, if you want to reserve a specific type of wagashi, and pick it up on a later date. They are located at the Japan Hall across Buchanan Hotel and Mira Japanese Grocery Store.
author: Jade M.

description:
Still the best mochi ever.  Big, soft, plump, and filled with bean paste.

Oftentimes I barely make it here before they close, and by then there's barely any selections left.  So I either order one of each different kind they have, or however many I can with the little cash I have.  All the flavors are great, so it doesn't matter what's left.  Cash only, and that usually limits the amount I can buy.
author: Karen L.

description:
Soft, fresh, perfectly textured MOCHI?? Yes pleaseeeee!!!

My mom came here before a college reunion and picked up a box of mocha has a hostess gift. It was perfect for sharing and she bought a few extras for me. I only wanted to try the fresh strawberry one and it did not disappoint. It was actually the most perfect mochi I've ever had...which is saying a lot considering that I love mochi so much that my pup is named Mochi...

The mochi was super fresh, kept for 2 days, and the flavors were perfect. It was a huge success with my mom's college friends too. It's actually the perfect dessert to bring on a trip because you don't have to worry about cutting it or making a mess when eating it.

I will definitely have to go back and try all the other flavors!
author: Jennifer S.

description: I adore this place and its retro feel. I will say that I've had mixed experiences with the mochi, though. I don't recommend the peanut (it's stuffed with what tastes like a big glob of Skippy...) nor would I recommend the black bean pancakes (very dry). But the red bean is exquisite, just melts in your mouth. My cousin described the texture "baby flesh" and I have to agree. So soft! I will say that my absolute favorite mochi experience was in LA at Fugetsu-do in Little Tokyo--their boxes are truly amazing (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fugetsu-do-los-angeles?select=Q007cEKDjvCNgQzIRut5cw). But if you find the right mochi, Benkyodo can be just as good.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
FOOD: I've only tried their mochi and their doriyaki that are usually made fresh everyday! My friends love their mochi and even tho I'm not a mochi fan, they have a good variety of flavors ranging from mango to strawberry to blueberry. It's made fresh everyday and if you don't get there in time, all the popular flavors are sold out!!!  
ENVIRONMENT: it's a corner diner/bakery and seems to be for locals that come for breakfast. It's a small store and it has tons of snacks lined up at counter. Older store, could use some updates. 
SERVICE: The elderly couple that probably owns it is usually pretty nice and they opened the door for us when we came right at 5 when they closed but we called ahead of time to let them know. They are always really nice. Too bad it's cash only, sometimes I forget and don't have cash on me at all.
author: Vicky C.

description:
A very old time place that makes really good mochi. It's cash only, so make sure you have a few bills in your pocket.

And dont tell, but there are two kinds that I secretly love that you cant get anywhere else- the one with red bean filling that's like a cinnamon donut hole on the outside, and the chocolate one that's like a ding dong ( or is it a ho ho? You know that thing you begged your mom for at the grocery store as a kid...that one) only it's awesome.

End result: mochi purists in my family super happy and the closet classic American junk food enthusiast ( me) also happy.
author: El B.

description:
Scrumptious Mochies/Manju 

Filling was fresh, good balance of sweetness and plenty of it 
Mochi had just the right about of chew and can tell its freshly made in house

Overall Thoughts

A must place to stop by when you are in Japantown
author: Eddie W.

description:
Came to Japantown so because mochi is my favorite, and read from Yelp about this, so gave it a try. 
The location is around in the end of the street, came inside and full of local ( Japanese local ). There was a guy on the counter and saw us but he didn't bother to say anything and he left doing something for his other guest, and i turn around to him with my expression then he realized that ( i guess ) because he said something will be back to you.

For me, the mochi aren't that bomb, the texture of it was good, not too chewy, but the filling ( red bean ) was kinda too sweet. The cake with mochi inside was good, not over sweet. 

The price isn't that bad around $1 and cash only. Small place and kinda noisy when i was there
author: Claudy H.

description: The mochi at Benkyodo is next level shit. I don't even like mochi but the ones here are perfectly chewy and soft and fresh, yum. We got the hakutai (red bean) and pink hakutai (lima bean) for less than $3! And both were incredible. We came after lunch and already there was limited stock - I'd recommend coming first thing in the morning.
author: Judy S.

description:
What a great value for fresh mochi. The strawberry mochi had half of a real strawberry in it. Is it lame that I got really excited about that? The ratio of filling to mochi was just right. The person behind the counter was very nice and patient with me as I mispronounced everything. I'll be back.

Only complaint is that I wish they were open on Sundays!

Cash only - don't forget! I think it was $1.20 for a standard mochi.
author: Evelyn M.

description:
UPDATE (03/21/14): Mochi have now increased to $1.35 a piece, but they are worth every danged penny.

STOP EATING ALL MY STRAWBERRY MOCHI.

NO REALLY. I MEAN IT.

At $1.25 a piece, Benkyodo's lusciously fresh STRAWBERRY MOCHI sell out like hot cakes in Antarctica (because I imagine people who live in a really cold place would want something hot EVEN more). Call in early to reserve some over the phone. CASH ONLY and NOT OPEN SUNDAYS.

So what makes these mochi as popular as Gucci?

They are chock full of smooth white lima beans, delicately flavored with strawberry, enveloping a fresh and ripe strawberry slice (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/v3w0oeOnIGM-dI31yC9Dyw/l.jpg).

Hm, maybe they're better than Gucci.

I've also tried other items, such as their KURI (GOMA), which is manju baked with smooth white lima beans and a sesame garnish (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WxdIjxDpVP64hpVYVx6VKQ/l.jpg). Its filling is subtly sweet and is encased in a smooth shell (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eRUqYtTmHX3zi2EjFkyU_w/l.jpg).

Then there is the AGE, which is a Japanese donut with smooth red beans, sprinkled with sugar (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/CpKeYo1ETa7c7ZfylVMXOQ/l.jpg). I adored the delicious red bean filling, which went wonderfully with the fried crispy exterior (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/f-ZQToRfRMQaRa-tOm2aYg/l.jpg).

No-frills, no-guilt Japanese desserts that will have you wanting more than just one.

BUT YOU BETTER NOT WANT THE ONES I WANT.
author: Adele F.

description: This place is dedicated to Mochi and you must try it.  It's been here forever and own and run by multiple generations of the same family. I was notified that the latest generation is not taking it over and they will close it soon.  Sad.  So hurry up and get fresh good mochi while you can.
author: Darrell K.

description:
After reading so many good things about Benkyodo, I sent the roommate there to grab me some mochi and manju while I was at work. Well, he went a little overboard and actually bought one of each item they offered!

July 2013
Manju and Mochi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#4lypmHpeTDddsfUT6Jmtjw
*Mushi/Fukashi - steamed bun with smooth red bean http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#ZtHpWOTbfmQ6iN54f82A7w
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#VQWq0A2MpYWZO372NxeN0A

*Kuri (Goma) - manju baked with smooth white lima beans and sesame garnish http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#vS92HshkXgRNZrkjqJs0vQ
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#mmxaVfbQWEltAYRDCAbr-g

Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#33_Q1zXUlIXq6aSdpqmuAw

Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#qjoK64xVcNBb7ruWOI0KBA
*Kinako - mochi with smooth red beans and sprinkled with soybean flower http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#8EWEnquWcM6MFgVIkfm2eA
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#gAa4Xh0MvhnhiBOF0gO9xg
*Blueberry mochi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#-0D4F-x4cVJgCfqzkGkyzw
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#typIhLK90h2g0raktisTbA
*Red bean mochi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#VfqbvwzeY_m4dRROWJzHrA
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#9QvIgSyVr-meryMErkS4nQ
*Misc http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#M9HH-Il9g2MU6d-gSmdcdw

Anpan http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#ClA0Mw2t9NWVQyqxbpH3Zg
*Shiro http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#lY4SEWTAzRjfdOvKUG_xzQ
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#XSiABEf-NRA0fzxXt-SGag
*Koshi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#uUHsvQsPUjyatVemftahGA
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#RutwqfKhig7jTQJo53oSGw
*Tsubu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#5lqPsNDUeU8zYLZ-P0BjUQ
Inside: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco#TaNEoCbE_rDS-2NCeB1mdw

So many treats! The mochi was so good! My favorites were the pink habutai and blueberry mochi. So soft and chewy. But not overly sweet. The chofu and red bean manju were good as well. The baked outer cake like layer added a nice contrast to the creamy filling.

I wasn't a huge fan of the Anpan as it was too bready for me. I'd pass on that next time. A box of mochi and manju already makes me a happy girl!
author: Elena N.

description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9QKs1f7DN-w

@1:20 for gorgeous video shots of the mochi we had for breakfast on Saturday!

Food: 
PLENTY OF MOCHI AND LOVE THE SELECTION. 
The mochi's were all delicious and super authentic. I've been to Osaka to try mochi over there and this tasted like the real thing! 

I got a bunch of things, but the most memorable ones for me were:

Strawberry filled mochi (5/5) 
SO GOOD! Inside the soft mochi was a piece of real strawberry that was so sweet and delicious. 

Dorayaki (4.5/5)
Very authentic and tasted beautiful. Not too dry either, which is a common problem I find.

The Service: (4/5) 
Friendly lady, but not really into talking (which is completely fine). 

The wait (5/5) 
No wait when I went - around 9am on a Saturday. 

Would recommend.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This is only for their fruit mochi. 

Amazingly delicious strawberry mochi of the day. Real fruit & strawberry paste filling inside. Perfect taste, not too sweet. The texture of the mochi was soo soft, unlike the commonly found mochis that are too chewy or got too much flour... 

I could actually taste the freshness of that rice flour. 
Best mochi I've ever had. No lie. 
Will go back for sure.
author: Leilani B.

description: Cute little manju/mochi shop and diner in Jtown. I'm fairly certain my mom bought mochi here when she was working in SF and pregnant with me many years ago, so I'm somewhat partial to Benkyodo. My favorite is the Age (fried donut-like pastry filled with red bean), but their strawberry and red bean mochi are tasty too.  The peanut butter (filled with what tastes like JIF or Skippy) was too salty and heavily peanut that it overpowered the delicate texture of the mochi, so I would stick to the more traditional variations.
author: Bella L.

description: Nice, fresh mochi and manju here. I really enjoy mochi and this place makes 'em like how they have them back home in Hawaii. They have regular an, lime bean an, and I guess because it's in season, a blueberry flavored mochi with blueberry filling. I really enjoyed that one but I guess its a seasonal thing. My favorites were the blueberry, lima bean and kinako dusted mochi.
author: Kenson K.

description: By the time we went there wasnt much left. 3.5 stars for this place. The fried donut with smooth red beans was delicious. Not really a mochi to me but still good. The baked mochi with lima beans was also good and only had 1 left so we figured we would try it. But the best one was defintely the green mochi with red bean fillings. Really good texture!
author: Prima Z.

description: Was expecting mochi more like the ones in the supermarket. Tried a few kinds, the kinako mochi was ok, too soft and not much flavor. The kuri manju filled with white bean was too sweet to eat in one sitting. Also tried the yabure manju (steam bun with whole beans, only 1 left), too much red bean. There wasn't a large selection of flavors even though we went in the morning, they probably change based on the seasons. Prices are very reasonable, about $1.25 a piece for a good-sized mochi. Packs come in 6, 12 and 15, they give a discount if you buy larger quantities. The atmosphere reminds you of Mr. Miyagi, early 1980's vibe on the other side where they serve light meals and tea. Worth sitting at the counter for some tea, it will take you back in time.
author: Anonymous R.

description:
A simple and unassuming gem of a Japanese bakery.

I came here with my mom last time we visited SF to try something different and explore this little part of japan town. We're not mochi experts, but we are now officially fans. The bakery owner is great at helping you find some mochis that you will like. We loved them all, especially the blueberry and the baked ones. 

The little diner counter doesn't serve anything quite as gourmet as the bakery counter, but it's a great place to chill out and have a soda and soak in the view of all the crazy mochis and watch the pros order so you can get an idea of what you might want to snack on. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Mimi N.

description: Love this place. My favorite so far is blueberry and peanut butter. Great when paired w tea. The cashier/manager was really nice. Boxes make great gifts! Cash only.
author: Khanh N.

description:
Strawberry manju and blueberry manju!!

Small hole in the wall mochi place that hand makes their mochi's since they opened! I'm addicted.
author: Helen C.

description: Mochi heaven of various varieties. Soft and gummy as fresh mochis should be. We got our full fill of mochis from this wonderful find.
author: Andy N.

description:
Finally made it on a day when they are open! First timers want to try EVERYTHING, so ordered a bunch of mochi and did our tasting after lunch. 

All of our selections tasted very light and not super sweet like other companies tend to do. (The kind you find in Japanese supermarkets that are days old.)

The chofu was our favorite with a thin pieces of pancake and an opaque piece of mochi in the middle. It reminded me of ayu mochi, mochi wrapped with a pancake in the shape of the ayu fish, available during summer festivals. 

Next up was the peanut butter mochi. Just enough sugar, creamy peanut butter with some crushed peanuts. So light we could have eaten the whole box!

The blueberry one contained whole blueberries, a nice touch. The donut was filled with red beans, soft on the inside, crunchy on the outside. 

It all was nicely wrapped up in a white box tied with a white ribbon for easy carrying. Makes a nice gift, that is if you can keep the box closed. 

I have a new appreciation for fresh mochi. I can't wait til summer when maybe they'll have strawberry mochi???

5/15/16 OK the strawberry mochi is out and much in demand! I learned something new:  if you don't eat these soon after you get them, you can freeze them then thaw them on demand. Amazingly they come out of the freezer well and not gooey. Oh yum! And the kinako taste freshly roasted and oh so good. A must try!
author: Carlyn C.

description: A mochi lover's dream! Great little neighborhood spot.
author: Daniella O.

description: So many to choose from. I got suckered into all the colors and flavors that I ordered a whole dozen for myself. Needless to say, I couldn't finish them since they don't really last more than a couple days (the mochi stiffens and loses it's chewy texture). Cash only so only get what you can eat.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Maybe I'm not the right one to talk bc this was my first authentic encounter with mochi, but I just really didn't like it. I was expecting a smooth and light texture (I've only ever had ice cream mochi and the kind you put on froyo) and these were dense and gritty. The strawberry tasted fresh and yummy, but the outside mochi had zero flavor. They only had like 6 flavors also. The place has bizarre hours. Idk just didn't live up to expectations, but again, I admit I am not well versed in the world of mochi
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
I love the mochi from Benkyodo - everything is so fresh and delicious!

Mochi are some of my favorite Japanese sweets and thank goodness for Benkyodo as now we can enjoy some of the best mochi around without flying to Japan.  They are truly exceptional - ultra soft, chewy and just melt-in-your-mouth.  Also, since they are made daily, everything tastes very fresh.

They are also reasonably priced, with each mochi costing around $1.15 - $1.35.  

Since I can never just eat one, I packed home over a dozen mochi:

* Kinako: green mochi with red bean filling

* Pink habutai: pink mochi with white beans inside.

* Strawberry manju (seasonal): it has fresh strawberries inside and fresh cream.

* Habutai: white mochi with red azuki beans

* Peanut butter mochi: pink mochi with peanut butter fillings - my only savory pick of the lot.

My favorite is their strawberry manju followed by the kinako.  The peanut butter mochi tastes very interesting, though; I would've never thought that peanut butter goes well with glutinous mochi, but I actually really like it.

Tips:
* Mochi is best enjoyed fresh on the same day it's made, but once cooled to room temperature, it is good for up to 3 days except for the strawberry manju.
* cash only :)
author: Veronica C.

description:
I actually went into this store base on a guess. A lady next to me was eating the blueberry Mochi and saying how good the blueberry is. I wanted to try one not really knowing what she was eating hahaha. I saw a corner store that look like it was selling baked goods so I went inside and found the Mochi. 

I ordered the blueberry Mochi. I got the last one on the tray :) The blueberry Mochi is very good!!! So tasty!!! I usually don't like Mochi but this one was so soft and just chewy enough and so tasty. It was so good that it entice me to go back to the car to get more money, since they only accept cash, to go get another Mochi even though I was kind of full from my lunch. I gotta  one with red bean paste inside it. The store owner actually recognize me haha she was like  I guess the blueberry one was good. I just nodded my head haha I like the blueberry one the best. :)
author: Jenny L.

description: My professor recommended this place to try mochi. It's nice to actually go and purchase something from a place that's older than you and is part of San Francisco's Japantown history. Before entering, I imagined a huge mochi factory place, but it's a split area of a mochi/sweet area and a coffee shop. The place is very tight, so you'll be squeezing into people. Make sure to also know what you're getting because the sales ladies tend to be brash, so don't get shocked if they tell you to move to the side if you haven't made up your mind. Oh, make sure to bring cash. They're cheap and so delicious! The mango flavored mochi is by far my favorite.
author: Monica Colleen D.

description:
In existence since 1906, Benkyodo is one of the original businesses in Japantown.  The shop has been at its current location since 1959 and run by the family's third generation bringing the mochis and manjus to its customers. 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/benkyodo-co-san-francisco?select=By2aesmbW0Pq8Ib6UgwOSg#By2aesmbW0Pq8Ib6UgwOSg)

On the occasions that we are in Japantown, it tends to be in the afternoon.  If we have the urge to stop by Benkyodo for its famous mochis, they are sold out.  But on a recent Saturday afternoon, we stopped by and lo and behold they had three of their 15 to 16 varieties available.  Being our first time to indulge in a Benkyodo mochi, we asked which of the three the worker recommended.  He suggested we try to Yomogi, a green mocha with whole red bean.  Out the door and we dug right into it. The mocha was so soft with the right chewy texture.  The red bean filling consisted of a paste with whole red beans.  Very tasty!  So good that that I forgot to take my pic.

One down and 15 to go.  Will definitely have to make an effort to get there earlier in the day to try the other delicious delights.
author: Al L.

description:
Traditional mochi done right. I like how much filling they give you for each mochi, and the simple packaging the staff take time to wrap your box in. My favorite is the chofu (no filling, mochi wrapped in a pancake) because I'm a sucker for anything wrapped in a pancake. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Christine L.

description:
I was hoping to try one of their fruit flavor mochi that has real fruit in the middle, but sadly there were all gone by the time I got there.

Ended up bringing a selection of their other mochi home. Mochi is fresh which makes all the difference. My favorite was the sakura mochi because it wasn't too sweet. It's filled with red bean, and has pink rice on the outside wrapped with a sakura leaf. 

TIP - Get here early to score one of their fruit mochi.....Maybe you can get your hands on their strawberry mochi and tell me how delicious it is,  I missed out.
author: Nicole S.

description:
the mochi was soft and chewy... the fillings were perfectly sweet.  We ordered a variety of mochis, but the favorite was the Peanut Butter ones...although, none of them disappointed.   Also try the cinnamon with sugar mochi that resembles a donut hole (LOL).

Cash only.
author: Margaret W.

description: In the heart of Japantown, I'm sure there are plenty of mochi places to try.  We stopped by mid-afternoon.  When we got in line there were 2 mango mochis left!  My heart sank thinking the people in front of us would order the last 2.  But, just as it was our turn to order, they brought out a full tray.  We tried the white mochi with red bean paste and mango mochi.  The flavors are seasonal (I'll have to come back for strawberries another season).  I love mochi, and the texture of this mochi is perfect.  Not too firm and not too sticky.  I also hate when there is so much powder on the mochi that you take a bite and a cough from all of the powder.  The mochi here is probably quintessential mochi.  I don't love red bean but I also don't hate it, and the red bean here is actually pretty sweet.  The mango ones were good too, but I actually prefer the red bean. I'm glad we picked this place for mochi.  I will definitely come back for more.
author: Anjelica C.

description:
Love that this is a mom & pop place. :)

The mochi is SO big & delicious. The blueberry & strawberry are definitely my favorites! I was pleasantly surprised to see real blueberries & strawberries when I bit in! The mochi is bigger than a normal one I'd buy or had tried and it's very soft. 

Usually, I find that mochi is too hard and can be unpleasant to eat, but this place makes it just right. I came back asap to try different flavors.
author: Mel T.

description:
Yay finally! This has been in my bookmarks for so long, im so happy i got to finally try it!

It's a tiny store, but this review is mainly for the mochi :). Got the apple manju and the strawberry manju. (both at $1.25 i think) 

Omg! They tasted so nice! The strawberry one had a strawberry inside of it and it was so yummy. The apple one had little apple bits in it. So yummy and soft, and it also had that chewy texture to it. MMM~

It's only cash, but the prices are decent since the size of the mochi is pretty big. Definitely happy with this place :).
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Not bad but not amazing. 
Maybe I'm just not a fan of mochi unless its mochi ice cream. 
The glutinous rice shell is super soft and the inside isn't overly sweet. 
The blueberry was ok.
The pink mochi with lima bean was better. 
The red bean was nothing special. 
4 mochis for under $5

I hear the thing to get is the strawberry one. But when I went, they didn't have it. Maybe next time.
author: Heejin L.

description:
I stopped in because my friend used to live in SF and wanted me to bring back the mochi. Thank goodness she did! I love this place!!

The place is tiny and the mochi looks almost too cute to eat. I got her a dozen and decided to get myself a dozen. When you get a dozen, they put it into a lovely box and wrap it nicely. LOVE that. 

This is, by far, the freshest, softest mochi I've ever had. They're also bigger than other mochi I've had - I'm from the east coast, BTW. I prefer the white bean filling, but the red bean filling is fantastic as well. I ate over 6 of my dozen. I think my hubs was worried he wouldn't get any, so he started eating them quickly. I'm sad that the fruit fillings weren't available :( 

So, I bought the mochi on Saturday and my friend didn't get back to work til Tuesday. I was worried the mochi wouldn't be yummy then, but she assured me it was fantastic. If I had known, I wouldn't bought myself ANOTHER dozen.
author: Marivic L.

description: Awesome delectables !!! Fairly priced great selection....HOWEVER GET THERE EARLY OR ELSE...you won't be able to have any
author: Scott U.

description:
I'm japanese. I've been to japan and had good mochi and this passes the test!! 

First, there's a lot of variety. For those that don't like traditional mochi, I recommend the blueberry mochi or apple manju. For the bean lovers, you know the standard. 

Don't know what else to say. Soft mochi with yummy fillings at a decent price. 

Still have to come back and try the ichigo. 

They are closed on Sundays. 

A must try!!
author: Noji N.

description:
Still the best mochi around. Their fresh blueberry mochi is so soft and perfect. Each bite is full of blueberry bliss and made fresh.

For the real thing - come here.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Superb!
After living in Japan for a very long time, I can say this is one of the finest places for O-Manju! Keep up the hard work! Gambatte-kudasai!!
author: Pradeep C.

description:
Back in NJ, I don't really know of any places that sell Mochi that is made in-house. That being said, when I found out there was a Mochi bakery right near my hotel (Coventry Inn), I couldn't resist visiting JapanTown for a quick visit. The bakery was clean and plenty of people were coming in and out. You can even stay there and hang out while enjoying whatever you purchase! There's plenty of sitting space.

I got the four common Mochi they sell, and they were all delicious and pretty heavy in my opinion. The paste in two was a bit dry but it wasn't a big deal- I was just excited for Mochi in general! For four, it was about $5.50 which I had no complaints about because I thought it'd total up to more. 

The only thing I wish was different was that I wish they had more flavors!!! I was so enthusiastic about trying different flavors but the only unique one they had was peanut butter. I think they rotate the unique flavor based on the week or something. It'd be nice if they had a couple of options though.
author: Megha S.

description: Cash only mochi. Not the ice cream kind, these are room temp and filled with traditional bean pastes as well as some different options like blueberry and peanut butter. Good place to pop in if you have an extra 20 min before your movie at the Kabuki.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I finally got the chance to check out Benkyodo Co and the hype is real. Seriously, the mochi is killer! I tried both the blueberry and red bean paste mochi. The red bean is my favorite and the blueberry reminds me of blueberry pie.

Benkyodo Co mochi is much better than anything you will find in the supermarket. These guys are pros, and have been hand-pounding mochi since 1906. Fast forward 100+ years and they are still going strong! 

I look forward to returning and trying more tasty treats :)
author: Rachel S.

description:
As I was walking around the neighborhood looking for an afternoon snack, I saw benkyodo in the corner with people in the window just smiling and stuffing their face with this powdery dough. So I walked in and saw this amazing assortment of mochi and I was impressed.

Pros:

Mochi: The mochi is fresh inside and out. The inside filling is bursting full of flavor. 

Service: the lady that works here is super kind and she even wrapped up a nice box for me take home.

Prices: All the items in the store are inexpensive, makes for a cheap and quick snack break.

Cons:

Cash only: Luckily this place is cheap so I was able to grab a bunch of items back home with me with the limited amount of cash I had on.
author: Lucy D.

description:
Came here for the mochi! They are super delicious and big for their cheap price. My bf and I came 3 minutes before they closed down and they were super friendly! 

Definitely mom & pop food place and it's super cute. Will be coming back for more mochi =]
author: Corie L.

description:
After tasting various mochi in the city, nothing compares to the freshness and high quality mochi that Benkyodo produces. This mochi matches up with another one of my facorite mochi places in Hawaii, Fujiya. Regardless, I love how this mochi place is so close to home and a bus ride away.

I have come here on dozens of occassions and I have tried most of their mochi. If you a fruit person, the strawberry mochi is definitely the bomb. The mochi is soft and chewy and the small strawberry adds the right amount of texture and a burst of sweetness. Try this place on a trip to Japantown, you won't regret it!
author: Jessica E.

description:
CASH ONLY!  Apple Manju is new to me, I got 2 of those, 6 Strawberry mochi, & 2 white bean manju.

When the guy was boxing it up he said the apple manju was still warm!  What?  well, then I have to have 1 more to eat it now!  It was really good!  Not too sweet, like a warm apple pie with real apple chunks, not the cheap pie crap.

Strawberry mochi - soft rice pounded to softness with a tiny slice of strawberry in it.  It's good.

Still haven't tried the bean manju yet, will be good though I just know it.

CASH ONLY!
author: Ann L.

description:
A truly special San Francisco place. 

I recently was browsing a bookstore and came across a book about the history of San Francisco's Japan town.  In that book, there was an image of Benkyodo from the 1910's!  It truly felt like I went back into history and it still sits in the same corner store.  I'd definitely recommend the strawberry mochi.  These are great gifts to give since they're so special.  A reminder that they're closed on Sundays and that they do run out of flavors sometimes!
author: Candace C.

description: Came here for mochi while my husband and I were at the Cherry Blossom Festival. Kept hearing good things about this place, so I decided we should just go. Was a little bummed that we didn't arrive early enough for any of the fruit mochi, but the ones I chose were still better than I expected. We like it so much we wanted to go the next day, but found they were closed on Sunday. But best mochi around here, not too sweet like it can get sometimes, and such great consistency! It wasn't too dense or chewy. It was just right. Highly recommended!
author: MaryJane C.

description:
Was surprised that the store is also a diner, there were a couple bemused looking patrons eyeing me blearily as I walked in to peruse the mochi counter. I ended up getting one box (last one of the day at 12:00 pm!) of the peanut butter mochi, and an assortment of the pink habutai (pink mochi with white lima beans), blueberry, yomogi (green with whole red beans) and kinako (green sprinkled with soybean flour and red bean filling). 

The mochi themselves? So delicious and soft! The blueberry one really made me burst into a smile - it was sweet an unexpected, just like this shop. I wish I had tried some of the other flavors but I felt a little awkward standing there just eyeing the counter... perhaps if there were a little brochure or something to describe the fillings? Or if the staff could explain it as well? That'd definitely bump it to 5 stars, for me.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Sometimes I cry to myself thinking that this place is halfway across the country, and that it will be a very long time before I can have these lovely snowballs of fresh mochi again.

I'm only slightly exaggerating here. I've only been able to eat East Coast supermarket mochi. This is honestly better than anything else I've had. It's fresh! And I didn't realize how much freshness mattered to mochi! It seriously was like eating something with the texture of snow. It's also insanely affordable, at less than $2 a bite. I'm sending everyone I have ever known to this place; that's how good it is.
author: Roger F.

description:
The last few times I've been to Japantown, it was either a Sunday (when the shop is closed) or completely forgotten to go there (since it's outside of the plaza at the very edge of what's still considered Japantown, by all the ramen restaurants adjacent to Post St).   My colleague had raved about this little shop for years.  I guess it was finally meant to be.

The store sells a vast variety of imported snacks AND...mochi and manju.  It's your traditional non-ice cream mochi.  I used to love that stuff, but it looks like my palette is evolving once again.  It isn't until you have great manju that can shift your preference like that.  Sadly, manju selection is a lot slimmer...2-3 different types.  I love the baked shell/crust that offers a great balance in texture with the bean filling.  When you eat mochi, everything is mushy inside your mouth.  With manju, you can definitely where the thin crust ends and the generous filling begins.  UH, I could kick myself for not getting more manju as now I'm officially obsessed.  The manju here is legit!  The manjus from my past have always been too thick with the crust....meh.

As a gift box, I chose 10 different confections (combo of mochi and manju) for over $11 (about $11.50).  The entire thing is wrapped expertly and ribbon tied properly.  I chose these fresh variety over the pre-boxed imported goods from Nippon-Ya inside the plaza.  It's made locally and FRESH!

BTW, very important to point out it's CASH ONLY!

WHY oh why are you so far from me?  SIGH...I missed over the years...
author: Melinda Y.

description:
I've been coming here for years but just realized that I never Yelped it.  This place has the best handmade mochis by far.  My fave is the fresh strawberry which are seasonal during usually the summer months closely followed by the blueberry which are usually available the other months.  Both fruit ones do need to be consumed day of purchase but trust me, it wouldn't last past it anyways.  The rest can keep up to 3 days but does harden a bit with each day.

I recommended it to a friend who ended up driving down from Sac to pick up a box for himself and another couple boxes for friends making him a hero in their eyes.  They have boxes for 10, 12, and 15 pieces and "plates" for less than 10 pieces.  It's a great gift as you'll spend about $11-$18 per box depending on what you choose and you too may end up coming out a hero.  

Side note:  Cash only (I think they also take checks)
author: Joyce Z.

description:
The two times I've patroned them, they were five minutes to closing. They usually just have the red bean ones left, but from what I've had, the other flavors certainly seem promising! The mochi texture is soft and perfect amount of gooey. I'm not terribly experienced with mochi, but from my mochi standard (Nisshodo in Hawaii) this is pretty A OK! 

Also the old school diner look is adorbz and the owners are always so nice!
author: Angela L.

description:
cash only. freshly made mochi which is a rarity in the city. they have certain ones on a certain day. their popular strawberry ones are only on Friday and Saturday. 

other popular ones are the peanut butter one and the blueberry filling ones. 

there is a little cafe with bar seating in there for food but looks like regulars eating there. I saw one customer opening a small box of cereal onto a box and pouring the milk in. 

this place is a gem! make a visit when you're in Japantown.
author: Jules L.

description:
Happened to be in the area on a weekday after a doctor's appointment and decided to try it out. They close at 5 PM, so it's been really hard to come by to try them out what with me having a career and whatnot.

They only sell the Peanut Butter Mochi in 3 packs, which at first I was bummed about because I just wanted to sample them, but they were so good I promptly regretted not picking up 2 packs. 

Also tried the Blueberry Mochi and the Kinako. Blueberry one was tasty, but I think it made the mochi texture a little off. I have to admit redbean isn't my favorite, but I wanted to try at least one. Peanut Butter Mochi is where it's at!

Reasonable prices too and cash only. Guy at the counter was super friendly and patient!
author: Christina R.

description:
1st time here... and 5-stars FOR REALS!!!! 

Before being introduced to fresh made mochi, I usually just get the prepackaged ones from Ranch 99 or wherever. But now, I can't revert back to that crap! 

GET THE STRAWBERRY MOCHI!!!! THERE'S A SLICE OF REAL STRAWBERRY IN IT!!!!
author: Stephen Y.

description: I love this place!  Their mochi is so tasty and they have seasonal flavors too!  Come early though, because they do sell out of the seasonal stuff early.
author: Angela H.

description: This is my go to whenever I am in Japantown and wanting some mochi! This place is a mom and pops cafe that also has great snacks. I come here every so often and buy their fresh mochi especially when they have strawberry or blueberry mochis. I tend to get at least 4-8 at a time because they are very inexpensive and delicious.
author: Angela S.

description:
Why are there no lines here? Have all of SF given up hope that you do not have to wait in line or pay your next paycheck to get authentic, handmade, true to form dessert? 

As I walk into this establishment, there's a sense of pride and heritage. Mochi sitting in its faded away wooden crates inside a slightly blurred glass cases. Each piece costs $1.15 and its cash only. It's cheaper than golden gate egg tarts and its made fresh. You bite into one, and you are Blown away. It taste like heaven. This is Mochi and this is what happens when a traditions are passed through 3 generations of Mochi making. Sorry, cupcakes with six months of heritage... This is something you can't buy.
author: Youna K.

description:
Benkyodo is that one place where I could pick up mochi for a party and end up eating all the mochi I picked up before the party. That's how good Benkyodo's mochi is!

Now what's so good and addicting about the mochi? It's soft, it's chewy, the texture tastes like it has been rolled for hours, it's super fresh, and best of all, they have the mochi with the fruit in them! Blueberry, strawberry, Mmm good!

FYI the fruit mochi is dependent on the seasons. 

Highly recommend preordering for the holidays or for any major gathering just so that you can make sure you get the mochi you want. Luckily I preordered for Christmas Eve because by the time I arrived for pickup in the morning, there were only 2 flavors left!

PS - Don't forget to bring cash!
PPS - It's helpful to master the art of the getaway car so that one person runs in, picks up the mochi, and then runs out to the getaway outside. Street parking around the area is difficult to find and for the spots that you do find, it's a squeeze and will challenge your skills at parallel parking.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I always try to come here when I go to japantown for their blueberry mochi and azuki (red bean) mochi. Their blueberry mochi has actual blueberries inside! The texture of the mochi is definitely soft and make sure to wipe off the excess mochi powder off your mouth. You don't want to walk around the city with a powdery mouth, do you? (:
author: Jennifer L.

description:
After a friend raved about this mochi, i had to try.  The shop is super small, mom and pop, on a corner and looks pretty old.  I only sampled a few mochi, the lima bean paste, green tea with red bean, and a green tea red bean with soybean powder.  The lima bean paste was definitely too sweet.  I really enjoyed both green tea mochi with whole red beans.  Many shops make it too sweet and don't use whole red bean, this place makes it just right!  The mochi is super fresh and delicious, soft and slightly sticky.  I prefer a chewier mochi that doesnt stick to my teeth, but this one was okay and passes.  

One mochi is really big, the best $1.20 you will ever spend!  Presentation wise, it could use a little work, some mochi are lopsided and not firmly closed off, but i didn't mind because it is super tasty and fresh.  Only wish the mochi didn't stick to my teeth as much.
author: Terence N.

description: If you love peanut butter than you have to try the peanut butter Mochi. It is amazing. At first I thought it would be overly dry, but the Mochi was moist and really balanced the crunchy peanut butter. This place is a must visit for good quality Mochi that reminds me of the stuff I got this past summer in Japan!
author: Quintin W.

description:
The best mochies/manjus I've had since Japan. You can see they make them fresh in the back and as soon as they sell out, they are completely out. It's a large bite and totally worth the money you pay. It's tender, chewy, and has the freshness that you need after walking all over Japantown. A must-go place if you're in the area. 

Tip, you can call ahead and place your order in case they run out. Also, you must try the strawberry manju. They put half a fresh strawberry in a manju. AMAZING!
author: Christina L.

description: Best mochi I've ever tasted. Love the peanut butter ones and the blueberry. I wish I was there to try the strawberry ones too. I even enjoyed the ones with the red bean inside and I don't really like the red beans.
author: Crystal T.

description: This is a weird review because I actually didn't go to the physical location. My friend brought some of their Mochi to a house party and I thought it was very good. The individual pieces are pretty fat 2-3 inches across. The Mochi is so soft and chewy though! I don't usually eat Mochi like that. The piece I had also had chunks of strawberries. Yum!
author: Danielle C.

description:
O.m.g. 
It's a good thing that I don't live in SF.... because I would come here all the time! 
Had this on my list of places to visit when I came here on vacay, and BARELY made it in the door before closing time. I actually thought it was closed, but we saw someone else walk in so we did too. Very glad I did. 

I was going to order what was left in the counter, but the sweet woman behind the counter (I assume owner, too) told us she had other flavors and put together a sampler box for us. I liked them all, but yes, the blueberry mochi was the best. They were all super soft and chewy. Like. So. So. Good. I wish I could go back and get more. 

Until next time...
author: Natalie T.

description: Best manju in the city hands down! Don't hesitate, just go and try it for yourself. You will not be disappointed.
author: Mandy S.

description: I love Benkyodo so much- I drop by occasionally to buy myself mochis, brought a batch of their blueberry mochis to a family gathering, and most recently, ordered 120 strawberry, blueberry, apple, and peanut butter manjus for my wedding. The staff was so sweet and easy to work with. I came in to the store to place my order and prepay, and the gentleman there took my husband and me to their back workroom to discuss our plans. We arranged for our best man to pick them up the morning of the wedding. Benkyodo phoned me the week before to confirm my order, and they made everything very easy. I put the manjus in little red/white cupcake liners, put them out on a cupcake stand on my dessert bar. The wedding guests really enjoyed them, and I was so happy to have Benkyodo be a part of my wedding. I highly recommend them!
author: Michelle P.

description:
I have been on a hunt for a really good mochi shop and I think I have found the one! This place is delicious! My hubby and I are from out of town and we made a trip to the city just to try this famous mom & pop shop.

They have a variety of flavors to choose from --  I tried the blueberry mochi and red bean mochi.  Boy are they SUPER soft and chewy!  These tiny desserts will literally melt in your mouth at first bite! They're not too sweet like most other mochi's I've had. The service is excellent; the staff is very friendly and sociable. If you're a mochi fan, I'd recommend you pay this place a visit; you definitely will be satisfied! 

I got a few mochi's to-go for my mother and they were kind enough to gift wrap the box for me. Don't expect any fancy-shmancy wrapping because there's only one type of wrapping they offer -- white butcher paper. Lol. 

There isn't a private parking lot for this place. We found ourselves having to circle the block quite a few times to find parking.  

I definitely will be back for some more mochi's! :)
author: Mei W.

description:
It's truly the best mochi I've ever eaten. 

I bought a box to give to someone and I accidentally ate half of it! If you are in Japantown, definitely worth giving this place a try since the mochi is really fresh!
author: Christine Y.

description:
Very Good Mochi. And it taste pretty good. Parking is bad. It was hard to find a parking spot. But the wait was worth it. 
Good Job.
author: Harold Y.

description: The mochi here is so fresh! Buy a strawberry one and a peanut butter one and then mush em together for a pb&j mochi. Perfection!
author: Maya S.
