description: Benkyodo is a family owned sweet shop that I've just recently been going more often in the past 3 to 4 years. The history of the place definitely shows as you enter the shop. It has a very 70s interior.. with customers in their 60s-70s drinking their morning coffee and socializing near the counter area.. The mochi is made fresh daily... Once it's sold out, it's sold out for the day. So always try to go there early. Some of the regular kinds consists of red bean, green bean, whole red bean, etc.. They also have seasonal flavors such as blueberry, strawberry, and mango which are ALL DEELIGHTFUL.. the mochi is chewy, soft, and not too sweet. My Grandma loves them and can probably eat half a dozen all by herself. If you want to please the elders, buy some and have them try it.. This treat is great because it's not too sweet, and not heavy at all. A great snack to have when you're visiting relatives or small get togethers.. The price is also very reasonable, so if you're visiting SF jtown, buy a piece and I'm sure you won't regret it. This place is historical and is one of the few Japanese owned places left in Jtown..
author: Samantha W.

description: Love it so much!!!! very soft and not too sweet. It is perfect and I can't stop eatting!! I bought a box with 6 pc. and cost 7.50. I finished it within 10 mins =-= so happy~~
author: Orange S.

description: I've never had mochi like this before. The outer dough layer is so delicate and soft, not chewy like the ones in Vietnamese coffe shops. The filling so not too sweet, striking just the right balance. A great place to get a primer on proper Japanese sweets.
author: Alice W.

description: Dang it, I ate the whole box in a day! The mochi here is homemade, really fresh, soft, and tasty. I loved the ones I chose, but the blueberry one was definitely the best because it has a few real blueberries inside! I need to try the strawberry one next since I hear it's the best, and not an everyday flavor.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Good fresh soft mochi.  that about sums it up.

the red bean paste yummy but my favorite one was the blueberry because of the slight tangy flavor it gives

Sweet enough so that you could probably enjoy 2 in a row and save the rest for later
author: Tina A.

description:
Does your Valentine like supporting local businesses?

Does your Valentine adore cute desserts?

Does your Valentine have a serious mochi addiction?  

Then get on over to Benkyodo and pick up some of these!

http://bit.ly/i3W3RR 

J surprised me with these and of course I loved them.  I've been a long time fan of Benkyodo and their homemade mochi.  Since they have been making mochi in SF for 100+ years, clearly they know what they're doing.  The ones with red bean paste inside are probably my favorite but I've never met a Benkyodo mochi I didn't like.  All include that essential ingredient:

L-O-V-E.

Happy V Day yelpers!

----------------------
Update 7/2013:

New Benkyodo mochi favorite:  Fresh Strawberry!  (Sorry Red Bean.)
author: Amy C.

description:
My favorite mochi shop by far in the Bay Area. Mochi has basically been my life since first discovering it in high school, and I am always in search for the best mochi. Of course, the manju varieties here cannot beat the ones in Asia but Benkyodo Co. remains dear to my heart. If you have never had fresh Japanese manju or mochi, you are definitely going to be in for a delightful treat! Once you've had them fresh, it's really hard ever going back to the commercial, packages ones!

Since I don't live at all near SF, I always order a box of manju to bring home for my family or for my own sweet indulgence. I've tried most of their offering and my favorites have been:

-STRAWBERRY MOCHI (baked with fresh strawberries and are always the first one to sell out!!!)
-Blueberry with real blue berries in filling
-Sakura (cherry blososm), often wrapped with a shiso leaf?
-Green tea (Habutai) mochi with red bean filling
-Above (Habutai)rolled with kinako (soybean powder)
-Chocolate Marshmallow
-Peanut Butter (OMG!)
-Pink (Habutai)-lima bean filling

some more traditional manju, that I like are
-Imo (cinnamon coated manju with lima bean filling)
-Mushi (steamed bun , with red bean filling)
-Chofu (plain mochi wrapped with pancake)
-Age (Japanese donut with red bean filling)

Just talking about this makes my mouth water. This is must-go if you're ever in SF! Wonderful service and the mochi retains well for a couple of days. They make great gifts especially after wrapping! ENJOY!
author: Jenny Z.

description: Brought home a dozen mochis.  The kids raved that it's the best mochi they've had.  I was surprised to see one left the next morning.  And even a day later, that mochi was so delicious and fresh.  Aside from the usual red bean, we tried the mango, apple and peanut butter.  A must have if you visit Japantown.
author: Kat W.

description:
Ok...so the only mochi I was previously familiar with was the mini kind that they sprinkled on my yogurt at the Times square pinkberry.  The authentic mochi still can best be described as the pinkberry employee described hers: like a cross between a marshmallow and a gummy bear (only less sweet.) (My traveling companion described it as "gross" and promptly spit it out but I'm all for trying new things.)
The strawberry was good, green tea with red bean paste center was just ok and the blueberry flavor just didn't work imo. Wished they had had peanut butter flavor!! Four came to about $4.  There is also a little lunch counter in the store. 
Cute, something different to try at least once
author: Lisa A.

description: Cute little store!! When I came here during my breaks and would see local seniors sit at the counter chatting and eating mochi. Strawberry and blueberry (seasonal) are my favs!! But gosh they run out early. I moved to LA now and can't find mochi as good as these. I hope they continue to make delicious mochi years to come because it is such a treat!
author: Logan N.

description: Yummmmy.... delicious.... fresh mochi here.   Thanks to my friend who introduced me to this place... will come back next time I visit the city.
author: L D.

description: Mochi was very good, but giving only 3 stars since when I got there, there were only 2 kinds of mochi available.
author: Rsblok E.

description: This is the old school, classic mochi joint in SF. Been loving their mochi since I was a little kid. Fresh, soft, amazing. They have the mung bean and other fillings besides classic red bean (which I actually am not that big a fan of, so the variety is fantastic). This is your one-stop mochi place in Japantown. It's a pretty small shop and they usually sell out early so come early for the best selections. Miss this place sooo much since I moved away from SF. Not a bad thing to say about their mochi!
author: Amber G.

description:
CASH ONLY!
Benkyodo reminds me of a truck-stop diner but replace the truckers and roadtrippers with quiet, contemplative elderly folks. Seriously, late monday morning, we were in the company of hip obaasans and ojiisans (grandmas and grandpappies). Who would've known this was such a social hot spot? 

We picked a few mochi and dined in with some hot tea. There's just nothing quite like biting into freshly made mochi: soft, delicate, pure red bean-filling deliciousness. My fav was the one covered in powdered soy. We tried what looked like an apple pastry-- good but nothing like their more traditional offerings. Loved it so much, we ended up coming back a second time to get two boxes for gifting.  

I love my elderly peeps, so I'd come just to have a mochi and hang around. Beats a hippie-dippy coffee shop anyday!
author: Jenny H.

description:
I can't believe I've forgotten to write a review for Benkyodo. It's been a year since I've been there, but you know what they say, better late than never! 

I remember calling their shop because my brother and I couldn't find where they were - we knew they were in Japantown but that was it. And they were closing in a couple of minutes! The man who took my call quickly dismissed me and said they were about to close, until a lady (who turns out to be his wife) got on the line, apologized for her husband's abruptness and gave me directions while we speedwalked it to their store.

Finally, we make it there and the grandpa-san unlocked the door for us. The man I talked to on the phone turned out to be a welcoming feller and was the mochi-maker along with his dad. The wife turns out to be Filipino too! So we ended up shooting the breeze for quite a while. Really nice, enthusiastic people. They made it such a memorable experience, and taking home their delicious mochi was an even better treat!  

Please stay open, cos the next time I'm in San Fran I'm stopping by to say hi - and to get some mochi, of course!
author: Lee D.

description:
I have been looking FOREVER for a place that sells good mochi! I used to go to the Nijiya market at Japantown for their mochi that's in three different colors with a red bean filling, but that's no longer satisfying enough. 

I came here today and since this place is CASH ONLY, I didn't really get to order all that I want. :( I should have gone off to the atm first, but I didn't so I was only left with enough money to get one mochi. I chose the blueberry mochi since I saw the price for that one. $1.20. That mochi was DELICIOUS. It even has real pieces of blueberry inside which surprised me! I thought it would have just been some blueberry jam or something. But no. It wasn't. It was really good. And the lady that was serving me was really patient. :) 

This place is definitely popular. About a minute after I came out, 5 other people seemed to have came in and were waiting to order. 

And now that i know this place exist, I can't wait to come back and order more. ;)
author: Venus L.

description:
I can never find time to visit the 9-5 eateries in town. So, I took the day off to come here. I'm not even kidding. I don't even take the day off when I'm sick (yes, I'm one of "those" people). I just knew it'd be worth it. And it was.

The age (deep-fried, Japanese pseudo donut) is incredibly good. It's kind of like a donut hole, but rolled in sugar and filled with red bean paste. Just delicious. Plus the fact that it was freshly made (I'd arrived around 10am) made it that much better.

The mochi. Oh, the mochi. I know it's blasphemous to have blueberry (or any fruit, really) mochi, but the blueberry really is divine. So tender and melt-in-your-mouth good. I was told their sakura (cherry blossom) flavor is only available during the weekend (womp, womp). The classic flavors (green tea, red bean) are pretty darn excellent, too.

Now I get why this place is so highly rated. The mochi is as good as the ones in Tokyo. Oh, and service is super friendly. A simple "arigato" goes a long way.
author: Adena B.

description:
Long overdue update: 

A while back, I went on a mochi hunt in Southern California because I believed that I could find something even better than Benkyodo.  I was wrong, because their mochi was not nearly as soft as Benkyodo's.  Flavors were also artificial, fillings were chalky or the flavors were off, and this one place had a ridiculously small mochi to filling ratio (Mikawaya, of THE famed Mikawaya mochi ice cream).  All these places had 4, 4.5 stars, and none compared to Benkyodo.  Only Shuei-Do Manju in SJ comes close.  So don't look any further, Benkyodo is the best.

PS: Blueberry mochi is available in the winter to spring, and strawberry mochi is available late spring to fall.  Although both contain whole, fresh fruit, the strawberry is better.
author: Vivian H.

description: Tasty mochi. Cheap, comes in a variety pack or singles.
author: sean l.

description:
3.5 Stars

I really like their mochi - it's fresh, chewy & flavorful.  But it's a hit-or-miss with the service.  Sometimes the people are friendly, sometimes they're not helpful.
author: Rose A.

description:
Bobby...you rock!  Thank you so much for filling such a big order for me the day before going on vacation!  

Navigating around the city on the weekends can be tough especially when you are trying to pick-up a bunch of things for a party.  My friend was around the J-town area and offered to pick up the mochi (thank goodness!).  However, his son was sleeping in the car and finding a parking space was near impossible.  

I gave Benkyodo a call to give them the heads up that my friend will be stopping by instead of me.  Bobby answered and told me to tell him not to worry about parking, he'll come outside with the mochi.  Yes, the owner himself came out and delivered the mochi, talk about great customer service!  Not expecting any change, my friend wanted to give the leftover $ as tips, but Bobby ran back into the store to grab him the change.  He didn't want the tips, he smiled and told my friend to have a good time at the party.   What a nice guy!

I love their mochi and I heart their customer service even more!  Bobby....thank you for being the awesome owner that you are!  Too bad strawberry mochi season is over for this year, but definitely check out their blueberry mochi when you get a chance!  :)
author: Janetto L.

description:
Heard about this store from my Sidecar driver, checked on yelp, and I approve! The asian lady that works there is cute/funny and explained what each mochi was. She recommended the strawberry mochi and the white mochi with smooooth red bean, which were both really good. Wish I bought more!

Tip: Cash or check only.
author: Christine C.

description:
After getting lunch, a friend and I wanted to stop by Benkyodo to get some mochi.

We got Chofu (pancake wrap with plain sweet rice), inaka/yabure (steamed bun with red beans), yomogi (green mochi with red beans, and pink habutai (pink mochi with smooth white lima beans). 

The chofu was good and it was very adorable! The inaka/yabure was weird looking and wasn't to my liking because it was dry...the pink habutai made up for it with it's soft mochi stickiness and the smooth filling. My friend ate the yomogi which he liked a lot. 

I love Benkyodo Co!
author: Sofia R.

description:
The peanut mochi was such a pleasant surprise: we simply expected a peanut butter filling, but the center was choke full of crunchy peanut bits too. Who knew such a harmonious yin and yang existed between mochi and peanut.

The red bean was alright: a tad too sweet and watery for my taste. I think it's because they used fresh red bean paste, and the moisture had seeped into the mochi by midday when we purchased the goodies.

The blueberry mochi was fun to eat, with juicy bursts of real blueberries embedded in the mochi. I'm not sure how well these two flavours go together, but as I enjoyed it in Alamo Square with the iconic Painted Ladies before me, it felt like the quintessential multicultural San Francisco experience.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Yaaaasss mochi. Their mochis are so fresh and delicious, and they offer slightly unconventional, like peanut butter mochi, to the more traditional red bean/white bean paste mochis.

Cash only, and the mochis will run you just over $1. My favorites are the seasonal strawberry/blueberry mochis, which have real fruit inside. I think the real gem is the texture of the rice flour, which is soooo soft and just pulls apart so well. If you're craving real, authentic, Japanese mochi, this is a really good find.
author: Kate M.

description:
I'm attracted to crazy flavors so it's no surprise that I walked out of here with a blueberry mochi, peanut butter mochi, lima bean mochi, and green red bean mochi. 

The blueberry mochi was the winner by a long shot. First of all, all the mochi is delish. Soft and chewy and not too sweet. Just like the best home made you can imagine. But the blueberry had little blueberries studded inside that would burst with juicy goodness inside your mouth - perfectly complementing the mochi dough. 

Least favorite was the peanut butter. I felt like the pb was very dry and rich and wasn't a very high quality of pb. Maybe it is but it kinda tasted like that stuff inside Reese's Pieces. 

Lima bean mochi (pink habutai) and red bean green mochi (yamogi) were good even if not as interesting - still some of the best I've had.

I definitely want to come back for some more fruit flavors. All the mochi were ridiculously cheap at $1 for most of them and $1.25 for the blueberry. Maybe all these desserts for $3-5 in SF are warping my mind.
author: Jean K.

description: Hands down the best stop for fresh made mochi. Don't let the old fashioned café exterior fool you - this houses major tasty snacks galore. Also has a few diner-style savory options on the menu, but I come here strictly to satisfy my sweet tooth. The earlier you arrive in the day, the more variety of mochi you will find. I almost always go for the "chofu" (mochi wrapped with a stamped honey cake crepe) and either the green tea or blueberry mochi when available. On my most recent visit I tried the "age" (imagine a sugar donut filled with a generous amount of red bean paste) and the pink mochi with lima bean filling - in honor of Valentine's day, it was topped with a heart shaped mochi cutout. Next on my list are the strawberry and peanut butter mochi. They go fast!
author: Elaine W.

description: Outstanding old school mochi shop!  The mochi was very fresh with a nice variety too.  I loved it!
author: Bee M.

description: This place and the people are adorable and sweet! It's a mom and pop shop with the most legit mochi in San Francisco. It's CASH ONLY, PEOPLE. If you're craving a blueberry mochi with real blueberries, come during the week. I love them, but I come on Fridays and Saturdays. That's when they have the strawberry mochi. TRY IT. YOU MUST. I would come every weekend if I could, but I'm not the kind of gal to carry cash everywhere. I'm too lazy. If you're not lazy and it so happens to be Friday or Saturday, stop by! Get that strawberry mochi! It is divine I tell you! I would buy all of them if I ever carried that much cash. Make the stop to Japan Town! There are tons of other things to do, too. Get some ramen, takoyaki, or some cake from Yasukochi's. Do it all! You won't regret it.
author: Lyra C.

description:
Delicious mochi!  peanut butter mochi....chocolate mochi! sweet, chewy, full of flavor!
love the classic mochi filled with red bean or white beans as well.  beautiful mochi!
they are a half diner as well for food, but i have never had anything else here besides the mochi.
author: Linda T.

description:
The strawberry mochi here is BOMBTASTIC. Ordinarily, I don't really like mochi. The texture and flavor never really did it for me. (Asian desserts in general -- just not that into them)

But Benkyodo's strawberry mochi is a whole different story. The uber-soft mochi outside is filled with a delicious and creamy strawberry filling, and fresh strawberries. It actually tastes like a dessert without being too sweet.

I'm currently devising reasons to get myself up to Japantown to get my hands on some more of the stuff. They're closed Sundays and the strawberry mochi is only available Thursday through Saturday so plan your schedule accordingly!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
The mochi is good. It's not great but it doesn't have to be. This is not a patisserie. It's got a Japanese convenience store vibe with a counter displaying a variety of mochi. The one with blueberry filling is top of the heap. 

The guy at the register is not one for chitchat. No chewing that fat with this guy. Don't ask him if they take credit cards. They don't and it irks him to say so (although it might be funny to pop in and keep asking him; if you're bored or in need of amusement). Perhaps he relishes the nonconformity of saying no to plastic in 2014 almost 2015.  I'm pretty sure they lose more customers than not with this throwback to the early 1970s. So has this place. A time capsule containing mochi. And one cranky old man behind a register. "Hey, do you guys use Square!?"
author: Jahan T.

description:
I'm usually unimpressed with the mochi I buy in Japantown stores / Nijiya, so when a good friend bought me and my sister boxes of mochi (he lives near Japantown), I appreciated the sweet gesture but wasn't expecting too much.

I left it in the kitchen for my roommates for a day and came back to try one (I was happy to see they had walloped 2 of the 6 by then).  I cut myself half a manjuu and half a purple mochi.  Oh my goodness.  The manjuu was good (bao-like bread stuffed with adzuki) and the purple mochi was blueberry flavoured!  It was so delicious!

Then my friend told me he bought it from Benkyodo and I had to Yelp it.  I am definitely dropping by the store to try all their flavours and will definitely only buy mochi from here as gifts from now on!!
author: Letitia L.

description:
Being a total newbie when it comes to Japanese desserts, I learned after the fact that my mochi adventure at Benkyodo contained no mochi.....only manju

Red bean - wasn't a fan at first but apparently there's a tasting order & you can't have the red bean after the white bean.....having the red bean first the following day, the flavor was much better

Guess it's just like a wine tasting in reverse - go for the reds first when tasting mochi (or manju as the case may be)

White Lima bean - super sweet & super good

Strawberry - 1 single strawberry enveloped w/ a strawberry sauce - it was also sweet & really good.  

Would get all 3 again & would like to explore more but there was a huge line & no descriptions as to what things were I didn't want to waste the staff's time, asking about every little thing.....& I didn't want to risk getting 1 of everything in case I didn't like their mochi.  I'm a newbie for crying out loud.....I don't know!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Get the strawberry mochi. Just do it.

They also had blueberry when I went, and that was also delicious. Lesson learned: get whatever fruit mochi they have.
author: Janet P.

description: Great little hidden shop in Japan town. I tried all the mochi here. I prefer the plain one with no filling.
author: Nina M.

description: Best manju in the city. So smooth. So delicate. Yet, with such intense flavor. One bite of their their blueberry manju and I was in love. There is nothing quite like it.
author: Mona W.

description:
I always try to come here, but I'm always late! I guess I always just ended up there at the wrong time. 

However, this time around I was super early to meeting up with my friends for the ramen festival, I decided to try and get some mochi at Benkyodo. Thank goodness it was open and a decently short line so I got in line. 

I ordered the following: fried, strawberry, green tea, pink with lima bean, and red bean. 

The fried one was pretty good and definitely the one I first tried since it was the most likely to become bad by the afternoon...

My favorite though was the green tea and strawberry ones. Now to come here more often...and not have it be closed!
author: Nina Y.

description:
WHERE HAVE I BEEN ALL MY LIFFEE??? 

Can't believe I only recently tried this. The first time I came here I was expecting to order several strawberry mochis, only to find out that it's served Fridays and Saturdays only. But she told me that I could call ahead and reserve them, which is fantastic! I ended up snagging the last 6 the next time I came back and she gave me a discount and charged me regular price instead because she thought they were smaller (which didn't look like so to me)

SO, only the few mochis I've tried so far. 

STRAWBERRY - So soft and amazingly delicious! It's the right amount of sweetness and my favorite mochi of all.

WHITE HABUTAI - Insides have save smooth red bean which I love more than the whole red beans one. Its my second favorite

YOMOGI - Similar to the white habutai, but just with chunks/whole red beans instead. Not bad, but I prefer the white habutai more

BLUEBERRY - I love blueberry fruits itself, but I just cant seem to like blueberry flavored anything, and this was no exception. But that's only my personal preference. But for those who actually like blueberry everything, definitely give this a try!
author: Harriet W.

description:
HANDS. DOWN. THE. BEST. MOCHI. I'VE. EVER. EATEN. Goodness gracious, does place know how to do mochi RIIIGHT! 

Came here at around 1 pm to find a small store with half food shop and half mochi shop. There was a huge glass case lined with tons and tons of different kinds of mochis. We ended up paying a little over $7 for 6 mochis. They sell plates of 4 you can buy and we ended up going with their popular strawberry one, regular mochi filled with red bean, green mochi filled with red bean, and another one filled with their white bean. They also sell pre-packed box of 4 peanut butter mochi (that you can't buy individually), which we ended up grabbing a box of as welll. The lady at the cash register told us she LOVED peanut butter and those were definitely her FAVE.

She definitely was NOTTTT lying. The peanut butter mochi is BOMB. DOT. COM. It's like if Jiffy threw a party for their peanuts and decided to use a mochi ball as a venue. Too weird? Sorry. But honestly it's just THAT good. Their mochi is the perfect amount of chewiness, softness, and sweetness and stuffed with exactly the right amount of filling. 

Their strawberry one was also really good too. I normally hate fake strawberry flavoring because it reminds me of Pepto Bismol, but if you're like me, don't be scared to try the strawberry mochi. It's more like a bean paste infused with subtle strawberry flavoring and it's SO good. They also have a small slice of strawberry in the middle of the mochi for a nice surprise! 

This place is most definitely worth EVERY penny. If you have something bad to say about this place, there is PROBABLY something wrong with you. No I'm just kidding, but seriously go here. I'm so glad I don't live in SF because I'd be at this place probably every morning waiting at the door for their shop to open like a dog waiting for its bacon dinner. 

Seriously, amazing.
author: Vicki L.

description:
They have super fresh mochi that's the perfect texture, even 2-3 days out (store in a cool dry place, NOT in the refrigerator). No wonder they've been in business for over 100 years.

My favorite is the chofu because I like the contrasting texture of the pancake on the outside.  I'm usually not a fan of super sweet things.

Hopefully I'll eventually get to try the elusive strawberry manju.  Make sure you eat them soon because they will go bad after 2-3 days.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
AMAZE!!!

I only had the chofu and and the strawberry mochi. 

The chofu was good.

The strawberry mochi. Oh. My. God.

You have to try it and while you're at it but at least a whole box worth of it. You bite into it and its a mixture of the juices of the strawberry and sweet flavor and soft texture of the mochi. I definitely recommend it.

Strawberry mochi is only made on Friday and Saturday so if you're in town those days, definitely stop by.
author: Christine D.

description:
Love them!
Strawberry manju's are in season and I can't resist them!  Also made a birthday girl really happy when i gave her a box of assorted mochi's.
author: Stacy D.

description: The mochi here is so fresh and delicate. I've never had homemade mochi before, only the pre packaged kind or mochi ice cream. Better get there early because if you wait, they will sell out of most flavors. And then you will be sad and have no delicious mochi to eat!
author: Cynthia J.

description: I am a huge fan of all different kinds of Manju. This place might not look like a typical dessert shop you'd come to expect but they have hands down the most fresh and yummy manju in the city! I have been coming to this place for years and they have always been very consistent with their quality. Don't miss their fruit mochi with fresh seasonal fruit that's a must!
author: Menghan Z.

description: Lots of different flavors of Mochi. Not the frozen ice cream kind if that is what you are looking for. The people are always very nice and welcoming.
author: Orleana P.

description:
We came here after hearing that there was a really good mochi place near Japantown. I've been to Japantown quite a few times over the years, but never explored the neighboring streets much since I just mostly looked around inside the mall area. It's pretty much across the street from the plaza hidden in the back of the line of shops. When you walk in, the mochi counter is on the left and I think they sell real food and snacks on the right. The owner was very nice and explained what the fillings were inside each of the mochi and manju.

What we ordered:
- Box with one each of all the mochi flavors ($5): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=zuljh1rg25lYd3Znd5UmjA#zuljh1rg25lYd3Znd5UmjA

The fillings were mostly a combination of red/green/white bean and then there was one with strawberry filling and a whole strawberry inside! The strawberry one was definitely both of our favorites. I realized I like fruit mochi a little bit better since the red bean, etc. type of filling kind of starts tasting the same after splitting four of those mochi haha. Don't get me wrong though, red bean is yummy too! What sets this place apart from the other mochi I've ever had was that the skin was so incredibly soft and chewy. I don't know how the mochi even stayed intact because they were so squishy!
author: Jessica C.

description: Really love their mochi!  soft and fresh. reminds me of what I used to have on the streets in my hometown.
author: Shuting Z.

description: I've been stalking Benkyodo Co. for literally years. Every time I found myself in the area either they were closed or I was too late and they had sold out of all their goodies. Finally last weekend the stars aligned and I was able to try their fresh mochi. The red bean and green tea was probably my favorite "classic", but the blueberry was killer. The lady at the counter said arigato as I completed my purchase, when I replied arigato gozimasu without skipping the beat she seemed simultaneously shocked and entertained. Pretty sure that made the day for both of us, or at least me. Mental note: learn more bits of languages!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Five stars here is a no brainer! If you are so lucky to 1) try this place or 2) get there when it's open (limited hours), you will be glad. Best mochi/manju in the city-fresh and gooey and yummy flavors (strawberry!) The diner-feel can be a bit daunting because you might feel like you're intruding on the regulars. That's not a problem. Just be prepared for the cash-only and you're good to go!
author: Lauren K.

description: So far, I've tried the peanut butter mochi and the chofu (plain mochi with no filling, wrapped in a pancake).  I liked the chofu, and I definitely want to try the strawberry mochi that so many people seem to be raving about on here.  I wish they sold plain mochi with no filling, since I'm not a fan of the bean fillings, which doesn't leave me with many options here.
author: Cici A.

description:
How have I not made a review for Benkyodo?

Well, if everyone else hasn't convinced you to try their mochi.. you are missing out. Their Mochi is awesome and they have a variety and they are not too expensive.

Strawberry and peanut butter are my faves...
author: Roger A.

description: This place was a 4-star for me based on the red bean and green bean mochi -- high quality and fresh with an interesting old school storefront that doesn't *quite* count as a hole in the wall (it also sells hot dogs and coffee). This place elevated to 5-star status once i tried their fresh strawberry mochi (seasonal). Amazing!!! Even my parents, who've had their mochi for years, raved when I brought them home a few to try. DEF try the fresh strawberry mochi.
author: Shirley L.

description:
Undoubtedly the softest, freshest mochi I've ever tasted. I had the opportunity to sample some of the mochi here on a food tour of Japantown, and I was quite surprised with the texture of the pastries here. I had known mochi to be a chewy food, but it's so fresh here that it nearly melts. 

I've been told that the mochi makers here are up at the crack of dawn pounding the rice and rice flour into delicious bites. Definitely swing by if you've got a sweet tooth.
author: Geoffrey H.

description:
We interrupt this broadcast to anounce that there are two new flavors available here:  blueberry mochi and apple manju mochi.
There are whole, sweet blueberries mixed with a rich berry flavored paste.  
For the apple one, think of mom's apple pie... but mochi style.
The blueberry one is a hit with me, since strawberries (my normal favorite) aren't in season right now.  
If you're craving for blueberries and sweets, this is the spot to hit.
author: Mike C.

description:
The manju here MELTS in your mouth. This place has been around so long, I wouldn't even question their expertise in mochi-making. Here are some suggestions:

1. For a mouthgasm: try the strawberry mochi. Fresh strawberries are included in the filling.

2. Classic: Try the red bean filling (anko). Can't ever go wrong with classic!

3. Favorite: Saturday mornings only they make Ohagi. Ohagi has the red bean (azuki) on the outside of the mochi, and the mochi rice isn't fully hammers/crushed so it has similar texturing of rice-pudding in a more solid state. 

Enjoy!
author: Andy M.

description:
Peanut butter mochi is the latest feature.  Chunky peanuts.  And I'm not even a huge fan of peanut butter, but this was creamy and nutty.  It's three to a plastic tray. We called ahead and they put some aside for us. 

Said they make it on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, but today was Wednesday. Go figure. And I've seen it for sale on Tuesdays.
author: Shirley N.

description: Lucky day today.  I was the last person to get fresh manju today.  One of my favorite Japanese treats.
author: Brent T.

description:
I've walked by this place so many time and only recently discovered the wonderful mochis they have!! The blueberry is my fav. And the one with the lima bean paste and the red bean paste with soybean powder are delicious too. The sakura was interesting since the leaf is savory. 

The mochis are so soft!! Can't wait to come back! I've always ate ALL of it in the same day (even when we got 15 mochis b/n the two of us...) so not sure how well it sits and if it hardens.
author: Jenny W.

description:
If you are allergic to peanuts or even strawberries, I am sorry.  Please STOP reading this as the green eyed monster might make an appearance and you should not try this at home or otherwise.

Some may consider this suggestion sacrilegious but if you take a fresh strawberry mochi and pair it with a peanut butter mochi, you will have the most divine PBJ experience ever.  Or at least I did.  And will again.
author: J. P.

description:
Great place to get mochi! It's relatively cheap and super yummy!

~ The lady who works there is really nice!
~ The peanut butter mochi is pretty yummy surprisingly.
~ I always can't wait for my favourites: strawberry mochi. Sadly it isn't year round. They put real strawberries in them!
~ They also sell food like burgers, although I haven't tried them, but I always see most likely, elder regulars there eating so it must be good.
author: Samantha Y.

description:
The owner/worker there is pretty honest about how long these will last, which was nice of her 'cause she advised me not to get the mochis for my mom who I was going to visit a few days later.

Love this place! The blueberry is my favorite.
author: Jamie L.

description: I buy moochi here any time I'm in the area.  I wasn't much of a moochi fan until I discovered this place.  Boxed moochi doesn't even compare to the fresh product found at this bakery.
author: T S.

description:
As one of the original businesses in the historic Japantown, Benkyodo Co has been operated by the same family for the past 103 years. Their store is separated into halfs where the left sells a wide variety of fresh mochi and Japanese rice crackers and snacks, and to the right is a small diner with a similar but elaborated set up as Joe's Ice Cream. I've been coming here for many years and their mochi has been consistently the best, even better than the ones at Little Tokyo in LA. In the past they usually run out of mochi by 3pm regardless the day of the week. Yesterday, the place was packed with mochi enthusiasts and they needed all the help they could get. 

I think it's fantastic that they now have a wider recognition because this place is as good as it gets. My Yomogi (green tea mochi with brown soy powder and whole red beans) was heavy and sweet with outstanding red beans at the center. The Chofu (sugary plain sweet rice with pancake wrap) had a lighter taste and it was one of the best of its kind. I also tried their new thick red bean paste with awesome sticky rice in the middle and loved it. My all time favorite, strawberry manju (strawberry mochi filled with lima beans) was as soft and heavenly as ever. The common thread between all the manju and mochi here is the fact that they are ultra fresh and soft with a consistency that I have not observed anywhere else. If you want traditional handmade mochi and manju, I'd say this is the best place to get them on the West Coast. 

Service was friendly and down to earth. My mochi was wrapped in a nice package like always and they each only cost $1. Closed on Sundays. To learn more about the history of this place visit: http://www.benkyodocompany.com/about-us/index.php.
author: Daniel L.

description: Had the rice cake and blueberry mochi. The rice cake mochi was a bit hard...but it was okay. Would've liked it fresher. The blueberry mochi is on another level. The skin is delicate and had a pleasant, soft chewiness. I was worried the blueberry inside wouldn't be sweet but it was amazing! I devoured the the two blueberry mochis I had in one sitting.
author: Rachel L.

description: The best mochi I've ever had!! Fresh, soft, sweet and delicious. These are to die for
author: Brian G.

description: Perfect and fresh. Only downside is you have to get there early. Not much left by the afternoon. While there's not much parking right by the shop, there is s paid lot under the mall across the plaza.
author: Joe B.

description:
My family has been coming to this manju shop ever since I can remember. The staff is friendly, quality is consistent and most of all the variety that is offered.

If your looking to satisfy your sweet tooth or looking to try a new sweet treat. Stop by and enjoy a piece of manju - you will not be disappointed. 

I can't wait till I'm in the area to order a box of manju.
author: Kristina S.

description:
As you can tell from previous Yelpers, this place is the awesome.  I was actually in the area to take part in the Real Escape Game and needed to kill some time. 

I wish I had been hungrier to tray allllll of their offerings, but today the peanut butter mochi was calling my name.  They come in package of 3 (you may be able to find a 2 pack hiding out) and are only sold prepackaged due to allergy issues.  The mochi is perfect.  You can definitely tell it is fresh and the portions are ample.  The peanut butter is the perfect combination of sweet and salty.  

Stop by this place if you've got the time.  Keep your eyes peeled as it can easily be hidden if you're not paying attention.  Cash or check only!  Hit up that ATM.  It. Is. Worth. It.
author: Lauren R.

description:
(with the girlfriend at Japantown)
HURRYYY! COMON.. DOUBLE-TIME!
what time is it? 4:58PM ALREADY!? 
hey wait.. YES! THEIR STILL OPEN!

This is THE spot for you MOCHI ADDICTS!

I had the honor of meeting the original owner over some drinks (his mochi shop down in LA) and he was very knowledgeable of all things, mochi. He discussed the process of handcrafting mochi, the history of mochi from Japan to the present, and how it all differs from his competitors. By the end of the night, I was fiending for some actually REAL mochi and was determined to get some!

Fresh handmade pieces of heaven -- that best describes the mochi at Benkyodo. Their mochi has converted me! I use to love those prepackaged mochi balls (with filling), which can be purchased at local Japanese supermarkets, but once I tried Benkyodo, it just doesn't compare! Try the Lima Bean Mochi [http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/rA2tvyJ15TO1za9ukb1gNw/l.jpg], it's surprisingly delectable! 

The only downside is when more than half the time I'm at Japantown, it's wayyy pass their operating hours.. (5PM + Closed Sundays) but when I do feel like smashing 60MPH in the afternoon down Buchanan street -- well, let's just leave it at that.

PS: CASH ONLY
author: Albert L.

description:
OMG! This place is the bomb! My cousin suggested I try this place out when we were in Japan town. Well, I was a little impatient with the line,but once I sunk my teeth into those fresh moist mochis, I believe why it is the BEST I have ever eaten!  

I had the ones with the Strawberry was in the middle...
author: Lisa C.

description:
I always pass by this place but never go in because I always think this is like a fast food cafe..........but it is not.

Came here the first time around 5:00pm but most of the mochi were sold out.  Then I came back the next day at noon.....much more selection!  So make sure to come early.

I tried  the Green Tea, Strawberry and Pink mochi and they were all so good.  Soft, fresh and chewy and the fillings were not overly sweet.  The price was reasonable too.  

I can't wait to go back there
author: Liza T.

description:
Mochi: sticky rice cake.
Manju: rice powder flour cake.

Appearance: can't tell the difference between the two.
Texture: soft chewy exterior with delightful filling.

Recommendation: Strawberry Manju. White lima bean filling with FRESH strawberry.
Favorite: Kinako Mochi. Red bean filling covered in soybean flour.
author: Marti L.

description: My favorite mochi place in all of San Francisco. Maybe the whole world. Just kidding, I haven't been to Japan yet. However, this place makes very fresh mochi and I would recommend the strawberry one the most because it has chunks of strawberry in it. The other flavors are good too. I normally order a whole box with each flavor.
author: Jason L.

description:
Still delicious, but I'm going to dock a star because the ichigo daifuku (strawberry manju) used to have MUCH more strawberry in it!  Now it's too sweet and the bits of strawberry as so meager.  Very disappointing.  Used to be my favorite.

Chofu is still excellent and my favorite because it isn't too sweet.  I'll have to come back to try the blueberry one...

Call ahead and reserve if you're not going to get there before 3pm!  They usually sell out by then!
author: Ruth C.

description:
Mochi - this is the place to go.  Fresh, delicious, authentic mochi.  I can't wait until the fresh strawberry mochi is available soon, but now they have blueberry to keep your palate entertained.  

Whenever we're in the neighborhood, we have to get at least a boxed dozen to take home.  My favorites are the ones with smooth red or lima bean or the chofu or suama.  They are so fresh and so good.  

They have peanut butter mochi also and are very careful to do them separately in case a person has peanut allergy.  I asked because a friend of mine is allergic and wanted to make sure before I brought them some.

This is a great treat for the family if you are looking for a unique dessert.
author: Maria S.

description: Good place to hang out with the older generation or when you're feeling homesick.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Just like a Godiva chocolate shop but with mochi instead! Fresh different flavors of mochi are made in large batches and displayed behind a glass counter. You pick a size of box or tray or whatever you want, and you can fill it up with as many different flavors of mochi as you'd like. Some are really pretty and there are a lot of different flavors! 

The mochi are SOO FRESH!! SUPER SOFT and tasty!! Because it's so fresh, it only lasts 3 days, so if you get some, better EAT it FAST! But once you taste it, you won't have a problem eating all of it at once! 

CASH ONLY!!
author: Amiee H.

description:
Mochi is my all-time favorite treat. This is a serious proclamation, because I am a devout Treat Feind. My sister has been taking me to Benkyodo since I was a kid, and when I was in high school I would drive myself all the way from the 'burbs just to indulge in these simple, delicious sweets. 

If I calculated all of the reasons why I moved to San Francisco, Benkyodo would be The Ringer in the treat category. This mochi is the real deal. I've never been to Japan, but I imagine this is as authentic as you're going to get stateside--these handcrafted puppies literally melt in your mouth. Sinking your teeth into one of Benkyodo's spherical, gooey, bean-paste-filled maleable balls of heaven is a MUST-TRY if you have wandered into Japantown. 

If I had one day left on Earth, I would come here for dessert.
author: Meredith C.

description:
It seems like every time I have a craving for some mochi at Benkyodo, it's past 5:00pm or it's a Sunday... which means that if I haven't made an effort to stock up on their goods sometime when they're actually open, I'm screwed! Lucky for me I had a meeting at 4:30 around the Japantown area earlier in the week which dropped me within spitting distance of my favorite mochi shop in town... score!

I've tried every single mochi they offer and I honestly can't say I've had a flavor I've disliked. It takes a while to figure out which offering is which, and the older ladies behind the counter don't have much patience for inquiries... so I literally just point at three or four of them each time I'm in there and trust they'll suffice. And you know what? They always do. 

It's one of the original Japantown businesses dating back to the pre-quake days and they've got that old school, drug store/soda fountain vibe going on, so if you have visitors in town, you should consider this place a must stop!
author: Ruggy J.

description: Their mochi tastes AMAZING!!!! I cannot ask for any better! Everyone here is so happy and friendly. I love this place!! :) It is so much better than those pre-boxed ones. Strawberry and pink ones are my favorite, but strawberry one might get sold out even before the noon, so make sure you call and ask them to hold it for you.
author: Yumi K.

description: If you are ever in Japantown in San Francisco, make sure to stop by Benkyodo to try some of their delicious mochi pastries! Wether you enjoy traditional green tea with red bean, sweet peanut butter or savory red bean paste, Benkyodo has a wide variety of choices of mochi for everyone!
author: Melissa M.

description: This place has been around for more than 100 years. It's a gem-- they make the best mochi in San Francisco, and other than Torrance, CA, perhaps the USA. Besides the standard red bean, I'd suggest trying seasonals (and more Western-oriented sweets) such as the strawberry and blueberry filled mochi. Another favorite of mine is the little pancack-- see photos. My other favorite thing about this place is the food bar. It's usually filled with geriatric Japanese enjoying rock bottom prices on fountain drinks, hot dogs and white-bread sandwiches. It feels good to come here because you feel like you are contributing and enjoying the same places that's been shared and cherished for generations. It's priceless, really.
author: Brian J.

description:
Delicious, freshly made mochi, amazing and friendly staff, what's not to love?

I've been to Benkyodo a few times and until my most recent visit, was always unlucky to get a hold of the popular but elusive strawberry mochi since they sell out so fast. Yesterday I got there before lunch and finally got the strawberry mochi - oh my goodness! So good. I guess it's seasonal and there's fresh strawberry in it. The mochi is so soft and chewy and not too sweet. My favorite!! 

The other flavors are well made and tasty but I personally find them a tad too sweet; but then nowadays I find a lot of sweets 'too sweet'. 

That strawberry mochi though (drool).
author: Jing D.

description:
This place and Mochi Cream (San Jose) holds a special place in my heart for excellent quality Mochi.

We lucked out called in advance and got the following flavors:
Strawberry, Peanut Butter and Blueberry Mochis:(http://instagram.com/p/cFej2onh99/)

Chunky peanut butter texture in the peanut butter mochi was alright.

The Blueberry and Strawberry tied for first place. The experience becomes preferential when you try both of these freshly made organic creations. Would you prefer the bursting of blueberry flavor blasting through your mouth?

Or, how about the prickly sweet jam of seasonal strawberry singing to you a summer time sonata?

Either way, you win at life. Sometimes, the simplest things in life are also the most rewarding (and affordable). At a going rate of $1.10 per mochi, with friendly customer service and an accessible product I'm surprised they haven't raised the prices after all this time. .

If they accepted credit cards, they would have gotten a perfect score from me. 
107 years of Handcrafted Japanese Delicacies, Domo Arigatou Benkyodo!

4.5, cheers!
author: Ryan M.

description: Vacationing in SF and had set my sights on visiting Japantown.  Stopped into this charming diner/sweet shop and bought a couple of freshly made mochi balls.  The fried Age with red bean and the strawberry.  They were soooo yummy that I braved the walk the next day from SOMA to purchase 12 more to take back to the East Coast.  Yep they were that good....
author: Sandi K.

description:
To be fair, while I enjoy mochi, I'm more a fan of Chinese fillings like black sesame and peanut, rather than traditional Japanese fillings like red or white bean, finding the latter to be overly sweet more often than not. So with that in mind, I'll say that Benkyodo does still suffer the issue of overly sweet fillings, but the texture of their mochi is amazingly soft, and definitely among the better ones I've tried.

There's also a good variety of mochi types here, including your traditional daifuku and manju, though, as usual with Japanese mochi shops, I find the selection of flavors somewhat limited. And at around a buck per, the value you're getting isn't bad (just remember to bring cash).
author: Johnny W.

description: My family and I were celebrating all of our birthdays in one weekend. Four birthdays means four desserts, of course. One of them were a box of mochi. We got one a few with red bean, and white bean, a few mochi and a few manju. There was a lot of variety and it was relatively inexpensive, just over a $1 each. The lady also wrapped it and tied a string around it to make it look a little prettier.
author: Leslie P.

description: The strawberry made me a mochi lover again after years of avoiding mochi altogether after buying some gross stale packages in Japanese markets.  There isn't a single bad flavor, but strawberry is still my favorite with peanut butter a close second.  The red bean filling is also great even though I usually really hate red bean!
author: Denise M.

description:
Blueberry MOCHI!!!

After wandering around Japantown on a Saturday afternoon I thought it would be a good idea to check out Benkyodo and grab some of this awesome, freshly-made mochi I had been reading about on Yelp. I was not disappointed. There was a line when we got there but I'm glad we waited because the blueberry mochi was DELICIOUS!! It had big chunks of fresh blueberry inside and the pounded rice surrounding the blueberries was so soft, and fresh that I don't think I can ever go back to the grocery store-bought mochi I was eating before. This is the real deal people, I was impressed.

The store itself is very small and there was a mini diner on the right side as you walk in. You order mochi on the left and you can order one by itself (like I did) or a box set and they will wrap it up for you. Prices are reasonable, the mochi is fresh and the employees are nice. Definitely an awesome find in Japantown!
author: Sam F.

description:
looove benkyodo!  

age - donut with smooth red beans (sooo delish when freshly made) and kinako - mochi with smooth red beans and sprinkled with soybean flour are faves i always get.

the seasonal fave strawberry mochi - smooth white lima beans with fresh strawberries and strawberry flavoring is a must when available.

lucky to have tried the once featured chocolate marshmallow mochi :9

will grab imo - baked with smooth white lima beans and cinnamon coating once in awhile

peanut butter mochi - pink mochi filled with peanut butter is good but too rich to have more than one.
author: she q.

description:
Benkyodo has been around since i was a kid running amok in J-Town.   Family-owned since the 50s, consistently  turning out the good sweets.

Fresh mochi......mmmm......cant ask for anything more.
author: Juv C.

description: Best mochi around SF. get there early. Everything is awesome but all the fun interesting flavors are sold out early.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
handmade manju and mochi
real fruit fillings
get the ones freshly made
ask for recommendations
cash only
$1.10 a piece unless stated otherwise
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I remember the first time I had mochi when I was a kid, I was so confused by what I was eating.  On the one hand, it was soft and floury like fresh bread or pastries, yet it was chewy and sweet like candy or gum.  I mean seriously, what the heck is a kid to think?

When I finally made it out to Benkyodo to try some of their infamous fresh mochi, I had a feeling it was going to be good just from walking in.  From the aura of the place itself, you can tell that they've been in business for a long time - the decor and look is like a transplant of a coffee shop right out of the 50's.  I could just sense that those comments about them having the best mochi in SF just might be true.  

The glass case in the counter featured about six to eight different varieties of fresh mochi, alongside some pre-packaged types and other assorted treats.  Everything looked really good, but still being pretty full from lunch, I decided to go with just two for my family and I to try.  After a couple minutes of deliberation, ended up going with the Habutai (regular white mochi filled with red bean paste) and the Pink Habutai (pink mochi filled with lima bean paste).  Both were plumped up nicely from the filling, and the mochi was soft to the touch and bite.  The filling in both was pretty sweet, but really full in flavor.  And at just a $1.10 per pop, it's so worth it!

Unfortunately, didn't get a chance to try any of the fruit mochi (namely the strawberry mochi people have written about, or the blueberry I saw either), but I'll definitely do so on my next trip there.  Considering that their mochi won my parents over as well, I'd say it's safe to say it just might be sooner rather than later!
author: Mike L.

description:
Stopped in during the Cherry Festival.

It's been too long;happy to say Benkyodo's Manju's are still the tongue bomb.

Wow, soft, slightly chewy, moist, fresh and flavorful.

The best Manju I have ever had.

Decor: cool 1950's decor, replete with a long counter and dining stools that were from the Happy Day's.

Customer service: fine.
author: Bert K.

description:
SUPER DELICIOUS AND FRESH MOCHI! MOUTH-WATERING AH-SO-FREAKING-AMAZING-I-WANT-IT-ALL good. 

I bought a box of 10 for a party of two and finished it all within a day! I was tempted to go back in to buy more but it closed at 5:30pm. Each mochi ranges from $1.10-$1.40. SUPER reasonable considering it's handmade. With love. I could taste it. 

My absolute favorites:
chofu- pancake over sweet rice mochi- it's like. a pancake wrapped mochi. How could it get any better. Perfect flavor and melt in my mouth amazing.

yomogi- green mochi with whole red beans- I want another 10 of these tomorrow! Wasn't too sweet or overbearing. I loved it! 

I'm definitely going to make a stop here whenever I'm in the area.... or on my way downtown....or on my way back....or any day I want delicious mochi. 

Cash Only! And bring lots so you can stock up and maybe share.
author: Patricia K.

description: My favorite was the sweet mochi pancake and the strawberry mochi. The strawberry  mochi had a real strawberry inside. Yumm! The mochi was soo good.They are freshly  made too. I'm so glad I got to try them.  I would definitely  come again whenever I'm at Japantown. This is definely on my "favorites" list.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Hoooo, man. It's a small non-pretentious shop, very unassuming nestled in the center of Japantown ........ only with some of most AMAZING mocha you can get in the city!!! GREAT flavor and texture!! Best of all, not too sweet either!! 

Price is reasonable, CASH only, which normally would tempt me to dock off a star, only because I hate the annoyance of having to deal with cash. (Yes, I've been living in the city for years and still have yet to get used to this. Don't be a hater.) I was also tempted to dock off a star because they close so early and are closed on Sundays - but that's not really on them; I know it's a small business but it just made me sad that I can't come here on a whim to get mocha at a random time in the evening or night. 

Also, the first time I came here?? DON'T MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE I DID AND COME IN RIGHT BEFORE CLOSING AND ORDER ONE MOCHI BECAUSE YOU'RE SKEPTICAL OF THE RAVE REVIEWS. Also come in early so you get your choice of delicious flavors!! The more popular flavors go super fast - AND GOOD REASON. I'm probably buying them all out from under you.
author: Lena Y.

description: Oh my god. I've been living in San Francisco for about 8 years and have only just found this gem. I feel like I've failed my Japanese heritage by not going to this place more often! The mochi here is soooo delicious. The texture is so soft and delicate. When you bite into a piece it's like biting into a cloud! We ordered the strawberry mochi and as soon as I took a bite, I was transported to my childhood days with my grandma and my trips to Japan. I'll definitely recommend this little bakery to anyone looking for some authentic and delicious mochi.
author: Kaydee D.

description:
Mm, mochi. I tried the mugwort and azuki bean one, as well as the blueberry one. I got the first one mainly because I liked the icy green coloring, but the azuki bean innards had a good flavor and weren't too sweet. The blueberry one was more special though since the fresh fruit and the moist rice paste went so well together. Made me want to make a batch of ichigo daifuku of my own a la the microwave method.

$1.10 per piece of mochi at Benkyoudou, which isn't bad since you're getting the fresh stuff and not little frozen squares from typical Japanese marts or those bizarro and yet oh-so-tasty ice cream mochi balls.

There's a little coffee counter area to get some caffeine to go with your mochi. Free wi-fi too, though after being there for about half an hour to check my email and whatnot, one of their regular customers came over to harass me about not making additional purchases. I'm not going to ding Benkyoudou for the awkward sauce ladled on me by a customer since I'm going to cut them some slack and assume he wasn't just a messenger. Perhaps he simply wanted my table, but just a warning for the shopkeep to watch your clientele. I was about to pack up to go anyway, but it certainly makes me less likely to hang out there in the future.

A shame, since the mochi is solid stuff and the atmosphere of older Japanese ladies having coffee is such a calming one.
author: Kevin L.

description: The mochi here are very fresh. The outside is very soft and not too thick. The red bean inside is very smooth. I tried the white and green mochi.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Was staying across the street and happened to try the peanut butter mochi. This is the definition of perfection... east meets west. Better than any reese's peanut butter cup. I usually hate mochi b/c I find it rubbery and bizarre in texture but this mochi skin was silky, soft and melt in your mouth. Contrasted with crunchy peanut butter- oh my gosh. To die for.

Which I brought more home...
author: Jane P.

description:
I need to add this place in my "Hidden Gems of Japantown" list.  Their Wagashi (Japanese sweets) is excellent no matter which one of their creations you try.  Do not mistaken these with packaged wagashi that  are injected with enough preservatives to withstand a decade shelf life.  These are fresh mochi (sticky rice) and anko (red bean) that you could normally only get in Japan.  Their sakura mochi, which was in season, was outstanding.  

Note that Benkyodo could use a good marketing consultant to better present their products and the store.  The reason it took so long for me to try their wagashi was because I thought that this was a cheap hot dog and milk shake joint judging from interior & exterior appearance.  It almost looks like they sell wagashi "on the side".  I know that Tokyo wagashi places over do their presentation and packaging, but a little of that may help Benkyodo expand their customer base.

p.s.  While I am a huge fan of Benkyodo, they should not be #1 in Best of Yelp in Restaurants category (on 2/6/07).  It's a shame that The Dining Room at Ritz is ranked below Benkyodo.
author: トモ T.

description:
This has to be the oddest-looking diner-bakery combo in San Francisco. I've passed by this miniature space at the end of the cobble-stoned Buchanan Street walkway in Japantown a hundred times, but I was never tempted to go in. From the outside at a passing glance, it looks like one of those dives you would find in between a nut store and a pawnshop in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Except here you will not find old men talking about how great Shecky Greene was in the Catskills.

Instead, you think you'll find elderly Japanese frozen in their stools....well, at least the kind you sit on. But it seems to attract all ages. There may be places like Benkyodo within the confines of downtown Tokyo, but I guess I never noticed. Imagine my surprise when it turned out to be a split-identity eatery --- half luncheon counter and half manju bakery. Manju, if you don't know, is the Japanese pastry that sort of looks like Chinese dim sum, though it's not baked --- it's just glutinous rice pounded to oblivion, molded into various geometric shapes and filled with different kinds of fillings.

I finally tried both sides of the schizophrenic Benkyodo with a friend, and each was actually pretty good. I had an egg salad sandwich on white Wonder bread, and it tasted surprisingly fresh especially with a fresh piece of iceberg lettuce and a tomato slice. Very cheap. There are two women who serve at the counter, and there are a couple of small tables, too. You can tell they have a regular clientele because at least three guys just sat there staring out the window without eating or saying anything. I think it would have been nice if they talked to each other.

The other side of the space is actually the main attraction. It's a virtual manju-palooza --- rainbow manju, strawberry manju, peanut butter manju, toasted mochi, and of course the plain manju with the red bean paste inside. Even though I am addicted to starch, I am not that big a manju or mochi fan, as I find them chewy after a couple, but I have to give praise for the peanut butter ones that had to be individually wrapped. The woman told me they were legally bound to wrap them separately. Uh....OK. If you are looking for something a bit different from the Japan Center eateries, this may be worth a try.

FOOD - 4 stars for the manju, 3.5 stars for the egg salad 
AMBIENCE - 2.5 stars 
SERVICE - 4 stars
OVERALL - 4 stars
author: Ed U.

description:
I JUST HAD. THEE BEST. MOCHI. EVER. %@*#&(@$

so soft, so perfect, and each filling is excellent. melt in your mouth. little heavenly clouds. take me away. 

lately i've only been reviewing yelp only in times of urgency. yes,shame. my last one was to warn you yelpers about a horrific experience. this one... O_O drools..

no words.
author: Maiden D.

description: Japantown destination point #1. The friendly clerk was very helpful in describing what each mochi is and giving advice on how to get the whole strawberry mochi (so goooooood). I have been here twice and missed out on it. It is only available on Saturdays and they sell out FAST! She recommends calling in advance and then they will hold some for you which is great! I ordered peanut butter mochi and a blueberry mochi. Peanut butter mochi was very rich and indulgent while the blueberry mochi was fruity. I enjoyed both and would order again. I didn't try the traditional red bean mochi because I feel like you can get that anywhere. I'm saving my five star review for when I try the whole strawberry mochi.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Straight up legit melt-in-your-mouth mochi. 

I'm a mochi monster and heard this was an SF #must. 

I literally had a few minutes to spare before heading to work and I wanted to spend those precious few minutes getting a box of mochi to take back to Virginia (the land that slacks of good Japanese-anything). 

It's such a cute little store on the corner and the Japanese lady that works there is so sweet. I was in such a rush but she tried to educate me on the spread of mochi that she had on display. I had her box up whatever she recommended and she did not let me down!
author: Shannon A.

description: Im impressed by how smooth and soft the red bean inside the mochi is! Superb quality.
author: Veranna N.

description: If you love mochi then this place is for you! These little mochi balls are so soft, tasty and affordable! The fried mochi was my favorite! It was like a donut but better! I could eat these things all day! Its the perfect after dinner dessert or mid day snack. I got one of each and wish I got 5 of each!
author: Nia R.

description: Yummy mochi.. come early for the seasonal fruit ones. It's seldom I make it early enough, but when I know I want something I call in advance! I have tried their famous strawberry and blueberry ones.... DELICIOUS. I swear I have gained at least 5 lbs. just eating here.
author: C M.

description: The best mochi I've ever eaten stateside. The strawberry was, hands down, my favorite (there's an actual piece of strawberry inside), followed by the green tea. The fried donut-style mochi wasn't my favorite, surprisingly enough, but perhaps it was because I didn't have it fresh. I love how small and local the shop feels and the simple packaging is perfect. I'll definitely be back.
author: Melinda L.

description: Family friends bought a box of fresh mochi today and they are DELICIOUS!  So pillowy soft and filled with finely textured and creamy red bean and white bean paste that aren't overly sweet.  The strawberry mochi though was the star for me with its juicy and fresh filling.  My new favorite mochi store eeking out Fugetsu-Do by a small margin =D
author: Eric F.

description:
I walked into this unassuming little corner shop in Japantown and was absolutely transported. I'd been expecting a typical Asian bakery, but was surprised to find that Benkyodo is two parts amazing: half of the space is an old-fashioned diner counter, and the other is an authentic Japanese confectionery. It's all totally quaint and full of quirky flavor.

The legitimacy of this place is undeniable. On the diner side of the restaurant, little groups of elderly Japanese locals sat shooting the breeze over coffee and newspapers. On the bakery side, customers stared longingly at the treats inside the pastry case and purchased mochi by the dozen.

I tried three different types of mochi (white, pink, and strawberry) and they were all sublime. Typically I prefer my desserts with ice cream in the middle (can you blame me?!) -- however, the bean fillings are not only authentic, but just the right amount of sweetness. I'm guessing you can't go wrong with any choice you make here. Benkyodo is a complete and total gem.
author: Julie D.

description:
The only freshest, tastiest mochi shop I know of in the bay area. Besides getting mochi from LA, this is my favorite local mochi shop. 

I cannot wait for summer to arrive because I love strawberry mochi.. guess I am going to have to wait but in the meantime, they have blueberry mochi with real chunks of blueberry in the filling. yum!

This shop is family owned and the owner really knows his mochi. I always stop to pick up some delicious mochi whenever I'm in Japantown.
author: Lauren K.

description: Dropped by Japantown and wanted to try this place out.  The shop is pretty small.  We all tried a strawberry mochi ($1.40 each).  It was delicious.  A lot of flavor packed into the mochi.  There were fresh strawberries inside and the outside was perfectly doughy, soft and chewy with powdered sugar.  I would definitely come back to try some of the other flavors.
author: Christine D.

description:
Since leaving Japan and Hawaii, I haven't had mochi in almost a year, so I thought it was time to finally hunt for it in California.  

I came across Benkyodo and was curious what they might have ...  They have some of the traditional items (mochi with sweet bean paste), but also more modern one's like peanut butter and strawberry mochi.  And yes, there is real strawberry in it!

The mochi was fresh, delicious, and tasted GREAT.  I only wish they had chocolate peanut butter mochi and a few more selections.  However, what they did have was tasty and I'm glad to have found a place that actually makes it here in California.

I'll have to try some of their other items in the future.
author: Mary B.

description:
There is no other place I know of within 100 miles of San Francisco to get the best mochi.  Freshly made, the only way to eat mochi.  Fresh is less than 8 hours.

Come during new years, buy a whole box and delight everyone in your circle of friends and family.

Without flying to Japan, you can't find anything like this.
author: Tony T.

description:
We come here for their mochi - we have never eaten at the grill.  From the looks of it only the locals eat here, most everyone else wants mochi.  Mochi are little pastry like desserts, some have a cake-like exterior some are covered with rice flour dough.  The inside filling is usually made of either red bean or lima bean paste.  

While my description might sound unexciting they are all are delicious and wonderful to look at.  

Benkyodo's specialties are the seasonal fruit mochi (strawberries in summer, blueberries most of the other time) and their peanut butter mochi.  These are exquisite. If you don't get there early (like before 1:00PM) you may not find any of the fruit or peanut butter mochi left.  What we do is call ahead and order in advance.  They hold the mochi for us.  Prices are $1.50 each I believe, might be a small variance depending on the type.
author: Ethan Z.

description: A good place to get some really soft, tasty mochi. It looks very hole in the wall and is easily passed by. A nice sweet treat if you can catch it within their limited operating hours.
author: Timothy L.

description: I usually always take pictures of what I eat so that I can post them onto Yelp.  I failed to do that when visiting Benkyodo because the mochi/manju were just that amazing.  I didn't have much cash when I went, though, so I only got to try a couple: the yomogi daifuku and one filled with anko.  So. Good.  And really reasonably priced too, considering how delicious and well made they are!  I cannot wait to come back!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
love, Love, LOVE this place!
The texture, the flavor, and the freshness makes this place the best place to go for manju.
author: Julie L.

description:
Peanut butter mochi was solid. Blueberry was kind of strange.. the texture of the filling just felt off. 

I want to give more stars because they were very nice.. maybe if i try a couple more one day..
author: Eugene Z.

description:
I have never had a legit mochi/manju experience until the day I walked into this cute little place. My boyfriend and I walked in and I saw all the different kinds of mochi and stuff. I was mesmerized. I didn't know there were so many different kinds. Immediately I was lost and asked for some guidance from my boyfriend. I realized I shouldn't be asking him so I asked the nice lady behind the counter to help and she was kind and patient with me =] We ended up ordering a whole bunch of mochi and stuff, but I was extremely excited for the strawberry mochi. 

After leaving with our box of mochi that was wrapped and tied with ribbon, my boyfriend and I ran to the car and immediately tried some mochi. It was delicious, the strawberry was the best. It is gooey and chewy and filled with actual strawberries! If you order this you have to eat them within 2 days (the day you got it and the next day, because since it is made fresh the strawberries and other stuff will not be as good after.) The others were great as well but the strawberry one will forever be in my mind when I think of mochi! =]
author: Jayne A.

description: Awsome way to start the day the lady working there was super friendly. She gave us lots of tips and places to go. Also the prices are cheap and its a local mom and pops shop (supporter of home businesses) also the fresh made mochi was so so so ono! (Delicious) i had the red bean filled mochi with soybean powder on it and its was awsome my girlfried had the strawberry she loved it. To sum it up its a super great comfy feeling place to start your day of with a smile!
author: Royce N.

description:
[M]ona: 3.5 Stars
[W]ayne: 3 Stars
Average: 3.25 Stars

+ Fresh Mochi
+ Mochi with Real Fruit Filling
+ Makes Great Gifts
+ Conveniently Located Close to Japantown

- Closes Early (8am - 5pm)
- Cash Only
 
[W] This Japanese spot specializes in making Mochi. The only thing that sucks about his place is that it's always closed whenever we try to go. I'm not a big fan of sweets and desserts so this place was okay to me. This is also a cash only spot as well which kind of sucks. The store is conveniently located near the Japantown Mall so it's all walking distance within shopping and other restaurants. Parking is usually fine during weekdays but during the weekends....that's a whole lot of patience you must have haha.
 
[M] We tried the Strawberry Mochi http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=rLAuRgwbauLT6grhGxTWpQ and three other ones with Anko inside http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=DwvO_xnEFZlWar6c5qQv_Q. My favorite are the ones with the fruit fillings. They are made with chunks of fresh fruits. The strawberry and blueberry is a must try! The ones with Anko (Red Beans) inside are alright. It's softer than the packaged ones you get at Nijiya or at other grocery stores but nothing out of the ordinary.

[W] These mochis would make great gifts but if it was me personally, I think I would just prefer the ice cream mochis instead.
author: Mona C.

description:
Went here after reading all the rave reviews and being a sucker for mochi I couldn't resist checking this place out during my recent trip to SF.

Yes lives up to the hype! The mochis are incredibly soft and melt-in-your-mouth delicious. They remind me of the ones I'd buy back in Japan around my house. Not too sweet (a problem with pre-packaged ones I find) and had the right balance of mochi and filling. They were so good I went back before leaving and bought a plate of 8 to bring back (which was roughly a $1 per mochi). My mom agrees they are delicious and had that familiar authentic taste.

The lady selling them is very sweet as well. I love family-owned businesses so I really hope they keep this place open for years to come! It is cash or cheque only so bring lots of bills!
author: Shiori M.

description:
They don't really need another review but their mochi is AMAZING. My Japanese mother states it is the best she has ever had. 

Also of note, I placed an order of 75 mochi for my wedding. It was easy to call and place the order - we had no problems. 

Now my mom keeps trying to drop subtle hints about bringing her more mochi...
author: nikko m.

description:
After the little old lady who sold mochi downstairs in the Japantown building (same side as Benihana's), I didn't know where else to go! Thank goodness Benkyodo was there to the rescue!! With lots of mochi varieties I can't wait to eat them all! The only problem here is that they usually sell out before noon!! :(

Would it be possible to special order from them?? Hmmm...
author: Kristen C.

description: Not much to say.  This place is the OG mochi & manju spot in SF.  They supply a ton of places, and basically are the top dog in mochi in the Bay Area.  My wife who is from hawaii says it reminds her of places on the island.  But yeah, the mochi here is the shiznizz~!!
author: Arthur Y.

description: Loveee Benkyodo. Strawberry mochi season is over, but that's okay. I still love the  blueberry mochi and the peanut butter mochi. Just preordered some today for my friend's birthday tomorrow (It's awesome that they allow this!). I hope she likes it, although I already know she will. The red bean ones are good too. But some of my friends don't really like it. So I just buy strawberry, blueberry, and peanut butter for friends. But when it's just me, I can eat em all. Yummm. Not only are the mochis great, but so are the owners. They're really friendly, and I'm always very pleased when I leave the place.
author: April D.

description:
Service is great. I went in to "try" mochi. I ended up getting 7. I tried the blueberry first it was SO sweet! I only bit into it once.
I also tried the pancake with bean filling and that one was less sweet but still too sweet for my liking. I planned to take the rest home to LA since my boyfriend wasn't a fan either. 

I went back and got 2 donuts, those were really good. I also got 2 hot chocolates ( they weren't good) I guess because they come from a package. 

Anyways, if you're not a fan of mochi, I wouldn't go. 

I am definitely not a fan of it, too sweet. :(

I spent $12 dollars on all this, that's the good part.
author: Yessenia O.

description:
Who Loves Mochi! I do! This place is by far the best I've ever ate.  The owners are very nice! Left side of you have a fresh mochi and japanese snacks and on the right you have a hot dog / hamburger stand.  

The mochi is so good, I went there 3 times last week.  The mochi is worth every penny.  I heard from the owners that this mochi store has been in the family for over 106 years.  Wow talk about history and a gem in SF J-town.  I wish they moved here to LA J-town.  

Monday-Wednesday they have Blueberry Mochi and on Thursday - Saturday they have Strawberry Mochi.  During the week they serve the red bean and lima bean paste mochi as well. All very fresh and so yummy.  Strawberry is my favorite but they are all good I would love for my friends from SF to bring me some!  

I hope you all try this place, I want to go back even now.  This should be in the 7x7 San Francisco 100 things you should eat before you die!
author: G C.

description:
My friend recently bought some mochi for me to try, and O-M-G, they are sooooo good!  I've never heard of this place, but if I had earlier, I would've came here all the time!

He got us the red bean and white bean, which I thought red bean was better, but they were both still really good.
