I tried it the day after it was purchased, and it still tasted soft and fresh to me.  People say you need to eat them fresh, but I can only imagine how much better it would've tasted fresh.  

Even though I've only tried two flavors, I already fell in love with the place! I would definitely make a trip to try more next time!
author: Nancy S.

description: I came at the end of the day, so I'm guessing that explains their lack of variety. But I did try their strawberry and green bean Mochi and it was delicious!  Will be coming back, hopefully earlier this time
author: M G.

description:
Their mochi is the bomb.com

Looks like a diner from the outside, never would have walked in if my friend didn't tell me to go there. But, I'm sure glad I did. Had the original red bean one & the blueberry one - both were really good. Why am I just NOW hearing about this place? MMM, nomnomnoms.
author: Denise L.

description:
STRAWBERRY MOCHI!

either call and tell them to reserve you one or go early like before noon. they only make these I believe... on wed to friday or something. so call before you make the trip
author: Erica L.

description:
Love.

Came here after eating lunch at Tanpopo. There were soooo many choices. I bought six because I ran outta dough (see what I did there?).  Place is cash only. I absolutely loved their red bean filling and strawberry mochi. Oh gosh. So amazing.

Mochi is made daily. New flavors everyday. So fresh.. so soft.. heaven. *faints
author: Tiffany H.

description: Hands down the best mochi you can buy.  Words can't describe how soft and fresh the mochi is here...you just have to try it.  I can't tell you how many times my asian friends have suggested 'good' mochi places and yet, nothing comes remotely close to what Benkyodo creates.  My favorite is the blueberry mochi and white bean paste.  I would eat these everyday if they weren't so loaded with calories!
author: Debbie L.

description:
We live along the SF Peninsula, which for us, is a centrally located for access to San Francisco, San Jose, and the East Bay.  The bad thing, however, is that we're too far for Shuei-Do in San Jose and Benkyodo in San Francisco.

Fortunately, we just finished our family CNY banquet lunch (), and still had the afternoon to digest our food, and to have some snacks for the rest of the day.  I was going to suggest some ice cream, but wife suggested that since we're in the City, let's head to Benkyodo first.

Brilliant idea, and the kids thought so too!  A doubleheader of sweet stuff today!

As long as I can remember, I've coming here for years for their mochi and manju.  There's nothing like freshly made mochi and manju.  Their delicately chewy exterior, wrapped around different kinds of smooth bean paste.  Depending on the season, some mochi and manju are filled with fresh fruit.

Parking was difficult this mid-afternoon, so my wife and my oldest daughter hopped out of the car, and entered the store to make their choices and purchases, while I circled around the car.  The came back out with a nicely wrapped box of mochi and manju (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=Gbj56mCsL9nJmpgFQDedBg).  The kids wanted to open the box right then and have one, but I convinced them to wait after we get ice cream.

Of course they agreed.

When we got home, we opened up the box and starting eating a few (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=RLDwgKpw6qoQedYPVqqTvg).  They ran out of their seasonal apple manju and their blueberry mochi, but we buy a couple of their chocolate marshmallow mochi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=FS5Gx9OybmKOieyBxP9PYg).  The rice exterior had a nice chocolate taste, blending well with the mochi taste.  Inside, there was a marshmallow inside the red bean paste (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=msXV8PYIz0f6vZ9V0cyAhg).  Yum!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=T0upy2IKWQVa4xAi4gVaQQ
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=dN5XMPHmoY19Ggwl8HMpyg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=-Fq-X5dz-iZ3s1QQfr_1dA
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=jfY8S08HrHj_sASVYZ8Row

By the end of the night, the box was empty.  All so good!
author: Steve L.

description:
Benkyodo mochis are my happy food. They are sweet but will not make your tooth ache. They are  fun yummy treats and just  very cute food!

Blueberry Mochi (Look at the whole fresh blueberries!) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=bWy1BVnBmJgCVVw00JJv5A

Peanut Butter Mochi (Oh, so chunky peanut buttery delicious!) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=vNJGHUALT30ORbfzxizi0g

And the cutest mochi of all: Bean Mochi with a tiny red heart! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=yPYbXBxwgv6Hd2Ms3NHY8A

If you haven't had mochis from Benkyodo yet and you live in the Bay Area....you are missing out on one of life's little joys.  (For those who live faraway, you are excused!)

Visit Benkyodo in Japantown for freshly made mochis at  this  momma and poppa store.  No preservatives added. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=wNuMY6ZhOHPtM3xYTN43YQ

And the cherry blossoms are starting to bloom right now!!! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=1D5VUOVxWC48dgB6iZ2GLQ http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=oSxn-sAg2_dA-MZIPdcg2A

5 cute, sweet and happy mochis: $5.50
author: Leah E.

description:
Old-world traditional flavor. 
I've never had mochi as good as this.
Not mass-produced. Handmade does make a difference.
My favorite is the Strawberry, Green Tea and the effin' PEANUT BUTTER!!!
BONUS: Spotted an incredible M3 on the way out with this killer matte gray paint job and 19"or20" VMRs. He had Kanye's "Flashing Lights" blaring. 

...Old mixed with the New, I guess
...Enjoy while you can! Nothing lasts forever!
author: Derek N.

description:
Every time I go to Japantown, Benkyodo is a place I HAVE to go to in order to bring home fresh mochi! I love buying extra and bringing them home to my mom, she loves mochi, but anywhere outside of Jtown... really hard to find fresh HAND MADE mochi.

These things are made with fresh ingredients that if you let it sit past 2 days, it will spoil and get moldy so eat it when you get it or freeze it like my mom cause she can't eat a dozen in a day and she lives so far from the city that I can't bring them to her all the time.

Don't expect to get the same types of mochi everyday, it changes every time I go there. Which is awesome for me cause I get to try everything! nom nom nom
author: Erica T.

description:
Munching on my blueberry mochi ($1.10)
Only getting the fruity flavors next time
Cash or check ONLY
Hope to try the strawberry mochi when in season
I lost my appetite for mochi once the mochi server started yelling

This place has been bookmarked for quite some time now. I was excited to finally visit this store and try some good mochi! 

I've never encountered a cranky, old Japanese lady before until I came here. When I was in the middle of ordering, the Japanese lady behind the counter started yelling at the tourist behind me to stop taking pictures. She was kinda rude and was hard of hearing. I kept repeating which flavors I had wanted and she still couldn't hear me. ugh. I almost didn't feel like ordering after that because it was just awkward. I hope this was just a one off situation and she isn't normally that rude to customers. =\

But I was HERE already, so I got...

- Blueberry ($1.10): YUM! A few blueberries inside!
- Age ($1): donut hole filled with red bean and covered with granulated sugar
- Habutae ($1): white mochi with red bean filling
- Pink Habutae ($1): pink mochi with red bean filling
-------------------------------
Total: $4.10

After consuming these all, I only liked the blueberry. haha Overall, the mochi here was too doughy and thick. I definitely like the ones in Downtown San Jose's Japantown (Shuei-Do Manju Shop) A LOT MORE!! 

Tip:
- CASH or check ONLY
- Don't take pics once inside
- If in season, try the blueberry and/or strawberry... it's worth the extra $.10

Go green: take muni #2, 3, 4, 22, or 38
author: CeCe C.

description:
Life sucks sometimes. Case in point - I came here specifically for the strawberry mochi and was told it's a seasonal offering that's unavailable in the winter. Holy firetruck. I almost threw a conniption fit right then and there. 

Luckily, I managed to stay composed like the demure lady that I am and tried a few of the available varieties. Could it be that I don't like red bean-filled mochi? I lost interest after just a bite, which is rare for me. To its credit, the actual mochi tasted fresh and soft, and the Chofu (pancake wrap with plain sweet rice) was pretty good. However, all of the other ones made me feel sick.

I'll be back during strawberry season.
author: Suany W.

description: Best mochi in town and for so cheap.  They've been around since the 50s, and that says a lot for a business in San Francisco.  Line out the door and worth the wait.  So happy my friend Pauline L. showed me Benkyodo.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Darn you Benkyodo.....because of you I will never be able to eat "mochi" from Asian supermarkets again! You showed me the light.....how *real* fresh mochi is suppose to taste like. 

These handmade sweet rice balls will rock your world. I am absolutely smitten by the blueberry mochi. It's a unique flavor- soft gooey mochi surrounds sweet fresh juicy blueberries! They have delicious "traditional" flavors like mung bean or red bean, but every time I'm in Japantown (which is every other week for work meetings) I have to pop into this little shop for some sweet pick-me-up.

Benkyodo "shares" a store space with an old-school Japanese diner that serves burgers, melts, and such. You can just feel the authentic neighborhood feel of this place as older Japanese gents and ladies gather here to chat and sip coffee. You can really feel the history in this place. 

The storeowner is super nice- she apologized for the long wait and realized I only wanted 1 mochi- so she gave me a discount. Lots of people come to buy full boxes, great for gifts. 

Cash only!
author: Eva H.

description:
The texture of the mochi at this place is perfect. Soft and chewy! Erm... but I kinda have some beef with the amount of sugar in the fillings. The only flavor I can tolerate is the blueberry which I love! 

Please please please; I beg of you oh wonderful people at Benkyodo, to add less sugar to your fillings. It would make a better product and I would be able to eat more of them!! 

Oh just thinking about eating a whole box in one sitting makes me sooo happy.
author: Shum S.

description: This is the fastest visit-to-review turnaround I've ever done on Yelp, and for good reason: the mochi here are second-to-none! The bean paste they are filled with is velvety and a bit sweeter than the ones you pick up at the Asian supermarket. They're also more delicate, literally like little pillows. And what a surprise it was to find actual blueberries in my blueberry mochi! Only (minor) downsides are that they're on the sticky side and are around $1.20 each but I guess it's reasonable since the mochi are handmade. I still have to get my hands on those elusive strawberry mochi. Nevertheless, Benkyodo, you've earned a spot on my must-haves list!
author: Caralisa L.

description: It's hard to find authentic mochi. Benkyodo usually has a few flavors available. I love their red bean, and when they have it, the cherry blossom one. I'm not a huge fan of kinako, but I definitely want to try that next time. The mochi here is not too sweet, which is just the way I like it.
author: Sherry L.

description: I arrived kind of late and all of the fruit flavor ones were gone with the exception of blueberry. Even though I'm not a big fan of blueberry, it was pretty good so I can imagine what all of the other fruit flavors taste like. The tupical flavors, like red bean, are just OK. I'll give them another try but I'll have to make sure that I go really early next time.
author: Diane M.

description: Fresh mochi mmmmm. The blueberry was not what I expected though! There were a few blueberries in one corner of the mochi ball and they weren't sweet at all. I guess I'll have to try the other recommended flavors!
author: Kermy K.

description:
was here super early to set up for the cherry blossom festival and nothing was open yet except this place. and i remembered i had bookmarked it, so i decided to go in.

small, one side looked like a diner selling coffee and donuts, the other is the mochi!

I had no idea what to get, so I ordered six different ones.

strawberry- definitely my favorite, real strawberries and sauce in a thick mochi over. a little too thick to me though
green tea-....green tea mochi with red bean filling i think, my second favorite.
the rest.....were okay, eating them made my mouth kind of try, you need some hot tea to eat with these....6-7$ for 6, kind of pricey, but if you're just visiting, don't hesitant to stop by!
author: Christine M.

description: I went to Japantown only to eat at Benkyodo. I grabbed a blueberry mochi and..wow. Absolutely delicious! Just the right amount of sugar and the blueberry flavoring was delicious. I usually don't like chunks of fruit in desserts, but the pieces of blueberry in this mochi had the finesse to pull it off. I'm coming back!
author: Zak C.

description:
This mochi is even softer than the ones you get in Little Tokyo (Los Angeles), I have to admit. Traditional and non-traditional choices are both yummy. Check out the shelves of senbei and other snacks, too.

Eat in or take out. Our "plate" of selected 8 pieces was packaged in a rectangular plastic take-out box, perfect for road tripping.
author: Elle V.

description: this place has mochi. we've gotten a box twice and not regretted it. we are partial to the mochi that have fruit inside. we think they are often too sweet and that there is too much filling in the bean ones. the vibe and decor of the place are pretty cool though-- it looks like a diner. they sell hot dogs... and mochi... and probably other stuff.
author: Matt J.

description: They are fresh, soft and yummy! I love the red bean paste in all the mochi. They also have great green bean paste too which gives a break from everything red bean.
author: Emily C.

description:
After eating more mochi than humanly possible while I was in Hawaii, I've been hankering for more. I did a Yelp search for mochi and Benkyodo came up. I finally made it here one Sunday after dim sum and I wish I'd gotten here earlier. They were sold out of most of the things I wanted to get! Grumph!! :(

I suppose that was a blessing in disguise since it saved me from my gluttonous self. I just got a CHOFU (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=tMjdRD_l2zuAw8QQkdgfMg) and YOMOGI (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0100LAmvjZPFjEPswwrDBQ?select=OJ0AYwUFV5AFPJ9bXzwGOQ). The chofu was plain sweet mochi wrapped in a pancake and the yomogi was green mochi with red beans. Both were great! The mochi was fresh and soft, like what I had in Hawaii. I actually liked the chofu better because it has more chewy mochi goodness. 

Will definitely make it back here to try their other selections. Now, if only I can find mochi ice cream as good as Bubbie's in SF...
author: Steph L.

description: One of my favorite places to get Mochi and Manju. My grandma who is of Japanese decent really loves this place because she said the way it's made is how it's like in Japan, not overly sweet like other desserts from different countries. She also loves how it reminds her a little bit of her homeland. For me I love this place because of how I can get a taste of traditional Japanese flavors and how friendly staff is. The only downside is how small it is like traditional shops in Japan. But if you're just going for the desserts it should not be a problem. I don't have just one favorite flavor when I visit here because all of them are amazing. So if your looking for authentic flavor come to this place.
author: Grace M.

description: The best mochi in town! a good variety and flavors at that. Mochi's are baked/cooked fresh and tastes so good. The ladies who helped me out with my order to take back home to florida are so nice and so friendly, they even hooked me up with a couple of extra mochis on top of my order. Just remember, IT'S CASH ONLY..good thing i had enough to pay for my order and tip the lady.
author: Thara F.

description: I've never had mochi THIS light soft and cloudlike. Even that fanciest mochi store on market Street doesnt have mochi this soft and delicate. The blueberry one had whole blueberries in it. The mango had real mango pieces and they were so fresh and perfumey - not at all canned. These are craftspeople at work here. Its artisinal. Eight pieces of freshly made came to under ten dollars. That's amazing.
author: Nan L.

description:
This place is a Jtown institution.  I've heard rave reviews about their mochi from friends and family.  After finally making it into Benkyodo recently, I can attest that they make the most legit mochi I've gotten my paws on!

They sell their red bean mochi for $1.10 each. They also sell boxes, I got a dozen for 12 bucks: 3 of each of the red bean-filled mochi.  Therefore, I guess there is a slight discount when you buy in bulk. They charge slightly more for the strawberry mochi. 

The mochi tastes fresh. Both the skin and filling of the mochi is soft, smooth and not overly chewy. It's the perfect consistency. It's like taking a bite out of heaven!
author: Matt S.

description:
Yumtastic mochi!

I love the strawberry mochi in the summer, and blueberry ones during the other parts of the year.  (the few times I risk it and eat fruit is for these tasty things)
author: Bon N.

description:
I think this place is cute!

When you've been coming to Japantown for years and have tried every fancy dessert they have to offer, it's refreshing to see a place with less frills.  I went in one afternoon, and the tiny place was PACKED.  Not only that, I was greeted by the strongest smell of coffee EVER.  Not that I'm complaining, I drink strong coffee like it's water.  There was a group of older folks chatting up a storm in the corner, and the lady who was serving them offered them a box full of donuts.  I got a little confused at that point, because the sign outside led me to believe that it was a mochi joint.  But I turned around and bam!  There was the mochi!

I guess I came in a little late, because all the peanut butter mochi sold out.  If you want to see more mochi, definitely come in the morning or right after lunch.  Even if you arrive a little later, you'll still have some good mochi.  I tried the Blueberry and Azuki bean, which were very good.  I also tried the Apple Manju, which I LOVED.  

The lady helping us was so nice and friendly. She mentioned that they'll be making strawberry mochi soon, so I look forward to going back. :)
author: Kai C.

description:
i remember back in the 80s when i was a little squirt frequenting j-town with my mom.  j-town was still authentic then...and the food was actually good.  we'd always stop by one of the restaurants in the mall and head over to benkyodo to grab a box of mochi.  this was the highlight of my outing.  the place hasn't changed since...

the place still looks rundown...it has been open since 1906.  if you weren't from the city, you'd probably never find this place other than from word of mouth.  it's on a little corner...a little intimidating if you don't have a purpose of being there.  but once you walk in, you'll see a really old school cafe to your right...and if you look to your left, you'll see a glass case full of different types of manju.  every person i brought here couldn't decide which ones to get.  and i always tell them the same thing...GET THE STRAWBERRY!  get 2 or 3 while you're at it.  and then...get one of everything else.  haha.  

today, we got 2 strawberry, 2 rainbow(plain sweet rice, 1 chofu(pancake wrap with plain sweet rice), 1 habutai(white mochi with smooth red beans), and 1 pink habutai(pink mochi with smooth white lima beans).  this came out to a little under $8.00.  awesome price considering the amount of work that goes into making these things.  

oh, and this place normally gets pretty busy and they tend to run out of a few types...it's the ONLY place to get quality mochi...5 stars to benkyodo!
author: Jen W.

description:
Found this place on yelp and have been dying to try their mochi. Only when i get in, I can't find the mochi, but a burger counter serving deli style foods. To the left i see a tiny counter with various mochi goodness. I was pretty disappointed with the gimicky American filling mochis. We tried:

Blueberry mochi -- probably the best of the unconventional mochis, strong blueberry flavor
Cherry blossom mochi (seasonal) - had a fragrant cherry blossom leaf wrapped around the red bean mochi, it smelled better than it tasted.
Apple mochi -- lame. baked apple pie inside. I do have to say it probably took some work to wrap mochi around the flaky crust.
Smooth red bean mochi--the classic, a must have.
Chocolate marshmallow-- supposedly their most popular, Bad bad bad.
I didn't try to the white bean paste mochi, but i heard it's super popular too.

Overall, the mochi it self was the winner, I think it's even hand pounded in the back. The line was manageable but there was a consistent line.   One cute Japanese grandma cut in front of me to order a sandwich, but since she reminded me of my own shameless grandma, I reminisced and let it slide.
author: William H.

description:
Finally tried the infamous Benkyodo. It's a blast from the past. Think mid-century diner with a side of mochi. These guys make they chewy, flavorful treat on site and sell out in the afternoon, so if you want to try a variety of flavors, come early. 

Oh, and the diner feel is complete with those bubblegum style mid-century light fixtures I covet.
author: Lee H.

description:
I was craving something sweet, cheap, and not heavy. Since I was passing by Japantown and I like walking on those cobblestone paths, I ended up at this place. It had an old school diner/candy store feeling to it, which I liked.

I'm going to admit that the only mochi that I've ever eaten were those pre-packed ones. And I thought those weren't bad. Now, that I've tried fresh mochi from here, those pre-packed ones are ruined forever.

I had a blueberry mochi and the white type of mochi with red bean in it. After the first bite of the red bean, I could tell that this was freshly made that day. Though what was even better was that the blueberry mochi had fresh blueberries inside of it!! So good.

The cashier lady was nice as well and gave me a discount because she said the mochi she was selling me was smaller than usual. I gladly accepted but I couldnt tell. They were still bigger than the pre-packed ones.

I only wish that this place was open later, but this place has a quality product. Try it out! I had two mochis for around 2 dollars!!! I'm sure you have two dollars in change lying around that you don't know what to do with or that will end up behind your couch. Might as well get a mochi.

5 stars!!!!!
author: Brian M.

description: The store is tiny and can be easily missed if you have never been there before. It's like a little bakery with a few bar stools if you want to order some drinks while shopping for mochi. I love how soft and fresh each mochi taste. The strawberry ones are my favorite, but they usually run out in an hour. I usually get eight in a box and share with my friends. Sometimes I just order that for myself. :D The origami store next door is pretty cool to check out too.
author: Ran T.

description:
I've tried a few mochi's so far - store bought, home made, the mochi shop in SJ...but this is THE place to get mochi. I've never had anything like it. 

It's melt-in-your-mouth soft but it still holds together. So sweet and tasty. 
We bought a few - green mungbean on outside with redbean on inside, white mochi with lima bean paste on inside (I even had a dream about lima bean paste after), and the regular white mochi with redbean on the inside. The last two are the favs. 

The shop is a corner diner split into an eating section and a mochi shop. Service was good. Love the history of this shop. 

And as others have noted this place is cash only!
author: Lori L.

description:
Still going strong, and an additional star for being the last Japanese-family owned place in this area as far as I know since the Sakai grocery shop closed.

Please support this wonderful shop!
author: George T.

description:
Walked in at noon on a Tuesday, was served promptly by a gentleman. Although I'd done a thorough read of things regarding this establishment, there were in fact signs (in bright green) underneath each item explaining what each mochi or manju (dessert) contained & their price. 

I had been in the mood for "sakura mochi", it being the season and all, but didn't realize this establishment made their own! Many time I've bought the 3 to a package (in Styrofoam) available in the supermarkets for $4. However, the last time I bought one it wasn't fresh and attempting to revive it with a little steam didn't work well either. This time I was GUARANTEED fresh and each mochi was $1.25 -- a tiny bit cheaper, plus I could just get TWO, which is perfect for me. Further, they were individually wrapped in saran wrap.

Quickly I was being rung up, but the REAL reason I'd walked in was because of all the rave reviews about the strawberry mochi here (although, I was fine with blueberry too). Since I hadn't seen them inside the counter, I asked gently if they had any strawberry or blueberry. I almost never bother to ask if something exists that I don't see -- I'm the opposite of the believer in a magic storage room. But I'm glad I did so, because immediately the man said, "Yes, blueberry!" 

And from the back, after a little looking, they were produced. Then I was politely asked if the two different types of mochi could be packed together. Yes, that was fine. He took the sakura out of their little bag and placed them in a plastic container that protected them from being crushed. 

Blueberry pie happens to be my favorite pie, and it is a dying breed. In fact, if you know of a DECENT, PLAIN BLUEBERRY PIE in San Francisco -- please tell me. Anyway, this mochi was like biting into a perfect slice of blueberry pie! I moaned! It was that good. The fragrance wafting out of the box was heavenly. I've also eaten a lot of mochi and this was STILL shockingly good and soft in texture. I'm saving the other for a friend and it's going to be hard not to keep it for myself. 

Sakura mochi (cherry blossom rice cake) is distinctively a blush pink with a leaf wrapped around half of it -- the entire thing is edible, although you can pick the leaf off if you prefer. Personally, I love eating leaves; grape leaves or Hawaiin ti-leaf are the stuff to me. The rice is not pounded into a dough, as in other mochi, but left whole creating a pleasant texture. Inside is smooooth red bean paste. The outside of the mochi will have a cherry fragrance, more subtle than a true flavor, more like an essence that is imparted when you eat. Additionally, there is a quick pat of salty water to the outside, so that a salty flavor also hits your tongue and emphasizes the sweetness by contrasting it. Not a complaint from me. It delivered.

Another yelper compared this mochi to a fancy chocolate shop and their certainly is a similarity in the combining of: flavors, textures, tradition, experimentation, and freshness! I can't wait to see my friend's reaction to their share of treats!
author: Ziggy J.

description:
What everyone else says - super soft, squishy, chewy fresh mochi!

I picked up 38 pieces for a plane ride back to Vancouver, BC.  STILL GOOD two days later :) .. 

By far my favourite was the fresh strawberry mochi.  Also enjoyed the crunchy peanut butter mochi.
author: Janice F.

description:
Fresh Strawberry Mochi!
Lima Bean!  Yum!
Hands down best Mochi in SF.
author: Liz A.

description: Mochi is fresh and soft, the way it should be. You can tell they make it with love. We had a strawberry and a peanut butter flavor. The peanut butter was the crunchy type , so it gave the mochi a good consistency since the PB itself is pretty thick. It also added a slight salty note, so is good for those that enjoy the salty/sweet combo.  If they made a chocolate flavor, I would be way thrilled. Hopefully that's in their future plans.
author: Lelly L.

description:
We're all guilty of purchasing those pre-packaged mochis from the asian supermarket. You haven't had a real mochi until you've tasted one of theirs!

I felt a little disoriented walking in here. I thought this is a bakery?! Why's there a tiny diner-like space as well?! Did I step into the wrong place??

Ordering can be a little difficult as not all of them are labeled. There is a tiny picture menu taped to the side of the register, of their regular items, I suppose. But still, it was hard to look at those, read the description and try to match up to the ones in the case. I didn't want to be one of those annyoing incompetent customers who point and ask what EACH one were. She left and came back and I felt pressured into just ordering anything! I left with 2 strawberry mochi's, a apple manju and something else I can't remember. 

It's ever-so soft and delectable! I thought mochi's are mochi's--glutinous desserts. Boy was I wrong! You can taste the freshness of theirs and the real fruit in the center confirms it's the real deal, none of that high fructose flavoring stuff. 

I was a little bummed that when I went, there wasn't as much of a variety of flavors available (where is the sesame, pb or green tea?!?!) or anything too familiar to me, but I shall pop in everyone once and again to see what their seasonals are. 

I didn't care for the manju, it reminded me of lunar mooncakes and was a little dry. Go for th mochis!!!
author: Ly T.

description:
As good as they say, the fresh strawberry actually HAS fresh strawberries in it! The lima bean was great, not as sickly sweet as so much lotus paste turn out. Friendly staff that somehow manages the crazy lines (and lots of locals in that line, always a happy sign).

Kind of off the moche topic, but I totally want to go back, sit at the counter, and have a good old american hamburger (then maybe some moche for desert).
author: David M.

description:
I called in at 12:30 and told the friendly man on the phone: "I want a dozen strawberry mochis." He didn't go, "Wow that's a lot" and without a single pause agreed and told me to pick it up within two hours because they were just starting to make them FRESH. 

If you don't know what mochi is, Benkyodo Co. is the best place to be introduced to this Japanese treat. Their strawberry mochi is a cool, sweet delight that oozes into your mouth with a tangy bit of fresh strawberry fruit. It's a seasonal treat, summer only, as they worth with fresh fruits. It's a treat that can hold it's own because eating a mochi from Benkyodo is like eating art. Specifically the strawberry kind. One bite  and you can taste how perfectly crafted a mochi is. It's hard to fight against the chewy outside texture and the gooey inside sweetness with powdery dryness. Beautiful combination.

Oh my god, I cannot stop. I'm coming home on Saturday and Japantown is my first stop (like always).

I've tried their blueberry mochi once. It wasn't as good as the strawberry, but for people who like a less sweet option; blueberry mochi is the way to go. Other than that, the other mochi flavours: green tea, lima bean, red bean are just as delightful, but not as sweet as the fruity ones.

My only problem is remembering the names. I always go, "What's that? What's that?" Because there's also this GREAT donut/red bean ball that tastes like an Asian krispy kreme delight (w/o frosting). My cousin got it for kicks but once we bit in, we were fighting over the tiny piece. Dreaming about this right now. 

oh, before you get excited in your knickers: CASH ONLY.
author: Christal Y.

description:
Seriously tasty mochi. I wish we had gone here straight away on Saturday morning instead of waiting until 3pm. Be sure that if you are going to visit this place to go early in the morning, as they will run out by the middle of the day! BEWARE: They are closed on Sundays. 

I got one mochi piece that looked tasty and believe me it was! I look forward to coming back here to get a box of mochi, manjuu and dango goodies to take home next time!
author: Tisha G.

description: Great place for those who like to try something different. I only had mochi ice cream before but this is very different. I would recommend the fruity ones, which come with real fruit inside. Weird texture but worth trying. Whilst trying our assortiment, I couldn't help but think of Harry Potter's candies.
author: Patricia D.

description:
Since I was little, this was one of my favorite places to go whenever my family went to Japantown. We'd all cram into the little shop (half of it is an adorable 70s-style diner!) and each pick 2 kinds of manju and then the lady behind the counter would wrap it all up in paper and a bow and we'd take it back home to enjoy. 

The manju they make at Benkyodo is divine. The soft, little balls of goodness are filled with sweet surprises. my favorite are the pink ones with smooth white bean or the gray ones with smooth red bean. I've yet to be in the shop when they have the strawberry manju, though my brother tells me they're amazing! 

This place has been special to my family for a while, and I'm so glad that they're still around. My great-grandmother used to take the bus from Chinatown just to pick up manju for my dad and his siblings! 

And at $1.10 a piece, it's such an affordable treat too. :)
author: Monica C.

description: I have to give 5 stars for my mochi craving.   Though the ones in Hawaii are more to my liking, this comes close.  Right now, I am raving about the blueberry mochi. Fresh blueberry in the kuri an.  What's not to love? I love mochi.  And their an pan is also awesome. My staple at Tokyo Fish.
author: Marck N.

description: Best mochi's you can buy! Strawberry and the peanut butter ones are the ticket but come early cuz they sell out quick. Heard the hot food is good also, as I'm writing this review I'm jonesing for one of their hot dogs.
author: T L.

description: The best manju in town.  I love it.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Don't let the exterior of this place fool you...it's a hidden gem!!  Freshly made mochi & manju.... yum!!!  I can't explain it...but it's just the right amount of simplicity, paired with the right amount of sweet and homemade goodness.  For those looking for an inexpensive treat, this is definitely one of the places you should visit while in SF's Japantown.  The owners Bobby & Rick are super nice guys as well.
author: Vindy C.

description: Love this place!  Love getting fresh mochi!  I don't care what others say, yes, I love the original redbean mochi but the blueberry mochi is DELICIOUS!!!  If I could, I'd eat a 1/2 dozen but I refrain and will have a couple a day until they are all gone.  So fresh, so awesome...
author: Michelle S.

description: I came here twice in a week, both times spending about $25 on mochi for friends, family and of course myself. I was sad to find out they no longer make the chocolate marshmallow. They did however have peanut butter and blueberry which are really good. If you love fresh and chewy mochi, you must stop by Benkyodo. They do run out certain flavors, so come early!
author: Adelina W.

description:
The family who owns this cute spot has been here for about a century. Everything here is handmade and the owner takes pride in the quality of his ingredients. He even makes all the peanut mochi separate from the other mochi to ensure there are no allergic reactions. 

I had a blueberry mochi. The mochi pieces here are huge and only cost $1.10. The dough of the mochi was soft and pillowy. It was very refreshing to have mochi that did not see the inside of the freezer. The blueberry filling was an unexpected surprise, it was definitely a new, dynamic flavor when paired with the mochi. 

This place is a must if you are in the area - so cute, so sweet, so good.
author: Stacy T.

description: The Blueberry Mochi takes the cake! It's so soft and gooey and inside lies a sweet burst of blueberries. They're whole and taste fresh and homemade. The most pillowy manju I've ever had.
author: Elise G.

description:
I lived in Puerto Rico for the majority of my life, and there are essentially no Japanese shops on the island (besides the odd 'sushi' place here and there - with no real Japanese employees, mind you). So I'm a total newbie when it comes to any type of Japanese food. Now that I live in San Francisco, I'll take weekends to explore new stuff.

Since I began taking Japanese language classes close by, I decided to explore Japantown for the first time recently. After walking around (and terrified of getting anything to eat for fear I didn't like it), I stumbled upon this bakery just as I was about to leave the neighborhood. I've never had bad experiences with any bakeries, so I decided to go for it. It's been one of the better decisions I have made recently.

I had no idea what mochi or manju was until I started asking about everything, perhaps annoying the person behind the counter (hopefully not!). So I just told them to give me a dozen, at least one of everything they had on display. After the first bite of mochi, I fell in love with these little gelatinous rice cakes. From the red bean paste mochi, to the apple manju, to the super-awesome fresh strawberry mochi, every single one I tasted was so good.

Although it took me 30 years of my life to discover these, I'm glad I can pass by every weekend after class to get some of these lovely little treats.
author: Dennis M.

description:
mochi here is the best!!! chewy, gooey, and made with fresh fresh ingredients, whether it's strawberries, blueberries, red bean. delicious!

it is kind of expensive...$1 for something so small, but still worth it!
author: Liwei Y.

description:
I've been hooked on frozen ice cream mochi for as long as I can remember and now I'm finally ready to make the switch to the real thing. That, and I now have a school and work schedule that allows me to visit Benkyodo before they close.

With over 100 years of serving up mochi and manju, they have these little smooth and paste filled confections of mild and natural sweetness down to an art. I especially loved the dorayaki manju that has whole red beans in red bean paste spread between two small dollar pancakes. It was SOOOO GOOD! I could easily eat it after every meal. I also loved the yomogi mochi and the strawberry manju, but I didn't find a strawberry slice inside like in the picture, however the strawberry filling was nice. Guess I'll have to try again! I tried to sample one of everything they had and came away with a box of 8 pieces for $8. It's a great deal for such an artistic, historic and decadent treat.
author: Chelsea P.

description: I find myself craving Benkyodo every time I think of a mochi. I grew up eating and familiarizing myself with the sweet ice cream filled mochis that you buy at 99 ranch, so I was never really used to the "authentic' bean filled mochis - well guess what, Benkyodo changed my mind! The mochis are so tender and everything just tastes...fresh! My favorite is the blueberry :) This is such a small hole-in-the-wall shop in the middle of Japantown but you cannot say that you've lived life until you try a Benkyodo mochi. They close pretty early, so make sure to go during the day! Also, cash only.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My all time favorite mochi store! My grandma lives in Japantown and I don't understand how for the past 20+ years of my life I didn't know this place existed! For the past 2 years whenever I get a chance I make sure I stop by here to satisfy my mochi craving! The store is pretty small and a little tricky to find.

I'm not a huge fan of red bean so my favorite flavors here are strawberry and blueberry. They are seasonal so just be aware of that. I love that the the strawberry mochi has real strawberries in it. The outside is so chewy and soft. I've bought boxes of them and normally my whole family gobbles them up in a day, but we've had the red bean ones a few days later and they were still good.

I definitely think it's worth trying if you're in the area.
author: Hana C.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a little girl... and need less to say, I am still a fan! Their manju's are amazing and so are the an pans! 

I live in Hawaii now so I constantly crave Benkyodo. Luckily, I had a chance to be a part of the Cherry Blossom Festival this year and came home with 40 manju and 20 an pan! 

You will not be disappointed by the service or food! Definitely a J Town staple. 

Don't forget to bring cash! :)
author: Edrea K.

description:
The mochi here is delicious!  The right amount of sweetness and the texture is perfect.  I enjoy the white bean filling.  

I came here during a festival going on in Japantown, and they were sold out of mochi.  My heart had been set on mochi as a mid-afternoon snack so I was pretty devastated.  I am seriously debating going here before work this week since they close early at 5 PM.

This place is miles better than Mikawaya in Little Tokyo LA.
author: Melissa W.

description: The strawberry filled mocchis are yummm...but they didn't have the blueberry filled.
author: Jing F.

description: I stopped by with my sister because she was hungry and I reaaally wanted to try their mochi. First off, you have to pay for parking (garage, street) Benkyodo is located in a plaza next to several eateries. It was packed on a Friday and could barely get my order in because people seem to love their mochi. They also have the Hawaiian biscuits and various macadamia nut chocolates. Score! My sister ordered a sandwich from the cafe section. The sandwich was just gross! They don't have a toaster and instead just "steam" the bread. The ingredients tasted old, too. I'll be back for their mochi though!
author: Joyce E.

description:
What a difference going here on a weekday!  The four of us had our choice of a dozen or more selections.  I had been telling one friend, D. about this place for ages.  I hadn't been able to get her some peanut butter mochi the last few times I had been there since they were always out of it.

Happily they had piles of PB mochi so we got our fix.

I also got some regular manju and strawberry mochi--which we haven't attacked.....yet.

Mochi and manju are about $1 each.....and they make them there fresh every morning!
author: Rinky N.

description:
Update March 07: 
OMG.... some yelpers are referring to Bobby as the Mochi Nazi? He will *freaking * LAAAAAUGH when I tell him this......

*************************
A true treasure here in sf japantown.. run by a family and with the highest quality stancards for mochi in california!~! I lived in LA where mochi is made almost everywhere, but ricky and bobby's creations are the best i've had outside of japan. their an-pan (bread filled with sweet azuki) is a highlight!! they can do special orders, and Bobby is always happy to help out!!! Their sandwiches for lunch are one of the greatest deals in town, cheaper than lee's deli and without the snotty attitude of lee's!

I LOVE their Peanut butter mochi!! They package it completely separately and it comes pre-wrapped, so as to avoid any cross contamination (peanut allergy folks can relax.)

If you truly prefer 5-10 day old mochi from some Factory in LA, be My Guest... I can also suggest some pseudosushi spots that Nobu and I like to venture into... (not that there's anything wrong with that.) 

Oh, and am pretty sure this joint is cash only. But I could be wrong, of course.
author: M'ia K.

description:
Grumpy cafe!!!! Every time I have been here I get the worst service. The employees are extremely unfriendly. Last time I came to buy mochi here the woman didn't move, she just pointed to a sign that said they wouldn't have mochi for a few days, with a scowl on her face the entire time. All I wanted was a box of mochi. I'm usually not nitpicky when it comes to customer service, but this was just unacceptable.
Lucky for them, they have the best mochi around, which keeps me coming back time and time again even if the service is sub par. It is always fresh and absolutely delicious.
author: Megan S.

description: I've been buying and eating from this place since I was in grammar school, now I' 70 and th is still the only place to buy, and eat Mochi , it's made right here just like it's always been. If you want the best it's made and sold right here.
author: Sam S.

description: I like my sketchers but I LOVE my mochis. They usually have a short line, but they move through efficiently and were patient as I chose the many that I wanted :) This is one of my favorite things.
author: christine l.

description:
This business opened in 1906. 
1906!!!!!

From their website: In 1906, Suyeichi Okamura opened Benkyodo Company - one of the original businesses in Japantown - on San Francisco's Geary Boulevard. When the family was interned during World War II, Benkyodo Company was forced to close temporarily.  After the war ended, the shop reopened, and in 1951 Suyeichi's son, Hirofumi, took over. In 1959, the shop moved to its present-day location at Sutter and Buchanan Street.

This place is 106 years old this year!!
Amazing history. Amazing place. With the recent closing of Uoki K. Sakai Co. Grocery store, this place is now the only Japanese family owned business in Japantown over 100 years old. Soko Hardware opened in 1925. 

With that being said, my elderly auntie and I visited here to pick up fresh mochi for the New Year. We stayed and had lunch at the counter. Good lunch, inexpensive, green tea, hot dogs and chips! I felt like a little country kid again visiting my city-girl auntie having lunch at a counter in Japantown. The mochi is oishi GOOD. 
You can feel the history of the place at that counter with the orange bar stools.
My old auntie laughs and says its nice to eat at a place older than her.
My 86 year old auntie and I will be back.

Note: You can also purchase the large kagami mochi here before New Years. Good to know.
author: Barb B.

description:
Benkyodo...

THE BEST PLACE FOR MOCHI!

It is mochi heaven! 

There are a variety of flavors and they have seasonal items!

Now before encountering this wonderful place, I never heard of such thing a thing as "making food only when the item is in season." 

Like with the places I frequent beforehand, who cared about fruits being in season? They'll just bring out frozen ones or whatnot.

But with Benkyodo, everything is made fresh and in season! The blueberry mochi, is HEAVEN! Strawberry mochi comes in as a close second! My favorite is the chofu though!

The staff members, most especially the lady who works there on the weekdays, is super nice!

I love Benkyodo!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
What else can I say that hasn't been said already thanks to Ken K :D 

I went here with my mom after lunch and wanted some mochi. I got strawberry mochi and peanut butter mochi that was wrapped separately. 

I luuuurrrvvveee the strawberry mochi, the mochi is by far the freshest, softest, bestest mochi I've ever had! Texture is smooth and not too sweet. I've been to Shuei-Do Manju Shop in San Jose and by far Benkyodo beats them hands down. 

The peanut butter mochi was also pretty good but not as fresh as the strawberry mochi. 

I only wish that they had Chi Chi Dango (do they even make this at Benkyodo?) *having flashbacks of Nisshodo Candy Store in Honolulu*

I.must.have.more.
author: Nette T.

description:
I love the mochi here!!  I have a very sweet tooth, so this is heaven for me!!  I love all of their mochi here, but I have discovered their blueberry one which is my fav and it is so YUMMY!   You just bite into it and you get the blueberry taste with the mochi in it - heaven I say!!  

I wish there was one near me.  I lived in the city all my life, but didn't discover this place until later in life and when I moved...=(  Better late than never, I guess.
author: James L.

description: I want to give them no stars. I heard the strawberry mochi was delicious and bought six of them. They were terrible. They were so sweet and the strawberries tasted so artificially made. Disappointed..
author: Sung Min K.

description:
Ohh my mochi! So fresh and so soft you can't not smile as you bite into this little bit of happiness. Try them all. Definitely try the age ("ahh-geh" which is like a sugar donut filled with delicious red bean), the blueberry (when in season... It makes the whole box smell yummy), and the suama (made on Thursday and Saturday I believe) as these are my faves. 

Service is always friendly and they wrap up your mochi in a pretty box to take home for yourself or to bring to a dinner party. I haven't met anyone who hasn't loved this delicious delight. Do yourself a favor (especially if you need a little cheering up today) and stop by Benkyodo for a treat. You'll definitely be smiling!
author: Gracie P.

description:
I'm not a huge mochi fan but you got to love this place with their variety of homemade mochi and this history of this place that's been around since 1906. 

You walk in and it feels like such an old school place with regulars in their 60's-80's eating at the counter on the right and then there is the beloved mochi section on the left with about a dozen scrumptious looking mochi flavors.  Conveniently they do have a mochi "decoder" picture chart showing all their mochi as I bet they've gotten tired of explaining all the mochi flavors for te last 102 years. 

I got a red bean mochi and althought it tasted very fresh and the fresh gooey flour was fun to eat on the outside. It was just okay to me but I know I'm not a mochi connosseiur. However, my friend visiting SF liked her mochi a lot.

Bottom line: Super place for authentic Japanese mochi and love the historic old-school feel of this place. Mochi is not for me but if you like this stuff, you need to check out this place. And I didn'try it, but the donut-looking red bean mochi did look great!
author: Jim C.

description:
I was so happy to finally get Wagashi (Japanese sweets http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wagashi)  from Benkyodo since it was always closed when I got there.  I am a big fan of Wagashi.  When I was in a middle school, I joined a tea ceremony after school program to be able to eat Wagashi everyday.

But I have to say I was very disappointed with Benkyodo... Sorry my Yelp friends who gave Benkyodo 5 stars I have to disagree...

1. They use a lot of food coloring for their sweets.  Wagashi in Japan have more delicate colors.  Yes Yomogi Mochi suppose to be green but not this bright. I can tell Benkyodo is not using much real Yomogi in the Mochi.  Yomogi is a leafy vegetable of the chrysanthemum family.  It adds beautiful aroma and little fiberly texture.  It also gives earthy moss color to the Mochi.  I could tell Benkyodo used a lot of artificial colors and flavors.

2. The design and taste of their Wagashi is not polished.  Japanese consider Wagashi as an art and they are created by Shokunin (craftsman who was trained many years)  I believe Wagashi have to be beautiful and delicate in flavor. (example http://www.ioi.tv/special/04_06/misuzu.html ) To me Benkyodo's Wagashi is like Inaka (county side) style and not polished.

I respect Benkyodo for it's 100 year history.  Yes they are better than packaged Japaneses Mochi / Daifuku you can buy at supermarkets.  That is why I am giving them 3 stars.  But I'm not sure if they can survive if thy were in Tokyo or Kyoto.


Just FYI - Mochi means Japanese glutinous rice cake.  Japanese Girls/Woman call it Omochi.  It is not womanly to call it without O.  So I never called it Mochi.  There are so many other word start with O in Japanese language for woman.  If there are something inside of Mochi, they are called Daifuku, Manju, or Dango (there are different names from different region of Japan) and no longer called Mochi
author: Chie J.

description: I've been coming to this place on and off for the past 11 years. They have deliciously fresh mochi! The woman behind the counter is so friendly and personable. I recommend the berry mochi (strawberry, blueberry, etc.) When in doubt, get a variety as you really can't do wrong at this place! I wish I lived back in the Bay Area so I could go more often!
author: Heather M.

description:
My love of mochi/manju began almost 40 years ago on Clement St, where my mom would allow me to have two pieces as a treat instead of traditional candy/sweets.

To this day, I just love them.  The texture, weight and lovely mix of flavors makes me smile.  The beauty is one or two usually are enough and they go beautifully with some tea.

Benkyodo makes some of the best manju around.  I don't know what I was thinking when I only bought one strawberry today in my mix box of 10.  I will have to remedy that when I return.  The texture is fantastic, the filling is rich and sweet but not overwhelming.  I considered learning how to make my own adzuki bean paste and mochi, but decided with Benkyodo just a few miles away, why bother.  They are amazingly fresh, lovely, and affordable.

The only thing I wish for is a better sign in English describing them (as another yelper noted, the lady behind the counter wasn't overly helpful) and slightly longer hours.  Really you can't make a bad choice; you just want to make sure you get enough of the ones you really like, so that you don't have to arm wrestle your husband for the strawberry or doughnut ones.  The web site does have a picture chart of the different manju if you do want to go informed (just found it!)

Obviously not a new discovery but so deserving of being on my yelp map.
author: Monika S.

description: Very delicious mochi, fresh and fantastic. A hidden store in jtown.
author: Karen J.

description:
I remember faintly, the several times I was invited to our relations get-together hosting the annual mochi-tsuki and having the opportunity to take home with me, lots of plain white mochi stuffed with the sweetened azuki bean paste.

So it was little surprise to find this little shop here, in the ever shrinking Japantown (sad tribute, indeed, especially since I've been coming here for at least the past 20 years) and I was happy to say, that although the best mochi I've had was in Japan near a small temple in Nagoya and a small family shop called Osaka-Ya in Sacramento.

My favorite mochi (sadly, but I'm traditional when it comes to Mochi) are the typical Daifuku mochi, with the sweetened azuki beans, in addition to the Yomogi daifuku mochi.  I also like the slightly less sweet and delicate chestnut paste filling of the Kuri mochi in a baked bread layer.  For quick snacks on the go, I like the Dorayaki: two small pancakes sandwich a Azuki patty (think a hamburger).......use to eat those with gyu-nu (milk in Japan).  Wow, natsukashii (nostalgic!!)

What I miss most, is the Oshiruko, where small round pieces of soft melting mochi are afloat in a warm sweet Azuki soup.  My grandmother made this on very special occasions and it is definitely a fave from the past.

Hours are a little restricting, in that most people can't make it here on a workday, but hopefully, they will keep up the great service and mochi selection available to the public  :)
author: Miika M.

description: Best mochi ever. ever.  Charming little shop in Japantown.  Wouldn't think much of it from the outside, however the Yelp reviews brought me in.  My favorites are the red bean, blueberry, and strawberry.  The only drawbacks for me are that they're open only during my work hours (8-5), and are often sold out by the end of the day.  One of my friends got Benkyodo delivered to me for my birthday through Postmates, which was pretty cool.  If you love mochi, think it's just alright, or have never had it, get your butt to JT and go to Benkyodo now before they sell out for the day!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
I was never a big fan of the packaged mochis maybe because I think the red bean paste would be too overwhelming since it looks like the mochi is bloated with beans? Yeah not too appetizing but seeing over 200 reviews for this place plus its 4 stars?! This I got to see. 

Before coming here I thought to myself, "Would I be disappointed to come here?" And guess what? I'm glad I came because the mochi balls from this place made me feel like I was on cloud 9. 

Now on to my experience;;;
Walked into the store and SCORE no line except for one guy. Well at least I thought there would be a line since everyone seems to love this place. The guy pissed me off because once he saw me walk in he quickly ordered like I was going to order all 4 racks of mochi or something. He took so long ordering I was literally standing there for 10 minutes and we had our car parked in the garage so every minute counts! He had one box full of mochi and guess what happens....he orders another box! *steaming* Give me my two mochi balls God Damnit! Anyway, after with the uy who loves mochi balls it was finally my turn. The sweet lady behind the counter apologized for me waiting even though she didn't have to and then ordred myself a white mochi  with red bean and the strawberry mochi. 

$1.10 per mochi ball (WORTH IT)

First bite into my white mochi....soo soffffftttttttttttt.....so red beany.....I know beany is not a word but the mochi ball made me say it. Probably the best ball I had ever bit into....(Don't think naughty now)
Then I tried the strawberry mochi, wow was that thing amazing or what? I didn't expect to actually taste strawberry because I thought "strawberry" meant for colors. After my 3rd bute into the strawberry mochi I find myself chewing on an actual slice of strawberry. Whoa that blew me away. It was so good. 

Thank you Benkyodo for making me love mochi! Well only your mochis!
author: Tracy A.

description:
The service is a hit or miss here. It really depends on what mood the guy is in. 
Come on, if you had been there since like what? 3, 4, 5am making freaking mochis you'd be grumpy by 5pm too so cut the guy some slack. It's a family owned and operated business, has been for many generations. 
It's currently being run by 2 brothers and I heard that once their kids are in college, they're going to retire...and that will be the end of their legacy mochi, and that will be a sad day because San Francisco will flood with my tears. 

One time I walked breathless. It was 5 minutes before closing and I didn't want to be a total ass (Come on, I work in the food industry, I know how it is) and I exclaimed "I'm here! I'm here I finally found parking! I'm sorry!! I know you're closing!" 

You know what he said to me?

"Yeah, sometimes...parking is such a BITCH isn't it!?"

Susy C's face:  O_O
Susy C's friend: uhhhhh... yes, yes it is.
Susy C:  O_O
Susy C's friend: Yeah we need this this this and that.

Thank you have a nice day!

Susy C: Hey.. uhhh... *walks outside, nibbling on mochi* maybe i'm like, on crack or something but did he just say BITCH!?
author: Susy C.

description:
i thought i would be disappointed a few weeks ago when i was looking for parking on post st. NO PARKING! all the signs exclaimed. but i saw no construction, no activity.at all. so i parked and observed the sign more closely. near the bottom , there was a notice that if construction didn't start by 12 o'clock, then parking will be legal.

my cellphone read 11:59. so off  to  benkyodo i went. got four kinds of mochi($1), green and whites, all soft outer surface skin with different  fillings inside. i didn't take good notes so i have  to reevaluate them.
the mochi here is so unlike the vietnamese mochi you get in asian foodmarts or the imported ones. fresh mochi almost melts in your mouth while the others are rubbery.

today, tried the peanut butter mochi($1), it was so rich tasting! with cunchy peanuts, reminds me of skippy's  crunchy peanut butter.
strawberry was not in the house.
also, tried their no frills hot dog (2.35) crunchy with  a nice taste. garnishments are minimal with relish, onion, ketchop & mustard..

pros:
mochi can be a dessert or...
hot dog good value and tasty

cons:
mochi may be an acquired taste.
author: Victor G.

description:
It's just me in my happy little world, so I always try to just get two pieces when I casually walk by. Unfortunately, I always end up with 6-8 pieces, and I tend to casually walk by way too frequently. So yea, i can pack away a shit ton of mochi in my tummy.  

Also, I'm probably the only person in the world who has written a check for $6.08 for five pieces of mochi.
author: Wendy L.

description:
First time going here through a recommendation from a friend. The place is located on the corner and it definitely looks like a diner from the outside. Totally missed it and walked by while searching for it.

The inside is a diner on the right side and it does look like they serve diner food also. I thought I was in the wrong place until I looked left and so the mochi counter. 

The mochi's really fresh here and it seems like they're homemade. I ended up buying two of each of their popular mochis to try out. Got a total of 10, tried 3 random ones before the whole box was devoured by other people. They were all chewy and soft. I totally missed out the strawberry mochi. That gives me an excuse to come back...

This place accepts cash only.
author: Steven B.

description:
Good Japanese sweet place, this is the only place now in the city with home made stuff since that mean Japanese lady was gone. 

As growing up eating various wagashi in Japan, I have to say they are doing a great job. The only downside is their business hour is 9:00 - 5:00 and closed on Sundays, office people like me can only go on Sat.
author: Yoko S.

description:
THIS IS HOW A 5 STAR REVIEW GOES FOR BEYNKYODO...

Benkyodo has THEE best mochi's in San Francisco, hands down. 
Don't even argue with me, it's THA BOMB. 

I LOVEEEEE all their flavors and the best part of it is that it's freshly homemade. My favorite one is their strawberry. They ALWAYS run out of this because it's made to perfection -- no lie!! It has a white mochi outside and strawberry filling, and the best part is the fresh strawberry they put in there...but...

NOW THIS IS WHY I'M GIVING IT 3 STARS...

I just went back today to buy a box of 8 strawberry mochi's for special friend and his family, and upon eating it, I realized that the strawberry mochi did NOT have a fresh cut of strawberry in there!!!!!!!!! OMG I was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO sad. It didn't taste as good without the strawberry. I was really really sad since I bought 8 of them to share with his family but ended up not being the ones I especially enjoyed months ago. Sad face for Benkyodo.

Sigh! I hope they bring back the fresh strawberries...but I'm afraid I have to wait until strawberries are back in season.

Benkyodo, I will be back for more mochis, but I will be waiting for fresh strawberries in your strawberry mochi. I'm patiently waiting.

(Photos uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description: Best mochi I've ever eaten! Especially the fresh blueberry & strawberry flavors!
author: Mel S.

description:
Wow. who'd have thought this place has freshly in-house made mochi that are super tasty? they only have a few options available. but they are yummy ones at that! And the mochi are affordable! (only a dollar and some change each) what a steal! 

Strawberry mochi - was amazing! And only available for one more week! hm... i will be back next year! 

Pink Habutai - pink mochi w/ smooth white lima beans. yum! favorite!!

Yomogi - green mochi w/ whole red beans inside. yummy! (tasty but i prefer smooth red bean instead of whole ones...)

Note:: CASH ONLY!!!
author: Judy N.

description: The reverse red bean with rice mochi was ok. Favorites were the green mochi with red bean and powder and the deep fried red bean mochis!
author: S C.

description:
1st time here.  Mochis are very soft and small.  Had the blueberry, whole bean, soy powder, pancake, apple, and bean paste.  All yummy.  Sorry forgot all the japanese names.

They had a sign that said "Fresh frozen mochi for $3.75" that I found interesting.
author: Troy M.

description: Buying homemade mochi beats buying the ones in the grocery store any day. Delicious! I stop by here whenever I'm in the area; unfortunately, that's not often. Need to remember to come early when there's a bigger selection to choose from. Haven't tried the strawberry mochi yet, but I will the next time I'm there.
author: Diane D.

description:
Soft, chewy, pleasantly sweet, and that chunk of fresh strawberry in the strawberry mochi. Yes, the strawberry mochi is my favorite. Definitely the best place to get mochi in the city at $1 a piece. They always sell out, which means everything is made fresh daily. Come early before it's all gone.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Stopped here real quick after lunch and ordered one blueberry mochi for $1.25. 

Mochi was nice and chewy. More soft than actually really chewy, kind of melts in your mouth. The blueberry filling actually had blueberries in it and was really tasty. Not too sweet. 

Overall great home-made mochi :]
author: Gabby N.

description:
"I didn't know mochi could be this soft." J said, after taking his first bite into the green (red bean) mochi...the white bean was out of this world and the strawberry delightful. Didn't get to taste the peanut butter yet as they were sold out. Went there two times in one week as I was housesitting on Sutter for a friend. The 2nd time (yesterday), I discovered the woman gave me the wrong kind (4 pieces) so I went back an hour later and the man told her to give me 4 pieces for free...he raised his voice at me, saying, "I can't take this mochi back!" at least 3 times...I think he was upset with his staff? I didn't take it personally. 

I live with two people from Japan and so I have had the fortunate experience of eating mochi from Tokyo (fresh off the plane) and also home-cooked mochi.

Now that I've tried this place...I can't wait to sample another mochi place in San Jose, where my housemate (from Tokyo), says is better than Benkyodo.  (Boggles my mind)

This place has very fresh mochi...outer layer is very soft, beans aren't too sweet...tried 3 kinds...all were great. Will be back for more.
author: Grace C.

description:
MMmm this mochi is soo good. It only took me about three visits to finally visit the mochi shop on a day and time when they actually had mochi left in more than two flavors. The last time I went was on a weekday afternoon, which explains why I was able to get the full selection of flavors. I looked in the mochi glass case and counted the available flavors: 10. So I look up at the nice lady, and say "Can I have the 10-piece box? One of each flavor, please." Perfect. When I got home with my goodies, I took a bite of each one before passing on the remaining half-eaten morsels of chewy deliciousness to the BF. I think the chocolate flavor was a new one for me...it was just ok. I prefer the redbean filled mochi. 

Honestly, I can't tell between the different flavors. I just know they're all different colors, most of them filled with red-bean, and all of them delicious. And the chewy, doughy mochi just tastes so fresh and homemade here. Like I know the lady who packed my mochi might have been the one also making mochi early that morning, packing each doughy piece with red bean and made with love.
author: Jessie C.

description: Mochi is wonderful. Can't really add anything that hasn't been already said. Just buy some!
author: Kiyoko F.

description:
This is a fabulous place. My family LOVES their manju. I swear it used to not be quite as good (maybe a decade ago), but the last couple of years has been consistent. They have a great selection. The manju is fresh & delicious. The service is WONDERFUL. It might be because I'm there at least a couple of times a month, but they've always been kind, helpful, and very friendly with my sometimes obnoxious kiddos.

Bring cash. Don't buy more than you can eat by the next day (best the day of purchase). They always have things like habutai (plain), kinako, etc, but some of their other manju differ on different days of the week (i think... my son seems to know when they have his favorite, but I haven't paid enough attention to know if they always make certain things on specific days of the week)

Just thinking about it makes me want to run over there right now... yum...
author: lynn t.

description:
Incredible mochi, I like the strawberry one among all the others. 

It's definitely worth it if :
A. there is any left 
B. the place is open
C. you can find it
D. I didn't get away with all of them to share with my circle
author: Will C.

description:
A delicious mochi bakery nestled in a little diner-it's a like a dream really.
They have traditional and new flavors for everyone's tastebuds.It's a very inviting environment.
author: Van Cac Thi T.

description:
4.5 stars

I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time.  I had no idea they closed so early, so I was disappointed to find it closed on a Friday evening.  And I was really disappointed when I went out of my way one Sunday afternoon to find that they are not open on Sundays (doh! I should have consulted Yelp before leaving the house).  

So, after two disappointing attempts, you can imagine my manju craving was at an all time high.  After nagging my SO's ear off about eating manju, the oh-so-sweet guy got off work early last Friday and drove his a** to J-town and bought me a whole assortment of manju!!!  I was so ecstatic!  I couldn't wait to devour everything, I tore right through the nicely wrapped box.  He got me one of everything and I have to say my favorite of the bunch were definitely the peanut butter and the chofu (sweet rice cake wrapped in a pancake).  The pb manju was so fresh, and I love that they used crunchy pb.  The pancake they use for the chofu is sooo yummy, it's reminiscent of breakfast pancakes, but there's something uniquely different about it but I just can't seem to pinpoint it.

I would definitely go back to try their donut manju and any others I haven't tried yet, and to load up on the pb and chofu manju.  The minus .5 stars comes from my SO's complaint that the old man working the counter was not friendly at all and did not welcome any small chit-chat.  He was the only customer, but the man seemed to be in a very grumpy mood.
author: Diane L.

description:
I like to buy two, then squish them together to create a soft little butt, and rub them like a creeper until someone smacks my hand out of concern for public decency.  It's like when you see an adorable kitten or baby and people squeal, "Oh I could just eat you up!!"  but in this case, you CAN.

Recent years indulging in shinise wagashi shop tours and Toraya orders has skewed my taste for Japanese confectionary.   So the first time I saw Benkyodo's treats, I was skeptical.  Then I bit into the Pink Habutai, and it was like that scene in Ratatouille. I flashbacked to nervously eyeing the mallet while flipping mochi at New Year's mochitsuki, and begging my parents for unceremoniously cling wrapped strawberry mochi nestled between spam musubi and crack seed jars.    

It's always pretty quiet when I stop by though, like J-town in general.  Which, despite the high ratings, still makes me a little anxious.  I really hope they move enough mochi to be able to stay around for a long time.
author: K K.

description:
Wh-what?? They are thinking of closing? That's what I just read in Nobu-san's review. I hope that is just a rumor. They make mochi--daifuku, to be exact, daily! fresh! local! authentic! I think they are one of two places that do in the entire Bay Area! This is no trivial feat, people. I grew up on my grandmother's daifuku which took her all day to make with love and care. This place makes it the  same way, just as someone's grandmother in Japan might make, and better than what one would find in upscale department stores in Japan. The mochi wrapping is soft and fresh, the fillings perfectly sweetened! Also good are the other 'deli' type items such as sekihan (red azuki bean rice), dorayaki (a sweet that looks like a pancake sandwich with red bean paste filling) and others. They also sell the cracker that is the basis of fortune cookies (osenbei) --yes, the fortune cookie was invented by Japanese in the US, not in China and not in Asia.  I like the mini osenbei, which are the size of silver dollars and flat.

Anyway, the traditional Japanese sweets are fabulous. I am surprised the foodies haven't discovered this, but maybe just as well--more for me!! I have never eaten at the counter, but the menu looks like standard American greasy spoon fare which I could do without (and this one star off).

This place is the heart and soul of the Japanese community of San Francisco. I hope it never goes away.
author: 和子

description:
GREAT mochi and manju.  u should try all the selection.  everything is so fresh.  some of them just melts in your mouth.   the peanut butter one is interesting; ive yet to acquire that taste.  the sticky rice ball with the cherry leaf on top gives its a rather funky taste ( in a good way).  theyre only available on weekends.  

my all time favorite is the strawberry mochis with  pieces of strawberries in the center. yummmmm!   dont go late in the day, there wont be anything left.
author: Kris H.

description:
"...Now you can get with this...or you can get with that...
...I think you'll get with this yes...for this is kinda phat...
...If you get with that...then you will surely miss...
...Because that's so whack...I think you'll get with this!"

Hate to rip off Black Sheep, but I don't think I could of said it any better about the mochi here compared to other places.  From the eclectic Pulp Fiction diner feel to the mind-blowing strawberry mochi...this place is da bomb.  Now if we could only get them to stay open for a few hours longer...that would be the shiznit...fo shizzle.

"I think you'll get with this...For this is where it's at."
author: Justin L.

description:
I stopped by Benkyodo during the Cherry Blossom festival two weekends ago. I saw the rave reviews on yelp and had to try it afterwards.

The line was out the door, considering it was during the peak hours of the festival...but I am glad I waited because the strawberry mochis that I purchased were heavenly.

Super soft and not overly sweet, they were perfect. They even had a fresh piece of strawberry on the inside. 

Until now I've only had store-bought mochi, so perhaps I'm not an expert on this but Benkyodo's mochi balls were pretty damn good to me. No complaints here. 

I will definitely swing by again whenever in the area.
author: Patricia Q.

description: Mochis from before cannot compare. Sooooo soft. I tried the blueberry (my favorite) "Age" donut (so bad but oh so good) "Pink habutai" pink mochi with Lima bean (semi sweet) strawberry (good but I think I'll pass next time and get more blueberry mochis next time. Huge fan of blueberries) and last but not least peanut butter mochi (crunchy nummy goodness) had to get 6 of that. Really friendly. My go to place now.
author: Glessie C.

description: The strawberry mochi was heavenly. Wonderful! No more supermarket mochi for me. I've wanted to try this place for awhile, I'm glad I finally got to go. Will definitely come again.
author: Shella C.

description: So good!!! Soft and chewy , not too sweet . Nice people behind the counter is a plus! You should go and try it!
author: Berny D.

description:
On Mother's Day, my family and I were having lunch in Japantown.  I've been talking about trying this place for a while, and I knew it was in Japantown but not exactly sure where. Then my mom remembered that it was literally just around the corner (even on Mother's Day my mom still thinks about everyone else's happiness!).

Seeing my excitement, my dad offered to walk with me to Benkyodo since he's been there before. But my feeling quickly faded when we saw the closed sign on the door (they aren't open on Sundays). Since then my dad has been determined to make his little girl happy. Two weeks later he comes home with a white box full of treats from Benkyodo! I cut every piece in half and dove right in:

Peanut butter - a must for peanut butter lovers like myself! Heck, it could be just a glob of chunky Skippy for all I care rather than "all natural" or "organic", but the PB was just that much better inside mochi!

Strawberry - oh, I LOVE berries season! Whole, sweet strawberry inside these treats. Luckily my dad knew to pick up several of this flavor. My favorite.
 
Red bean and white bean fillings - yum, yum, YUM!

Chopped apples - wasn't inside the soft mochi but rather a "bun." The crunchy apples were tasty as well, but I think I'll stick with the mochi.

And every piece was just incredibly soft and just sweet enough to satisfy your sweet tooth without giving you a sugar rush. And I can honestly taste the homemade feeling of them =)
 
For this daughter, it's the simple, sweet treats in life that make her happy.  Who needs jewelry when you have chocolate and Benkyodo? Thanks, Daddy!
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Solidly good, fresh mochi, though we came at about an hour before closing and were not able to try the Strawberry mochi or the Peanut butter mochi.

My mochi-eating buddy and I sampled 6 types of mochi (See my picture!)--everything that was available. At $1 apiece, they were typically priced for fresh mochi. I found the non-standard ones less appetizing--unless you're really fond of glutinous rice, you'll probably want to skip the specialties. The mochi-mochis, however, were pillowy soft and chewy, filled with yummy, not-too-sweet, beans.

I want to come back and have a Strawberry mochi. The others are good, but I've been spoiled with mochi all my life, and have had better.
author: K W.

description:
This is my favorite mochi place outside of Japan or Hawaii, and interestingly enough the establishment itself reminds me of both of these places, mixed with a little bit of traditional Americana/50's diner. They sell an interesting mix of things at Benkyodo, including coffee, sandwiches, hot dogs, rice crackers, Hawaiian cookies and of course, their specialty, mochi!

The mochi here is a mochi-lover's dream come true- big, beautiful, with a variety of fillings and cheap! The day we went they had plain mochi, peanut butter mochi, fresh strawberry mochi and azuki bean. I sampled all of them and they were all fantastic. So fantastic, in fact, that I can't stop thinking about them!

I highly recommend trying the mochi at Benkyodo. Just remember, cash only!
author: Daniela A.

description: Noooooommms. Really good mochi. Soft and the fillings aren't too sweet. I got a box of 14 or 15 for my family that I was visiting later and ate two of them before they noticed. They even wrapped the box in paper to make it look nice. I went in the middle of the afternoon and they ran out of a lot of the types of mochi; they only had three types left, so come earlier in the day if you want a larger variety.
author: Frances L.

description:
