Hands down, Benkyodo offers the most delicious mochi treats in the US!!
Great consistency and a good balance of sweetness!

Some recommendations:
- don't forget to bring cash
- order a box of treats for yourself (must include the basic mochi)
- now order another box for you to eat after you devour the first box
- order additional boxes for your parents & loved ones 
- remember that Benkyodo does NOT open on Sundays 

I was in town for a friend's wedding and bought a box of mochi and inhaled it in the car ride to the wedding. I was looking forward to going back the next day to get boxes of treats to bring back to the East Coast and sadly came upon a unlit storefront as it was Sunday and Benkyodo was closed. :(

You will not regret stopping by this gem of a store!!!
author: K P.

description: Wow the place is FINALLY open! This is my 3rd time in the last couple months trying to get some mochi and this is the 1st time the place is actually open during business hours. I got the strawberry mochi and it was heaven. Then I had the smooth red bean mochi and it was heaven also. Pillows of chewy sweet Heaven.
author: Karen T.

description:
Oh Benkyodo, how I adore your manju but not your attitude.

I think this is definitely the place to get your manju fix, but oh my goodness can these people get moody.  During one visit into the city on either December 29 or 30 AND early in the day, was told they were sold out because they were only handing out pre-orders for New Year's.  How stupid is this?  Don't they know on regular business days they have walk in customers like on the day I went in?  Just make more than the orders, silly people.

Age (donut w/smooth red beans) is ok.  Always seem greasy to me and I don't much care for kinako (smooth red beans with soybean flour).  Chofu (pancake wrap with plain sweet rice) and doriyaki (pancake w/whole red beans) are two of my favorites.  There are at least a dozen more to pick, including peanut butter mochi.  When they have it, they keep it wrapped and separate (very smart, considering peanut allergies) from others, so ask or look for it if interested.  They also have a seasonal strawberry mochi that is soooo good.

I like to take my time and 'study' the counter, but they are not very patient people.  Maybe next time I'll call and ask what is available and place an order before heading in.
author: Yvette M.

description:
Benkyodo has been around for over 100 years. WHAT! OVER ONE HUNDRED YEARS, PEOPLE. I think they know what they're doing.

You *must* have their strawberry mochi when it's in season. It is the best ichigo mochi I've ever had and you will be very sad when they don't have it.

My inner Japanese is very happy to have a manju shop close by!
author: Judy C.

description:
This is just for the strawberry mochi we tried there. Absolutely delish with a piece of fresh strawberry tucked inside. 

And to top it off, the woman working there was very sweet.
author: Jen N.

description:
Om nom nom nom.

Can I just write that for my entire review?  Because that's really all I feel like doing right now.  Eating mochi after mochi after mochi.  One after the other.  After the other.  Om nom nom.  Nom nom.

If you like your mochi fresh, soft, and with a sweet, melt-in-your-mouth gooeyness, you will, like I currently am, be in love.  And,  despite having bought several extras with the idea to distribute to friends, you will want to eat them all for yourself (to my friends who are reading this: Oops!).  

And if you're at a loss for which one to try, I say go for the strawberry mochi.  It's got a smooth creaminess that is accented by the slices of strawberry found inside.  DELICIOUS.  AAH!

Note:  I will admit that I have been having a love affair with french macarons recently, but after trying Benkyodo's desserts today, I might have to have an adulterous affair with Japanese desserts a la the strawberry mochi . . .
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
Alas, no strawberry manju/mochi today, but I did get to try three other delicious flavors

1) kinako - manju that is lime green in appearance with a dusting of light tan soybean powder, and filled with smooth red bean, this was very smooth and chewy; the flavor is not very strong but subtle

2) age - looks like a beignet, it's like a donut hole filled with red bean and then rolled in sugar; it was very sweet and tasty

3) roppo - my favorite of the bunch, it's a square pastry (almost like moon cake in texture) filled with smooth red bean. Understated but full flavor, and not overly sweet

Cheap at $1 each, and the lady behind the counter was very very sweet to us.

Interesting that there's also a sandwich counter in the shop, along with a lot of other Japanese savory and sweet snacks!
author: Katherine P.

description: I love the mochi here, especially their seasonal fresh strawberry mochi.  Unfortunately they are closed on sundays
author: Judy P.

description: I called this morning to confirm that they would be open. Arrived at 8:45am and the owner said "yes we are open but not selling mochi until 11am due to orders" could that have been mentioned on the phone when I called earlier in the day? Great mochi, but miscommunication and poor service.
author: jennifer m.

description:
Oh... mah... gawd. 

I'm new to enjoying mochis, I hate to admit. I used to not like red bean paste at all, thought it was gross. Now I crave the stuff. I don't know what happened, but a couple months ago I re-tried paste and then all of a sudden had to have it. Then I retried the gelatinous mochis (the Daifuku kind at 99 Ranch) and found my new favorite friend. 

So if you too are like me and want to take your chances, Benkyodo is a GREAT place to retry the paste.

So I started to do a bit of Yelpresearch to find good mochis and found this listing. We went round last Sunday and damn it was closed. I then clued in and checked the hours and we were back today. 

My GOD THESE THINGS ROCK. That review that mentioned the bean to paste ratio? So true. You get SO much paste in these things. And they're so fresh the gel is for-awesome-beyond-words. I'm so glad I bought 10 - oh I thought it was gluttonous but it was just smart. Between the man and I, I'm sure they'll be gone by tomorrow. I better take pictures for Yelp fast.

Next time I'm getting some with non-red-bean insides...

And the lady was real nice.
author: Jen D.

description: I haven't even been to the shop yet and I'm a fan. My aunt and uncle brought over box to try and the strawberry mochi was so amazing and fresh! I can't wait to try the rest, and I'm not even a big mochi fan.... but the taste was perfect!
author: Samantha D.

description: Very tasty mochi and manju here. I particularly liked the peanut butter mochi and apple manju. The red bean paste manju was pretty good as well. The lasy behind the counter was very friendly and helpful to boot.
author: Jennifer P.

description: My dad is a huge fan of red beans and I came across this store and thought it would be a perfect gift for father's day. I am not a fan of mochi but I really liked the strawberry mochi. I didn't try the red bean mochi but I heard from my parents it was good or they were just saying that to be nice...Anyway, I read that the strawberry mochis were popular and that the would run out by the end of the day. I called ahead and the owner said he would reserve the mochis for me. The owners were super nice because when I got there I was going to pick out some red bean mochi and she was patient with my fickleness.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Sweet, sweet mochi. How I love and desire thee.

Here is Benkyodo, a tiny little shop tucked around a corner. I hadn't even noticed it was there until my good friend pointed it out!

OMG, sooo delicious. You know a place is authentically delicious when it's packed with little old Japanese people.

I LOVE the blueberry one. Next time I go, I might get a box of 10 just of blueberry. The white one with the red dot is also pretty good!
author: Rachel H.

description: Extremely crowded. Long lines. Really, REALLY good mochi!
author: Denise B.

description:
The seasonal strawberry mochi is simply delicious... the pair of sweet lima bean with a tart strawberry blanketed in the smoothest of mochi skin will leave your mouth in HEAVEN! I wish this was how pillows tasted. 

All the other selections are solid from what I've had. It's hard to pit Shuei-Do against Benkyodo...they're both so consistently and equally excellent at their mochi craft.
author: May N.

description:
Gf and I went to this place and ordered one of each mochi available in store, except peanut butter. I didn't pay attention on each mochi description. Every single one of them looked delicious. We skipped on dorayaki ones though.. since we both have tasted it before.

All of them taste good. I should've buy the peanut butter one as well... since I love peanut butter a lot. I'll be back next time I'm in SF.
author: Yohann S.

description: This is the bestest mochi I've tried ever in my life!!! The strawberry flavor is the bomb!
author: Matt C.

description: Freshest biggest mochis I've had.  I'm not  usually a fan of these gluttonous shaped babies, but these are something else.  Try their special in season mochis (currently blueberry and apple) for mochis outside the standard red/green bean filled ones. They taste best the sooner you eat them and don't keep for very long.  EAT!
author: Peg S.

description: Old school cool with a fun twist.  I love the red bean paste mochi, but the blueberry mochi is a teaser.  Yin and yang, but entirely delicious!
author: katharine r.

description:
peanut butter mochi, kinako, and seki-han.  
FANTASMIC. this shop, along with sweet stop bakery across the street, are cornerstones of jtown.  you wanna know where the local nisei/sansei are at? here, sitting at the counter.  an absolute MUST if you wanna taste real sf food.
author: Karina U.

description:
Let's get to the point.  The Okamura Family has been making mochi, etc. for over 100 years with family pride showing so deep you can taste it in the mochi.  Should I rephrase that?  Nah ... I often bring Benkyodo goods into my office in Burlingame for Staff and CFO.  CFO says her family cannot eat any other kind of mochi, only Benkyodo.  Listen up, let that be it ... with similar comments from other office kin folk ... score dude, get it while you can.

The traditional is always nice and faithfully portrayed at Benkyodo BUT catch the chocolate and marshmellows mochi ... ahha ... chocolate subtle goodness with mochi vibes.  Allen loves the chilidogs ... the counter action is retro in the best of ways.  The mochi is IT.  Back these guys, they have been doing it right, for over 100 years.  Can you say that?  Help the tradition live on!  Pics on their website ~benkyodocompany.com~Terry says, check it out~

I would click on their "useful/friendly/cool."  You should stop by, it's worth a special trip.  Make a day out of Japantown for it's one of only 3 left in the United States ... and support the JCCCNC.org ~ ahaha ~
author: Terry A.

description:
I love this place!  My 5 year old daughter loves this place!  It has been here forever, and exudes the kind of charm that only a 100 year old place can.  

We love the Habutai and Chofu.  But the absolute best are the seasonal fruit  mochi: the strawberry and blueberry are amazing.

They also have a peanut butter mochi which is delicious and apple manju which are a great choice for someone who is not as adventurous.

The mochi itself has the perfect texture, soft but still toothsome.  The filings are fantastic: silky smooth and not too sweet.  They have both the really traditional flavors/styles, and more "contemporary" flavors.  

The folks here are always so friendly and helpful.  If there is something that is not in the case, they will often let me know when it will be coming out  so I can reserve a couple for later.  I never leave without a dozen to take home and a couple extra for the road.  I hope they are around for another 100 years!
author: Scott T.

description:
An impromptu stop after going to CPMC with mom up the street. Actually we went across the street first to Yasukochi's for my brother but as expected, at 230PM, the cases were already empty save for a few danishes.

I needed to fulfill a sweet fix and went into Benkyodo. I wasn't sure what I wanted, I'd been here a number of times before and I was just going to get the usual with the red bean inside. But the blueberry was calling my name and so was that LAST apple manju!

The blueberry had fresh blueberries inside that just popped sweet yummy goodness and worked with the super soft melt in your mouth fantastic mochi. 

The apple manju was SUPER yummy too and so glad I got the last one.

Have to head out that way next week and I went online to plan my next attack. So so so glad I picked the 2 I got which are apparently new to the menu! YAY!
author: Dina V.

description:
Mochis! Mochis!

I love Japanese desserts but never had a fresh mochi before until I discovered Benkyodo.  Benkyodo is an unassuming little corner coffee shop in Japantown but is known for their mochis -- especially the strawberry mochi.  If you have a sweet tooth, you will enjoy this delicate treat.  The strawberry mochi has a sticky rice outer layer and filled with soft creamy white bean paste with a fresh strawberry in the middle, when it's in season. 

There are other flavors as well.  Try this if you like sweet & sticky desserts.

Tip: Get the strawberry mochi when it's in season.
author: Lis A.

description:
The lady at the counter is so sweet. She explained all the different types of sweets there are. if she isnt there at the counter yet there is a picture  that also tells u whats' what 

The mochi here is sooo good and the texture is so soft.. The strawberry one is my favorite. The others ones are good too. The apple manju is like a apple pie. they have mochi that either has whole red bean or smooth red bean paste. i like them both. I haven't tried the blueberry one yet.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Pink Rice Perfection
Fresh Whole Strawberry Inside
Love At First Bite, Yum!

Get the strawberry manju... you won't regret it. Go early before they run out!
author: Leslie T.

description:
I'm not completely sold on Benkyodo. This was the first time I had ever been to a fresh mochi and manju shop so I had high expectations - maybe I didn't order the right stuff because I was a bit disappointed.

I ordered a blueberry mochi, apple manju, and something else that I can only describe as a ball of anko (red bean paste) wrapped in what looked like steamed matcha (green tea) cake/bread. 

I wanted to try the strawberry mochi that many reviewers raved about, but since I didn't see it in the display case I went with the blueberry. I can't say I really liked it. It had a white lima bean paste filling with real fresh blueberries, but the combination didn't really mesh well for me. I thought the lima bean paste wasn't quite thick enough, and the mochi didn't really taste like blueberry. I actually think this would be made better if they made a concentrated blueberry jam and mixed it into the lima bean paste filling because there wasn't enough blueberry flavor. The mochi skin itself tasted fresh and chewy.

The apple manju was also a let down. Once again, the outside skin tasted fine but the filling was boring. It tasted like Mickey D's apple pie filling, but it fails to leave an impression - I actually think the filling needs more cinnamon.

The matcha bun type thing with anko wasn't too bad. The anko definitely isn't canned (the canned stuff tends to be super sweet). 

These three pieces cost me $3.50 - which I think is an okay price for homemade mochi/manju since preparing all the pastes and is probably a lot of work. As someone who has tried the microwave method of making mochi, I appreciate that someone can make these by hand and have them come out so beautiful. 

There's also a cafe, I think I saw a few hot dogs on a hot dog roller that didn't look that appetizing. While my purchases today didn't exactly thrill me, I'm willing to give it another try and maybe be a bit more adventurous in my selection next time.
author: Monica W.

description: Wow. THE place to go for delicious, handmade mochi.
author: Sophia B.

description:
super soft mochi.  the blueberry mochi was delicious!!!  They were actually closed by the time we got there but was nice enough to open up just for us.  

$1.20 per mochi which is pretty cheap since it's a good size.
author: JY L.

description:
I'm sitting here with sticky hands, smiling with white residue dirtying my mouth and watching it fall all over my shirt. What an embarrassing mess. If anyone walks by and see me, they would sure wonder. 

Hold on, give me a moment to swallow.

NOW THAT WAS GOOD! The best mochi in San Francisco. My favorite from benkyodo? The fresh strawberry mochi. The fresh strawberry mochi is made of rice cake that is soft and chewy, it is covered with flour to prevent the ball from sticking to your hands. It is filled with semi sweet white bean paste and centered with a nice big piece of real strawberry fruit. The combined texture of the chewy rice ball, the creamy bean paste and the kick of tart strawberry will sure send a pulsating mouth orgasm from the tip of your tongue to the pit of your tummy.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Delicious.  Pricey.  Agree on the strawberry mochi.  I can't believe I didn't find this place myself, and so, must begrudgingly thank Yelp for the introduction.

It has a total mom-pop feel, and the mochi really is so fresh and so good.  It's cash only, and that annoys, but only until I eat one of their strawberry mochi, and then will agree to any and all requirements by this establishment.

They have a funny aged coffee counter where Japanese locals hang out.  They serve - that's right - deli sandwiches.  *snicker* I didn't see anyone eating a sandwich,  so I would just assume that people go there for the snacks and coffee.

Come here, buy mochi, eat. Repeat.
author: HQ G.

description: Best place in the area to get mochi and manju! I've been coming here for as long as I can remember and the mochi and manju are still just as delicious as I remember. Kinako mochi is my absolute favorite here. There is a very nice selection just make sure you don't come towards the end of the day because usually all the good stuff is gone.
author: Beca P.

description:
If you haven't tried Benkyoto's mochi in Japan Town, you are missing out. What you are looking for is a simple, coffee shop on Buchanan Street just down the way from the Denny's. Most people walked pass this store and not know they have the most delicious and authentic mochi. This is as authentic as the mochi you get in Japan. I love this place for many reasons:

1. Delicious, fresh mochi. 
The mochis are made fresh everyday onsite. The people who make them are Japanese (if you have read my other reviews, you'll know this is my pet peeve). When you go, you can see mochi displayed in their glass case shelves and mochis being made in the back room behind a curtain shielded doorway. It is as fresh as you can get. 

2. Authentic and wonderful flavors
The mochis are very authentically Japanese, soft, but slightly chewy. Their regular mochis flavors are the Green Tea with azuki (red bean paste); regular white mochi with azuki; yellow bean, baked mochi. In the summer, they made my favorite, the strawberry mochi with a whole strawberry covered with mochi outside. Oiishii! 

3. The store is independently own and has a simple, down to earth, non-pretentious flavor to it. I just love walking in there to find locals (mostly older folks) hanging out of the bar having coffee and a piece of mochi chatting about. It makes mochi shopping so much more interesting. 

The store is kind of hidden in Japan Town and you kind of have to look for it. Trust me when I say this: Once you have Benkyoto's mochi, you'll never buy any pre-packed or frozen mochi you find in supermarkets ever again. Benkyoto's mochi is fresh, the dough is slightly chewy and the filling is sweet, but not over powering. It is just perfect with a nice cup of hot Japanese green tea. I'm making myself hungry as I'm writing this review. Aren't you?
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
Best mochi I've had so far in the U.S. from the places I've tried in Los Angeles and New York. Loved the strawberry mochi/ichigo daifuku, one of my favorite eating experiences. 

The mochi is very obviously made fresh everyday and they will run out, so get there early. The texture is divine and whatever flavored/sweetened white bean paste they use, it's delicious. Oh, and the strawberries were amazing. Only sold during strawberry season, which happened to be when I visited!

The shop itself is very small and hole-in-the-wall feeling; it's cute. The people were friendly. Bring cash; from what I remember it's cash only.
author: Zayn G.

description:
FINALLY, I got it! I've been coming to Benkyoto every time I crave for freshly made mochi, but was never impressed or inspired to write a review. Maybe because I've been trying too hard to love it so I don't write a bad review. Thanks to the blueberry mochi so I finally understand why this place is so raved. Weird I know. Nothing Japanese about it. But the mochi is soooo softy, like a baby's buttcheek! The blueberry filling is just so pleasant and refreshing.

Why don't they make matcha mochi with red bean filling? Can you please make them? I really do crave them so badly...
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I love mochi...and Benkyodo makes awesome ones.  My favorites are the Pink Habutai (with white lima bean) and Strawberry Manju (has fresh strawberries in it).  These little pillows of dough definitely brighten up my day, especially since they are only $1.10 each ;)

Note: cash only!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Having been around for over 100 years, they must be doing something right.  My faves are the strawberry mochi, escpecially when there's fresh strawberries inside...too bad they weren't in sesaon year round, new chocolate marshmallow and the chofu, for those that don't like the bean paste - this is the one to pick - the soft mochi inside wrapped in a pancake.

TIP for strawberry and chocolate lovers: CALL AHEAD AND ORDER!
author: Lori M.

description: Adding to my best of list.  Benkyodo handmade mochi is beyond heavenly.  I've tried so many recipes at home but just can't get it as pillowy soft as they do here.  I like to keep it simple with the smooth red bean filling, but we always bring an assortment to parties and they all go like hot cakes.
author: Lisa S.

description:
My first taste of Mochi was sold to me by an elderly Japanese man outside of a supermarket in Osaka, Japan........that is where my culinary love affair with Mochi began. 
I am so happy to have Benkyodo Co. just a few blocks from my apartment in San Francisco, every time I walk through Japan Town I stop and have a mochi or two. 
Keep making that delicious Mochi!
author: David P.

description: Legit. Maybe a bit sweeter than I remember getting in Japan, but who cares? It's handmade everyday and tastes amazing. One of the gems of Japantown in my opinion
author: Matt R.

description:
The flavor of the season is.....BLUEBERRY.  I wanted strawberry but they were featuring blueberry today.  

Today, in a epic whirlwind of trying tons of edibles around Japantown and Pac Heights, I came in here and ordered the blueberry mochi, the mochi with the pancake wrapped around it, and a white bean mochi with baked pastry around it.

I barely got out of the store and slinked down the alleyway behind the store.  I could smell the fragrant blueberries.  The heft of the mochi in my right hand felt empowering.  After one bite, I was in Nantucket, picking blueberries in the bramble, cut-off denim shorts, blue and orange stripped t-shirt, pigtails, barefeet and freckles.  I was 7 years old again.  

BUT THE CRAZY THING is that those were not my memories!  I've never been to Nantucket.  I never picked blueberries.  I never had a blue and orange stripped t-shirt.  That is some powerful mochi to conjure up someone else's fond childhood memories and make me think they were mine.  That is some Willy Wonka magic right there.


The white bean mochi was at the recommendation of the nice man behind the counter with very good English.  He spoke better than me.  And he did not think less of me when I confessed that I abhor red bean.  He said that it doesn't make me a bad Asian daughter.  Forgiveness and a sweet.  

On the other side of the store, this place looks like a non-ironic diner.  The formica counter with the hot dog cooker.  The loyal patrons.  The cop stuffing his face.  I hope this place never goes away.
author: Christina C.

description: I was delighted when I saw that they had sakuramochi during girl's day. Makes me want to return every Japanese holiday to see if they have any specials other than their incredibly elusive...never mind! It's a secret! THIS REVIEW NEVER HAPPENED.
author: Margaret S.

description:
MOCHI MY TONGUE WITH YOUR GOODNESS BENKYODO!

DAILY FRESH MADE MOCHI's ... yesss you can smile now. 
However this isn't the only thing that makes these little balls of soft, plush, slightly gooey and dare I say sweet but not overwhelmingly sweet little balls, melt in your mouth as you take your first bite. The mix of outer sticky sweet goodness mixed in with the almost honey like flavor of the red beans is a perfect sugar on sugar combination.

My personal favorite is the DEEP FRIED MOCHI with sugar sprinkles on the outside and sweet red beans inside. It's almost like a donut, but dare I say better? you be the judge. Second favorite is the GREEN MOCHI with a toasty flavored powder on top. This mochi has more depth to it's taste with slight sweetness. Then I tried the STRAWBERRY MOCHI which was unique in flavor. There was no red bean paste, but some type of strawberry goo with a slice of REAL STRAWBERRY in the middle. Delish!

UmMMMMm...Are you still reading? WTH! STOP DROOLING AND GO TRY IT ALREADY!
author: Shanna K.

description: This is a rating for the mochi! Not sure how the diner food is. I had mochi with fresh strawberries and some kind of bean paste. Ridiculously delicious, really great mochi texture.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I absolutely love mochi, but my girlfriend never had it before so the first thing that came to my head was Benkyodo.

We entered the store and were greeted by a nice old lady. Since this was my gf's first mochi/manju experience she had no idea what anything was and looked to me for help.  Unfortunately my explanations weren't really doing it for her so we looked to the lady behind the counter.The lady was nice enough to explain what each individual mochi was. All the workers there are incredibly friendly and wrap your purchase in a gift wrapped box.

So we ordered a couple strawberry mochi and a bunch of other flavors so that we could try everything. I was loving every bite that I took and was happy my gf enjoyed it too. Shes not the biggest fan of red bean so the strawberry was her favorite. I love red bean, but I think the strawberry would be an easy second in my book.  I would have to say that anybody who goes here should try the strawberry.  Overall I can't think of a thing i would change and the whole box of mochi was just a blur.  A big giant delicious redbean filled blur.
author: Domingo D.

description:
I will definitely have to get here early next time!

Unfortunately, I arrived here late in the day so there was only  green tea mochi left. I would have liked to try some of their other flavors, but the green tea was still excellent (very soft and flavorful). It's not a good as the ones from Japan, but it's the best that I've had in the States. I'm still looking for a place that has the triangle shaped mochi (like you get in Kyoto).
author: Laura P.

description:
We sure did find out about this place in a roundabout way: A couple months ago we went to the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park and I was intrigued by something on the menu called manju. Considering ourselves semi-experts on Japanese cuisine & culture (as much as Westerners can be, anyway) we were surprised because we'd never heard of manju before. Turns out that what they called manju was really just mochi dusted with soy powder (sounds weird but tastes delicious!)

What was really unique was how soft and melt in your mouth they were. About a billion times better than the mochi one can buy in Asian grocery stores. And about ten times better than the mochi I've made at home (in a microwave!)

The Tea Garden charges a fortune, though: $2.50 per piece. I was so happy to find out, once we made our way to Benkyodo, that their prices were way cheaper so we could buy a lot more mochi! Anyway the connection, which I forgot to mention, was that the Tea Garden buys all their stuff from Benkyodo, which I found out from asking the server, so we went straight to the source and were delighted to find a lot more variety than what the Tea Garden offered.

Some recommendations: 
The green mochi with red bean paste dusted with soy powder.
The white mochi with a pink dot in the middle with white bean paste (again sounds weird but tastes so yummy! And it's a great change from red bean paste, which is in just about every Japanese dessert. It's also not as sweet as red bean paste).
The chocolate marshmallow mochi.
The square baked manju with white bean paste.
The round baked (or fried?) manju with red bean paste, I think it's coated with sugar, it tastes much like a donut (sinful!)
The apple manju-seasonal. Tastes like apple pie.

There were more but I can't remember them. We actually ordered one of each because I wanted to sample them all! And we weren't disappointed, either. A couple of them weren't that great: the white steamed manju with red bean paste. They were hard, perhaps because it was late in the afternoon when we bought them? Maybe they're soft in the morning when they're freshly made. In any case I'm happy that we tried them all, it was so worth it.
author: amii c.

description:
Mucho Macho Mochi.

That's right.  If you can say this phrase as smoothly as it tastes,
than you are a polyglot, a person who speaks multiple languages.

In case you are clueless, the first word is in Spanish for many; the second word is in English for manly; and the final word is in Japanese for soft, doughy glutenous sweets.  Together the phrase "MUCHO MACHO MOCHI" describes my love for these Benkyodo finger food.

Many people buy the ice cream mochi at Trader Joe's and think it is so phreaking good.  Well, get ready to be blown away by the uber-squishy , fresh golf-ball sized mochi with different flavors.  For a buck a piece, try three of my favorites: strawberry, peanut butter, and azuki beans.

Most tourists have never been here because this store is located in the back of Japantown.  There is also an old-school diner counter for the locals to dine.  

Please look at their website and call ahead to see which flavors they will make fresh that day.  Buy a dozen, because these bad boys go quickly if you leave it on the table.

**

Shorter version for Yelpers with A.D.D.:

The freshest mochi
I have ever tasted period.  
You are a stoogie
for not trying this
if you love sweets!

Dedicated to Elite Yelper Rita Y.  She is a mochi monster.
author: CT L.

description: The mochi here is amazing. Each is so ridiculous soft and fresh, it's like eating little balls of fluffy clouds. Most mochi I have eaten are like those frozen ones you buy at grocery stores with the frozen icecream/filling inside with a thin, chalky layer of mochi casing. I don't think I can ever go back to eating regular mochi. Benkyodo didn't have a huge variety when I went like the ones showed in the pictures on yelp, maybe it's cuz I went too late in the day and they were sold out. But of the ones I had, the 2 different kinds of red bean filling (smooth and whole) and the strawberry mochi (with an actual fresh strawberry inside), they sold me.
author: Kelly C.

description:
All these years of watching Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations are making me an increasingly adventurous eater. It's not that Benkyodo serves chocolate covered bugs, but for a white girl, bean desserts are pushing the comfort zone.

Upon arriving at the tiny shop, I was too intimidated to ask what every little thing was, so I got one of each. At $1 a piece, the total was $12... not too shabby!

I roped my friend into trying them with me, but he and I both quickly discovered that not all of the manju are home runs. I thought the manju skin was yummy and a perfect texture, but the bean fillings were kind of yucky. It's totally a taste thing, so I wouldn't detract points for that. But still, it wasn't earth-shattering.

I do think I'd love their mochi (no filling), but I'm assuming they were out when I visited since everything I bought had beans in the middle. Next time, I'll specifically ask for the mochi rather than manju. BUT the strawberry manju sounds intriguing and less heavy than the other varieties, so I'd definitely love to try it. 

I feel lucky to have access to this kind of authenticity in the US. Their work is time consuming and meticulous, which doesn't go unnoticed. I'd recommend Benkyodo to anyone.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Where have you been all my life??

Benkyodo has THE BEST mochi in the world! :D
Okay... my world... considering I have never been to Japan, but I have tasted a fair share of mochi and Benkyodo has the best by far.

I can't wait to go back for more!
author: Hannah K.

description:
I'm a costco cake - duncan hines frosting kind of girl, so I never really appreciated mochi...and all asian desserts. I read so many reviews about the mochi here at Benkyodo, thought I had to give it a try and see if it doesn't change my mind on mochi. Result? I like Benkyodo mochi! The texture of the mochi was soo smooth and soft and silky and chewy...all rolled up in one sweet bite. The red bean paste inside was sweet, and was well balanced with the mochi. 

There weren't any cool unique flavors the day I went - and it was still early afternoon! Boo!
author: Carol L.

description: Get the strawberry mochi. It has a fresh strawberry in it! The mochi is so soft and had just enough chew, it was definitely freshly made. It really is the best strawberry mochi I have ever had in the states.
author: Giang L.

description:
This is the BEST MOCHI place that I've found outside of Japan. They sell their fresh, daily-made mochi at a counter inside of a tiny diner. It's an odd place for mochi, but who cares if it helps contribute to their reasonable prices ($1.00-$1.50 each).

My favorite is the classic mochi with smooth red beans (azuki). I love the taste of the soft, pillowy mochi with the sweet azuki paste. (The blueberry mochi was a close second). 

Next time I'm going to try the peanut butter mochi and the strawberry mochi (when it's in season again).
author: Karin V.

description:
Benkyodo! They make all the mochi in the morning and close shop when they sell out, mMm freshness.

They have the tastiest mochi- soft, subtly sweet, and always precious, none of that packaged stale rubbery stuff. 
The Strawberry, white bean and Kuzu are some of my favorites but I'd probably eat any mochi there.

My mouth waters when I think of that place and I like the Asian-American Diner/Mochi duo, its such apart of history. 

Go Amazing Family Business'!
author: Rosalyn S.

description:
WOW!  The freshly made mochi was MOCHI-LICIOUS!  I ate 3 in a row in like 5 minutes.  Yes, I know, very lady-like wolfing one down with powder all over her lips.  Can you say hot?

When I can eat a sweet snack, I know is something I can eat on my elimination diet, I get super-duper excited.  It's crazy how food can make a person so elated and so depressed at the same time (well only when you know you can't eat something delicious).

So I got to eat one of each mochi that had been made that day and the sad part was there were only 3 kinds.  On their website it looks as if there should have been at least a dozen kinds.  I was a little sad about that, but really once I bit into the traditional mochi, all my cares melted away with the sticky rice mochi and red bean filling.  Oh the joy in my mouth with the sweetness and texture was really like the feeling you get when you flirt with your man.

I am going back again soon and hoping for more variety but not expecting any disappointment regardless.
author: Susan C.

description:
If you are looking for cheap mochi, this is the place.  The service wasn't very good.  It's not super sweet, but I didn't really like the texture-- I felt the skin was a bit too wet and sticky.   I bought 6 mochi, but didn't feel like eating it after I ate 2.  I don't think I'll go back to this place. 
"Minamoto Kitchoan" on market street is so much better!
author: Elena L.

description:
Mochi is delicious and they have a more filling to rice cake ratio. The chocolate marshmallow mochi is my favorite. If I can make it to San Fran, this is my go to spot for mochi. 

I bought 40 and was given 2 free peanut butter mochi. But they wouldn't let me select any of the strawberry mochi in the gift set because I wasn't going to give them away until 2 days later. The strawberry mochi is best eaten fresh.
author: Linda S.

description: This place probably doesn't another review but boy, it was worth the drive.  The mochi was so soft and fresh.  The lady behind the counter was really nice and gave great recommendations.  I bought 8 different kinds but the green mochi with soy bean power was my favorite!  Next time I have a craving, I will be going back!
author: Cindy L.

description: Yummy! Finally made it here!! We brought a box of six mochi.  soo fresh and delicious!  at $1/piece, i think it's pretty worth it! the special, which was chocolate and marshmellows were awesome!!  my second best was strawberries...! the others were mostly filled with red beans, and they all pretty much tasted the same.  service was not very friendly either, but thats okay.  yummmy! we gotta go earlier next time though, b/c i felt like we missed out on the yummy, unique stuff! LOL
author: Tramy V.

description:
I came back on Yelp just to say the blueberry mochi and chocolate marshmallow mochi were amazing.

Soff and supple and packing a bunch of flavor. The blueberries ooze out into the white bean paste and explode as you bite into them. The chocolate mochi has the perfect chocolate flavor with a nice bitter chocolate finish and smooth texture. 

I love mochi and I am totally in love with Benkyodo, I wish there was one here in LA. Fugetsudo needs to get with it.
author: Crystal T.

description:
Could not wait to try their mochi, and I'm sure the lady at the counter could agree as my and my friend purchased 2 of everything! If it wasn't for yelp i would have never discovered this rad bakery! So big thanks to the yelpers!

Like I said, I ordered two of everything, alot? not really. They have a fair sized selection of mochi treats, some not even mochi! Their specials today were Blueberry and Apple, both of which I haven't tried yet, but am dying to!

The taste quality is definitely distinguishable to the air-sealed box versions that i thought only existed before the disvoery of BENKYODO CO.! The mochi is is soft, chewy and tastes suprisingly fresh. How you ask? Cannot even explain it in words. Just tasty! They are also reallllllllllllly realllllllly sweet! So don't go and order 20ish mochi to devour on your own; share, because it's caring. I had two or three and that was enough. but for those with a huge sweet tooth, maybe you could go for one or two more.

The mochi's are about $1 each if you buy them in 4,6,12's, etc. If you were to get Apple or Blueberry then add .10 cents please. Very fair!

Will be back for more mochi soon...
author: Alex C.

description:
Ok, I have been wanting to check this place out for a while...but didn't until recently. What have I been missing? 

If you think that ice cream you buy at Trader Joe's, or even what you buy packaged at asian grocery stores is real mochi...well, I suppose I can't say much about that...but Benkyodo is heavenly. It's squishy, cool, just slightly sweet, and filled with fresh ingredients. When you bite into the strawberry, you are surprised with a glistening fresh strawberry tucked into the gluten. I crave them. They also have traditional bean flavors and green tea, etc. which are excellent, but I'm kinda digging the strawberry.
author: N B.

description: This place is just amazing and such a great gem in SF that I feel not many people know or talk about. In my opinion, it's one of the most authentic places in Japantown. The mochi has the perfect texture and best of all, it's freshly made! I feel bad for always forgetting about this place. But it definitely gives me my Strawberry Mochi fix every time I go.
author: Amimee D.

description:
I guess everyone is reviewing the place simply based on their mochi. In all fairness, I see how there's no way to rate this place on the decor or the service. It's just a small coffee/bakery shop. I came here on Tuesday and looked for the Strawberry Mochi that all the reviews were raving about but they had none!! It was still early, just turned 1pm & the women behind the counter said that they were out. So, I had to settle for other Mochi. I had 2 red bean, 1 chocolate marshmallow and 1 other one that I do not remember the name. 

It's true, the mochi here is definitely fresh. And just like others, when I thought of Mochi I think of the ice cream mochi that they sell in the ice cream isle. But this mochi is waaaay better. I guess I'm giving it three stars because the lady behind the counter did not really explain to me what the mochi was even when I asked about different flavors. I'd probably be better off going with someone who knows more about it to get the better service. 

I'd come back here with someone who can help me out. Hopefully I can try the fresh strawberry mochi.
author: Sarina I.

description: Fresh, light, absolutely delicious little treats ready to devour. A bargain at just $1/piece!!!!! I tried the red center mochi and it was fantastic. The mochi was HUGE and so fresh, and light. Really just a delightful little treat. Down the strip of shops across the street from the huge mall, it is tucked in the corner and ready to tempt your taste buds.
author: Mandy L.

description: I don't think I've had mochi better than this except in Taiwan. I tried the white bean smooth, the red bean smooth, and had some of my friend's donut one (Agemochi) and they were all perfectly delicious. The mochi themselves are fresh and made that day, with a chewy skin that is just thick enough and a flavorful filling that brought out the bean flavor (not too sweet!). The owner was a very nice old man who chatted with us and was  very helpful in selecting mochi. We'll definitely be back, if just to get some strawberry mochis (they run out so quick!).
author: Dustin H.

description: Best chili dogs! Uncomplicated with a tasty popping-skin hotdog and old-fashioned  plain chili on a small bun, served on a diner counter (no chairs or tables available) by a guy named Bobby. The best.
author: Mia T.

description:
This is the third time I've been in here. 

Got in around 12:30pm after our lunch in J-town. There were 2-3 people ahead of me. I only saw 2 trays of mochi under the counter. Finally it was my turn to order. A typical ojisan asked me what I want. I asked if they have any strawberry or other filling of mochi left besides the smooth red bean mochi in the tray. He told me they're all SOLD OUT already but will have more in the afternoon. 

So I ordered 8 red bean mochi and wanna try the "sticky rice" pieces next to the mochi. I honestly had no idea what they are, but the atmosphere in here was really stressful, so I told the ojisan I will take two of each of the round and oval shaped sticky rice, pointing to them. He said impatiently, "they are exactly the same, except the round one has 'say-see-me' in it."

I got really confused and asked "sashimi?!?"    

He rolled his eyes and scoffed "SAY-SEE-ME! SAY-SEE-ME!!!"

Ok ok, I get it... Sesame...

So rude!!! This place reminds me of Seinfeld's soup Nazi episode. This is the Mochi-Nazi!!!  

The mochi is good, but a tad too sweet. So definitely not worth the abuse... esp after we discovered the $53 parking ticket on our windshield... We were only 4 minutes late when the parking meter expired!
author: mei c.

description:
omgsh omgsh omgsh!
I will walk 8 blocks through the Tenderloin to reach one of my favorite little shops in the city: Benkyodo. 

Their fried red bean mochi is like a Japanese donut that is not too sweet and filled with oozing red bean of amazingness. I love taro, and their taro mochi hits the spot. EVERYTHING is good here, just be adventurous. Although it is relatively expensive, you gotta do it. 

I once got 5 pieces of mochi, sat down at the counter, and was ridiculed by the old uncle sitting at the other end, "You are going to eat FIVE PIECES!? In ONE sitting!? Ba ha ha!" But I DID IT! And enjoyed every piece with extreme enthusiasm. Then making the trek back to Union Square area, I was feeling a little nauseous. woops!
author: Sony M.

description: First time eating mochi here and... it's simply amazing. One bite made me buy 2 boxes. one for a birthday gift for my gf. the 2nd for myself Lol... The service is really nice and they give good details on their products. I will always stop by to pick up some mochi.
author: Andrew C.

description: Recently received a box of mochi as a gift.  Since Mochi is not readily made anywhere and everywhere in America, Nice Work.  However, if you go to Japan there is just so many to compare to.  Solid stuff here.
author: Shiho F.

description: I love the fact they have "Ichigo Daifuku" the strawberry mochi!! This place make me imagine what was the Japanese American life like around the war time. I hope nothing will change. Forget about renovation and such coz this place is wonderful the way it is!!
author: Coko K.

description:
This place is a little bit off the beaten path of Japantown. You might not even know it was here if you didn't do some exploring! It's not a must-go-to, but it's interesting. They've been making mochi for over 100 years, so they know what they are doing. Cash only!
I am a big fan of the strawberry mochi because there is a fresh ichigo inside! And I feel that you either really love mochi, real mochi not ice cream mochi from Trader Joes, or you hate it. 
I took my cousin here because he had never had real mochi... only ice cream mochi... and he HATED IT. I think beans in desserts are just kind of a weird idea for Americans to handle.
Once when I was in high school, we went to Japantown for our Japanese class field trip. I told my group I wanted to go here. (11th grade Natalie, mind you). So a bunch of my classmates and I ventured off onto the other side of the street while everyone looked for comic books and pens... We ran into our Japanese teacher in the store, who is actually from Japan, buying mochi... So I think that confirms that this place is pretty good.
author: Natalie C.

description: Yummy Blueberry Mochi & Roppo (square baked mochi w/ red bean paste)
author: Anthony M.

description:
When I die, I want to be mummified in a gigantic* mochi from Benkyodo.  Wrap me in that sweet rice dough and throw me into the ground.  SO I CAN EAT MY WAY OUT.  What...you thought I was just gonna die?  Bitches, please.  I'm gonna fucking come back as the hottest, most awesome Zombie you ever saw.  First, I'm gonna eat my mochi bodysuit and then i'm gonna move on to the entire city of San Francisco and I'm not going to stop until I eat the brains of every last one of you faux liberal, fascist asshole pieces of shit.   I might be vegan but I am done with you chumps and anyway, I heard human brains taste like Strawberry Shortcake and I fucking LOVE Strawberry shortcake. Delicious.

*I think I am a size 18W in Mochi.
author: Laura B.

description:
This is the most authentic place in San Francisco. It is a real gem. Appears to be family owned and operated for decades. And the mochi is made fresh.

Once you go here, you will never buy mochi anywhere else!
author: Maria M.

description:
I can't believe so many people love mochi.  It brings tears to my eyes.  I'm so flattered you all love a Japanese sweet so much.  (Not me, the mochi.)  Shucks. 

So anyways, I thought I'd tell you all that the amateur version is easy to make since Benkyodo is rarely open when I'm loitering in J-Town.  You make it in the microwave in an instant.  I use to bring it to school when I was a kid and everyone hated it.  Come to think of it, no one liked any of my Japanese food.  Everyone laughed at me when I brought rice balls to school, and I begged my mom for a tuna sandwich.  Boy, times have changed.  Okay, can I not make myself sound old.  Anwyays, here's the recipe to try at home. 

1    cup  mochiko sweet rice flour (white box)
1   cup water
1/4  cup sugar
    katakuriko (potato starch) or kinako (soy powder) for dusting 

1.  Mix mochiko and sugar in a bowl
Add water and mix thoroughly. (Add a few drops of food coloring for color variation; A few drops of flavoring for taste variation.)
2.  Put in a microwaveable dish. Cover with plastic wrap.
Microwave on high for 4 minutes. Take off plastic wrap. Cool for a few minutes.  Shape into mochi.  
3.  Fill it with red bean paste, peanut butter if you want to copy Benkyodo, ice cream, or don't fill it at all.
4.  Dust with katakuriko (potato starch) or kinako (soy powder) to prevent mochi from sticking.

My favorite is slighly pink mochi and I stuff it with red bean and strawberry!  

And, last but not least, eat slowly so you don't choke.  Its a plus to have a warm cup of green tea on standby incase the mochi starts to get stuck in throat.
author: Wakako U.

description:
This shop is basically a cozy little storefront in a little mall town.On Saturday mornings at 8 am there is a group of coffee guzzling grumpy looking men all crowded around an orange laminate wrap around counter top. I thought this was adorable.  
The Mochi : The mochi is better than average and less than phenominal. I will continue to make the trek to Shuei-Do Manju Shop in san jose for my mochi. The reason I didnt like the mochi was because the mochi was a bit heavy and chewy for my taste and the beans weren't  super silky. I had all of the flavors and I liked them all except for the peanut butter and the blueberry.
author: monika w.

description:
Japantown has always seemed sad to me. Not pathetic, necessarily, just melancholy. Like, I can hear the wailing souls of dead Queen Annes and Stick-Eastlakes mowed down in middle age by an overzealous Redevelopment Agency, the pained cries of the people of the Nihonmachi removed from their community into unjust internment, and the pleas of the awkward layout and cheap building materials and perpetually depressed commercial climate preyed on by brokers and developers. I don't mean to be harsh, just that Japantown is where I go to feel unmoored, disconnected, and blue.

Well, it was. Until it became where I go to stuff my face with azuki mochi.
author: Megan W.

description:
Best Mochi I've ever had in my life!
Strawberry mochi is a must. It comes quite as a surprise when taste the actual strawberry inside.
author: Joyce B.

description:
Years of fresh mochi goodness forgone...thank you Yelpers for pointing me in the direction of these Benkyodo mochi. 

Many years ago my friend and I were in Japantown looking for a place to grab lunch.  We looked in the window of Benkyodo.  The menu of American sandwiches and the hot dogs rolling around on that machine didn't appeal to us, so we moved on.  I didn't think Benkyodo had anything special to offer.

I wish I had stepped inside and noticed the counter of fresh mochi...I had three red bean filled ones yesterday - plain white, green, and green w/ powder - oh, they were so good - like babies - tender and soft.  Wonderful red bean filling - not too sweet, not super smooth but with bits of bean, very beany.  The shell was very sticky and very fresh.  Lots of paste - high paste to shell ratio.  The same bean filling appears in their yummy red bean buns.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I've only had better mochi in Hawaii, and that's because I followed the advice of my annoyingly picky Korean mother and went to Palama Market.  I love their strawberry mochi.  The peanut butter ones?  Not so much.  

If you're looking for a little something to bring to a dinner party, mochi is always a yummy choice.  Me?  I buy a dozen and eat them all myself, greedy pig that I am.  If you've had a mochi from Benkyodo, you've done the same thing...come on, ADMIT IT!
author: Kristina R.

description: Wow. It's the same way I felt when I tried the salted caramel ice cream at bi-rite and a sandwich at Ike's. One of those, there's no way this can be as good as it's yelp! hype. and then, sh*t. it's all that and more! I had no idea mochi was supposed to taste like this. I tired the red bean, lima bean and green tea and got a manju since I'd never had that before. The manju was not for me. Kinda like a small apple turnover but drier. The mochi however was soft and melt-in-your-mouthy and uh-mazing! I'm going back today to try the peanut butter mochi (bringing a friend though cause those come in 4 packs and there's no chance I have the willpower to resist eating the whole box). Yum!
author: jenny h.

description:
The Mochi here are made in the traditional way, by pounding the gelatinous rice into a dough in a huge mortar.  I heard that the owner uses the same mortar that was used by his grandfather.

The dough is so deliciously sweet and pale and soft, it is like biting into baby flesh.  Well, what I would imagine, anyway.

There is a cool old-fashioned counter that begs for an afternoon of people-watching.

Oh, and please be careful!

"Mochi is very sticky and somewhat tricky to eat. After each new year, it is reported in the Japanese media how many people die from choking on mochi. The victims are usually elderly. Because it is so sticky, it is difficult to dislodge via the Heimlich maneuver. In the Japanese comedy film Tampopo, a house vacuum is used to suck it out. (Some lifesaving experts say that a vacuum cleaner is actually efficient for stuck mochi.[1])" - Wikepedia
author: Liz S.

description: Man, oh man I sure do love anything sweet in my mouth.  I wonder why its taken so long to write a review? Anyway, I tried the chocolate and marshmallow mochi and oh my freakin god it was delicious.  The taste of chocolate was subtle, gah but made me melt away.  I was a bit surprised since the size outdid the rest of the mochi, it was pretty slightly huge.  I'm pretty sure you've had a similar experience when the mochi kind of sticks to the roof of your mouth and you have a tingly sensation. Yep Benkyodo makes some good mochi indeed.  Another favorite is the strawberry mochi along with the green colored sprinkled with yellow powder and suama :).
author: Glu C.

description:
What else can I say about Benkyodo that hasn't been said?

We ended up in J-town after stuffing ourselves with dim sum at Koi Palace, so were more than full when I coaxed my wife and sister-in-law to go to Benkyodo after reading all about it on Yelp.

Benkyodo is a weird little place because the right half of it is a diner and the other half is where the mochis are sold. We bought a plate of four that included two strawberry mochis, one sakura and one "donut" filled with red bean paste. 

We were still full from dim sum, but I ate one of the strawberry mochis almost immediately. It was soft and melted in my mouth and the best part was the strawberry slice that was embedded in the mochi. We ended up going around town and forgetting about the other three mochis and i inadvertently left them in my car overnight, so we didn't eat them until the next morning...

And they were still great! The mochis were still soft, which is a testament to their freshness, and the donut with red bean paste was especially good.

Seeing that picture of those beautiful strawberry mochis on the Yelp home page for the last month has been...frustrating. Well, if that picture every made your mouth water for some strawberry mochis like it did mine, then go to Benkyodo immediately!
author: Arnold G.

description:
Across China, Taiwan, and Japan there are lots of small mom & pop type businesses, particularly restaurants or shops specializing in a specific delicacy, and are known to do so for generations.Those that have surpased a century in age, are come to known as, in Chinese ,"bai lien lao dien" (Mandarin) or "bak leen lo deem" (Cantonese) which translates directly to "100 year old shop".

But there's a lot more behind that meaning. What do these businesses have in common?

- In addition to age, a lot of history and contribution to their local community. Perhaps a landmark and or representation of the finest they have to offer.
- Receipe(s) that produce magical works of art for public consumption.
- Receipe(s) that at times may require the full use of one hands, creating things from scratch. After all machine made can only do so much. 
- Receipe(s) for products (food for example) handed down from generation to generation, strictly within the family (amongst men only was the general rule, women in the family were thought to be of liability and would marry outside, and not entrusted with the original family receipes or the business. Only boys or men next in line would qualify, like the kings in the old world)
- A firm dedication and committment to preservation of tradition, culture, methods of preparation, execution, and thus consistently maintaining quality. The essential spirit of the business.

There is a sushi-ya right by Tsukiji Market called Sushi Bun that I did a yelp review on. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/hPsrvt8CMSkTudm5uMmLtQ?hrid=MyCauJ98P0A6aI1TByML8Q

150 year old place, handed down at least 4 generations. A true "100 year old shop"!

Benkyodo Co, I would say they are the only true "100 year old shop" in the whole of the Bay Area and they have my full vote on this, and probably the only place I can think of that does everything very well based on first impressions.

I cannot believe after living in SF for so long, that it took yelp reviews for me to check this place out. I have passed by this place on Sundays, it was always closed, and from the outside certainly does not look very interesting.

I have never really been a big fan of wagashi and mochi...until yesterday. During my last major visit to Japan in 1999 (joining a guided tour unfortunately), I had samples of numerous similar types, perhaps they were machine made, or the flavors just didn't sink in with me. Our tour guide told us these were called "grass cakes", literally mochi made with a type of grass leaf (hence the color), which interesting enough the Hakka Taiwanese took that concept and made a steamed salty variation of it (using preserved veg, pork slices, daikon etc) called Ngeh Ban.

But yesterday morning I found a rare opportunity to be in the area. I went into Benkyodo and this was a bit before10 am. On the right was a coffee shop counter service place, with lots of old/retired Japanese Americans. To the left was the actual store itself, with a very impressive display.

I had the pleasure of having one of the owner's daughters serve me at the cashier. She was very patient and friendly and to top it off very helpful. I ended up buying four pieces, and ended up picking two of their most popular flavors, the Kinako mochi (smooth red bean with soybean flour) and the strawberry mochi.

I made the mistake of eating the strawberry mochi first. Never have I had such a wonderful, smooth, and fresh piece! To top it off there was a small fresh piece of strawberry inside. The flavors and textures really played tricks with my tongue, as there were hints of sour and sweetness hitting from all sides. I'm definitely coming back for more if I can. Forget the "chocolate roses" from Murata's Cafe Hana in Kintetsu Mall, get strawberry mochi's for your female boo, dudes. That yelper joke about his female gal pal getting multiple orgasms from eating one was certainly not kidding. In case you were wondering I managed to keep my pants dry after eating one of each (then again I only ate one, maybe not if I had several...), but can't wait till the next time I head up there!

The Kinako was excellent in its own way. A lush green outer later, with a very refined and delicate red bean interior that was gushing with flavor and not overly or sickly sweet. I can see why San Francisco magazine in 2001 voted this as one of their "must eats" lists, which Benkyodo Co proudly mention on their website.

I asked the daughter if she was interested in learning the mochi making process, and she said she isn't learning it at this time, but her older brother is. It sounds like owners Ricky and Bobby are still set on retiring once the kids hit college, but unless something changes, I can only hope this place can remain open for the many years to come so that my generation and the next, can continue to appreciate goodness like this.

Thank you, Benkyodo, for letting us know what authentic, real fresh and delicious mochi can be (and should be).
author: Ken K.

description:
My parents left South Korea during the authoritarian regime of Park Chung Hee.  Of course I don't remember that since I wasn't quite 2 at the time but after his assassination, my mother and I went back to visit the family she'd left behind.  I must've been about 3 or 4 and I don't remember much except for spending a lot of time with my grandfathers.  

My paternal grandfather had been a high school principal which is kind of a big deal there.  I was the first born to his first born so he liked me a lot.  He would ride me to the park on the handlebars of his bike.  I later found out he also told my mom about behaviors he noticed in me so that she could make sure they didn't become bigger issues.  Apparently, I was shy.

The last time I spoke to him, I was 11 and he was dying of cancer.  I hadn't seen him in 7 years.  My dad was going to be flying out the next day and they told me to get on the phone and tell him to hold on until my dad arrived.  I was scared of what he would sound like.  I thought his voice would be very weak or hoarse.  The reality was worse.  He sounded just like my father.  That night I dreamed of fire and lava.  The next day he was gone. 

I'm not sure what my maternal grandfather did as an occupation but he was very social and active.  My first memory of him is of a balding, small man that I used to follow around like a puppy.  He would introduce me as his granddaughter and I never felt so proud.  The last time I saw him, I was 12 and the language barrier was bad enough that I was often mute around him.  I was there in the winter and didn't have gloves so he took me to a corner store to get some and I had the strongest sense of deja vu.  The night he passed, I dreamed in white. 

I associate mochi with my grandfathers.  I can remember eating the red bean filled ones on new years with both of them and whenever I bite into one, for a moment, I'm sitting on the handlebars of an old bike or trailing behind a small old man who walked at a very fast pace. 

I hadn't had mochi in a long time but Darin brought a variety from Benkyodo to a picnic recently.  They were all good.  The mochi was soft and not too sweet and the different fillings were sufficiently mashed and tasted right.  

I guess I could also go into why my grandfathers make me think of the Japanese but I'll spare you.
author: Seong P.

description:
When i'm not craving indian curries, or chocolate, I usually go for mochi because they are such satisfying little snacks. However, all mochi is not created equal. If you try the pre-packaged stuff that is sold in markets and then try the mochi sold at benkyodo you will notice one big difference-FRESHNESS. 

I actually have passed up benkyodo many times, not knowing they sold mochis. Until one day a friend introduced me to this place. I felt like I just discovered a pirate's treasure filled with mochi's for my consumption. I bought a whole dozen's worth and pretty much devoured it with a friend in one sitting. Who am I kidding....I probably ate 80% of them, but it's to be expected of me. So no surprise there. Favorites included the azuki filled, the strawberry, and the sakura mochis (seasonal).
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
I LOVE manju. I've tried nearly all of their selection, but my favorite is the age manju, AKA doughnut manju. Deeeeeelicious!

On
another 
note:

Bobby helped me with the hoji manju arrangements for my grandfather's funeral in October, and again for the 50-day service in November. He made getting the manju one less thing to worry about, for which I'm eternally grateful. Thank you, Bobby! 

Great article on Benkyodo: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/archive/2001/02/08/MNL92388.DTL
author: Amy D.

description:
Not sure why it took me this long to review Benkyodo. I've been going there for years. YEARS I tell you. 

Some people like their manju on the stiff side. I prefer mine a little softer - so for me  freshness counts big time. There's nothing like biting into a mini-pillow of sweet rice goodness, that literally melts away.

I've been known to drop in and pick some up if:
- the sun is shinging
- the fog has rolled in
- I have guests coming over
- I am walking by the store while it's open
- I see the owner's smiley face 

And best of all, if I am hungry, I can saddle up to the little coffee counter in there and hang with some of the seniors from the neighborhood and have lunch. Helps me keep my fingers out of the nicely packaged box until I get home. 

I love their manju/mochi and everything else about this family business that makes it such a special part of Japan Town.
author: Stephanie I.

description: I'm not gonna write a long review for this.. All I need to say is "Strawberry Mochi" !!!!!
author: Juliane N.

description:
Jedi-master level class rating for this true mom and pop place down in JTown. Yes, it looks like cheap diner, and in fact, you do get cheap diner food here like burgers, fries, hot dogs, and pop. but the true Force-filled food here is their mochi. This stuff is hand made, filled with yummy goodness worthy of any purple lightsaber and it is cheap to boot. This is like, Megan Fox in the Princess Leia slave outfit good! 

the red bean mochi is so creamy you think that the owners flew to Tokyo that morning and smuggled a ton back here. the blueberry mochi is also a winner, as is the white bean mochi. and let me say to all my padawans that the mochi skin is so smooth and silky, I'd give up the rebel base on the Endor Moon if they give me their secret to making it so good.
author: Jerry C.

description:
You know when you get something somewhere and you want to be polite so you say something like, "Oh, I'll be back later." and you never go back...

Well, that's exactly what I said to the sweet lady at Benkyodo after I purchased a strawberry mochi. 

Me: Walks out of Benkyodo and casually takes a bite of the mochi...
Me: Walks back into Benkyodo and buys 5 more different kinds of mochi

This is the only time in my life I have ever said,"Oh, I'll be back later" and actually went back...

Yeah, it's THAT good...
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
FYI:
I'm sure many of you already know this but Benkyodo was driven out around the time of WWII and then reopened later by the previous owner's son.
author: Emahlee H.

description: The most yummiest & softest mochi ever!  Tried the blueberry which was an interesting flavor, lime bean mochi, & the soy powder red bean mochi. My fave was the soy powder red bean. I really would like to try the strawberry but with no luck when I get there.  It's a bit expensive, $1.20 or so for each, but its a must try! Not to eat it all the time but just giving yourself a treat sometimes, is worth it!
author: Alyce l.

description:
I've been frequenting Benkyodo for over four years.
I've also tried mochi and manju at various Japantown offerings across California.  Nothing comes close to Benkyodo.

The Strawberry Mochi (w/ the whole strawberry!) is the epitome of mochi greatness.  If they ever succeed in tearing Japantown down, I wouldn't think twice to throw myself in front of the bulldozers just to save this place!

I bring boxed dozens when I visit friends and family, and families of friends.  Let's just say, thanks to Benkyodo's confections, people are always asking me to visit them; thus making me a hot commodity.

Thanks again, Benkyodo!
author: Chase C.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?

The first time I visited Benkyodo I was just as timid as Amanda C.  I ordered a whole box of assorted goodies to-go under the guise that it was a gift.  I guess you could say I was lying, but what's wrong with buying yourself presents?!

Each piece was indeed a present, wrapped in pillowy soft rice dough, filled with a dreamy delicious filling... 

Let's just say that all I ate that day was manju and mochi.  We shall not speak of the comatose that overtook me later that afternoon!

Both the manju and mochi would have been accompanied well with hot green tea and a box of assorted goodies would be a great gift if you're visiting a friend.

My second visit consisted of myself and a troop of friends, one of which was visiting from the Middle East.  Everyone fell in love with the mochi, Chocolate Marshmallow was a hit, as was the Strawberry!

If you haven't visited Benkyodo Co., what are you waiting for?!  Get off your butt and head to J-town ASAP!
author: El T.

description:
The tomogi mochi and the age donut are my lovers.  The strawberry mochi was kind of "eh" and the special weekend mochi (the one with the chunky sticky rice on the inside and the red bean paste on the outside) made my buddy scrunch up her face after tasting it.  Though I suspect I would've liked it if I had gotten a chance to eat that one.  =P

This place does not have nearly as much variety as the Mikawaya mochi boutique in L.A.'s Little Tokyo (to which I give 5 stars), but the taste and texture are comparable, and Benkyo-do does offer a couple unique creations you don't often see anywhere else.  

Service was nice and friendly.  J-town seniors just chill around the dining counter chatting.  Old Asian people who hang out at dingy diners are awesome.
author: Diana Y.

description: Freshly-made mochi. No where else you can get them except there. Blueberry is my favorite.
author: Iris C.

description:
WWWWWWAAAAOOOWWW!!!  I'm so glad that I finally got to try out some manju at Benkyodo.  I can understand why there are so many great reviews.  Today, I purchased half of a dozen of Yomogi. 

Admittedly, I am not a fan of the red bean.  Yeah, yeah, I know...half of me comes from the Japanese gene-pool.  Yeah, I also know that my family were bakers AND makers of manju back in Kyushu.  WAAAAHHH!!!

Anyhow, the manju is so good that I actually ate 4 out of the 6 manju that I purchased in a 2 hour time frame.  Like the Colonel's Fried Chicken, it was "finger lickin' good"!  The mochi was soft and sweet and the red bean was not overdone and not underdone.  It did not weigh heavily on my tummy, as I had expected it to.  

Honestly, I called my mom right up and made her jealous by telling her that I was eating yomogi manju on a beautiful SF Saturday morning...
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Put three indecisive girls together and you'll spend at least 15 minutes standing in front of the counter deciding amongst 12 different mochi selections. We had to let at least 4 people go ahead before we finally made our selections.

Here's Sweet Treat #2:

"1 baked mochi, 1 strawberry mochi, 1 red bean mochi, & 1 white bean mochi."

Okay.. so my review will be a bit biased because I personally don't really like mochi. But everything Japanese is so darn cute, that even knowing its mochi, they looked too cute I thought they'd taste good. Wrong! Despite being bite size and perfectly molded and packed, I still wasn't a converted mochi lover. But you deserve stars for just being family owned and operated, and oh-so patient with us.
author: Sue Y.

description:
The lady behind the counter was sweet, I like her. When I asked what was most popular the unsurprising answer was, "EVERYTHING is popular!" I can see why. Our mochi balls and red bean bun and red bean donut were all great. I particularly liked the donut (ugh, so American of me) but I was wishing we'd have stayed in and had some tea. 

I'd definitely like to go back, maybe with someone who knows their Japanese sweets as well as my finicky taste-- I bet they could really make my taste buds dance!
author: Jen S.

description:
This place is almost lost in time,  part all American diner, part Japanese sweet shop, small but holds a lot of treasures!  I've never tried the hot food they serve, but i swear by the mochis they make.  My favourite is the Sakura mochis they make, but they are seasonal.  you can get them year round at some of the supermarkets that are around, but none come close to being as good as these are.  I use to do event planning for the university I went to and I had a Japanese inspired dance where i bought and served 100 of these mochis.  Everyone loved them and they all gone within an hour and people were still asking for more!

They are a super friendly, family run business and are always willing help, or explain what mochis are for those who don't know.  Don't feel bad about asking what they are, you're not alone.  the only draw back is that they don't accept credit cards or debt.  Cash and checks only!
author: Brian J.

description: After reading all of the positive Yelp reviews for Benkyodo recently I just had to give this place a try.  I made my first visit on Wednesday morning and I purchased three varieties of the manju (the Habutai, the Yomogi, and the Strawberry Manju).  The Yomogi became my instant favorite.  I loved the texture of the bits of whole red bean in the filling.  The Strawberry Manju must be eaten slowly in order to get that hint of strawberry essence in the smooth white bean filling.  I have often purchased the pre-packaged manju and mochi found at Asian supermarkets, but that will be a thing of the past soon.  I visited Benkyodo for a second time Friday afternoon, and I can't wait to taste some of the other varieties I picked up.  Thank you fellow Yelpers for introducing me to this Japantown treasure!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Aside from Shuei-Do in San Jose, this is pretty much your only option for authentic, wagashi (Japanese sweets).  And what an option it is!

Old traditional favorites like yomogi ("the green one", with a kind of herb pounded into it (mugwort)) sit next to new-fangled innovations (I'm looking at you, strawberry-an filled daifuku!), lined up in the case waiting for your selection.

There are over a dozen kinds of manju here- and even if you can only refer to them as "that one with the baked outside" or "the pink one," the staff is happy to cater to hungry newbies- there's even a cheat-sheet by the register so you can see what's in each kind without asking.

Highly recommended.  For first-timers, I recommend the kinako-covered manju, the yomogi, maybe a couple of the baked outside ones (make sure to get a selection of insides!)  and of course "the pink one."  Can't go wrong with the pink one.
author: Brian D.

description:
Strawberry mochi is still on my mind, filled with delicious white anko (sweet bean paste) + a slice of fresh strawberry!

They've been around since 1906 and are one of the last mochi making places in San Francisco.  According to this article, this might be the last generation to run this shop, depending on whether their kids want to continue.  

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/02/08/MNL92388.DTL&hw=benkyodo&sn=001&sc=1000

Go eat their mochi while it's still around, a living legacy.  Carpe diem!

PS:  Go early for better selection.

PPS: They also have an ol' school counter that serves ice cream, burgers, etc.  Retro-ol'-school-cool.
author: Cathy K.

description:
I am totally impressionable.  So when I kept seeing shining reviews for this place pop up every time I was on Yelp, and the fact that it is 3 blocks down from my house, I had to try  Mochi.  
I tried going there and found nothing in the counter so I assumed I was too late.  I tried again on my way home last Friday and I was extremely pleased.  I am new to the world of Mochi but the soft and subtle sweetness of the delicate little treats is just heavenly.  
And the people that work there are very nice...the nice lady explained to me what each thing was and indicated I would like the strawberry mochi, she was right!
I must go back and try all of them. Hooray for mochi!
author: Nilu r.

description: Fresh mochi at good prices, and tasty, tongue tantalizing, too! Don't miss the fried mochi. It's what would happen if a donut and a mochi had a one-night stand. Mmm... the peanut butter (crunchy!) mochi is pretty good, too.
author: Bee H.

description:
i just figured out why my boyfriend gets me these things before he leaves on long trips. CARBS! mochi is grinded rice and rice is my favorite carb in the whole wide world! it's also my worst enemy. my mind is always telling me no, but my body, my body is telling me yes. HE WANTS ME TO GET FAT so when he's gone no one will even care to look at his territory. i knew he was sabotaging me with the bearded papa's cream puffs, but this was just evil. i thought these past few months i was just going through puberty again with the rapid growth of my ass and my chest, but mr. chef knew what to feed me to plump me up. maybe he's fattening me up so he could eat me. 

he knows my weakness is the strawberry mochi ones because i get a rash from strawberries but eat them anyway. benkyodo, please hide the strawberry ones when my boyfriend goes there.
author: Renae C.

description:
Mmm, chewy starchy sugary Japanese confectionary yum.

After plowing through Yasukochi's Sweet Stop with five slices of cake, I couldn't stop there. I asked someone if there was a shop in Japantown that sold fresh mochi and they told me kitty-corner from Super Mira, at Benkyodo.  

Luckily I only had a few dollars left, otherwise who knows how much sugar and starch I would have left that place with!

Benkyodo is an interesting amalgamation of old school tiny coffee shop and fresh handmade manju shop. I walked in and expected to smell rice flour and red bean paste. Instead I was greeted by a waft of coffee-shop; the same coffee smell you'd find in any bakery in Either Old Chinatown or New Chinatown.  I loved the old school sign on the wall that posts their menu of chili-cheese hot dogs and egg salad sanwich ilk. I was looking for the corndog and french fries, the staple of a similar -looking joint my prepubescent friends and I used to frequent after school.

Onward to the main reason I came here- there was a line of about 8 peole in front of me, givign me some time to consider what I could get with my four dollars. I ended up passing on the Sakura (or Girls' Day) and peanut butter manju and went with strawberry, kinako, kuri and ima.
