i've never had a strawberry mochi with a white bean and strawberry filling before- I've usually had it with the red bean- it had a lovely fresh strawberry flavor and aroma, but a little too sweet for my taste. 

The kinako was great- wonderful texture of the manju and such fresh flavor. 

I've never had the kuri or imo before but they were both good- I think I prefer the imo over the kuri as the imo had a slight flavor advantage with the lightest hint of cinnamon. the texture and density of the kuri and imo outer layer was good- it wasn't dry or powdery nor was it cakey. These both had silky smooth sweetened lima bean fillings. 

I love the fact that they are one of only two manju shops still around in the bay Area, and I'm planning on trying more of their flavors. For freshness and variety this place is artisan shop for manju!
author: Mortiche W.

description:
Thanks to fellow yelpers... I finally gave this place a try on Friday... LUUURRRVE the Strawberry Manju (Smooth white lima beans with fresh strawberries and strawberry flavoring)... OMG... the skin was soo smooth, soft and thin... there were fresh chunks of strawberries inside and it was just the best mochi I've had in a long time.. 

I also got 'Chofu' (Pancake wrap with plain sweet rice) -- pretty yummy, the pancake was really moist, fresh and fluffy. Plus the 'Dorayaki' (Pancake with whole red beans) -- Good too... just wish that I had some hot tea to go with it!

However, the 'Fukusa' (Green sponge-like pancake with whole red beans) was average... didn't suit my taste.. took a bite and didn't want anymore of it.. 

Overall, if you visit this place... YOU MUST ORDER THE STRAWBERRY MANJU!!.. I think I'll be returning soon  to sample a bit of everything on the menu =) *drools*

Updates: We drove 42 miles for their strawberry manju and to our disappointment, it was all SOLD OUT! *tear* So we decided to get something else instead since we were already there...Tried the peanut butter manju, Kuri (Manju baked with smooth white lima beans), and the Pink Habutai (Pink mochi with smooth white lima beans)..

Peanut butter was too 'chunky' and peanut buttery... definitely not my fave, I had to scoop most of the peanut butter out with the spoon and just eat the skin of the manju... not a fan of the Kuri either... it was kinda dry.. but I did enjoy the Pink habutai, although I think that was just a 'stand in' for the strawberry manju since the skin looks the same =P
author: Kym L.

description:
Mochi is a Japanese confection.
Its outer is of rice flour,
pounded into silky perfection.
Its inner, sweet bean paste,
wrapped together,
with attention.

Benkyodo Co, is where it's freshly made,
its selections abound,
can make eyes go dazed.

That with strawberry filling, may be seasonal,
at a dollar,
makes your wallet lighter, 
but your mouth, 
happier.
The emerald, dusted with sesame flour,
simple but a staple,
makes the sweet tooth,
appeased.

So forget the store-bought,
shrink-wrapped,
leathery golf balls,
go visit Benkyodo Co
for a fresh bite,
of that foreign dessert
that will make you spout,
domo
arigato.
author: Ethan x.

description:
I used to work across the street at Sanko with whole bunch of Japanese ladies and their favorite manju place is Benkyodo.

Their manju are sooofftt and chewy, not sticky.  The one with sweet rice and red bean paste outside is one of my favorite.  Of course you can't miss the girl's day manju.  It's plum flavor with red bean paste middle (i believe) wrapped with shiso leaf.  

A box of manju with choice of coffee or tea was the thing to do at Sanko for our 3:00 tea time break :D  Gawd, i miss working with those ladies.
author: Gigi T.

description:
I have to admit, I'm a mochi-snob. The texture of the mochi here is so soft, you feel like you're biting into a pillowy cloud. It's thick enough to offer a nice filling-mochi ratio, but thin enough that it seems to melt in your mouth. The fillings have just the right amount of sweetness, offering a strong red/white bean flavor. (I find that other places err with adding too much sugar, or adding too much crap to the filling so it tastes really processed).

If available, get the fruit filled onces (blueberry, strawberry). I love the bursts of fruit mixed in with the bean paste.

In addition to the mochi goodness, I like sticking around and getting a a turkey sandwich to chill out with the japanese elders. It's so nice to have such a neighborhoody place - I can roll out of bed and show up in my PJs while I grab the first batch of mochi at 8am :)
author: PJ V.

description: very cute, very tasty mochi - although most have a bean paste inside, and only the blueberry and peanut butter are non-bean fillings this week (Jan 2012). They will wrap it for you very kawaii-like if you say it's a gift and order a boxful. About $15 for 13 mochi.
author: Lily K.

description:
Great mochi!  
But I'm convinced that Joyce and other yelpers must have been to a Benkyodo in the Mirror Universe because there was nothing friendly about the service I received there about a few months ago.  I got there one afternoon, and there was only one kind of mochi in the glass case.  When I politely asked about their usual selections of mochi, the Japanese woman at the counter curtly told me that they mainly do wholesale and implied that they would not sell a few mochi at a time except for leftovers.  I want more mochi, but I'm afraid of that woman!
author: Ryoko M.

description:
They have blueberry mochi now!
The blueberries were sweet and pop in your mouth, releasing their juices into the bean paste and mochi.
I may prefer these to the strawberry ones. If the strawberry isn't ripe it's sour against the sweet bean paste.

There were no other fruit offerings when I went, which was 4pm on a Saturday. There were a fair number of blueberry mochis left, though. Great snack if you're feeling peckish wandering around J-town.
author: Amy N.

description:
This is one of two places in San Francisco to find freshly made mochi. The amazing thing about the mochi here is that the mochi is not made from glutinous rice flour, but rather from real rice that is pounded and pounded into a glutinous paste -- the old, traditional way. Yum! 

I've had mochi here twice and both times was incredibly pleased. It's a nice change from the traditional Western sweets that tend to be a lot harsher on the tooth. The mochi here is so fresh that it almost melts in your mouth. It's good to come here at different times of the year because the store always puts out seasonal mochi, like the fresh strawberry ones that so many people rave about.
author: Yvonne W.

description: I'm personally not a big mochi fan but the kid is.  He had a craving today for some mochi and we were in the area so we stopped in.  We got in just before a big rush...was 2nd in line so the wait was not bad and the service was good.  We picked up 2 boxes of the 6 mochi per box.  One for us and one for one of our best friends.  The kid was happy and the best friend was happy...makes me happy!
author: Stella C.

description:
Five stars for making my girl friend from Toronto have multiple orgasms while eating the strawberry mochi.  If you can make a girl do that, that alone is worth the five stars.  Alas, the orgasm was wasted on me instead of a straight guy....what a pity. (Note to the single men: you might want to keep these mochi on hand with the mood strike for a little something something. *wink wink*)

This was my friend's first trip to San Francisco and we swung by here after a great lunch at the Korea House.  I been wanting to try out the mochi since so many fellow Yelpers were raving for this place and since I got there on early Friday afternoon, so we decided to check it out.  A nice Japanese woman greeted us at the counter and we decided to which of the mochi we were going to get and try.  We settled on strawberry mochi, red bean and the peanut butter ones.  

The red bean was great, not too sweet and just the right amount of red beans in it.   The mochi itself is nice and soft, the best mochi I ever had in my life.  The peanut butter mochi was fill with nice dense crunchy peanut butter.

But the strawberry mochi, which has real strawberry in it with jelly is the star.  The conversation went with my girl friend and I went something like this....

Me:  Oh my god this is so f@^&#* good!
MT (moaning):  Oh my god this is so f@^&#* fabulous, I can die now!!!!  Oh my god I think I just had multiple orgasms!!! I can't believe it!!!!
Me (giving her the death stare):  .........,   why in the hell are you telling me this!??!?!  Do I really have to know?!?!?!
MT:  Yes you do and I don't care. This f@^&#* rocks!

If strawberry mochi can make her do that.  I don't want to know what else could.  She is single and if you want to know more information on her, let me know. ;)

Other than that,  go to Benkyodo Co and have your own orgasms.
author: Chris C.

description:
I feel ashamed that I only recently learned of this place.  The pink,  peanut butter-filled manju rocks - as do many others like Strawberry, and the more traditional red-bean filled varieties of course. As a kid I used to eat only the mochi exterior and toss the fillings - much to my Mom's disappointment. "Mottainai!!" she would say...The Japanese term for "what a waste."

I encountered pleasant service both times I have been.  I even busted out some Japanese and was responded to in kind. Many Japanese folks in retail shops won't converse with a "Hapa" like me in the mother tongue, so I was pleased. :-)

I think Benkyodo is truly is a San Francisco "institution" having been here since ~1906. I understand the family was put in a concentration camp during WWII and restarted the business after the war.  The old storefront has a captioned photo in the book, "San Francisco's Japan town" in the Images of America series.

At any rate, I have not had any food / drink other than  getting manju to go...but I did have a pleasant experience. I will be a regular going forward.
author: masugu m.

description:
I've been going to Benkyodo since the 60's. A great place to catch up with my Jtown friends and sneak a little sweet mochi treat. Bobby and Ricky are doing a great job continuing the family tradition that has flourished for 100 years. Dang that's a long time!

Waking up early to prepare the mochi is a tough job, so please don't monku about them closing at 5pm.
author: umeboshi l.

description:
I hate to go against the grain, but I thought Benkyodo's mochi were rustic, at best.  

While a strawberry always makes a pleasant addition to daifuku, the rice flour and bean paste in Benkyodo's version was overly sweet.  The traditional mochi-based daifuku and manju that I had were also too sticky, as if too much water had been added to the base.  The texture of the mochi wasnt that smooth either.

The inaka steamed mochi was nothing special and the baked ones paled in comparison to others that I've previously had.

The mochi here remind me of what your mom might make at home: humbly presented with a recipe that's a little off--quirky in a rustic way that is undeniably homemade.  

I recommend Sakura-ya in Gardena (SoCal) for the most ethereal, smooth mochi you will ever have.  But Eiji (SF) takes the cake for the best I've ever had: a strawberry daifuku with a strawberry that is 3" large with a thin layer of red bean paste and mochi rice cake on the outside.  Eiji is a restaurant so make sure you call ahead to see if these babies are on the menu that night.
author: Monica T.

description:
Man, I wish more people talked about the true time when this shop closes because I went around 3pm and there was basically nothing left!  I was so sad...YOU YOU greedy mofos just had to take them all!  I really wanted the PB mochi because I LOVE pb!  But nope, lucky there was just enough red bean mochi for each of us to have one.  It was really soft and yummy, but man it was just teasing me.  You can't just have one of those suckers, you know!  

Man, next time I head to SF I'm showing up at that shop at 8am sharp.  I'm not messing around this time.  I want my PB and all the other flavors they have.  Then I'll come back around 3pm and laugh at all the people who couldn't get any because I was greedy and bought a crap load of them.  I'll say, it SUCKS HUH! 


...and then give them a pb mochi  :P
author: Jenny C.

description:
Benkyodo is my go to place for mochi.  It's the last mochi bakery left in San Francisco.  They have a great family staff... it feels like Cheers every time you walk in.

I LOVE the peanut butter mochi... it will seriously be the death of me!  I have conflicting feelings about Benkyodo being closed on Sundays... on the one hand, I'd have peanut butter mochi 7 days a week =).. on the other hand.. Id have peanut butter mochi SEVEN days a week!  Ugh! I'd be 1000lbs before I know it!

They celebrated their 100th anniversary this year!  I hope the family legacy lives on forever!  

Happy 100th Birthday Benkyodo, here's to 100 more!
author: K M.

description:
I almost teared trying my first strawberry last night. Yes, take my Benkyodo virginity OH mouthful of heaven.
I was there 845 AM today. Im a big fan of morning afterglow.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
The lowdown:

a. Fresh mochi and manju
b. Cash or check only establishment
c. Benkyodo also has cookies and crackers
d. They no longer have the big box that fits 15 manju pieces. Choose wisely - or in pieces of 12 at max per box.
e. If you go a few days before the New Year in a procrastionators fashion, do not expect to get any manju until after the New Year
f. They have peanut butter mochi!
g. Super yum on my charts!
author: Judy L.

description:
Fresh, soft, light and melts in your mouth...

Believe the hype.  I did- and it more than surpassed my expectations.
author: Vitamin C.

description: Although I was a little put off when I walked in and saw how small the store was, the manju and pancake mochi was really yummy!  If you like mochi this is the place to go.
author: Meg B.

description:
Finally, this afternoon, I got to go to Benkyodo and try the mochi that my brother has been raving about for the past few weeks (and that everyone else has been raving about for the past 100 years!).  Unfortunately, I got there a little too late to get any of the strawberry mochi, although I managed to snag one of the last two packages of the peanut butter mochi.  We also got the classic red bean and white bean.

The mochi are in a word, exquisite.  Soft and pillowy, they almost feel like they could melt in your mouth.  They are unbelievably fresh and the fillings are delicious.  The peanut butter seemed a little odd since I'm used to a red bean filling.  But, being the peanut butter fan that I am, I still found it to be interesting and delicious.  The star of the bunch, though, was the red bean.  We got both the smooth and the whole bean, and both were awesome.  I prefer the whole bean to the smooth, since it had a nice texture and offered a good contrast to the chewy dough.  The fillings are sweet without being cloying and the dough has enough flavor to be eaten on its own .

Overall, I would definitely go back to Benkyodo to get more mochi.  Hopefully, next time, I'll get there early enough to get the strawberry mochi...I can't wait to try it.  The lunch counter looked intriguing as well, so perhaps it'll be a full meal for me the next time I'm there.
author: Angela H.

description:
Talk about hole in the wall. To the left you have hot dogs and hamburgers and to the left you have mochi.  Try the strawberry ones, they are pretty tasty.  The red bean paste is also very good.

Great size and they stay soft and chewy 2 days later as well.

Very filling and quite tasty so give it a shot. It's worth the price in my opinion. I've been told that when they sell out, its game over.
author: Joel Y.

description: I love this place! It helps me with my mochi craving! Good thing I work kind of close by to this place.  The first time I came here it was hard to find the place because it does not seem to be a mochi place since I thought they would have more displays for mochi! Anyways! The donut mochi or fried mochi was soo good! They pound their own mochi flour! My teacher told me that the mochi taste better when it is super fresh and after 11am it does not taste good anymore.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Benkyodo makes the BEST melt in your mouth mochi, ever. When my parents used to visit from NY, they would always pack up several boxes of Benkyodo mochi to bring back to their friends there. 

My favorite is the pink kind with white bean filling. MMMMMMMMMM.
author: Susan I.

description: these are the best mochi treats around. made fresh with azuki beans, sweet mungbean paste, strawberry, peanut butter or plain. wonderful taste and nice gooey texture. try them, you'll like them!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Best Japanese Maju place.  I wasn't a fan of Mochi until I found Benkyodo. My favorite is the fresh strawberry mochi, but they're not in season now.  The lady will give you instructions on how long you can keep them (3 days), etc.. Others like delicious too.. I love to pet those little fluffy silky mochi.. man they're so cute! :D

It's oddly located next to a fastfood burger/milkshake stand (breakfast bar).  I don't see how they relate to each other.  The mochi treasure is on your left when you enter.  Don't miss it!
author: Carina N.

description:
Another place I had to visit thanks to Mia S.! 

Unfortunately they didn't have peanut butter and only a couple strawberrry left. But the strawberry was the best I've had, and trust me, I've had a lot! Their mochi is really soft and is one of the best I've had in the U.S.
author: The Sock S.

description:
Really fresh mochi....the strawberry is my favorite... the guy if you ask him explains all the different kinds of mochi that they have....the mochi itself was okay...

a little difficult to find... had to ask around...i

RECOMMENDATION: 
Get there early to get the mochi flavor that you want because when i went the strawberry mochi was almost gone! I went 30 minutes before closing..
author: Omi Y.

description: Mochi!! Have no clue which ones have what in them but I just eat them and wait for the unexpected taste & reaction. lol My gf works a block away so she oftens comes home with a box of assorted mochi. I have yet to be able to tell the differences in taste/quality from other places that sell this because I have tried others. But hey if it tastes good why change?!?
author: Jeff C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for the longest time, but everytime I make it to Japantown, it's either too late or on a Sunday.  

Fortunately my mom happens to be around that area one day and for some reason (perhaps because I mention it too many times?), she called me and asked if she should get some mochi to try.  I was ecstatic.  

Unfortunately, they ran out of the strawberry ones that every review seems to mention, and all we got were 4 different red bean paste mochis.  My mom had no idea what exactly she bought, whatever looked pretty, I guess.  

Well, the whatever-mochi she got were delicious!  You can definitely tell the difference between Benkydo mochi and your average mochi from a grocery shop or those supposedly "Fresh" ones sold in Japantown.  The Benkyodo ones tasted truly fresh (I know I sound like a Subway commercial right now).  The red bean paste was still sweet, but doesn't have that processed food feel.  You can actually tell that they were chunky red beans, not just sugar!

One star off for not having enough strawberry mochis by 2pm.  C'mon, when will I ever be able to make it to Japantown before 2pm?
author: Candice B.

description:
Mochis & Hot Dogs....what an interesting combination. 

Benkyodo is on the side of J-town I never walk through. When I first saw the shop, I thought it was one of those places where senior citizens have their coffee, cops buy their doughnuts, and drunken old men may stumble in to after a drink or few at the bar. Turns out, I was wrong. Benkyodo is a cute little diner on the corner. There is a very homey feel to the place, which gives it a very unique atmosphere. Benkyodo is a confections place that doesn't have that smug feeling surrounding it....(*ahem ahem GODIVA*)  Also the fact that I can eat a hamburger, then spin my chair around and have mochi for desert is awesome. 

The mochis are real tasty. they have has the perfect texture...not too chewy and soft enough to bite all the way through. I don't know if I missed it, but if they have mochi with fresh fruit inside...then it would hands down be the best mochi ever. :)

Recommendations: 
Habutai - White mochi with smooth red beans
Imo -  Baked with smooth white lima beans and cinnamon coating
Cherry rice wrapped in pickled tea leaf 
Age - Donut with smooth red beans
author: Lisa T.

description: No rating yet... came on Wednesday evening amd there was only the lima bean flavor left.... bought a few. They were okay. Will come again possibly earlier to try the strawberry and blue berry
author: Mohammed G.

description:
My mom loves mochi and she thought these tasted very fresh and yummy.  Unfortunately when I went, they were sold out of all flavors except for red beans and lima beans.

I can't wait to go back and try the strawberry and chestnut flavored mochis.

Service was also top notch.  The guy who was helping me was very patient and helpful in explaining the 6 different types of mochi that were leftover.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I love the mochi here and the variety the shop has to offer. Each is unique with the perfect texture, taste, and flavor. Most importantly, none are overly sweet. The filling on the inside is smooth and have a paste like consistency. Best of all, they're hand made!

My favorites are the pink mochi w/smooth white lima beans and the strawberry manju filled w/white lima beans, fresh strawberries, and strawberry flavoring. They do tend to run out so you'll want to pick them up early esp the strawberry manju.

I DO NOT recommend the peanut butter manju. It's just a mochi filled w/reg peanut butter. It just didn't taste right to me. Also try any of the red bean filled mochi - all are very good. 

We usually end up getting a box of mochi ...about 10-12 costing us more than $10, but well worth it.
author: Veronica H.

description: I really wish they had longer hours.... and had more mochi. If you get in here within 3 hours of closing, most of the yummy stuff is already gone. The quality is insanely good and the texture and flavors are dead on. Sinfully delightful.... I can't wait to be back in SF when they're open so I can gorge around on the mochis and roll around in the leftover rice powder.
author: Vicky L.

description:
I remember coming here after grade school for manju snacks.  This place is a staple J-town.  The sell the best manjus I've ever had.  Why I'm finally writing this review, because I just came here and ordered the Fresh Strawberry & Chocolate Marshmallow manju and they were divine!  They even gave my niece a free strawberry one.  Everyone here is always so nice and helpful.  
My friend told me the Peanut Butter manju is to die for but unfortunately they didn't make that kind today.  
Delicious and reasonably priced - averaging $1/piece.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Great Mochi, 
Lurve the interior.
Old Japanese folk just chillin at the counter.
Now this is what Japan Town needs more of.
A cultural, neighborhood gathering spot that reeks authenticity.
Long live Benkyodo
Holla
author: Tak H.

description:
I love this place! Best Mochi in San Francisco. I've never been a huge fan of Red Bean Mochi...but I love plain mochi, no filling, and kinoko (try it, brown sugar, white sugar, and kinoko--from Asian supermartkets). 

After having made mochi a few times, go Japanese roots, I've learned that it's not that easy and it is harder then it looks. Benkyodo's mochi is soft and smooth and tastes delicious. Try the strawberry mochi...def well worth it. Although, before you buy it...ask to make sure they have real strawberries or not...it depends if it's strawberry season (otherwise they just use strawberry paste).  Oh yeah, and the peanut butter mochi is also good, or so I've heard (I'm allergic). 

Try it...I recommend it if you've never had mochi. Def one of the better places! Everyone on my Japanese side of the family always comes here...I swear! Even my Nisei grandmother  (and all her siblings) & my Issei grandfather loved it!
author: Alison N.

description:
This is a culinary landmark of SF.  This establishment is as significant as the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and Fisherman's Wharf.  Shame on you if you live in the Bay Area and you haven't been here yet.

And the culinary icon of this establishment is the mochi.  Without a doubt, this is the pinnacle of mochis.  

The hours of the establishment is odd, so be prepared to get there before lunchtime (and not on Sundays since they're closed) if you're looking to try all their flavors. 

FYI - you go through all my reviews, you'll note that this is my first and only 5 star rating - that is how important I believe this establishment is.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
STRAWBERRY MOCHI!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Fresh strawberries, soft, chewy mochi. Only $1. Worth every penny!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
We have been eating mochi at benkyodo for years, whenever I go the SF I always stop by here and buy couple boxes to share. There is no other place like this.  Absolutely the best mochi ever! Last time they didn't have the donut one, my favorite... :(   
Its actually very easy to eat a whole box yourself.....very tempting. ooh I want one now!
author: Leo S.

description:
I stil don't get what's the big hype about this place. I should've known. I don't like red beans so imagine going there with most of the filling of the mochi is red beans! They didn't even have the peanut butter anymore. The strawberry was okay compare to others. The selection was very limited maybe it's because I came there like 3 in the afternoon? 

Honestly, won't be coming back. I should just stick with mochi ice creams =)
author: Perry S.

description:
Fresh strawberry mochi, and crunchy peanut butter mochi! Sheeezzzee, who knew? It takes the pbj to a whole other level. I want to sleep hugging a mochi pillow filled with peanut butter goodness. 

Don't miss on the more traditional bean fillings, but there's a chocolate marshmellow mochi that blows my mind. Get there early for best selection. The helpful gentleman at the counter gives you a thorough rundown on their offerings.
author: Antoi C.

description:
"Why lie? I want Manju." Simply put, their manju is a drug. I get cravings for it. When I stop by, I buy lots of it. My last purchase was for 12 strawberry manju. I've purchased 15 or more before. It's that GOOD. Also, the strawberry one is seasonal, so summertime is the best time for some fresh strawberries.

I would also recommend their habutai, pink habutai, and kinako. But these are my personal preferences, but there should be something for everyone.

Oh yeah, they've been around since 1906. That's some real history right there. It's nice to know that they made it through some tough times and I hope that they stay open for many generations to come.

Psst... They sell candy too.
author: Edwin L.

description:
The place doesn't look like much but it doesn't have to. Authentic, handmade manju... you don't get that very often anymore!  I've read elsewhere that this is a family business and it doesn't look like the next generation is going to be carrying on the business. It's such a shame too. The day will come when there will be no more handmade manju shops in the Bay Area and that's just darned sad.

I've been here once or twice (and had manju from this place from other shops) and they certainly do make some good mochi. Are they rude? I haven't encountered any rudeness and believe me, that's a big deal to me! Tasty food with history, I'll buy that! Hopefully it will convince them to stay around as long as possible.
author: Michelle N.

description:
MANJU!! yummy!! My ex boyfriend who also happens to be japanese turned me on to this place. He also very proudly corrected me when I called in Mochi.  I thought I had good Manju, but when I tried the Manju here, I was impressed. So impressed I had to buy at least 2 of every flavor and bring it back to my family to try. My two favorites are the red bean and the peanut butter filled. 

I seriously have to come here everytime I make it out to Japantown. the run out of  Manju very quickly, so don't get there too late. The people are super friendly, and the place looks like a small diner.
author: Carla T.

description:
Best Mochi in TOWN!

Sneak here and get your strawberry Manju & Kinako on - eat it as quickly as possible so you won't have to share it!

Yum Yum
author: sHoo o.

description:
Tasty mochi.  Creative selection.  My favorite is the strawberry even though it's $1 a pop.  Still can't bring myself to try to peanut butter version, but I will... some day.

Mochi is supposed to be rustic.  People see that as a negative?  I say it's a plus.  Much better than mass produced mochi muffins...

I have had better ...  and worse.  It's conveniently located on the corner so your cohort can wait in the car while you pick up the goods.  I am a very nice & courteous customer but the woman always seems to be annoyed to take my order.  Maybe I am not tipping enough... or maybe because as a complete blondie I am too much of a kyokugaisha...
author: Cat K.

description:
I love manju and mochi. It's something I've grown up with and would never be able to live without. Benkyodo is the only place in Japan Town that sells fresh mochi/manju. However, I don't find their stuff all that great. It gets a lot of attention from being the oldest and only shop in J-Town, but I really think that their sweets are just average. (On many occasions I found that the kuri manju is too sweet or dry... and it's my favorite snack so it kills it for me..)

They have made some weird Americanized mochi/manjus, and it scares me. Just like that review by Becky S. says, the peanut butter one? WTF? I think the taste is tailored to those who still think that mochi is an ice cream or to those who only eat chicken teriyaki and california rolls.

There used to be another manju shop where the resturaunt Suzu (?) is now located. That was owned and operated by an old Japanese couple and they made much better stuff. It was sad that they decided to retire so now I have no choice but to go to Benkyodo.

There is another awesome manju shop located in the San Jose Japan Town, I highly suggest checking that place out.

But yes, Benkyodo, you shall only recieve 4 stars from me..
author: Yuri K.

description: All the mochi I've tried here has been pretty good, but my favorite by far is the strawberry mochi.  You can't beat fresh mochi made with fresh strawberries.
author: Karen W.

description:
I was super full from brunch, but I managed to eat 6 mochi all by myself because they are just so good here!  The mochi is tender and chewy, and the fillings aren't cloyingly sweet.

I heard good things about their strawberry mochi, but they were out of it when we got there.  Maybe next time.

UPDATE: I have since tried their strawberry mochi and it's AWESOME.  Tender mochi, wrapped around a sweet juicy soft strawberry.
author: Sonia C.

description: FINALLY - got me some fresh mochi when they usually run out or they have been too moist - but I have to give 5 stars because the texture was perfect and the fillings were not too sweet. This is practically a lost art and I'm so glad that people are out there who appreciate it because there are so few mochi shops...as far as I'm concerned, there is no substitute for fresh mochi!
author: Dee Z.

description:
Best Mochi/ Manju in the states..
Where ever i end up i'll keep coming back to this secret place!
Just tried the PeanutButter Mochi.. o so good!
Nobody does it better!
author: JASON L.

description:
Strawberry filled mochi... Nihon doesn't even have THAT!!!  Mochi is so soft and the bite of a real strawberry within it is just like Awwwww YEAAAA!!!

I just wished they came in other flavors like *MANGO* hint, hint Benkyodo.
author: Yoko H.

description: I've tried to make manju and mochi Japanese desserts and its a labor-intensive process.  The Okamoto family painstakingly and lovingly devotes time and care into making their sweets.  Been coming here since I was a kid when my parents would bring me -- had hot dogs at their old-fashioned counter and then a mochi or manju treat afterwards.  I only come for the Japanese sweets now.  I've tried other Japanese dessert places which have "bells and whistles," but the main sellling point of Benkyodo's sweet confections for me is that they're guaranteed fresh and preservative-free (most of the pre-packaged Japanese-style mochi in the local Japanese and Asian stores aren't, especially if shipped in from abroad).
author: Bodhi D.

description: You know you have a serious addiction when you visit a place three times in a week. I will warn you now. Once you have the donut ones, you keep coming back again and again and again and again .........
author: Sophia C.

description: I've been here for Mochi once and of course it's great!  You don't need to a guy from N.C. to tell you that.  I really want to get back for a cup of coffee or something and just sit down at the old counter.  I love places like Benkyodo.  They're what make J-Town so great.  You have to visit this place at least once.
author: Corey V.

description:
Another place from my childhood.  My dad would sneak my sister and me here after gorging ourselves in JaJangMyun for a few of these delicious treats!  Until my Americanized palate was developed enough to fully appreciate the raw kind, my dad would settle on giving my sister and me the fried kind with white bean.  *drool*

Both my mouth and eyes get a little watery every time we step into this place.  After they closed down the giant Sanrio store, I begin to fear for the gems of Japantown!
author: Grace K.

description:
Great fresh mochi, manju, and other wagashi (Japanese sweets) produced not by one of Japantown's touristy joints but by a great local, family-run business that has a century of history behind it.  The texture of the treats are fantastic, mainly because they're so fresh: Think meltingly soft, almost fluffy sweet rice. Mmmm.

If you're in the mood for mochi and related treats, I urge you: Please, please support this great business and try to get here before closing instead of looking elsewhere.  If they're closed you can always go to Nijiya or Nippon Ya, but the stuff there won't be fresh-made, and the items at Nippon Ya in particular contain a lot of crappy ingredients designed to keep them shelf-stable for weeks, even months.

(Nippon Ya is also a lot more expensive as a rule: I can get a nicely wrapped box of ten huge, fresh manju for about $8 at Benkyodo - or shell out $13-$14 for twelve TINY, not-fresh manju at Nippon Ya.)

I'm taking one star off because I basically agree with Chie J.'s review: Benkyodo isn't afraid to use artificial colors and flavors here and there, and the manju taste a little too rustic.  What I mean by that is that most of the manju are a little too sweet for my palate, which is something I normally deal with when I eat Western desserts, not when I eat wagashi; even paired with a strong/bitter tea some of the treats are quite overpowering.  Because of these issues I stick to Benkyodo's plainer, less colorful manju (and their komochi, which is great when gently steam-fried).

P.S. Go there now while it's still late winter/early spring so that you can try their fresh sakuramochi!  OM NOM NOM.
author: James L.

description:
Really strange location as I almost walked past it until I realized that they were sharing a space with a diner.  

Their mochi were very fresh and very delicious.  My only problem is that it's so far away from San Jose!  I also go to Shuei-do and I think they just have slightly different mochi/manju and I enjoy them both.
author: J L.

description:
Strawberry Mochi is so good!!  After I read the reviews, I just had to drive by this place and pick up some for myself.  One taste and I'm hooked.  I tried the cherry blossom flavor one and let's just say that Eiji makes it better, but their strawberry mochi rocks!! I'll def. go back to try the other flavors. 

I like how the mochi is not too sweet.  The filling and the mochi blends very well together.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I love mochis and redbeans and any kind of rice cakes, but I don't get why this place is getting so much hype. Register lady was nice and the "mochi" side of the store is ok, but whats with the nasty hamburger grill/diner on the other side? Kinda ruins the authentic experience. 

Had a few regular red bean flavors and a peanut mochi which was not what I expected AT ALL. It was a huge mochi stuffed with crunchy skippy peanut butter. Like come onnnn. I thought it was going to be more special than that but Skippy PB?
author: becky s.

description: the strawberry and the kinako mochi...so ono.
author: Craig I.

description:
i went to the cherry blossom festival last saturday and benkyodo was at the very top of my list of places to visit. by the time i got there, they were all sold out of their super delicious, ooey, gooey manju. :-(

luckliy, i had an excuse to stop by japantown today, as i was running around town doing errands ... and finally got the sweets i was craving. but now that i'm home, i'm totally kicking myself. why did i only buy 2 pieces of strawberry manju??? two??! oh wait - i remember why. because if i bought any more i would have inhaled it all in one sitting. 

i'll be back for more next week. :-)
author: cynthia q.

description:
The mochi are so delicious!!!! I need to go again at an early time to get more of a variety..my mouth is watering writing about it.

EDIT
I went there again and got some more delicious mochi. I love the strawberry one. Also the owner was really nice, he gave me and my friend a free mochi :)
author: Chatree T.

description:
Went into the store for the first time and I love this place... it reminds of time standing still...that this place still looked like this back in the 50's ^_^

The counter lady was very helpful...pointing out what each manju piece is, but since I got there in the afternoon, I was out of luck for the famous Strawberry Mochi. However, I picked up a piece of pink habutai, regular habutai, yomogi and a red dot habutai.

All so fresh and soft. I don't think this mochi is sweet as some reviews have claimed...I've tasted real authentic out of this world mochi back in Hakone, Kyoto and Tokyo and the taste holds up to their standards. 

I hope they make their sakura mochi's for the upcoming Cherry Blossom festival, I'd have to beat everyone off with a stick or my handy ken-do sword.
author: Pauline L.

description:
We have been wanting to go here for such a long time based on the reviews on Yelp and I am so glad we finally made it.  I think I was expecting a flashier interior,  but the mochi was amazing.  We got two of everything to try them all out.  While I didn't love all of them (why would we?) this was some of the best mochi I have outside of Japan.  

Do check this place out if you like mochi and also follow everyone's advice and get there early.  We saw tray after tray disappear before our eyes!
author: Sean O.

description:
I don't know how many starts would be appropriate for this review.  I read all these great reviews, and I live very close to Japantown, so I thought I'd check out some things people love in that neighborhood.  

I think Mochis are something you could only appreciate if you grew up eating them.   I don't know what kind I had, because only the strawberry one was labeled, but seriously, a mochi is like the last thing on earth I would reach for when I had a sweet tooth.  Fake mochis, you know, ice cream covered with dough, I like.  But that's neither here nor there.

If you like mochis, you probably would like these.  I mean, they seemed fresh, but. . . if this is your idea of a sweet treat I feel bad for you.  Oh, I guess I should say the strawberry one had a piece of fresh strawberry in the filling that tasted good, but then I'd rather just eat a strawberry and avoid the starchy, bland, gooey blob that is a mochi.  

Don't get me wrong, I'm not one of those people that is afraid of certain food textures, it's just that there is not much actual taste to these things either.

(I gave 3 stars because they are probably a good place to get mochis if you like them, and I don't want to totally screw up their stars because I think mochis are gross.)
author: Muriel D.

description:
Ok, I'm sold.  In fact, I may bump the rating up to 5 stars tomorrow morning after getting some freshly made mochi at 10am.  

I've had mochi stuffed with gelato as well as the mochi that's sold in the freezer packs at mitsua.  These were ok, but I never understood what the whole mochi craze was about.  Mochi did not appeal to me like boba and froyo did in it's heyday.

But now, I think mochi is good.  It's more than good actually. It's "I need to go back tomorrow" good.  A friend of mine recommended this place and I read all the reviews and thought to myself, hmm.. maybe I can give mochi another chance.

I tried the strawberry mochi (yes yes, that does not make me a mochi expert), and the pancake stuffed manju (even worse, huh?). LOL.  I also have every other mochi they have including the traditional red bean stuffed goodies.  

What I like about this place is that it isn't overly 'floury' tasting as a result of being indudated with too much bisquick or something.   This place is a must-visit for those who have been so-so about mochi.  

I got a feeling I might bump it up to 5 stars tomorrow morning.
author: Johanan L.

description: Oh Benkyodo, I'm pretty sure you were one of or THE oldest mochi shop here...I really wanted to like you...but it just didn't happen for me.  Maybe I will try again, but it was just a little disappointing.
author: Alanna K.

description:
A true piece of nostalgia in Japantown.  

Benkyodo makes the best mochi I've ever had.  When I say mochi I mean the actual rice dough.  I know its just rice flour, water, sugar, but the final product here is just exceptional.  Super chewy but not overly sticky, just the perfect texture.

Back to the mochi's and manju's with fillings...

I've had most all the different flavors and the red bean mochi and peanut butter mochi get my top vote.  The first time I heard of "smooth white lima bean" filling (which they use for alot of their creations especially the popular strawberry manju), it didnt sound appetizing but I had to give it a shot.  It's not for me.  The lima bean filling is sort've pasty (which the red bean is also), just a sort've unpleasant in my mouth pasty.   Peanut butter mochi is all that I'll ever need from benkyodo.  

Rock on benkyodo for keeping with your tradition.
author: Eric W.

description:
I'm eating mochi from Benkyodo as I type, yummy! This place was a little hard to find and it does look like a 1970's diner, with the mochi case on the other side. The selection was a little sparse, I think they got cleaned out, but I got 8 different types of mochi, downed 4 so far and they were all soft gooey and fresh.

Not sure what to get? Just ask the guy behind the counter, he described each one for me and also helped me pick out a few. I'm sure he's used to it, considering how rare mochi is outside of Japan.

I think they should also try their hand at mochi ice cream, my personal favorite.
author: Venatius P.

description:
I'm eating a fresh strawberry mochi right now as i type. Delish!!!! They're still pretty good the next day...

I learned of this place as i was yelping random foodstuff one night while bored, accompanying the bf on his on-call job. After reading all the great reviews, I've been bugging him to take me to Benkyodo ever since. So yesterday, he brought me a whole selection of the mochi at work. gotta heart him...

First bite of the peanut butter mochi... "oh... its ok... "
Second bite... "umm... this IS good"
Third bite... "yummy yummy!  mochi in my tummy"  

I guess its true what my adorable co-worker dave says about japanese food. It does taste better the third time...
author: Wendy Y.

description:
These little manchu and mochi suckers are the best I've ever had. At first, i saw them and thought they'd just taste like any other pre-packaged mochi from Japanese and Chinese markets. How are they different? Well, let's see... first, they're a lot bigger. They cost about a buck to a buck ten a pop, so you get good bang for your buck with their larger size. Size aside, a key reason why they taste so good is that they are made fresh! Depending on when you go, you may have to wait for them to make their manchus/mochis (i had to wait half an hour for them to bring out their specialty, strawberry manchu). 

if you get the chance to stop by, I highly recommend the strawberry manchu - it's filled with a slightly creamy lima bean paste along with a fresh strawberry. Not too sweet, but really soft and virtually just melts in your mouth. In fact, it was so good that I had to mail it to others... which, er... didn't end up well on the other side.
author: Kevin T.

description:
fresh blueberry mochi balls?!  WOW.

apparently they serve seasonal fruits (apples and strawberries) but you have to arrive early to get the first pickings.  awesome selection of japanese snacks, and the people that work here are super nice.  bring cash, yo!
author: Meesh K.

description: Benkyodo is one of those places you have to visit if you are ever in the neighborhood.  The manju here is as good as it gets.  I only frequent Benkyodo for manju about 4 times a year tops, but it is exquisite every time.  If you are just looking for a bite to eat, they serve sandwiches, burgers, and dogs.  I usually come here when I want a quick meal.  My suggestion is to order a Cheeseburger with chopped onion (emphasis on the chopped onion,) and an orange freeze.
author: Anthony N.

description:
I do not frequent the lunch counter, but if you want mochi / manju, Benkyodo is the place to go if you are in Japantown. 

The strawberry mochi is great. Can't beat the freshness since they are made on a daily basis. Be sure to eat them the same day you buy them or they will start to get hard and not as delicious.

Don't wait too late in the day since they close rather early and the strawberry ones sell out, especially on the weekends. 

If i have visitors coming from out of town or friends that want something Japanese-y I always offer to take them there. When people come back to the city, they always complain that they cannot find good manju or mochi in socal. *shrugs* maybe there is somewhere but not that they know of.
author: edie t.

description:
kinako mochi. red bean and soy powders. pure indulgence! thank goodness we don't have these in LA, unless I'll be 10 pounds heavier from munching these everyday.

pics - http://www.yummycrave.com/2010/04/i-left-my-tummy-in-san-francisco.html
author: Monica W.

description:
I used to go to this place on Sutter (by Fillmore) for mochi, then they retired and closed the store. Then it was between Benkyodo and this place in the Japantown mall. Then the place in the mall became a noodle shop. Now Benkyodo is the only place I know of that has fresh homemade mochi. 

Once you have eaten fresh, you will never go back to any of that packaged stuff you see in the market. Soft, luscious and delicate, it is not chewy and won't weigh down in your stomach in a big blob. That's why it is really easy to suck down a six pack (piece) in one sitting. I am more of a purist, but the strawberry mochi is really good. Light and fresh, not too sweet or overly jammy.
author: CS C.

description: The fresh Blueberry and Strawberry Mochis are one of my favorite reasons living in SF!  No joke.  They are so so so so good!  And I'm not even a huge mochi-connoiseur or anything.  The non-fruity mochis are decent, but it's definitely the fresh fruit varieties FTW!
author: Tina F.

description:
I heard about this place but was put off by the diner, didn't know that they actually sold manju there.  Fast forward 9 years and my uncle who was in town asked me to go buy manju there.  After trying their manju, I was so happy...  I finally found manju worth eating and I didn't have to drive all the way to San Jose or Los Angeles to get it.  Then 2 weeks later my friend brought over a 1/2 dozen manju from Benkyodo and I was hooked.

I know they are one of the last to hand make their manju.  Keep up the good work!  Gotta go get me some manju!!
author: Chibinko -.

description: I have yet to find a place back here in NY that comes remotely close to the amazing mochi that Benkyodo has. I've been here a couple times, and all I can say is that fresh mochi tastes worlds apart from the prepackaged mochi I have to resort to here. The rice skin is much, much softer and is thinner as well, allowing them to pack in more red beans than I usually get. And the variety is fantastic as well. The regular green-skinned mochi are great, but I have to say that my favorite is the donut mochi. Yeah, it's probably not terribly healthy for me, but the sugar-coated donut-like skin with the red bean is pure heaven. I only wish that it stayed fresh longer so I could bring back a box with me...but I guess I'll just have to make do with going all the time when I'm in the Bay Area. It's a nice quiet shop at the north end of the Japantown plaza, and the hostess is a very nice lady who is quick to help describe which mochi is which.
author: Asuka N.

description: Being a big fan of Sam Sato's on Maui, I had to stop by Benkyodo while in JTown.  Number one on my list is the peanut butter manju followed by kinako.  I think Sam Sato's white an (lima bean) is still my all time favorite but Benkyodo ranks right up there.
author: Les U.

description:
Love, love the mochi here! It's all freshly made and the texture is soooo soft and tender when you bite into it! This has to be the best mochi place in the Bay Area! You can get different flavors of the mochi too! My favorite is the white bean paste! YUMMY! 

The mochi place in San Jose doesn't compare! It's too bad that it's so far away from the South Bay. Next time I'm going to buy a whole box for me to eat through out the week! Definitely a must try if you like sweets!!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
My sister heard about this mochi so we decided to give it a try.  Boy am I glad we did!  What delicious, fresh, soft mochi...  Around 6 bucks for 6 pieces and totally worth it!

Oh, don't be scared by the diner look to the place...  There really is a diner on one side of the shop and they sell mochi on the other.  I mention this because my sister and I almost walked away because we thought we were in the wrong place.
author: A L.

description: STRAWBERRY MOCHI.  This is a MUST TRY.  A word of caution though, they sell out.  Since it's Winter and strawberries are not in season, they do a blueberry Mochi with is just as spectacular.  YUM!  Everything else is very traditional, made fresh and delicious!
author: Tim W.

description:
I can't believe I've been living in SF for 11 years and found out about this place last year from watching the Food Network! And for 4 of the years I lived very very close to Benkyodo. 

Whenever I passed by I would only see seniors drinking coffee and a hot dog machine. I had no idea it was a store front for mochi and manju! I grew up on these little pillows of heaven. Needless, to say once I discovered the place my cheeks started to resemble a manju ball so I laid off for a while. It just makes me happy knowing they are nearby.
author: Marley Q.

description:
These guys are great.  Not only do they make great moochi but they also make great sandwiches.  

This place has been family owned for the past 70+ years.  The current family members ricki and bobby manage this place with great dedication and passion.  They get up around 4 am every morning to start making fresh batches of moochi.

The space is also extremely comfy.
author: Alan T.

description:
Mochi making should definitely be considered some kind of art and Benkyodo puts together one of the best masterpieces I've ever had in the form of a rice cake. If you are so lucky, make sure you stop by and try their Strawberry Mochi. There's a fresh strawberry in each mochi piece that is covered in mung bean and then enrobed in fresh rice cake. It is absolutely delicious and will bring a smile to any mochi lover's face! 

Another plus at this place is the great atmosphere. It's great to see the locals dine and chat with the servers at the old school diner counter. The staff there is always friendly and who wouldn't be considering they make such wonderful product!
author: Christina N.

description: Who would give them anything less than 5 stars. Their monju is so good and they really make some unique stuff as well. My favorite has to be the apple one. Its pretty much like apple pie. But make sure you get there early or else they'll run out.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
This is THE PLACE to go and sooth your craving of freshly made mochi.
I love their green mochi that is stuffed w/ white bean paste and sprinkled with mung bean powder. The Japanese doughnut stuffed with red bean is pretty good too. Another fav is the Chofu which is a very simple mochi wrapped inside a thin layer of pastry.

  Thank godness for us that this 100+ year institution has served anti-Japanese movement during WW II.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Walk in and look to your right...
looks like a cool shot of a small-town diner, straight from a movie.  Just replace the elderly Japanese gentlemen with morbidly obese truckers.  One day, I'll try the hot dogs.

Now look to your left.....it's a mochi party!  So many flavors, so little time.  Next time I'm at the bar, I will avoid that last gin & soda and instead put the same money towards a dozen of these babies.  Only tried a few so far (strawberry was pretty tasty) but I'll be back for more.  

Gotta gotta catch em all!
author: Neej M.

description: Yummers!  I've been wanting to check this place out for the longest time because I keep seeing it on my front yelp page, and I LOVE MOCHI.  What everyone says is true.. The mochi is soooo good, I want to try every flavor!
author: Kymberli C.

description: A box of fresh mochi from here is definitely the way to a girl's heart.
author: Jen C.

description:
This was really some good mochi!! I'm not a big fan but I love the lima bean, red bean inside the mochi! :) 
They have so many choices and it was hard to decide but I picked different flavors. They were all good.

Update: Many more visits later, I'm obsessed with the strawberry mochi! My gawd, they are absolutely addictive! I brought a box to a friend's get-together and everyone loved it! They were fresh and nothing like the prepackaged frozen ones in the store.
author: Yan M.

description: This place, hands down, makes my favorite dessert of all time. The mochi/manju they make fresh is out of this world!!! I remember going to this place with my parents back in grade school and it's still the same today albeit with a few more flavors. You can never go wrong with the classic white with red bean. I wish they would make giant ones, like one pounders, that would be sweet!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Frank H.

description:
The freshest mochi in town.  O-ishii desu!!!

(Note: closed on Sundays).
author: Tim G.

description:
It's a cozy place to mellow out. Not crowded the way I like places to hang out in. It is a valued company for over a century which is fascinating...Thats were I give it 4 stars.
The first time I went there was back in 1984 with some friends but I recently went there to have a hamburger. It was nice but the meat was small ( weres the beef?) The counter person was friendly and polite and the food was served quickly. Since we were there I ordered some home made manju and Japanese crackers.  
Last words on are: Don't expect too much. The down side is it needs a some minor cleaning and refurbishing of the kitchen area (behind the counter) 
I recommend this place. It's history in the making.
author: Smooth R.

description: These are big mochi balls... they're about double the size of what you get from asian supermarkets.  And they taste so good after i heated them up in microwave.  So soft.
author: Jessica N.

description: Didn't even know this place exist until a few weeks ago when we were starving and wanted a quick snack. Didn't even know I like manju until I tried their strawberry mochi.  The spongecake mochi is pretty good as well. My favorite is still the strawberry, but I better remember to go early or call them because by 3:30/4pm, the strawberry ones are all gone.
author: Jay S.

description: Traveled from Colorado to try the manju at Benkyo-do company. As others have said, the manju is fresh and very soft. Tried almost eight different kinds and was impressed with them all. No strawberry manju that day, but the blueberry ones were excellent! Brought back a box of manju and only wish Benkyo-do shipped! It's another reason why San Franciscans are so lucky.
author: David M.

description:
Yes, the mochi is good...

It's been good for the 25-plus years I've been coming here.

But I love the old-time Orange Freeze. Bobby will whip one up for you just like he did when I was in grade school.

Ice cream cones, hot dogs off that rolling grill thingy. Chilli served in styrofoam coffee cups. 

Old timers (many of who shaped Japan-town) sitting at the counter drinking old-people style watered down coffee. I know it ain't a cuppa Peets, but that coffee serves it's purpose.

And those simple "made-at-home" sandwhiches. Go for the tuna. It's just like your mom made it at home.
author: Anita R.

description:
If you want good manju, this is the place to go.  

Run by a nice family, Benkyodo makes buying manju the simplest of tasks - especially for the very Americanized person I am: they have a sign that indicates what is in every manju available.  Not only is it easy to know which to choose, but every one you select will be the freshest of fresh!

SO YUMMY.
author: P T.

description:
Every visit to Benkyodo ended with a tear on my face: it was always closed! Of course this was entirely my fault considering I consistently arrived at the place after 5 o' clock--their closing time--or on sundays. So, to find myself in Japantown unusually at 12 o' clock on Monday could not be more blatant a message from heaven. That day would be the day I try out Benkyodo's much hyped manju.

I splurged on a box of 20 (of course to share, mind you) and, well, they were pretty darn good. I'm a huge fan of red bean paste so the manju is like a perfect match for me. Benkyodo has a variety of manju, but I personally enjoy the pink strawberry one, the pink one with the red dot on the top, the purple one, and the green one with brown soybean powder. 

This is one of the few places around town that provides fresh manju, so go for it if you're in mood! Benkyodo has a casual coffee diner to boot.
author: Steven S.

description:
I LOVE the mochi and manju here! When it's strawberry season, they put fresh strawberry slices in their strawberry manju. Ordinarily, the strawberry manju is really good, but eating the ones with fresh strawberry are even better. Also enjoy the sakura ones, which are also seasonal. The habutai is also one of my favorites.

It's definitely worth straying from the J-town plaza!
author: Jane K.

description:
Wow--happy strawberry surprise!!! :)

I went with my 2 buds to Benkyodo during the Cherry Blossom Festival and got myself 2 strawberry mochis, a whole red bean mochi and a smooth red bean mochi.

I only tasted the strawberry... and YUM!!!!!!!  I took my first bite.. okay.. the mochi is good.. took my second bite.. yes yes.. very good mochi.. third bite.. WHAT IS THIS?!  A STRAWBERRY SURPRISE!!  FRESH STRAWBERRY IN MY MOCHI!! *ding ding we have a winner!*  and my last bite, yes yes damn good mochi!!

The mochi is definitely better than any other I've ever had (not like I'm Japanese, but this mochi had very smooth & stretchy texture)...

like the little kid in the Campbell chicken noodle soup commercial: "Yes, more please!"
author: Steph M.

description:
mochi?!? my favorite!!! 

came here recently to pick up some mochi and it was YUMMY~~!!! if you want a taste of japan, come here! these are fresh homemade mochi with different flavors! my friend, who came with me, ordered a box of mochi for her and her family. the mochi here is OH SOOO GOOD!!!

i'll definitely be back to try more flavors!!!
author: Kapo T.

description:
This was the beginning of a fabulous 5-star weekend.

Cute lil shop right on the corner of Buchanan & Sutter.  The strawberry mochi was incredibly delicious!  It was so soft, it just melts in your mouth.  Some shops make it too starchy, too rough, too dry, etc.  This place makes them just right.  The texture is smooth and perfectly sweet.  Next time, I will get a sampler pack!
author: Tom Y.

description:
sigh.  i just wish i found this place sooner and i wish the hours worked with my schedule - i do most of my groceries on sundays when this place is closed!

i had:
1) kinako - mochi with red beans and soy powder
2) blueberry mochi
3) chofu - pancake wrap with sweet rice
4) kuri - manju (i assume means a baked pastry) with sweet lima beans

all four were exceptional!  the blueberry mochi bursted with fresh blueberries!  the soy powder on the kinako was an interesting contrast to the sweet red beans.  chofu had an interesting texture - the pancake really complimented the sweet mochi rice.  the kuri reminded me of filipino hopia.

love, love, love benkyodo!
author: Christine P.

description: If you like a gummy piece of sweet stuff, this place is good. The woman behind the counter was unsmiling and quite frankly, looked depressed. We had the blueberry and it was better than the chocolate peanut butter which was yuck. This review isn't fair. I think I just don't like mochi...One positive.  Mochi is very attractive.
author: Bleep S.

description:
So for a different Valentine's day treat, I got the wife and I some mochi. It was a great treat.  Thanks to all the yelpers for the flavor recommendations.  I ended up getting Habutai, Komogi and Peanut Butter (suama was out of stock).  All were very good though I found the PB to be the best, though I am partial to PB in general.

If you are in Japantown or want something different as a sweet, stop by Benkyodo.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Best manju I've had. I'm not a big fan of manju but my husband is and he's addicted to the ones here. The skin is nice and soft and the fillings not too sweet. I wish it were still less sweet but I can't complain too much.

Our faves are yomogi (green mochi with whole red beans) and Pink Habutai (Pink mochi with smooth white lima beans) is pretty good too. We come here every time we're in Japantown.
author: pj n.

description: Mochi and Manju at its finest. Can't get any better than this place unless you can make it yourself. Love the ohagi, yomogi and strawberry manju. Absolutely yummy yummy for my tummy! ^___^
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Took Footloose and Fancy-free here as stop #2 on our day of gluttony.

Remembered this place saying something about good mochi but everything else was fuzzy. So was totally thrown off when I saw the hot dog menu. Errr... ok. But in my experience odd things like this just mean the food's supergood. Hopefully.

Mochi outside was yummy and chewy. Unfortunately I don't like bean paste. BUT judging from the ferocity F&F went through the mochi and the amount of soy flour all over her face, I'm assuming the normal mochi lover would like this place.

Will be making a return trip to taste the strawberry as hopefully it will be the answer to my love/hate relationship with mochi and its yucky insides.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
The best manju and mochi I have ever had, definately worth driving well over an hour and dealing with the hell that is San Francisco traffic to get there. Beware of the parking meter that is in a loading zone on Post near the place, you will get a ticket despite the incredibly misleading sticker on the meter itself.

Absolutely everything is worth a try here, theres even a coffee bar and other items to try aside from the mochi and manju.
author: Bruce C.

description:
let me start by admitting i know little about true authentic mochi. Accordingly, i'm not even going to try and really describe the individual pieces i purchased or which ones i liked best or whether it matches what my asian grandmother made (because i don't have one).

All i can say is that Benkyodo will introduce you to tastes and textures that the average person hasn't experienced before. So my five stars is really about the "go try it" more than the absolute rating against other quality mochi houses. It's a rating that's more about supporting the smaller specialty shops who put love and care into their food. It's a rating about trying something different with your friends.

Go check it out. And tell them I like the squishy gray one with the soft red stuff in the middle :)
author: hunter w.

description:
This place is awesome. I used to take weekly trips down there with my mom and buy maybe twenty or so and eat them throughout the week, if they lasted that long. They package them neatly in a little box or a styrofoam tray with tissue paper and colored bakery string.  Each one is less than a dollar and very fresh. The problem is, they usually sell out and close shop pretty early, so it's best to go in the morning. 
My mom tells me the strawberry ones used to have strawberry pieces and were more expensive, but I didn't have a taste for it back then so I don't really remember. It's still great the way it is.
author: AJ M.

description: TERRIBLE SERVICE!   I patiently waited in line to order a few boxes of mochi, while another patron rudely cut in front of the line.   I informed the man behind the counter that I was in line first, but he told me "He won't take too long" and continued to serve him.  He ended up ordering one mochi.. but ended up losing my business (of many years).  Customer service is just as important as your product.  Without good customer service you will end up losing your patrons in the long run.   He made a sale for one mochi, but lost my order of a few boxes...that's just bad business!   I will NEVER go back to that place ever again.
author: Bryce L.

description: I love this place -- their mochi is freshly made, and they have some really delicious flavors (strawberry is awesome! but of course, should be eaten fresh) and actually, if you have delicious mochi at other eateries around J-town they very well have actually been catered by this here bakery. Their mochi is so soft it's like eating clouds. My only gripe is the really limited hours, probably 5 times out of 10 when I come by and want some mochi, they're closed! They also run out of certain flavors pretty fast, but don't worry, if you call ahead they'll set them aside for you! They were recently featured in a yelp bulletin as having great macarons, so I'll have to try that next.
author: Kendall M.

description: I adore the mochi here!! Soooo yummy with its gooey-ness and sweetness. The chocolate mochi with marshmellow filling is great, and the strawberry mochi. And the tri-color plain mochi is great to snack on too!
author: Ashley C.

description: Maybe it takes a while to understand the whole mochi craze, but I think they're just ok. The ice cream kind and the fresh kind here. I had a selection of 6 different kinds, they were fine. I also tried a steamed red bean one which reminded me of a chinese red bean bun just much smaller in size. The mochi were definately cute and some of them had imprints of flowers, made you want to admire their cuteness than eat them. Service was great, the lady behind the counter was warm and friendly. I'd go back just to see here again.
author: Linda H.

description:
I dont know why but i love the name...benkyodo;)

the service was awesome and really helped 3 confused and indecisive girls finally make their life changing decision: strawberry, red bead, white bean, and something baked mochi. WOW seriously ask for help or you'll be standing there for awhile. 

Ok so ive never been a big fan of viet/chinese mochi (so ive read on their packagings.. i think it's a more recent add on name in light of Real japanese mochi's gain in fame ), but it was definitely interesting to try benkyodo's authentic homemade japanese mochi.

Similarities: sweet  pasty filling and floury glutenous outside.
Difference: Japanese mochi are so cute and a mouth full.. so dont over order cus they can be filling. 

Viet/chines mochi comes in packs for 3-4 at your local viet/chinese market (find them by the counters) they're a bit more flat and comes in a few variety like sesame and yellow bean.

take all mochi with tea.after awhile all the flavors gets lost to the sweetness.
author: Lynn T.

description: It is the best mochi I've ever had. EVER. I walked in here to get soda to-go one day, because it looks like a diner. I turned around, and there was a display case with all different kinds of mochi. That day I tried azuki and green tea. The second time I tried two that the lady behind the counter recommended. So light and fluffy. Such a cool thing to find by accident!
author: Merrilee T.

description: I stopped into Benkyodo the other day for a post-lunch treat and was excited to find sakuramochi! I didn't realize that they did seasonal manju in addition to the old standbys. It was delicious and definitely got me in the mood for Spring (even in spite of all this rain...)! The chofu, suama, and kinako manju were also terrific. The only issue was narrowing down which ones I wanted to order! I have been coming here since I was a kid, and the manju has always been excellent.
author: Sara Y.

description:
So i was around the area today and just had to see what all the hype was about Benkyodo Co. Let me tell you, these are best Mochis I have ever eaten! SERIOUSLY? The Mochi its self is so soft, yet so chewy.. and i just love how they have real fruit in the middle, but for $1 i think it's a lil bit to pricey that's why you only get 4 stars!

I'm definitely coming back here to buy a whole batch for my friends and family. YUM!
author: Brian P.

description:
The only mochi I've known are the frozen ice cream filled ones that you buy at Trader Joe's or get at Japanese restaurants. Sometimes my sis-in-law (Japanese-American from Hawaii) will get some pre-made, wrapped stuff from Japanese grocery stores in Irvine. But she's there. And I'm here.

Well, Yelp, pat yourself on the back for raising up this store in my consciousness. I'd always ridden by them on the 2, never went inside. Only saw the diner, boy what a superficial judger (ESTJ, thank you) I am. But then you had to list this on your home page for such a LONG time. I had to click in and see what it was about. 

And now, I know. They sell 'em by the box (4 in a box, 6, etc.). You go and choose 'em. (There's a directory to the left of the glass case so you don't waste everyone's time by asking "ooh, what's in THAT one?"). I'm on number 2 out of 4. 

These are like BUTTAH. Melt in your mouth. The skin is perfect. Not too chewy. Not hard & dried out by the oxygen we breathe. They're not cheap on the amount of red bean innards. 

I gotta figure out how to get my nieces & sis-in-law to come here (oh, they'd approve) since the shop is only open 9-5, M-Sat.
author: Liz K.

description:
I went here with my girlfriend to see what the commotion was all about, and it was sure very tasty.

We ordered 6 mochi for about a little over $1 each, so at first I was hesitant. We ordered one of each kind, though there were more than 6 kinds. 

Besides standard mochi, they had this fried mochi ball as well. It was crispy with delicate red beans inside. They're so soft and gentle to your tongue.
author: Bay A.

description: This place is so good! I woke up today just to drive to Japantown just to pick up some blueberry mochi's! I always seem to end up with 6 blueberry mochi's all to myself and I usually would finish them in a day or two. Great place and the lady behind the counter is always nice and always has a smile on her face. I can see myself going to Benkyodo for as long as I am living in San Francisco.
author: gloira h.

description:
This is the best O-manju in SF. I love the delicious, fresh smells and the diner ambience, it is much more casual and neighborly than a tearoom style.

I have had fresher Mochi at a couple of MochiTsuki ceremonies, but good luck finding that--this is not a criticism by any means, just my fortunate experience.

The coffee and tea leaves too much to be desired, even for a diner. They really should do better with the Ocha at least.
author: YearOf M.

description:
Until yesterday I thought that I liked mochi, then I experienced the mochi from Benkyodo and realized that while the frozen nugget of goodness said mochi on the side of the box, it wasn't the real thing. Actually, no mochi I've had before compares to the mochi at Benkyodo. 
The red bean (both whole bean and paste) are good, and the peanut butter is tasty, but it is the strawberry that is the real sensation. I think it is the chunks of fresh strawberry in the middle that puts it over the top. Soft, slightly gooey, bursting with flavor and incredibly fresh (they are made that morning) these tasty treats are a little piece of heaven on earth and at less than $1 a piece, they are a good deal as well.
author: Russ C.

description:
The interior of Benkyodo Co. reminds me of a diner since half of it serves burger and another half is the mochi counter. 

I bought 6 mochi in all--Kuri, Roppo, Suama, Yomogi, Inaka, and Age. My favorite out of these six is the Roppo, probably for the outer soft baked texture. I expected the Suama (plain rainbow rice cake) to be softer, but it was pretty hard. I also expected them to have every mochi listed on their website, but I only found like half of them at the store, maybe they sold out or only make certain ones on certain days. The sweetness of these treats are perfect even though these treats were intended for tea time. 

Overall, Benkyodo Co.'s mochi is pretty decent and its red bean paste is pretty smooth and nice.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Three words.  Peanut butter mochi.

If they had a Benkyodo in Los Angeles, I'd turn it into an unhealthy obsession.  I'll just have to be content with it as one of those "I stop there every time I go to San Francisco" places.
author: Jake B.

description: Why haven't I heard of these before while living in the Bay Area?!?!  These are awesome.  A friend came up to visit us in Seattle and brought us a box.  Absolutely yummy!  The box was filled with mostly fresh blueberry flavored mochis.  The filling is soft and gently sweet with a burst of fresh whole blueberries!  Gotta go back for the fresh strawberry ones when we got home to visit.
author: Wendy L.

description:
the mochi was good, i was expecting the mochi/tea experience and i was a little disappointed by the tea bag with boiling water and a soda cup lid i got but hey, fuck it. 
im only giving it three stars because im not a huge fan of the diner atmosphere i got.
 the mochi is excelent and i recommend eating it with green tea regardless of whether or not its some bag tea yamamotoyama. 
the woman who serves at the counter is also nice. :) 
worth checking out, if you're expecting some ceremony, probly not so much. will i go again? depends on if the other place has better tea most likely.
author: Ayaaki O.

description:
So far I have tried 7-8 flavors from this place (after only coming here twice) lol. Don't ask me what my problem is ok?

They are so delicious yesterday I ate 5 pieces again in one sitting.
So these are my opinions on the flavors:
strawberry Manju: I enjoyed the delicate flavor of strawberry but I just felt like it didn't have enough strawberryness to it. And the piece of strawberry inside was tiny. Still delicious but I would rate it 4 stars.
Peanut butter mochi: This was the one mochi I didn't like. The peanut butter was salty and crunchy. Just ruined the mochi for me but heck other people like it.
Pink mochi with white lima beans: Really good.
Chocolate marshmallow: Very unique! Its cool how they make the outside mochi part chocolate!
Mochi with smooth red beans sprinkled with soy flour: i love everythign about this except the soy flour.
Steam bum with whole red beans: love the red bean not so much the outside
Original with smooth red bean: FOR SURE MY VERY FAVORITE ONE!!! 
Green mochi with whoel red bean: delicious too! although I do prefer the smooth red bean
author: Em F.

description:
Peanut butter mother f***ing mochi... delish.
I think I've passed by Benkyodo Co. a hundred times and not once ever thought this part diner, part sweets and snack shop was a den of mochi madness (translate that into superb goodness). Then, Christine L., and her craving for peanut butter mochis began to haunt her... thus enter, Benkyodo.
This place certainly has character, and a plethora of products to examine and ponder about but the heart of Benkyodo, hidden beneath loads of crackers, chocolates, is no other than its famed fresh mochi. Don't think packed cold hard red bean green skin mush a la Asian supermarkets! It's almost... perhaps even just as, good as Shuei-do Manju back in San Jose. The skin is so moist, so delectable, and at a dollar a mochi pretty reasonable. Their flavors, so modern! My visits to Shuei-do were always filled with the mystery of tradition but here at Benkyodo where it almost seems like they are trying very hard to stave off a mochi stampede or any want for stardom, hiding their mochis filled with strawberries and pink colored bean pastes, chocolate flavored skins and--shining moment--the delightful three-pack of gushing crunchy peanut butter mochis, there is such boundless fun, such outrageous flaunting of anti-anko-ness. And yet, the skin... that's some damn good, old-fashioned made mochi dough.
author: Jessica L.

description:
My mom always told me that you could find excellent mochi in the bay area.  After searching yelp I decided to try Benkyodo.  We happened to arrive just as a fresh batch of kuri manju was being pulled from the oven.  Heaven in a box!  Hands down the best mochi I've ever had.

I've been a few more times since.  I took 4 boxes home for Christmas.  I placed an order with them a few days prior and it was ready for pick up when I arrived.  Awesome service and delicious treats!
author: Bryn M.

description:
Haven't tasted fresh mochi in over 40 years.  And Benkyodo did not disappoint me,  I forgot how good fresh mochi tasted. It quickly brought back memories when I was six and living in Japan. 

The Japanese lady was a little short with me, maybe because I was drooling on her  clean glass case. But I ended up ordering a big sample box with a little of each. 

I couldn't wait till I got back to the Tomo, which was only across the street. So I hurriedly opened the box, took a seat on a bench in front of The Paper Tree where my wife was shopping, and tried to eat the whole box.   I love the white bean mochi and the strawberry filled ones were my new favorites.
author: Jim C.
