description: My friend introduced me to Benkyodo a few years back and I've been coming ever since.  It's a diner/ mochi store.  Mochi is sold on the left side and they serve food on the right side.  I've only tried their mochi and each bite is heavenly!  Over the years, I've pretty much tried all their flavors and Strawberry (this is seasonal and has fresh fruit inside) and Lima bean (white mochi wrap on the outside with a red dot on top) are my favorite!  They have a variety of red beans ones as well with whole beans and smooth beans (ground up beans).  I'm not too big of a red bean fan so I default to the lima bean.  The mochi is thin, soft and chewy and the inside contains the perfect mixture of filling.  Once you've tried fresh mochi, there's no going back to package mochi.  It's just not comparable.  I also like to pick up a box of Kauai cookies when I'm there as well (they're reasonable priced!).   They're my favorite boxed cookies to pick up in Hawaii but I pick up mine at Benkyodo when I'm not going to the islands anytime soon.
author: Veronica N.

description: This place is a destination store! Bf and I would drive all the way from the south bay to get mochi here. They're the best in the bay area. Last weekend was the first time I tried their strawberry mochi. It's seriously delicious. I wish they can open a branch in the south bay.
author: RicknKeyna W.

description:
Benkyodo. I love you. Your mochi is delicious and always fresh. And. I really don't know what I'll do when you're gone.

Everyone loves the strawberry mochi which (when in season) has chunks of strawberry in it, but when it's not in season you just get the strawberry flavor. I myself prefer the peach colored ones with white bean inside. So soft. So tasty. So good.
author: Tiff L.

description:
Awesome little place for mochi. Who would think that a little corner diner-looking place would have super delicious mochi. We had a variety of samples with red bean and white bean paste filling. 

Will definitely come back.
author: Tom L.

description: Came for strawberry mochi, settled for blueberry.  The white bean mochi was really good, and the blueberry was pretty good too, but I don't think it justified my trip to Japantown.  I still like the stuff from Fugetsu-Do I can get at my local Japanese grocery store.
author: Jessica N.

description:
I wouldn't recommend going on Saturday or Sunday- the place is stuffed full of tourists. But what a wonderful treat after a light lunch!
We bought three pieces to try, finished it in 10 minutes, and went back in to get two more. 
OMG. The strawberry mochi has ACTUAL strawberries in it, not just some "strawberry-flaboured" pink goo. The kuri manju is also awsome. My personal favourite (which I got a second of) was the chofu. I definietely recommend this to people who don't like their desserts to be too sweet. The rice mochi is TOP NOTCH- it doesn't stick to your teeth and the chewiness is JUST RIGHT. You can actually taste the LOVE and HOME-MADE goodness. 
My mother also had the kinako which was excellent as well. 

Next time I'm definitely getting the peanut butter manju. 

Please do yourself a favour and try out benkyodo!!!! The best of  Japanese dessert right in the city!
author: grace h.

description:
The Strawberry Manju is my favorite.  

I also like the Age ("donut with smooth red beans").
author: Kat C.

description: Sadly I came here late on a Saturday afternoon, so most of their manju were cleared out save a few standards.  I loved the Inaka (steamed bun with whole red beans) with it's fluffy steamed bun and whole red beans which were not overly sweet.  However, it's the Kinako (mochi with smooth red beans and sprinkled with soybean flour) that really did it for me.  I'm not in the habit of eating freshly made manju often.  I usually grab one of those pre-packaged ones from the Asian grocers, which does not compare to what I encountered from Benkyodo's.  The mochi was soft, pliable and slightly chewy, with a sweet and incredibly smooth red bean filling.  Powdered with soybean flour, it was a delicious surprise!  I can't wait to go again to try the peanut butter manju, along with the strawberry manju with lima bean and the lima bean with cinnamon coating!
author: Janet L.

description: What a gem of a place! I haven't found anyplace else in the Bay Area that does fresh mochi like this. Fresh blueberry mochi and the peanut butter-filled chocolate mochi are awesome. Outstanding!
author: Steve B.

description: Went here during the Cherry Blossom Festival. Super good and fresh mochi.  I would definitely go back when it's not so crowded.  I also think the mochi would have tasted better had it been slightly colder instead of room temp.  It was kind of hot that day and it didn't fare well with the food selection.
author: k h.

description:
Where to start?  This place is a hidden gem.

The manju is to die for.  Honey's and my favorite are ... well we love them all.  But if we had to recommend only one, we'd recommend the peanut butter ones.  The food is fresh, the flavor is intense, and the way the dough melts in your mouth is indescribable.

Recommendation is to get yours often and get them early.  This is a family run store and it is apparent that they love to see their customers happy.

Highly recommended
author: Stanley G.

description:
I had to bring a food dish from my childhood for the Proustian Picnic Pot Luck Porno Shoot -- something that served as my proverbial "madeleine" prompting a logorrheic overflow of half-baked memories and other cheap thrills, although I was asked to leave my closeted homosexual asthmatic writer shtick at home. Your loss, fuckers. You have NO IDEA how well I can play a histrionic French pole smoker.

Anyway, this requirement overwhelmed me to be honest, because, fuck, the only thing I can cook up is a dish of hatred and terminal depression simmered in a light broth of nymphomania (yummers, but it'll burn your mouth) -- I can barely boil water (you do it with a microwave, RIGHT?)! So I started to panic. "Darin," I said, "Darin, think real hard, what did you love as a child?" and of course I immediately thought of McDonald's Egg McMuffins but then I realized that there ain't no fucking way I was gonna walk into a McDonalds and ask for 10 Egg McMuffins 'cause "Darin, think about it, people ALREADY think you're fucking anorexic, if you march up to the counter and demand 10 Egg McMuffins they'll think you're Meredith Baxter Birney on that Lifetime TV movie, you remember, the one where she played a bulimic and threw up a bag of potato chips and three gallons of ice cream in an alley dumpster, DAMN BITCH you overfuckingthink things, wait did I say all that OUT LOUD, like IN PUBLIC?!?"

I was confronted with the sad possibility of Cup-O-Noodles for everyone until the 102-year old institution that is Benkyodo provided me with a wonderful assortment of freshly-made manju and mochi. I purchased four of each of the following for only $21!

Habutai = white mochi with smooth red bean paste
Kinako = green mochi with smooth white bean paste, sprinkled with soybean flour
Pink Habutai = pink mochi with smooth white bean paste
Kuri Manju = baked bread manju with smooth white bean paste
Roppo = baked bread manju with smooth red bean paste
Hoji Manju = steamed bread manju with chunky red beans

They're all vegan friendly and fucking diabetically delicious. The only way they could be more delicious is if they were shaped like dicks.

Now, it's true that the consumption of copious amounts of mochi can kill you as the sticky rice could lodge in the throat. For example, in January 2005, 1 person died and 15 were hospitalized in critical condition as a result of consuming mochi on New Years, as reported by Asahi (http://www.asahi.com/offtime/04-05/news/TKY200501020019.html) And in 2007, 3 people in Tokyo died (http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/01/02/asia/AS_GEN_Japan_Rice_Cake_Deaths.php)

In fact, what I usually do for my white friends who, let's face it, OPPRESS ME WITH THEIR VERY FUCKING EXISTENCE, is don my kimono, feed them a ton of delicious mochi, and wait until they start choking. Then as they expire I scream "WHAT DAT ROUND-EYE DEVIRR?!? HEIMRICH MANOOVERR?!? ME NO SPEAKY ENGRISH MUDDAFUKKAHHH!!"

No, I keed. I speak English. I know the heimlich maneuver. Oh and some of my best friends are round-eyed devils. I say, DOWN WITH HATE! LET'S LOVE ONE ANOTHER! Suck it, bitch.
author: d s.

description: my bf bought all kinds of mochi they had on that glass counter.  we weren't able to try them all cause there were so many and we didn't want to eat it old so ya.  but out of all the ones we tried, we loved the strawberry mochi.  it was a little bit more expensive that the other kinds but its worth it.  the best mochi ive ever had.
author: R F.

description: Interesting place. Mochi was good and cheap. Neat setup up as half the place was a diner and the other half was used to sell mochi and other japanese delights. Price was reasonable too.
author: Eric A.

description: The mochi was as soft and good as my MIL used to make.  Strawberry, white bean & red bean were hits.  didn't try the peanut butter or blueberry (all out by the time we got there) But, the best part is that the price is no different than the packaged one in the store and this is so much better.  Wish I lived closer to get more of it!
author: Catherine W.

description: I LOVE mochi!!! And, I especially love the freshly made mochi that they sell. I have been a fan since I tried my first piece of mochi from this shop. This is definitely a must-visit destination in Japantown! I crave the chunky red bean mochi but my other favorite is the strawberry mochi with the white bean filling and fresh strawberry. It also makes for a wonderful gift too. I got a dozen assorted mochi for one of my friends for her birthday and it was very much appreciated. I only wish that they were open for longer hours to satisfy my mochi cravings (^_^)
author: Lisa M.

description:
So, a bunch of us were really excited about trying Benkyodo since its rated so highly on Yelp and headed over there on Monday. We rolled by and got rock star parking. We were thinking..awesome parking and mochi...excellent combo. We got there at 4:40, and had 20 min to spare before closing. Everything seemed to be going well until...
We walked in..We were overwhelmed with the Mochi choices and weren't sure which to choose. 
Mochi Nazi: Would you mind making your decision? I'm about to close.
We were thinking..wtf, the store doesn't close in 20 min.
Me: Could you provide some recommendations?
Mochi Nazi (in angry voice): the top shelf are our most popular
I felt panicked and just bought the choices in the top shelf...so we could get the heck outta there without angering the Mochi Nazi any further.
The mochis were ok. I've had better. I'm not sure if I could deal with such crappy customer service. He looked so angry that we were giving him business.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
a very dear friend of mine who loves manju & mochi was overjoyed when a dozen of mixed manju & mochi was received from me the other day.

the expression on that comely face was priceless when i handed the styrofoam of confections and soft rice cakes wrapped in a paper that was tied with a nylon pink string!!!! 

inside that special package was the most delicious, soft, fresh MANJU & MOCHI you could ever put in your mouth! the manju i picked were as follows:
 
KINAKO (has red beans & sprinkled with soybean flour),

 DORAYAKI (my personal favorite, like a mini pancake with whole red beans), 

AGE (mini donuts that looks like "baby" malasadas that has smooth red beans and has powdered sugar on the outside), 

SUAMA (it's made of sweet rice & it's plain..yet a luscious treat) and

S'BERRY ( pink in color & filled with smooth red beans)

and for the mochi varieties:

i chose the OKASANE  & KOMOCHI, which also won my affection!

this place never fails me. their products are always fresh, pure and consistent.

though, the place looks aged, it gives off a friendly atmosphere and some regular patrons can be seen sitting on the stool  chit chatting.

furthermore, they also offers some japanese snacks,hot/cold sandwiches and coffee.

certainly, a niche that will last for a lifetime!

thanks for making my friend satisfied and blissful!!!
author: Nelle A.

description: Love that it's been here forever.  My dad loves their fresh mochi - only trouble is you need to get there early!  Super friendly family-run shop - gave me a free strawberry mochi last time because there was only one left!  Also, I bought some once for a pot-luck - was a good idea if I do say so myself!  I don't know much about the different types of  mochi, but I like the green one!  And my dad likes the one with the peanut sprinkle :-)  Mochi - makes me happy!
author: Joyce L.

description: This place made me fall in love with mochi! I tried mochi for the first time last year and I'm so glad that they made my first experience a memorable one.  I love that everything is all homemade with fresh ingredients and everytime I take a bite, I feel as if I'm eating an authentic Japanese delicacy. I've had the strawberry, blueberry, green tea, and pink (habutai) mochi and I can't wait to try the rest of the flavors! My favorite thus far is the green tea partially cuz I LOVE red bean paste. The habutai with the lima bean filling had an amazing soft and chewy exterior bursting with a smooth, tasty interior with every bite. I remember paying $1 each for each mochi but last time I went, it was like $1.10 or so but each mochi is pretty big and surprisingly filling. I would totally eat one after every meal! I hope they make more flavors in the future! The lady behind the counter is absolutely friendly and I feel as if my aunt is giving me homemade food made with love to take home haha. I'm not sure if they have ice cream mochi but if they do that would be a chocolate covered cherry on top of a great shop.
author: Anna L.

description:
hey Bobby....Minamoto Kitchoan is opening August 31, 2009...

it is really the invasion of New WAGASHI on 648 Market Street at Downtown prices....check it out....ever been to NEW YORK, LONDON or Singapore??? They are hitting it in style....at that astroNOMICAL price point of NIPPON wagashi.sanbyaku gojyuuen.

hey y'all, it is $1.20 or $1 bargain and low fat...yummy handmade hard to find even in Japan, mochi gashi...my fav is the strawberry. 

All the Japanese mochi gashi are made by hand. Bobby and his crew used to get started around 5am Monday through Saturday to get the delicate sweets ready. Don't know if he will have another generation continue this wonderful gem for tea ceremony goodies, but like the rest of Japantown, the community is fading away and sinking into the annals of paperback printings of what Japantowns used to be like 50 years ago. CLOSED SUNDAYS.

(I like that this place has been around for 100 years, but I still fantasize about Yamada Seika's AMAZAKE manjyu...when they were on Sutter St and before that on Fillmore St., too bad the obachan has severe arthritis, but what no longer exists is just left to the ethers of MEMORIES...like the corners of a page in time)
author: miriam b.

description:
I must say what they have is quite genuine.  I am surprised how much of their sweets could resemble authentic ones in Japan.  

They do not "decorate" each sweet as much as people do in Japan, but well, still they are not ugly.  It's OK. 

Considering how awful ramen can be in Japantown SF, I guess they are worth five stars.  

I don't imagine I will be able to find a place that has better wagashi (Japanese Sweets) than this place, for a while at least...  Again, impressive, impresionante, impressionnant, indrukwekkend...
author: T T.

description: motis are great but sandwiches are just ok
author: Michael O.

description:
so I'm from texas, where sugar, eggs, flour are the main ways to make a thing called a dessert.  beans in a dessert? no thanks,  but everyone insists they are so delightful!  
So, I try 3- strawberry mochi, red bean paste mochi, and the doughnut fried one.  and... I couldn't stop giggling at the sticky, globby, amoeba like creature I was consuming. It was so bodily- no joke. but it was yummy! all my senses fought against it (in the form of many giggles), but i kept eating til they were gone. now there are cartoon blobs in my stomach, smiling.
author: Liz S.

description: mmm.. mochi!! their mochi is served freshed and delicious! the red bean is not to sweet or tasteless.. the mochi skin is super soft.. just the way it should be..
author: Amy C.

description:
this place is near my work--kind of!!!  so what if i take a long break.  are you counting every minute i'm on the clock?--and we go pretty often to eat mochi and manju.  it is so good.  so soft, like biting into a baby that has just gotten out of a warm bath.  if this does not sound appetizing, you'll know what i mean AFTER you go to benkyodo.  the only bad thing about it is that it's ruined me from ever enjoying any other mochi half as much.  

my favorites are the strawberry manju (with a big chunk of strawberry inside) and pink and regular habutai.  the peanut butter manju is also really good but it's sold in a shrink-wrapped package and isn't quite as fresh as the stuff in the bakery case.  

they also have a great selection of japanese and hawaiian rice candies and crackers--i love the twisty seaweed wasabi ones.  addictive!
author: kate s.

description:
I stopped in yesterday and tried the new chocolate marshmallow mochi--unconventional: YES    
-yummy: YES

Bobby is so nice!
author: Mrs P.

description: The peanut butter mochi and the chocolate marshmallow mochi were my favorites.  We went on a Friday so we didn't have to worry about them running out of anything, but I was a bit underwhelmed by the small assortment that was available.  Maybe the have a better variety on weekends?
author: Tina L.

description: Finally got to try this place.  And I bought two mochi - one with white bean and the other with red bean.  Both were fresh, delicious, and with the softest, thinnest "skin" around it.  90cents for one mochi isn't too expensive since it's such a treat.  I will go back to try more.
author: Michelle W.

description: Dude this place is seriously a hole in the wall! When we went in there was a bunch of grandpa looking senior citizens up in here.... seemed pretty laid back in an old 70's type shabby decor. Ordered blueberry, peanut butter mochi, and the pancake wrapped mochi. Blueberry mochi was soooooooooooooo good! It was filled with the white bean puree and actual blueberry compote. The mochi outside was soooo fresh and the blueberries burst into my mouth as i bit into it. The peanut butter one was pretty good but the actual mochi outside was a bit firmer tho. There was nothing special about the pancake mochi. I was really hoping to get the chocolate marshmallow or strawberry mochi but they didnt have any. I will definitely be coming back for more of the blueberry mochi and hope to try the other flavors! One weird thing tho was the owner asked us if we had any allergies to not come after them...i think she was joking... haha... ummm i think.....
author: becky w.

description: Finally, somewhere that's worth the hype. Benkyodo Co serves up some of the finest mochi around including the surprising and mouthwatering strawberry mochi and their version of malasada that tastes like a delicious donut crossed with a dark bean filling. On a nice, sunny day you can lounge in the plaza and gobble your mochi in sheer bliss.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Wow, you never have really had mochi unless you try the fresh ones. Not the ones you buy at the super market that are pre-packed and are days old., but the ones that are made here at Benkyoda. The funny thing is I am not a really big fan of red bean- I mean it when I say that... like the smell of red bean makes me nauseous. Some traumatizing event when I was a kid. The reason why I like mochi is for the white sticky rice flour dough, not the filling. Don't get me wrong, I like the filling too, as long as it is not red bean. I finally found a place that makes different fillings for their mochi. LOVE IT! The mochi that I have tried here was the Kuri and Kuri Goma, which is a baked dough with the lima bean filling. Liked the filling but not a fan of the baked dough. Apparently the difference between the two is that the Kuri Goma has a sesame garnish( the difference between the two that I could tell was the shape and size of the mochi). The Pink Habutai is yummy, fresh lima bean paste wrapped in the rice dough. My favorite was the Suama. It is just the sticky rice dough without any filling. LOVED IT!!! I did buy the Komuchi in a package of about 14, which is the fresh rice dough, thinking that it would be just like the outer coating of the mochi, but was a little disappointed because it definitely does not have sugar mixed into it. When they say plain rice dough, they literally mean rice dough with NO sugar. After opening the Komuchi package and eating about two of the little rice dough balls, the rice balls became hard as a rock a few days later. That was a little disappointing , but that tells me that they use fresh ingredients or that I just didn't re-wrap the package tight enough.  I did want to try the Ohagi, which is a black with a sweet rice center, but the lady at the counter told me that they only make it on the weekend- too bad for me. I will definitely come back here to try the other mochis and manju.
author: carebear l.

description: I love mochi so much especially when it's soft and smooshy like the ones they sell here! I went around 1pm on a Saturday and the mochi's were almost sold out. They only had the red bean flavor left but I'm fine with that. Try going before that time. I will go back to try all of their other flavors and make sure that I get there EARLY!
author: Shu L.

description:
I know I'll probably get a lot of flack from this review because everyone seems to LOVE this place, but I was truly dissappointed.

Couldn't wait to try this place because all of the fantastic yelp reviews, and I didn't think there was anything too special about a skippy peanut butter filled booger. 

It was kind of gross.
author: A. K.

description:
ode to benkyodo peanut butter mochi:

when i need a treat
youre there my sweet
when i want some crunch 
youre there to munch
if i need something gooey 
its you that i chewy
its hard to resist
my pb mochi bliss

okay, im obsessed. i am very fortunate to work just down the block from my beloved peanut butter mochi at benkyodo and needless to say i go there often. the strawberry mochi is good too.
author: ali k.

description: I am very worried about living relatively close to Benkyodo. After trying their mochi on multiple occasions and falling in love with it, this place is probably going on the list of places I will regularly frequent right below Starbucks. Its an addiction! How am I going to pass up strawberry mochi when it is only a couple blocks away???
author: Lauren Y.

description:
really good manju -- don't know them by names but love the soft mochi on the outside & red bean inside ESPECIALLY... MY FAVORITE the soft green mochi on the outside dusted with either ground sweet rice flour (or is that ground sesame) & red bean inside.   awesome with green tea or genmai cha......  

BUT  the BEST one i had closed down probably 8-10 years ago -- it was right in j-town vicinity on sutter st. (i think between fillmore & webster), i don't  remember the name, it was also a family owned business. i still miss it & hope a similar one will open one day..............but  i LOVED it particularly for the variety (baked, white bean, pretty shapes & colors -- nice presentation, with chestnut, dusted with cinnamon, etc.) , it was fun, they had so many to choose from compared to benkyodo.  benkyodo is the only manju place i know now..... 

thanks to other yelp reviews for the history & the sad fact that the store will close down for good...........i appreciate it all the more & will definitely have to go back as much as i can before it closes 

never had a bad customer mochi/manju nazi experience, glad i caught him in a relatively mellow mood everytime i've gone........
author: Cindi N.

description: I'm not much of a mochi lover, but this place makes it pretty tasty and it is genuinely authentic. My friend and I took a special food trip to SF the other day, and Benkyodo was one of the places on our list. It is authentic - real mochi.. no fake frozen stuff.. It was fresh and very tasty.. They have a large variety of mochi all at reasonable prices. The lady that was helping us was also really nice and friendly.. The next time I'm over there I want to try to little cafe part on the right.. the menu is cheap, simple and the hot dogs looked good. Haha. But until next time.. enjoy the mochi!!
author: Rochelle F.

description: Soft, pillowy, melt in your mouth manju.  After eating here, mochi/manju from anywhere else doesn't taste as good.  Try the strawberry manju, with fresh, sweet slices of strawberry in the middle.  The peanut butter manju has an interesting combination of textures--crunchy, sticky peanut butter with silky soft mochi.  Also, the red bean manju is yummy.  Each time I buy from Benkyodo, I tell myself to ration it so it will last a couple of days.  This way, I don't have to make the trek to Jtown so often.  But a few hours later, all the manju have been eaten.  How does that happen??
author: Swirls L.

description:
hands down the best fresh mochi i've had so far in the city.  i have been to kyoto where it's mochi-land and yes they are fabulous there.

why is it so mochi-lious?  the sweet rice dough is perfect and not very thick...it's soft and yummy to chew.  it's weird satisfaction i get from biting into one.  sooo good.  my mouth is watering writing this.

be sure to ask what is inside of them.  There's the usual: red bean paste, whole red bean, and lima bean paste.  it's best with jasmine or oolong tea.
author: Julia H.

description:
Benkyodo Co mochi, a mochi by any other name would taste as sweet?  
Nope, this is easily the best mochi I've ever had. 
 I had no idea mochi could be soooo good.  Living in Toronto I was just a five minute walk away from our chinatown where I stumbled upon mochi following my 'buy something I've never tasted once' philosophy.  This started my mochi obsession.  Who would have thought that beans could be sweet like a dessert? 
 I found Benkyodo through yelp by typing in mochi.  So I trucked my ass from my home in the financial district all the way across town and bought 12 pieces of heavenly goodness. Very inexpensive, about a buck a piece.  I'd never had strawberry mochi before and it was so smooth and fresh.   My favourite is still the red bean which is melt in your mouth good.   I will continue to take the 1 bus the 15-20 minutes for these delicious concoctions.  Benkyodo mochi is one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth...keep the jokes to yourselves ;)
author: Jenny C.

description: Go early and get the Fresh Strawberry and Chocolate Marshmallow manju NOW.
author: Lisa T.

description: There is nothing like fresh home made mochi and manju.  If you like either or both, this is a must try.  This is a place I never get tired of.  I've never had a problem with the service but am usually in and out with a dozen or so pieces.  Every piece is good and I hope they are around forever.
author: K L.

description: I've been coming here since I was a kid. This is one of the very few Japanese owned businesses in J-Town that survived the Internment of Japanese Americans during WWII and reopened with its original owners post-war. The BEST mochi/manju you can find in the city! Where else can you find freshly pounded mochi aside from New Year's day? My favorite manju are the green habutai (mugwort with red bean and kinako), pink habutai (white lima bean filling), the suami (sweet rainbow rice cake) and Ohagi (black bean paste on the outside).
author: Dr. S.

description: With 466 reviews, Benkyodo doesn't really need my affirmation, but I'll throw in my 5 stars and another "O.M.G." for the strawberry mochi. I didn't know such perfection existed.
author: Jaia W.

description: Mochi, unless it's ice cream mochi, is really not my thing.  But the ones here are excellent.  Incredibly soft, fresh, chewey rice dough and very sweet paste.  I got here kinda late on a Saturday, around 3, and they had run out of most of their flavors.  Waaaahhh.. I really wanted to try the strawberry and peanut better.  I settled for the white bean and red bean.  Anyway, the guy said I should get there before 2 to get my pick.  Still worth every single 5 star.
author: Natasha S.

description: The softest, most delicious mochi I've ever eaten. The strawberry mochi is to die for. That wonderful, delicate dough surrounding fresh strawberries...unbelievably yummy.
author: Jenny K.

description: "BLUEBERRY MOCHI" - sooooo good.  Hadn't been here in a while, but stopped in and tried some different flavors and all I can say is the blueberry mochi is the best!.  Thought it might be super sweet with the fruit fill, but no - it has just the right sweet balance with fresh blueberries inside.   Always fresh manju, and I think a little cheaper than Shuei-Do Manju Shop in San Jose which is also great - just depends on where your looking for your mochi' fix'!
author: s z.

description: Manjus!!!! YUMMY!!! Classics like red bean manjus will never fail you.  I like the strawberries ones too though oh God I'm salivating just thinking about them now.  Too bad its far away in the city or Id be going everything.  Oh so I guess its good that they're far or I'd be fatter than I am now :(
author: Peggy W.

description: So fresh! The mochi is soft, sweet, and delicious! Great filings: Strawberry, Peanut Butter, and Classic Red Bean. YUMMM
author: Albert H.

description: did i just end up going there the wrong time? mochi with peanut butter, gross.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Ok here goes...

The first time I went here it was during the nihonmachi festival and after reading all these yelp reviews and my current obsession for mochi, i had to try this place. of course, it was a sunday and i had no idea the place was closed. I walked up to the store and saw the closed sign...nooooooo :-(  alright...i'll try next time.

The second time I went, it was a monday afternoon around noon-ish. I was soooo excited to finally come here (again) and I was really craving some peanut butter manju. So I'm whistling to myself, and just thinking about how great it would be and I was already tasting the peanut butter and chewy rice and then....I walk up to the store once again and see the closed sign! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! Right next to it there's a note that the store is going to be closed for the next few weeks because they were on vacation. I came all the way here during regular store hours to see that they were closed again! Ugh....I was going to cry! 

A month later, I came here again for the third time. It was a Monday late afternoon and wanted to make sure I got here before they closed at 5pm. So I got to JTown at 4:30 and as I was walking towards this place, I started getting all paranoid that they were already closed, there wasn't going to be anything available that I wanted (esp. the peanut butter and strawberry manju) and that I was going to be screwed again. But the place was open (woohooo!) and as I walked in I directly headed to the counter with all the yummy mochi. I was still a little paranoid that something was going to run out because there was this lady in front of me that bought a few boxes and the mochi supply was dwindling. luckily, there was still the ones I really wanted and just to make sure i really experienced this stuff, i decided to buy a box of 20 (for $18.70....not bad) and a package of the peanut butter stuff ($2.70 for three) so i think I got three of each of everything they had.  

As soon as I paid, I walked out and rushed to the nearest bench to open my package of peanut butter manju. *sniff sniff* i think i started tearing up at this point.....it was soooooooooooo good! the texture of the mochi was soft and sweet (not too sweet) and smooth. and with the peanut butter, it was perfect! 

and then as i was waiting to meet with one of my girls, i decided to open the box and proceed to the strawberry manju....yummmmmmm
so worth it after the two failed attempts of coming here! my eyes are getting all misty just thinking about it!
author: Pippi L.

description: This place is good, but it gets pretty damn pricey. Well worth it for a treat every now and then. I had their strawberry mochi one time it was delicious. It had just right texture to it and it wasn't extremely chewy.
author: Christopher T.

description: This place is awesome. Outside of Japan, this is the best I had. I go there everytime hoping I'm not going to be left heartbroken when they tell me the "donut redbean" is sold out! Try it!
author: B. C.

description: I've been going to Benkyodo since I was a little child, and the manju here has always been top quality.  After you eat the wagashi here, you really can't eat the pre-packaged manju at the grocery stores.  The freshness of the mochi and the anko is unbeatable.  As a child I loved the Pink Habutai and the Kinako manju the best.  The yomogi is quite good as well, but my absolute favorite is the Sakura mochi.  Lately I've actually been going to Shuei-Do in San Jose, but I still recommend Benkyodo if you're in SF.
author: Mai S.

description:
regular mochi with red bean paste - yes!
deep fried mochi - yes!
peanut butter mochi - ...a little too crazy for me

i'd like to try the strawberry one, but they were all out by 3:30pm. 

the mochi here is better than shuei-do down in san jose, but it's not so much better that i'd drive to SF. the bean texture is more present and not as pasty or as sweet as shuei-do's filling.
author: Trogdor B.

description:
packaged mochi is just not the same.  fresh mochi is a billion times better.  okay, more like a trillion.  I wish the store was open later so i can stop by here after work when i go to Nijiya.

i always buy around 24 mochis when i go here (8 different types, 3 each).  it's that good!  it never takes me more than three days to eat everything!  i know, i'm  a pig.  to justify, i try to share some before i eat it all.

my favorites are the pink habutai followed very closely by the white habutai.  i'm actually not that big a fan of the strawberry ones; i find them too sweet.

oh, another thing, it's cash only!
author: H. L.

description: I DID IT!!  Finally bought myself a strawberry mochi form Bendyodo.  Pretty pricey, $1.00 for one mochi...but my god they are good!!  You haven't had good mochi until you've had them from here.  They are SO SO SO soft!!!  It was like eating a little piece of heaven.
author: hello k.

description: Talk about some fantastic mochi.  I've never been a big fan of mochi but after having a variety here, it's fantastic.  The filling is generous but that's how I like it.  I hate it when all you taste is the sticky rice cake.  This place has been in business for over a hundred years and you can see why.  The peanut butter mochi was excellent, by far my favorite.  I've never had mochi with that filling but I will definitely go back and get more.  I didn't get any of their diner food but I'm sure that's good too.  One of the owners, Bobby, is a hard working and very friendly guy.  I would suggest this place to anyone who craves mochi and will definitely visit again.
author: Ken W.

description: Awesome Mochi!! I had to stop by here as one of my destination when I'm in Japan Town SF today. The white & red bean mochi was delicious!! So soft and it almost melt into your mouth. hMMmm I got here a bit late so there wasn't too many option, that's the only reason why I gave it 4 stars. I will definitely be back again and will get a dozen to share!! Not much to write about but definitely recommend for people out there til' next time!
author: Thanh T.

description: i went to this place on my mini self-guided tour of japantown yesterday after reading about it here.  this place was: teeny, old, and also a diner!  half of the place is a counter-only diner with basic american sandwiches all under $4.  the other half is full of mochi in display cases, $1 per mochi.  i got two different ones to sample, letting the lady choose which ones.  the mochi were so soft, i loved how they felt in my hand.  in my mouth, though, not so much.  i just think i'm not a big mochi fan, so i don't want to hate much on this place.  if you like mochi, definitely stop by.  and you can get a turkey sandwich while you're at it!
author: micaela r.

description: Wow, Benkyo-do is up to 158 reviews!  I, as well, thank early first-thirty or so yelpers for the heads up on this place.  The manju selection is diverse, and I get the warm-fuzzies that I still live in a city with town-like features and small establishments like this one.  Keep J-town alive and patronize the small shops; don't let it go the way of the old bowling alley--gone, gone, gone.  The manju is sweet, squishy food pleasure.  Other early reviewers who referred to the Mochi Nazi properly forewarned me, yet I didn't believe it 'til I experienced the hostility of the dude myself.  Know what you want, be spare with your words, don't ask too many questions, LEAVE PROMPTLY, and you'll be fine to walk out the door with nicely packaged manju on a small styrofoam tray, wrapped in white butcher paper and pink string.  Just like a present.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Wow.  Real, fresh, HOMEMADE mochi.  Before coming here, I was never really excited about mochi.  I like mochi ice cream, but that's because there's ice cream involved.  Before Benkyodo, I thought that non-ice cream-stuffed mochi, "the real stuff", had to be hard, floury, and gritty balls of colored dough.  Let me tell you, I was wrong.  Give mochi another chance!  Benkyodo mochi is sweet (but not sickeningly so, trust me, my standards for this are high) and chewy but somehow FLUFFY and melts in your mouth. ?!?!  Is this possible?  No joke.  Their strawberry mochi has little pieces of (FRESH!) strawberry chopped up inside and it's iiiiiiincredible.  With a hot cup of green jasmine tea, it's the perfect afternoon snack.
author: Thuy Tien L.

description: Alas by the time I made it to Benkyodo, a lot of the mochi were already gone :( But we were still able to pick up a few pieces! Yomogi..Habutae...Mmm all superfresh and absolutely delicious! So far in terms of the kinds I was able to sample,. I would agree with the other reviewers that I like this a bit better than Shuei-do in San Jose. The mochi here are larger and are a bit more firm and substiantial. Unfortunately I'm not in SF all that often, but I was so happy to finally sample Benkyodo mochi!
author: Sandy B.

description: Strawberry mochi was so delicious! Also liked yomogi. I'm definitely going back to try the other flavers =)
author: Angela K.

description: Ordered the white bean and the strawberry flavored mochi for a dollar a piece. Overrated. Flavor was good, not great. A tad bland if you ask me. It taste like some of the packaged vietnamese desserts you can buy off the shelf at most vietnamese bakeries. It's a bad comparison, I know, but thats what it tasted like to me.
author: Wil M.

description: Want to find some yummy and fresh mochi?  This is the right place to go!  They have all kinds of mochi....and my favorite is the strawberry mochi!! Everything is made fresh and the owners are sooo nice!  I totally recommend everyone to stop by and get some little goodies from this place!
author: JenJen W.

description: This place is one of the few places I can think of that makes fresh mochi. Pretty standard selection, but the freshness and quality can't be beat. Mochi is like crack for my ma so whenever I want to get on her a good side, a six piece variety box always does the trick.
author: Joe C.

description: Peanut Butter Mochi is my fave. The other flavors are nice too but PB is still the best if you're not allergic to it.  The guy that operates this place? He doesn't like smiling :( Parking is a b*tch there.
author: Everett C.

description:
I've always been skeptical about buying fresh, bagged mochi at the supermarket because I'm afraid they'll turn out stale and ruin mochi for me altogether.  Problem solved since I've discovered this place during a fine stroll through Japantown one morning.  Tried the strawberry and red bean.  They were delicious (and fresh - soft and chewy)!  I've always passed by this store but never knew its contents.  I'm so glad I allowed my curiousity to lead me here (after getting wide-eyed from a mochi picture on the store window).  

The mochi itself deserves 5 stars, but knocked off one for the subpar service.  Having never been inside, I asked the counter person what the different flavors were and he instructed me to look at the tiny menu taped on the side of the counter.  Well that was a bit difficult as there were 2 people ahead of me waiting for their orders.  I swear, as I was trying to peer over the man's shoulder ahead of me to read the menu he thought I was trying to jack his money or something and kept looking at me.  Ackward.
author: Amy T.

description: yummmm, more mochi please! i want to try all of their selection, RIGHT NOW!
author: Stella C.

description: The mochi at this place is delicious.  My girlfriend brought back a box with a little bit of everything.  The mochi itself was soft and doughy and tasted great.  There must have been at least five or six kinds of mochi/fillings.  The ones I remember the most were the strawberry and peanut butter.  There were a lot of different sweet bean fillings as well, but the strawberry mochi is where it's at.  Bring a box and watch the mochi disappearing act.
author: Tony L.

description: The unanimous chorus of sixes had me dying to try Benkyodo. So, I hopped on the bus during my lunch hour and made it over to Japantown. The place is truly charming (in a mom & pop hole-in-the wall sort of way). I selected one of each selections, therefore 8 different kinds of mochi. The first one I tried was strawberry. It's delectable. It's nice and soft, and just sweet enough to be perfect. I have 7 more sitting on my desk. I'm not sure if they'll make it to the end of the day. ;-)
author: unhei k.

description:
as i'm writing this, i'm nibbling on kinako, habutai (white bean w/red dot) & an out of control strawberry manju. it took all the restraint i have to carry these around with me all day so that i could enjoy them at home with a cup of tea. had i known that my little white bag held insanely fresh, sweet clouds of goodness, there's no way they would've all made it home intact.

somehow, i'd never been to benkyodo before today. i'm usually in j-town later on the weekends, which means they're closed, and i always thought the spot was just a diner. there were a few people sitting at the counter while i was there & they seemed like neighborhood regulars. like pauline l. said, benkyodo does remind you of time standing still. it's a comforting nostalgia for me & i'd love to sit & eat sometime.

when i was growing up, my family used to get together with other family/friends for mochitsuki every new year. besides dipping our mochi in sugar/shoyu, we'd spread peanut butter on it. but i've never had peanut butter manju & was excited about trying benkyodo's. however, theirs is sold in a 3 pack & i didn't have enough cash on me (they also take checks). so i'll have to get that, along with some mochi, next time. i have bought their mochi at tokyo fish market before but am sure that gettting it direct from the shop is even better.  they also have a large variety of candies & rice crackers, some that i haven't seen since i was little. oh and, manju are only .90/each.
author: kristen m.

description: Really excellent mochi, but I took away one star for two reasons  1) the staff can sometimes be extremely unfriendly and unpleasant.  Maybe it's some kind of cultural thing I just can't understand and 2)no matter what you order, everything pretty much tastes the same.  But in a good way!
author: Kandi K.

description: First time I have ever had manju was from here!!!! A very nice sales lady brought some into the office for us and boy i was blown away. I tried not to make it obvious that i was practically OBSESSED with them at that point, but i definitely enjoyed them. Little story even shorter i just have to say go for the STRAWBERRY manjus! So deeelectable! I went there one sat and bought like ten of them, nothing else, could have explored a little more ( in which i have but ultimately obsessed with strawbry) but decided to keep it to the good stuff! Go in there and gets some!
author: Tiffany d.

description:
After reading all the reviews on Yelp, I was super excited to grab some mochi at Benkyodo.  Unfortunately, I was thwarted...  TWICE!!  Once because I didn't pay attention and it wasn't open on Sunday.  Then again because I didn't pay attention and it was the Cherry Blossom Festival, so everything was sold out.  

After all the suspense, I was a little let down.  The mochi was good, btu definitely not great.  It was soft and gooey, but just didn't quite hit the spot.  Maybe I'm just comparing them to the mochi I used to get when visiting family in Taiwan, now that is some good mochi.
author: Olivia T.

description: Can't get better mochi than this!  Fresh strawberry ones are the best, but too bad they're seasonal.
author: Conrad M.

description: The mochi's are soooo  good.  Try to have some immediately at the store if possible - or- as soon as you can after taking them home.  Don't wait - trust me...
author: Bessie T.

description:
Benkyodo mochi makes a girl happy. When you bite into a soft chewy sweet strawberry mochi you think of rainbows and unicorns. That said..they're always out of strawberry mochi. So I either need to get there earlier, people need to stop buying ALL of the strawberry mochi, or they need to make more. I vote for option number 3. 
p.s. yes it's inside the diner on the corner.
author: Emily W.

description: The manju at Benkyodo is very good.  On this recent visit, I entered the little shop and discovered a long line of customers waiting at the manju counter.  I purchased a strawberry mochi.  The mochi was soft (even one day later) and it was filled with white bean paste and a fresh strawberry. I definitely would buy it again.
author: D B.

description: Ooooohhhh.....I LOVE this place.  You've got to get there pretty early to take advantage of the assortment of treats.  Later in the day...around 3:30-4:00...it's pretty slim pickings.  I recommend the Yomogi manju.  It's green and has whole red bean in it.  Soooo good.  I prefer the whole been vs. smooth because it has more texture, although if I have to, I'll gladly eat the smooth.  The Sauma, which has pink, green and white stripes, is just plain sweet rice, which is pretty bland.  Once you've had freshly made mochi, store packaged mochi will always pale in comparison.
author: Idala T.

description: I've finally found a place in SF where I can get my "mochi-fix."  Ever since my trip to Hawai'i I have been determined to find a place that sells strawberry mochi in the bay area.  My quest for mochi was proving rather unsuccessful until yelpers led me to find Benkyodo.  Located close to the Peace Plaza in Japantown this small mom and pop joint serves up some pretty tasty mochi and manju.  While a bit sweeter and smaller than I'm used to...the strawberry mochi proved to be delicious and I can't wait to try some of their other flavors.
author: Jocelyn F.

description: This place is the best.  Definitely an institution. We're lucky to live across the street from j-town so whenever that mochi urge strikes,  we're just a stones throw away. It closes at 5 pm so definitely try to get there early for best selection. My son also likes the chocolate shakes they serve at the counter. Kind of random, I know.  The ladies who work there are also sweet, they take great care in wrapping up the packages of mochi. Such a treat!
author: Lori E.

description: Exquisite mochi. Minus one star for really lousy hours. Whenever I go to Japantown late on the weekends, its inevitably closed.
author: David P.

description:
i bookmarked this place after having read about it on yelp. since they're only open 8-5 monday thru saturday, i knew i had to wake up early on saturday and hit up j-town. why early? i dunno, but i always feel like i'll get the shaft on selection if go somewhere late. pretty much got two of everything so i could bring some to my parents for a try. 

the strawberry one was super. i wanted to cry it was so good. the peanut butter was good too. i've had the other kinds before, but i must be a baka because i didn't see the fried one. ok, so i didn't ask either. i was hoping they'd just have a crushed peanuts and sugar variety too, but again..i didn't ask. it was busy, i didn't want to hold up the line. i've seen too much of the seinfeld soup nazi episode to ask questions.
author: Shinn Z.

description: My first mochi experience was a good one. Now I have sweet little mochi balls dancing round my head *bouncy bouncy bouncy*...
author: Jennifer M.

description: The mochi is to die for but really I just wish I was cool enough to hang out on the diner side on a weekday morning and talk with all the jtown old timers while sipping on freeze dried coffee.
author: bianca francesca o.

description: The store may not appear to be impressive from the outside but their mochi is definitely world class. They have the best strawberry mochi! I can eat about 10 of them and not get sick of it.  Plus it has been around for 90+ years so it's gotta be pretty good right? I grew up eating a lot of mochi, my dad use to make mochi for us when we were younger, but sorry dad your peanut mochi is nothing compare to this place.
author: Brian H.

description: Maybe it's because I'm not a die hard mochi fan, but I don't know if I'd go out of my way to come here...good stuff though. From reading the reviews I was prepared for the Mochi Nazi....yeah...man is GRrrrUMPY. I even went here in the morning... so he's grouchy all hours of the day.  Since I was prepared, it was hard to not giggle at how blantanly mean he can be!
author: Tanger T.

description: I have to say first that I believe this is one of the oldest Japanese businesses in Japantown. So for that, I have a lot of respect. I used to come here as a kid and eat hot dogs at the counter and buy some sweets (back when we still called them sweets). I wouldn't say it's the best mochi in the history of mochi (there's a history of mochi?), but it's pretty good. If you haven't tried mochi before, come by here and give it a shot. The place is pretty simple and prices are reasonable in my opinion. You may be able to find street parking in the area. Or, if you don't want to deal with that, you can park in the lot over in the main mall building.
author: Al B.

description: I love the strawberry ones.  They're not too sweet and there's a little piece of strawberry fruit inside; that was a nice surprise.
author: Sara A.

description:
Absolutely the best mochi store in Northern California, hands down.  Some claim the store in San Jose's J-Town is better, but nothing beats Benkyodo for how soft their mochi is...and isn't that the point?

Don't even compare this to ice cream mochi. This is fresh, made-that-day mochi by a family-owned company that's been in the same spot for generations.

Get to know the different kinds and soon you'll have a fave.  Some like smooth beans, some like whole beans, and there are different mochi (the outer part) types as well. Yes there is great peanut butter mochi, covered with pink mochi (sweet rice flour), and now even new chocolate marshmallow flavor, but their old stand-bys are the best.

There is also a lunch/breakfast counter behind the mochi-and-sweets counter selling basic diner items, as well as treats such as Hawaiian-style cookies for sale over the counter.

The only complaint, and totally minor, is that there has been a recent change from their placing the mochi on styrofoam trays and covering them with paper, then wrapping artfully with a bow (blue or pink), great for giving as gifts.  But now if you buy four, they give you a clear plastic container, and always warn you (rightfully so) that edges are sharp.

Overall, this is as good as mochi gets!  Just wish they were open 7 days and longer hours!
author: Wahine M.

description: So my bf, Anthony and I, went to Japantown to waste some time before going to a party. He's never been there so I showed him all the stores I thought he might enjoy and even got to shop for DOMO stuff for myself. As the day was winding down, I thought to myself  "I havent had any Manju in a looooong time and I WANT SOME!!" I knew of this spot "on the corner" where they made different kinds of fresh Manju. So we walked from the mall across the street towards what used to be Denny's and up the stoned pavement to the "corner" of Buchanan and there was BENKYODO to my hearts content!! I wasnt even sure they were still open but low and behold the line was coming out of the door!! I made my way in and I bought 2 with the fresh strawberries, 2 with the white bean and one that's just straight mochi with the green and red coloring....cost me just over $5 and it was well worth it!! I tried having Anthony try some and it wasnt his cup of tea and I thought "OH WELL!! MORE FOR ME!! YAY" and I went on to eat the fresh strawberry one, SOOOO DELISH! Since we were going to a party I didnt want to ruin my appetite so I saved them for later. I cant believe they lasted until the next morning and it was as if I had just bought them! Nice and soft and fresh! You just cant beat this place. They have a great selection and really they are the only place besides this small mochi ball on a stick place that makes it FRESH! The price is well worth what you get and I'd recommend it to anyone! GOOD EATS!!
author: Tara Lei T.

description:
Ever heard grandmas and grandpas die on new year?  Because they couldn't swallow the sticky mochi. But let that not scare you. 
Just wanted to tell how Japanese love their mochi even it's a bit risque. 


If i must die because of mochi, let it be it from Benkyodo.
author: E B.

description: I totally dig manju and mochi to the fullest and to go to a spot where it's fresh and hand made makes you even more fuller! Fukusa, Age, Dorayaki, Habutai, Komochi... are just some of my favorites. I suggest getting "one of everything"- which will be wrapped in a nice box for about $10. FYI- there's a nostalgic diner-like cafe there as well. I'll pass for now thanks.
author: Leroid D.

description: I didn't have any tea but we shared a kinako, and peanut butter mochi.  I had no idea they also had an azuki-filled donut!  I'd love to go back for strawberry manju.  I'm not sure why there weren't more that day.  We came here to try habutai or imo.
author: Ai M.

description: The mochi and manju(ice) is freakin awesome.  Its definitley the best mochi and manjuice I have eaten.  I am not a red bean fan but the the red bean paste was to ricockulously good.  I was surprised how soft and smooth the mochi felt.  It was like rubbing a manatee belly.  The only problem I had going here was I had no idea what to order.  The pastries had no labels on the casing so I just ordered one of each mochi and manjuice.  The selecton was very limited probably because of the cherry blossom festival.  Either way I am going back tomorrow.
author: Fatty A.

description: The mochi is yummy, especially the strawberry one.  The fillings have real strawberries in them!  One less star because the mochi is no good unless it's fresh.  Shuei-do's mochi last longer if you must save your mochi overnight.
author: Hoa Q.

description: My mom has been picking up manju from this little shop ever since I can remember (like late 1970's!).  This place has completely spoiled me for anybody else's manju.  I cannot bring myself to eat the stuff from the grocery store that supposedly comes fresh wrapped in plastic wrap.  After growing up on Benkyodo's soft manju with just the right amount of anko inside, there's just no comparison.
author: Carri C.

description: Mochi here is incredible. So soft, so fresh.  Red bean filled mochi is to fresh and so delicious.  Don't buy the packages mochi bites at the front counter.  They were covered with mold the second day we had them.  I didn't give it 5 stars because of that.  Interesting place where half the place is a mochi counter and half looks like an old small diner area where the local clientelle consists of older men and women eating chili dogs and tuna fish sandwiches.  Very interesting place to say the least.  I would stick to the mochi because it is incredible!
author: Darren I.

description: Went for my first time to this place yesterday when I passed Japantown on my way home. It was a tiny little store, but.... the mochi are awesome!!! I got one of everything they had that day.. peanut butter mochi, smooth bean, white bean, red bean, and whole bean. Ahhh! they are soooo gooodd. The mochi skin is so smooth and just perfect! for a dollar each, but it's homemade and fresh!!! I'm coming back for more!!
author: Daisy S.

description:
imagine sitting on some nice grass out in the middle of golden gate park. not many people are around. its nice and peaceful. imagine looking up at the clear blue sky, with one roundish cloud floating around. over the cloud peeps the sun, a big round sun with a welcoming glow. it is as if it winks at you. you wave back and say hello. you continue to chew the most amazing Benkyodo mochi in the world. 

what a day. this place has hands down, the best mochi that i have ever had. the coffee shop has a very home-town feel to it. the traditional snacks that they sell are great, and the variety of mochi is greater. each and every mochi is nicely formed and filled. 

eat one, and you will never want another mochi from anywhere else, EVER AGAIN. Go to Benkyodo. buy a mochi. DO IT.
author: Tony W.

description: AWESOME!! This place rocks!! Mochi are deeeeelishious!
author: Chi chi R.

description: Five stars for utilizing the talents of older people and the traditional wrapping, but I prefer the taste of the the mochi from the fridge at Nijiya. What do I know though?
author: Johnny O.

description:
i know, i know: as if more people needed to jump on the benkyodo bandwagon.  sorry, kids.

so sometimes hulagirl gets desperately homesick for the land of hula.  which means i jump in my car and head to japantown so i can eat rice flour dumplings of deliciousness filled with hometown faves like adzuki bean.  sure they're not as good as my granny's but she never made peanut butter and wow are those delicious.
author: nic f.

description:
Oh yes, mighty fine mochi.

I thought the strawberry was awesome and the peanut butter as well.

The smooth bean one was good too, a bit too much bean compared to rice.

What can I say, my tastes are not traditional...I will say that whatever you get here is world's away from prepackaged mochi.
author: Darien W.

description: I am only reviewing on the manju....have not eaten here or anything else.  There manju is decent.  The variety is not that great imo,and the prices keep going up.  But hey in SF Benkyodo is one of the only places to get manju, so it will have to do when i am craving the stuff!
author: Shelley N.

description: The BEST!!! Their mochi is homemade and every year I ship some to family on the East Coast where they can not enjoy such a treat!
author: Rodger R.

description: I went again and found the service just aweful. i had to ask questions twice and the person was so unfriendly. i left without buying anything! not worth my time!
author: L S.

description: LOTS and LOTS of mochi!  We bought a box to take on the road!  All I can say is mmmmh!
author: Jay A.

description: The mochi here are just the perfect treat for any afternoon. Share some with friends!
author: R K.

description: Benkyodo offers a variety of very good Mochi and Manju, but get there early. They always sell out long before the 5pm closing time. I've tried every mochi there. But my favorites are the peanut butter, strawberry, and red bean mochi's. Very soft and not too sweet. A very well made desert and highly recommended.
author: HUNG L.

description:
minus 1 star for all the weight all these lil' suckers had given me!! love the strawberry ones.. pity they are not in season now thus no fresh fruit in the mochi.
peanut butter mochi.. heaven!
i'm not crazy about the donut ones like some yelpers but im definitely in love with this place and the lady behind the counter. 

OIISHI!
author: Shawna C.

description: I kept on seeing great reviews for this place and I thought...I have to try it to see what all the hype is about.  After a strawberry mochi that melted in my mouth...I now know what it's all about.  I only wished that Benkyodo were closer or that I was in the City more often because this place has the best mochi I've ever had.  It's a step up from Shuei-do in San Jose and two steps up from Fugetsu-do in LA.  Now that I'm thinking about it...I think I'll stop by tomorrow for some yummy mochi...since I'll be going to the Ghirardelli Chocolate Festival!
author: Tony N.

description: best mochi in san francisco.  especially when strawberries are in season.  CASH ONLY.  come early.
author: kulas a.

description:
Ok, I could go on and on about how awesome everything is in this place, but really, all I need to say is:

PEANUT BUTTER MOCHI!
author: Sharie M.

description: My previous exposure to mochi had been the store bought processed, packaged, enhanced by additives and preservatives, mochi and ice cream mochi. My first real mochi experience was this past year in Maui at Long's Drugs.  I picked up some fresh made Home Maid butter mochi and chichi dango and after the first bite, knew I had stumbled on the start of a personal culinary adventure and love affair with mochi.  During the same trip, I found a Home Maid bakery shop with their assortment of sweet, exotic mochi confections and had more of the butter mochi, in addition to trying coconut mochi, red bean mochi, and purple yam mochi. Many happy mochi memories and well enjoyed calories later,  back in SF my search had began of similar mochi I can either buy or make myself.  I tried buying the store bought, processed mochi just to see if it was any good, and it tasted stale, rubbery and overall bad in comparison to fresh mochi.  I tried several recipes, and found that my mochi skills need to be worked on and perfected.  I found Benkyodo off Yelp and it has become the best place to satiate my mochi cravings.   The fresh strawberry mochi is my favorite - soft and chewy with a sweet, juicy strawberry filling.  I highly recommend stopping in at Benkyodo for their freshly made, delectable sweets, where each mochi piece is handcrafted to perfection.  If you go on a weekday, there's convenient non-metered parking on Laguna or Sutter Streets.
author: michele g.

description: by the looks of the place, you'd have no idea this serves such fresh tasty mochi.  unforunately, they don't have all the flavors at one time -- only about 6.  but they are worth it.  try the chofu.  wish they had the kuri
author: Rob C.

description: I HEART YOU BENKYODO! Their mochi is one of the best! I also love Shuei Do in SJ, but Benkyodo has more selection. I think we got 20 pieces of mochi. Wanted to try them all! :) We got some smooth white bean, chunky red bean, chocolate with marshmallow, and peanut butter mochi. Wanted to try the fruit mochis, but they didn't have any more. It's ok.. just another reason to visit Benkyodo again!
author: Edilynne M.

description:
3.5

oooh i HEART mochi ... and i'll EAT mochi in a heartbeat ... yumm... def oishi oishi!! 

before i came into this place, i figured this was MOCHI GALLORE... thinkin wow, this bakery will seriously fufill my mochi-dose for the month ... when you first walk in, the right side has a mini american diner feel which i thought was strange ...  anyways, on the left, is where they sell my mochi ... i came in with such HIGH expectations ... they only had like 5 types... booo ... but man... the mochi was SOOOO good ... 

**never ever tried STRAWBERRY MOCHI before, but for $1, that was def oishi(yummy!) i've tried the other mochis before ...  try it, they have one fresh plumpy strawberry with a mochi blend.. mmm.

have to say, parking was quite normal, plenty of meter right up the street of buchanan... 

the lady in front was pretty sweet as well, extremely helpful and accomodating in explaining the types of mochi they had (whether they had crunchy red beans or soft, pasty ones!) i'm a fanatic for the smooth pasty ones...  (hint hint!) so now you know, if you ever get my mochi balls ... 

with the amount of mochi they have in this "bakery," i'd prolly look for a japanese market ... but i have to say, it's nice to buy your mochi individually, catering to your own desires...  yea, i'll come back...
author: Jennifer S.

description: wow, what a rude man at the counter.  we went to this business for some mochi on our school's fieldtrip.  this place is 100 years old!  how cool.  how NOT cool in the customer service department.  made the kids and teachers feel like crap.  thanks.  nice start to our day.  thank goodness the rest of the businesses in Japantown know how to treat customers.
author: seven s.

description: Terrible service!!!  Wanted to surprise my gf with an assortment on mochi and other treats. I politely asked the lady behind the counter how many of these treats would fit in a box....She rudely said that I just need to pick out the assortment that I want and she would do the box for me.  After I picked out my assortment, she said I need to have two boxes...She just wanted the sale and tried to rush me through to help the next person in line.  She gave me no description of what I was buying or how to keep them fresh.  I was sorely disappointed with the way they treat customers and even worst...when I ate one, it was nothing special...taste just like you buy them anywhere else.  I suggest they work on keeping their customers happy.  She has left a bad taste in my mouth and I will never be back!
author: Tokyokid G.

description: benkyodo's on yelp??  there's certain nostalgic places that make you yearn for the days when all you had to worry about was getting home in time to watch gi joe or the transformers.   benkyodo is one of those places for me.  don't know much about the mochi because all i got there were the donuts and hot dogs.  i almost miss Bobby making fun of my bowl cut...almost.   five stars for the memories.
author: J M.

description: I honestly don't like mochi but I go there for their sanwiches.  Everytime I go there, I tell myself to order something new but I always end up ordering a pastrami sandwich for $3.10.  Five stars for having good sandwiches and being family owned
author: James C.

description: No trip to Japantown would be complete without a stop at Benkyodo, a coffeeshop run by brothers Ricky and Bobby Okamura in Buchanan Mall.  This is no ordinary coffeeshop.  Ricky and Bobby are third generation manju makers, part of a dying breed of artisans who make these traditional confections by hand each day.    Benkyodo celebrated its 100th anniversary in June 2006.  If you stop by on a Saturday, be prepared to wait in line and go early because they can sell out fast.  It's kind of amusing to see how East meets West here, for my kids often look forward to ordering a hotdog with their kuri goma manju, baked manju with smooth white beans and sesame seed garnish.  When I'm there, it's hard to resist my childhood favorite, dorayaki, a pancake style manju filled with whole red beans. Benkyodo also has fun flavors like strawberry, peanut butter and chocolate marshmallow mochi!  Benkyodo Co.,1747 Buchanan Street. 415.922.1244. Monday - Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.  Closed Sundays.
author: Dina B.

description: not a HUGE mochi fan...but i had to stop by since i was in the area to stop by Ichiban Kan...when my boyfriend and i went in, first we were confused because it's like twighlight zone or something...on the right side it's a diner looking area with the booths and the menu on the wall where u stick the letters, soda fountain with BARGS (our fav soda, which apparently is huge in San Fran...i wish it was like that in So Cal) and then on the left was the case of mochi, knick knacks and japanese snacks. well, i got two strawberry flavored (unfortunately not the fresh strawberry that i heard was so yummy) and this one with white lima beans..forgot what it's called...and boyfriend got this small bread looking thing with white lima bean in it also (man...i'm probably annoying a lot of people by my descriptions) but anyways...boyfriend thought he wouldn't like it...but i didn't even get a taste of his cuz he finished it in like two bites...-_-...as for me...i loved both of my mochi... very yummy...definately will stop back when i go back up north! i LOVE J-TOWN!
author: Grace P.

description: i paid this place a visit because i was craving peanut butter mochi, and managed to get there before a) they closed and b) they ran out of mochi. it's a little odd when you walk in because they have a counter w/stools to the right that seems to be a cafe or something, and then to the left is a display case filled with lots of different kinds of mochi. if nobody is behind the display case, ring the bell to get service. i got a package of pb mochi (individually wrapped in case of allergies) and a strawberry mochi. the strawberry mochi, which i ate on the drive home, was okay -- i think it has some bean paste filling, which i'm not really a fan of. it also had a chunk of fresh strawberry, which was yummy. the pb mochi was really good -- not as good as the ones i got on maui, but almost as good. i was hoping for crunchy crackly pb but it was just super chunky. nevertheless, i'd go back for the pb mochi because shortly afterward, i tried making it and i got sticky mochi and pb EVERYWHERE. lol.
author: Clara K.

description: i'm not a mochi fan, but apparently people love this place.  the owners here are super nice and patient and was able to bear w/ me as i asked a million questions about the fillings of each mochi.  i don't eat mochi, but my parents liked the ones here, b/c they are very moist and soft, even the next day.  another specialty they have is the donut mochi, which is basically a donut w/ red bean filling.
author: Helen T.

description: mm really good and fresh manju... but go early since it's become so popular now.  Also, they make different types every day so for example if you want the kuri it's best to go on Tuesday.
author: Priscilla P.

description: To me, it's kinda pricey for mochi. I guess I'm more picky too since I had good mochi before. My favorite is the strawberry mochi since I never had it anywhere else before.
author: VVVV H.

description: Pink, green, green with soy powder, white, hmm... I'll take one of everything.   This isn't the store bought red-bean mochi that you find in stores on Irving or Clement, and definitely not the ice-cream mochi that Trader Joe pimps.  This is the real deal mochi.  Freshly made and so soft to the touch that it almost feels obscene to be handling them.  No matter, they don't last in your hands very long before you wolf them down.  The insides include not-too-sweet sweet bean concoctions (and others), and the outsides are multicolored, but really the outsides are more for show than taste.  I'd skip the soy powder mochi if you're driving - you'll look like you just finished a coke fest if pulled over by a cop.  And don't let the store throw you off, it looks like a well loved 50's diner, with  newspaper reading senior citizenry as perminant decor.  Just look for the glass cases of little round goodness.
author: San B.

description: Yum! I love Benkyodo's mochis...strawberry mochis are the best - although I do like how Eiji uses a whole strawberry, but can't complain. It's fresh and the perfect texture. The only complaint I have is that I wish they were opened at night past 5pm. On weekdays I can never make it on time. The only running chance I have is on Saturdays. Ho hum. :(
author: Jeannette L.

description: Mochi mochi! Their new chocolate/marshmallo mochi is a winner.  Very light cocoa mochi on the outside and sweet white bean paste and small marshmallows on the inside.  Not too sweet and it goes very nicely with coffee or tea.  This is a great new addition to their ever popular fresh strawberry mochi.
author: L T.

description: I only went to Bekyodo for the mochi, but oooooh is it so good!  It's also a coffee shop with breakfast and sandwiches.  A must try is their Peanut Butter Manjoo,  They use crunchy PB, and it is just sooooooooo good.  I can eat 4 in one sitting.
author: Janice L.

description: mmmm, i love mochis!  is this really the only fresh mochi place in the city?  too bad the ladies behind the counter are so stern.  maybe it's a good thing otherwise  i would come here more often.
author: Big e.

description: Having reading great reviews on the notorious Benkyodo Co. my friends and I decided to venture out to Japantown in search fro these goodies. We got there around 11. With two people in front of us, we waited no time to order strawberry mochi. I had two myself and was surprised to find real pieces of strawberry goodness in the center. The smooth paste was very tasty and it was tempting not to eat more than two. Wanting to purchase more for my family, I went back around 1, only to find a really long line. By the time it was my turn, they sold out of all of the strawberry goodness, but they had other options. Oh I can't wait until the next trip I make out there for these sweet treats.
author: Lily L.

description: love the pink habutai manju.
author: meijan w.
